fields.headline: Same result, different outcome
fields.standfirst: A first gives few clues to your fate
fields.trailText: A first gives few clues to your fate A first gives few clues to your fate
fields.body:
Take two graduates with the world at their feet. Both have firsts from top universities. Both are great communicators with a good range of work experience and a strong track record in student societies. But while one now drives a brand new Renault Clio and has eliminated her overdraft, the other has just taken out a graduate loan. Guess which one took the job in publishing.

While median graduate starting salaries edge towards £20,000, the contrast between what's on offer to the best-qualified graduates couldn't be more extreme. For those seduced by investment banking, bonuses and non-contributory pensions beckon. Those in the arts or media, however, languish in penury and dream of the long term. At a recent event held by the Association for Graduate Recruiters, a representative from Credit Suisse First Boston announced that they are now paying their trainees starting salaries of £45K. Can one graduate really be worth three times the other?

Sara Howard (not her real name), 22, graduated last summer from Exeter University with a first in economics. She started as a trainee analyst with a leading investment bank last September and now works in the money markets. Sara earns a basic salary "at the top end of the graduate range" and this year she'll also be eligible for a bonus.

"I'm in each morning at 7am and my department meets at 7.30am to catch up on what happened in New York and Tokyo overnight. The currency markets operate 24 hours a day and senior analysts present to us, outlining any major development and how the bank is looking to act on them. I'm expected to have a reasonable idea of what's gone on. I also need to be versed on other news that could affect the markets such as political developments or current affairs.

"We make money through buying and selling various currencies at advantageous prices. There's no formal training programme in place: I'm learning on the job, absorbing the information around me from the people I work with.

"This isn't a quiet place to work. You need the ability to listen to two conversations at once and when people call me at work they tend to comment on the amount of background noise. Dress in the office is smart casual and at this stage in my career I don't attend presentations or meet with clients. I'm mainly working before three screens at my desk, making transactions and modelling with spreadsheets. I don't take a lunch hour and work a 50-hour week.

"Only three graduates were taken on in my department and occasionally I feel like we're the chosen few. I'm the only girl. My university careers service pushed me towards accountancy, which I suppose they perceived as a safe, middle-class professional option. The City can be a risky place to work but I feel job security is largely based on performance.

"I don't think I'm being underpaid or overpaid for what I do. When you start a job you're never going to feel loaded because of graduate debts. But I am aware that I am earning more than most of my university peers when we go out and socialise. The fact that some of my friends are in less lucrative professions has a knock-on effect on the type of places we drink and eat, for example.

Bonnie Mitchell, 22, graduated with a first in English and theatre studies from Warwick University last summer. After doing unpaid work experience with publishing companies and magazines, she took a temping job with publisher Butterworth Tolley last September, which led to a full-time position as a product development assistant. Bonnie earns £15,000 a year.

"The division I work for is in business publishing. It's a steep learning curve but it's very interesting - I'm learning web development, human resources and facilities management, for example. I've just been put in charge of my first project, working on a product handbook. There are three of us based in a separate office. It takes me half an hour to walk to work.

"Around 30% of my current role is administration. The first things I do in the morning are open people's post, make tea and check my emails. But my main focus at the moment is market research on our competitors and on our present and lapsed subscribers into what services they want from us. It's a studious but relaxed atmosphere - I wear my trainers unless there's a big meeting.

"I work from 9am to 5pm and take an hour for lunch. If you don't take your time off it's really frowned upon. They like you go to outside and my boss thinks it's important for a healthy atmosphere. I feel that I'm constantly on deadlines that need to be met yesterday. But it is a realistic working environment in that they don't like you to get stressed and just want you to work as hard as you can in the time and space you have. I've a really good boss in that respect. I feel the work I do is really valued.

"Everyone has an allocated training budget and I've been sent on computer courses and a sub-editing and proofreading course. I also get sent on lots of business conferences.

"Towards the end of my degree I knew that publishing was what I wanted to do, although I was thinking of going to the fiction or poetry sector rather than into business publishing. I'm getting a great grounding here, though, and because there are more resources I'm getting a much better training. If I do want to consider fiction at a later stage I believe there are opportunities to move across.

"My salary will be reviewed in six months and I hope that I'll get a rise although it's not definite. I only envy my peers in terms of money. In terms of job satisfaction I'm extremely happy. I've got friends who are earning twice as much as me - deservedly so, I think - in blue-chip roles. I like to think that I could have gone down either route. I save on rent by living with my aunt but I don't earn enough to start paying off my student loans, I don't run a car and I've just taken out a graduate loan.

"This is the first time I've lived in London and I obviously would be enjoying it a lot more if I had money to spend. But my time will come. I'm still young. And anyway - how do you know when you've got it good, if you've always had it good?"

webTitle: Launch your career with a little help from friends

fields.headline: Launch your career with a little help from friends
fields.standfirst: But choose your referees carefully
fields.trailText: But choose your referees carefully
fields.body:
Eye-catching CVs and breath-taking covering letters are all very well, but there's nothing better than having an inside track when it comes to beating your competitors into a job. Recommendations from a previous employer, colleague, business contact or friend are a very important, but often overlooked, strategy when job-hunting.

Automatically including references with a CV is no more an expectation than it is to include your photo. But simply stating "References available upon request" is squandering a great opportunity to levitate your application to the top of the heap.

Good references from people who are held in esteem in your industry or profession can place you above the pack during the initial application process. For example, when applying for a junior lobbying position with a public relations agency, a heartfelt reference letter from an MP praising your qualifications would all but guarantee you an interview.

Here are half a dozen suggestions that may help you develop your list of referees:

1. Think positive

It's stating the bloomin' obvious, but when gathering references, stick to people who will write you a good one. If you are concerned that past employers won't help your case, you might want to turn to academic or training references, and character references.

Since three seems to be the magic number for references, one former employer, one academic and one character reference is a pretty good balance.

But use your best judgment and provide names and information of the people who will represent you best.

2. Use insiders

Your best bet is likely to be a friend or acquaintance employed by your potential employer. Perhaps you knew them at university or they have worked with you in the past at another organisation. They will provide the best reference because they are already trusted by your potential employer.

3. Beat the rush

If you have still to graduate, professional references in your specific discpline, whether it's astrophysics or zoology, can score the highest marks. Cultivate their enthusiastic support early on - befriending or impressing professors during your last term at university is often too late. No-one likes a creep and you won't be the first student seeking last minute favours.

Set out an action plan to increase your visibility with key faculty members and department heads. Serving on student or faculty committees or showing outstanding promise through special efforts in class or in assignments might persuade deans and professors to go that extra mile for you when you seek their assistance.

Beat the rush by securing your academic references long before graduation. Don't assume that professors will remember you a year or two later - they deal with hundreds of new faces and names every year. Serving on alumni associations after you graduate will help key faculty personnel to remember you.

4. Forget relatives

Don't on any account choose relatives as referees. Of course your mum is biased and your Uncle Bob is hardly an impartial judge of character either. The same goes for your yoga teacher or football coach. Being good in goals cuts little ice when employers are trying to determine your specific qualifications, on-the-job reliability and communication skills.

5. Don't leave it to chance

In a very diplomatic manner, gently encourage your referees to include this information in their letters: why they feel you are qualified for the position in question; their opinion of you both professionally and personally; and how long and in what capacity they have known you. You might even want to jot down a few notes for them, and give them a quick summary of your qualifications and a copy of the job description in question.

6. Confidential

Confidential letters of recommendation carry more weight than letters in your possession. Confidential letters sent directly from the referee to the employer are most effective.

webTitle: How to... job share your way to a personal best

fields.headline: How to... job share your way to a personal best
fields.standfirst: A smooth handover is critical
fields.trailText: A smooth handover is critical
fields.body:
You've heard of teleworking, flexible working, and endless other new ways of working. But now the latest buzz words on consultants' lips include job-sharing - where one full-time job is split between two people.

Job-sharing opens up the possibility, for example of working for one company Monday to Wednesday and then for another Thursday to Friday.

But does this mean you would gain double the opportunities? Or simply end up doing twice as much work for half as much pay?

"Yes, and yes", says Carl Gilleard, chief executive officer for the Association of Graduate Recruiters.

Over the years he has seen several graduates juggle two job-share positions. "Some thrive on it. They really do learn a lot, and very quickly. They fast become fully equipped with the skills considered very valuable in today's world of work."

However, Carl points out that for others, the experience is not always so rewarding - at least not financially. "People can end up having to squeeze full-time hours in to a part-time job. I've seen it happen - they get very tired, very stressed and at the end of the month their bank balance is no better off."

The benefits of job sharing are far from clear cut. But it is a possibility that graduates are prepared to consider. More than 80% of 18 to 24-year olds would feel more motivated at work if they had access to flexible working schemes like job sharing. So says a recent survey conducted by the Employers for Work-Life Balance organisation.

Chairman Peter Ellwood says job sharing "is now not simply about women with children, but something that everyone can embrace, irrespective of age or gender".

The business case for job-sharing is starting to gain momentum. And increasing numbers of companies are starting to offer it. Look, for instance, at the employment policies of Asda, HSBC, KPMG, the BBC and PricewaterhouseCoopers.

The latest evidence to support job-sharing comes from a survey commissioned by the Industrial Society and the Resource Connection, a flexible working consultancy. It found that job-sharers scored highly on their ability to lead, to solve problems and to remain resilient in the face of a setback.

Perhaps more significantly, it also found that around 70% of them were perceived to be outperforming their full-time colleagues in terms of output.

A case in point is Joanna Gordon who works in Bristol in the equal opportunities division of Lloyds TSB. She shares her position with another woman and together, says Gordon, they prove that two heads are better than one. "As a team I think we produce more work and I think the quality of that work is far greater."

Of course this set-up is not for everyone. The overly competitive, the grossly insecure and the fiercely independent need not apply. The same goes for the control freaks of this world.

You do need to be a particular person to make job-sharing work, says Julia Bashler. She should know. Julia was once a job-sharer herself and is now with the Industrial Society, advising undergraduates on how to get "employment-ready".

If you don't remember anything else ...

To job-share successfully, it's crucial, stresses Julia, that you are able to manage your time, to let go of control, and to work very, very closely with someone else.

Fitting in with the working pattern of another person was the key for Kerry Prentice who works within production management for Boots in Nottingham. "You've got to give yourself time to adjust to your job-share partner, particularly in getting to know how they work."

If that doesn't sound like something you could manage, then you'd probably best stick to doing things the old-fashioned way and settle for just one full-time position.

webTitle: Help: I want to go back to my old company!

fields.headline: Help: I want to go back to my old company!
fields.standfirst: A year ago I was made redundant by an organisation I loved working for. Now they're advertising for staff again. I'm really tempted to apply but would that be a mistake?  LS, media sales executive, Nottingham
fields.trailText: A year ago I was made redundant by an organisation I loved working for
fields.body:
A company you remain impressed with, even after they dispensed with your services must have something special going for it. Applying doesn't commit you to anything, so that wouldn't be a mistake; however returning might be.Going back to something that was once good leaves you vulnerable to disappointment.

Even if your memories are untainted by the rosy glow separation gives, a lot could have changed in the year following a crisis that caused them to shed staff.

That they handled redundancy well enough to leave you feeling positive is unusual. It's something you could flatter them with in your application.

Not going for this job could leave you with the feeling of an opportunity missed. Applying has three possible outcomes: they won't want you, things will not be as you remembered, or you'll be welcomed back. The first two would help lay the ghost of pleasures past firmly to rest, leaving you more able to concentrate on the present. Receiving a job offer would give you licence to ask more searching questions.

Unless you fancy a career of exits and entrances, check how stable their current situation is. If things are good enough to lure you back, use your previous misfortune as a bargaining tool. Hold out for a more responsible job and higher salary.

fields.headline: Somewhere for now
fields.trailText: Europe
fields.body:
Europe

Britain: Enjoy a weekend break at Melbourne Lodge (01707 335241) in the middle of the Brocket Estate, 30 minutes from central London. The price of £190 per person per night, based on twin share, includes breakfast and dinner.

France: Stay for two nights at the four-star Sofitel Le Mediterranee, Cannes for £279pp for departures on March 25. The price includes return scheduled flights from Gatwick, B&B accommodation and car hire for the duration. For reservations, call British Airways Holidays on 0870 2424243

Africa

Egypt: Cruise the Nile, visiting world-famous sights including the Colossi of Memnon, the Valley of the Kings and the temples of Horus, Hathor, Karnak and Luxor. The seven-night package from Somak Holidays (020-8423 3000, www.somak.co.uk), departs Mondays in March and costs £799pp (based on two sharing an ensuite cabin) and includes scheduled flights, transfers and seven nights' full-board accommodation.

South Africa: Explore Worldwide (01252 760100) is offering a 14-day tour of southern Africa, departing April 8 and taking in South Africa, Lesotho and Swaziland. Highlights include hiking deep into the Southern Highlands to isolated Basotho villages and staying in traditional clay and mud homes, and the Kruger National Park. The package costs from £1,210pp including flights, transportation, accommodation (hotels/ camping), some meals and the services of a tour leader.

Asia

Thailand: Gecko Travel (023-9237 6799, www.geckotravel.co.uk) is offering the opportunity to visit Bangkok, travel across the Bridge over the River Kwai and explore the forested hills of the Thung Yai wildlife reserve on the Burmese border. Departing March 24, the package includes accommodation, food, activities and flights for £1,150, or £600 if you wish to arrange your own flights to Bangkok.

Caribbean

Windward Islands: Trips Worldwide (0117 3114400, www. tripsworldwide.co.uk) has two-centre packages to Dominica and Guadeloupe with regular departures to the end of March, including flights, transfers, some meals, accommodation and local guides. Price starts from £1,600pp based on twin share.

North America

California: Bridge the World (0870 4447474, www.bridgetheworld.com ) is offering four-night breaks in San Francisco from £485pp including a tour of the city and the prison on Alcatraz island. The offer is available until April 4 and must be booked by March 19.

Rough Guides

Very knowledgeable about Esbjerg, but the other destinations fare badly. The search doesn't work in most versions of Netscape.

* Esbjerg: Generally thought of as being gloomy and run-down, but in the process of massive redevelopment. Plenty of hotel, museum and restaurant recommendations.

OAG

If you haven't heard of it, then probably OAG hasn't heard of it either. Esbjerg: Not found.

Columbus World Travel Guide

Columbus is a directory rather than a search engine, so you'll need to know which region to look for. Lacks the forthright opinions of the Rough Guides, but a better choice than OAG outside the major resorts.

* Esbjerg: An historically interesting port with a number of fine beaches.

Google

If Google isn't already your first-choice search engine, then you're probably wasting time.

* Esbjerg: Directs searchers to Esbjerg's online tourist office.

VirtualTourist.com

A US-based forum to which anyone can contribute recommendations and photos. Ploughing through the unselfconscious rambling is a bit like eavesdropping on stoned guests at a party. Occasionally enlightening.

* Esbjerg: "There is a great monument of four men looking at the sea - you can sit there the whole day gazing along."

Tourism Offices Worldwide Directory

Most national tourist boards now maintain large sites with their own search engines. Expect detailed and invariably enthusiastic results.

* Esbjerg: Vastly detailed directory listing everything from hotels to the Andrew Lloyd Webber Musical Gala next month.

Lonely Planet

Occasionally more remote destinations are mentioned in the Travellers' Reports, but Lonely Planet is stronger on rural regions outside Europe than within it.

* Esbjerg: Possesses a small airport and a railway station.

fields.headline: Cork tips
fields.standfirst: Guy Mansell finds that the Republic's second city is competing with Dublin for the culture crown
fields.trailText: Guy Mansell finds that the Republic's second city is competing with Dublin for the culture crown.
fields.body:
Cork is Ireland's second city, sunk into the valley where the river Lee meets the sea. Its centre is a small arrowhead-shaped island ringed with quays, just over a mile long and half a mile across.

The city's architectural looks are difficult to define, but can be dated from the late Georgian period through to Victorian. Terraced townhouses, often individually painted, on three and four floors, mingle pleasingly with shops and ornate public buildings reflecting Cork's prosperity as a major European trading port throughout the 1800s.

The city centre, being an island, has developed its own distinct calm "village" ambience. And with the nation's new prosperity, Cork has become a centre for arts and culture, attracting poets, painters and sculptors and especially those connected with music and dance.

There is no sign of Celtic heritage. Cork's history begins with St Finn Barre in the 600s, followed by the Vikings and the Normans in the 12th century. It came to prominence in the mid 1700s as the staging and trading port primarily to America and the West Indies. Ships would be provisioned for long voyages carrying local exports of beef, butter, tallow and hides. Shipping also spawned the thriving industries of sail making and cooperage.

What to see

A trip on the open-top bus (I£8) is the quickest and most informative way of getting to grips with the city . The main sights, such as the Beamish Brewery on south Main with a 10.30am tour (I£3), are located centrally. St Finn Barre's Cathedral, built in the 1860s on the site of the hermit saint's dwelling, is spectacularly executed in mosaics, stained glass and more than 1,200 carvings.

Cork's thriving arts scene is enthusiastically competing with Dublin. The Crawford Art Gallery, built in 1724 at Emmet Place, shows the works of contemporary Irish artists as well as some old masters. The Vanguard Gallery on Careys Lane specialises in emerging Irish artists, while the Triskel Centre promotes visual and performing arts.

The city's commercial and industrial history is best sampled at the public museum in Fitzgerald's Park, The Cork Vision Centre on North Main Street and the Butter Museum at Shandon, while the Old City Gaol of the 1800s gives an insight into the horrors of the convicts' lot.

Entertainment

Try to take advantage of the theatrical dance and music events. The comedy club on Coburg Street is one of Europe's best, while the Victorian Everyman Theatre on MacCurtain Street is well respected for the quality of its production. The Firkin Cran Centre across the bridge at Shandon is home to the city's ballet company, while the Opera House at Emmet Place plays host to touring plays from Dublin, as well as concerts and musicals.

"The dogs" are intrinsic to Irish culture, and the new Greyhound Stadium, which has racing every Wednesday, Thursday and Saturday, is only an eight-minute taxi ride from the centre. Entry, inclusive of an excellent three-course dinner, is I£25. However, all racing is suspended at present due to the foot and mouth restrictions.

Out of town

If you are seeking the "eloquence of the silver tongue", the Blarney Stone is 25 minutes away by bus. To the south lies Kinsale, where Charles II was crowned before going into exile.

To the east is Cobh, just a short train-ride away. The 42-bell carillon at St Col man's rings out the Angelus. The Queenstown Experience, a reference to the period when the town was renamed in honour of Queen Victoria, has a much-praised interpretative centre that portrays the heartbreak of emigration.

The extraordinary cult of road bowling is practised every Sunday at locations on the outskirts of the town. There are 100 clubs, so simply look for groups of people blocking the highway and lobbing steel balls down the road. There's also fishing, ranging from deep sea to catching trout on the Blackwater river. Or why not try your hand at sailing: Cork has the oldest yacht club in the world, established in 1720 - (00353) 21 4831023 www.royalcork.com - plus plenty of nearby golf courses.

Eating out

On one side, there is the sea, so think fish. The other three sides are cattle country; so think quality beef.

The Farmgate Café , Old English Market, Princes Street, Cork (021 278134). The owner Kay and "her gals" always have an Irish "traditional" on the menu, such as lamb stew or tripe and drisheen (blood sausage). Around I£6.

Another "must" is Ballymaloe House, Shanagarry, 20 miles east of Cork (021 4652531). A large country house set amid 400 acres. Lunch costs I£10-20; dinner I£20-plus; booking is essential. The house incorporates a renowned cookery school, and if you decide to book a room, facilities included an outdoor swimming pool, tennis court, and children's play area. B&B from £85 for a single; £135 for a double. The owners of the Ballymaloe also run the Crawford Gallery Café, Emmet Place 021 4274415.

At Café Paradiso, 16 Lancaster Quay, Western Road (021 4274415), creativity is Bridgette and Dennis Cotter's theme. Try their almond pastry gallete with spinach, sheep cheese, aubergine and beans. Lunch: I£ 3.50-£7; Dinner: I£ 15-18. Extensive wine list.

Isaac's, 48 MacCurtain St (021 503805), is close to the Everyman theatre; booking is essential. Starters such as Caesar Salad from I£5. Mains, such as king prawns, I£20pp. Wines from I£12.

Proby's Bistro, Proby's Quay, Crosses Green (021 431 6531). Close to St Finn Barre's cathedral. Contemporary Euro cuisine. I£25-plus per person.

Getting there

British Airways (0845 7733377, www.britishairways.co.uk ) flies to Cork from a number of UK airports for £142. Ryanair (0870 3331231 www.ryanair.com) flies to Cork from London Stansted from £98. Swansea Cork Ferries (01792 456116) operates return services between March and November from £149 for a car and up to five adults. For more information and hotel availability, contact the Irish Tourist Board (00353 1602 4000, www.ireland.travel.ie).

webTitle: 'I was heading 60 miles out to sea, to a pirate's hangout '

fields.headline: 'I was heading 60 miles out to sea, to a pirate's hangout '
fields.trailText: Sally Kindberg heads for the wild west of Ireland to visit a pirate queen's haunt 60 miles out to sea.
fields.body:
I left Knock airport provisioned with two bottles of the hard stuff - holy water from the Shrine Shop - and a packet of Lucky Sawdust for the Traveller to cover all eventualities.

The terminal was built to enable pilgrims to visit the shrine marking a 19th-century sighting of the Virgin Mary, but I was on a pilgrimage of another kind. I was heading for the wild west of Ireland to visit a pirate queen's haunt 60 miles out to sea. Clare Island was the stronghold of feisty Grace O'Malley, who controlled these coastal waters 400 years ago.

At tiny Roonagh Quay, 18 miles south of Westport, two ferries, the Island Princess and the Pirate Queen, were moored alongside. We were handed flyers from rival Portakabins above the pier. "The ferry service was originally run by the O'Gradys, but then the O'Malleys got in on the act," I was told by a young O'Grady on board the Pirate Queen.

After 15 minutes onboard, a humpy long-necked island necklaced with golden sand surged into view. The harbour was guarded by O'Malley's sturdy castle, a square refuge crowned by two chimneys, its slit windows commanding strategic views of Clew Bay.

As we found to our cost, the weather changed every few minutes. Heavy bursts of rain were followed by apocalyptic sunbursts accompanied by a succession of rainbows that leapfrogged across the islands.

We approached the remains of a Cistercian abbey, its grilled gateway fastened with a bicycle lock. A churchyard overflowed with the graves of generations of O'Malleys. I knocked on the door of a tiny cottage and was given the key by an old man. The walls of the abbey were decorated with medieval imagery. On one wall was the stone tracery of a tomb and a plaque carved with the motto terra marique potens - "powerful by land and sea". This is the O'Malley coat of arms, and the tomb is reputed to be that of the pirate queen. As I photographed the stone carving, a gust of wind slammed the abbey door shut, plunging us into darkness.

I returned the key to its owner. "Would you be an O'Malley now?" he wondered. I wasn't, but O'Malleys from all over the world come to visit their ancestor's island. "Are there any O'Malley pirates left?" I asked the guardian of the key. "Only the one with the ferry," he replied, showing several teeth.

Ryanair (0870 1569569, www.ryanair.com) flies to Knock from London Stansted from £123. From the nearest railway station to Knock, Claremorris, (Irish railways, Iarnród Éireann, tel: 00353 1836 6222, www.irishrail.ie), operates services to Westport, standard return £10.50. The ferry from Roonagh Quay to Clare Island costs £20 return. For information, contact Chris O'Grady on 098-26 307 (Bay View Hotel) www.anu.net/clareisland/pirate.htm

webTitle: Paul Kenyon: Secret filming equipment | My minder | A mini-CD player | A picture of my wife

fields.headline: Paul Kenyon never travels without...
fields.trailText: Secret filming equipment | My minder | A mini-CD player | A picture of my wife
fields.body:
A necessity: Secret filming equipment. I've managed to get equipment into Cambodia for Panorama without any problems, but somehow I always get stopped at Manchester airport - we were stopped three times while we were filming this series.

A luxury: My minder. I am supposed to use him all the time when I go out and do difficult filming. He's ex-SAS.

A memento: I try and buy a little photograph from each place I go to because I can't really go back there twice - just in case I bump into the person I have been secretly filming.

A favourite thing: A mini-CD player. It's so useful because if you travel with a group of people, you do get sick of them. So it's nice to be able to put the headphones on.

Lucky charm: I have a tiny little picture of my wife, aged about 10.

If only: I lose so many mobile phones and keys. If there was such a thing as a palm-top radar that you could switch on which would tell you where you'd left things, I'd definitely get one.

A memento: I try and buy a little photograph from each place I go to because I can't really go back there twice - just in case I bump into the person I have been secretly filming. A favourite thing: A mini-CD player. It's so useful because if you travel with a group of people, you do get sick of them. So it's nice to be able to put the headphones on. Lucky charm: I have a tiny little picture of my wife, aged about 10. If only: I lose so many mobile phones and keys. If there was such a thing as a palm-top radar that you could switch on which would tell you where you'd left things, I'd definitely get one.

fields.trailText: Europe
fields.body:
Europe

Crete: Kosmar Holidays (0870 7000747) is offering seven nights' self-catering leaving Gatwick on May 1 for £179pp, including flights and transfers.Other dates available.

Spain: Sail or windsurf in the sheltered Fornells Bay, Minorca with Minorca Sailing Holidays (020-8948 2106, www.minorcasailing.co.uk). Prices begin at £652pp for two sharing a self-catering apartment in early May, and include return flights from Gatwick, sailing tuition and use of boats and boards.

France: Belle France (01797 223 777) is offering a six-night cycling holiday, with regular departures until September, with guests cycling around 20 miles a day between hotels while their luggage is transferred by car. The circular route starts in the small town of Graveson and other stops are made at Beaucaire and Fontieille. The price is from £479pp (self-drive, based on two sharing) or £589 travelling by Eurostar and changing in Lille. The price includes six nights' B&B accommodation, bicycles and route guides.

Asia

China: Exodus (020-8675 5550, www.exodus.co.uk) has a 20-day trip along the Silk Road between Kyrgystan and Beijing, crossing the Torugat Pass, and finishing with a visit to the Great Wall of China. Trips depart Heathrow on July 21, August 18 and Decem ber 8 and 29 and cost £2, 395 per person including flights and B&B accommodation.

Caribbean

Cuba: Seven-night, all-inclusive holidays cost £689 per person through The Destination Group (020-7400 7037). Valid for departures (Wednesday and Saturday) between late April and July, the price includes flights from Gatwick, transfers, visas and twin share at the four-star Beaches Varadero resort.

North America

Florida: Hotel-based packages for a family of four, featuring seven nights in St Petersburg and seven nights in South Beach, Miami, cost £1,999 through Floridian Journeys (0870 7093050). For departures between May 1 and June 30.

South America

Galapagos Islands: Bales Worldwide (0870 2413208, www.balesworldwide.com) is offering 13-day packages in April, May and June for £2,450pp. Beginning in Quito, the trip includes a 600-mile voyage to the islands for a seven-day cruise that includes the chance to observe wildlife such as iguanas, fur seals, and tortoises. fields.headline: Going to extremes
fields.standfirst: Bored with cruising around gentle pistes?  Martin Bell  shows you how to ski steeper
fields.trailText: Bored with cruising around gentle pistes? Martin Bell shows you how to ski steeper
fields.body:
Skiing on steep slopes is intimidating. But it can also become addictive. Many expert skiers, who have become bored with cruising around on gentle, groomed pistes, cannot live without the thrill of descending slopes that even mountain-climbers find difficult to ascend. I must confess, I am one of them. No longer able to get my adrenalin fix from ski-racing at 90mph, nowadays I often get my kicks from making jump turns on slopes where a fall could be perilous.

On a 45-degree slope, you will be able to reach out and touch the ground above you, merely by stretching out your arm. Even to a confident expert skier, this will feel like a virtual precipice. We're now into the realm of "extreme skiers", now often referred to as "big mountain freeriders".

At 55 degrees, you can touch the slope above you with your elbow. And around 60 degrees, there is a limit reached: sometimes the snow will not stick to slopes this steep.

Not all snow types are identical. Wet snow is "stickier" than dry, powder snow, and therefore adheres to steeper slopes. So if you are seeking the challenge of extremely steep slopes, you should head for "coastal" mountain ranges close to the sea, where the snowfall is usually wet, heavy, and sticky. The Californian resorts are famous for steep skiing. But the Mecca of steep faces, with snow apparently impossibly clinging to them, is the Chugach range in Alaska.

Before heading on to radically steep slopes, you should be properly prepared. Acquaint yourself with the self-arrest procedure, which can be used to stop yourself sliding uncontrollably once both your skis have released. This requires you to manoeuvre yourself around so that you're sliding on your stomach with your legs pointing downhill. Now, if you do a slow press-up, your toes will dig into the snow and bring you to a halt.

Check the level of avalanche risk, and the stability of the current snowpack. If you're not an expert on snow layers, your best option is to consult your local ski patrol or mountain rescue service.

Technically, the key to skiing steep slopes is to make sure your skis are pointing downhill for the minimum time possible. The best way to do this is to use jump turns, where you turn your skis by pivoting them entirely in mid-air. You need to take off from one set of edges, and land on the other. It is essential to land with your skis already tilted on to their edges so that they bite into the snow immediately, to prevent you sliding away and out of control.

The only way to pivot your skis quickly enough to perform this type of turn is to rotate just your legs beneath you, while your upper body remains permanently facing down the slope. (This is a fundamental principle of all short turns.)

A solid pole-plant is important for all short turns, but for jump turns on steep slopes, it is absolutely vital. As you jump your skis around, you are almost in a state of free-fall. This sensation is what makes steep skiing so exciting, but during that phase you need to support yourself by remaining in contact with Mother Earth, via your pole.

The positioning of the pole-plant is also crucial; on flatter slopes, you can plant your pole in front of you, near your ski-tip - but on steeper slopes, you need to plant your pole further below you. This will help you keep your weight out over your downhill ski, providing a solid platform from which to launch into the next turn. Each time you finish a turn, you need to reach down the hill to make the pole-plant that will lead you into the next turn.

The body shape you're looking for is a curved "C", with your knees and hips angulated into the slope, keeping your skis well edged, and your shoulders leaning out to the downhill side. Many timid skiers find this difficult, and tend to "shy away" instinctively from the slope below them, by leaning towards the uphill side with their shoulders. But this will make any edge grip impossible. Mastering steep slopes is all about overcoming your instincts and applying good technique.

The final refinement of steep skiing is slough management. The slough is the stream of snow that your skis send cascading down the slope. It's not necessarily a full-on avalanche, just a lot of loose snow. If you find yourself turning through your own slough, it'll be difficult to see the ground, and if the snow is particularly heavy, you may even get swept off your feet. Free-skiing superheroes are often fast enough to outski their slough, but for mere mortals the solution is usually to slow down, and follow your slough down the mountain.

If you crave adventure, try applying these technical rules, and start working your way up to steeper and steeper slopes. You'll find that when you go back to the "normal" pistes, they will seem strangely bland.

Martin Bell is running ski courses for intermediate skiers this summer in Vail and Breckenridge, Colorado. For more information, call 001 970 845 5710 or visit: www.unmissable.com

fields.headline: Tignes spirit
fields.standfirst: At the scene of this week's world freeriding championships,  Jamie Wilson  tries the new-style skis to go off piste for the first time
fields.trailText: At the scene of this week's world freeriding championships, Jamie Wilson tries the new-style skis to go off piste for the first time.
fields.body:
Imagine finding the steepest, most frightening looking peak strewn with rocks, deep couloirs and vertical drops. Then climb to the top, click into your bindings and throw yourself off. If all goes well, you should arrive at the bottom a couple of minutes later after executing the odd bone-jarring 25m jumps, followed by a quick 360 and ending with a 60mph burst of speed.

I could not imagine it either, which is why, despite a half-hearted invitation to ride with the current world freeride champion, I kept my skis firmly cramponed to the piste 1,000m or so below.

If the hype is to be believed freeriding is the new snowboarding, and Tignes, one of the highest ski resorts in the French Alps, has set itself up as the freeride capital of Europe. Where once skiers feared to tread off piste, new ski design has allegedly made deep powder accessible even to the intermediate skier - which is me.

With sales plummeting as snowboarding has stolen much of the youth market, the ski manufacturers realised they had to act fast if the sport was not to become confined to a dwindling band of old age pensioners. Their response was to produce the freeride ski: shorter and wider to keep you afloat on powder, made with more flexible material to allow you to land jumps without snapping a cruciate ligament, and twin tips - a ski that turns upwards at both ends - to allow backwards skiing and access to a half-pipe, previously the exclusive domain of snowboarders. This was a ski for the new generation - also me.

I may be approaching 30 at the speed of a top downhill skier, but I'm still vaguely young at heart, and this ski was going to be my salvation. Tired of abuse from boarder friends who ridiculed my inability to venture off piste without ending up buried in a snow drift, the freeride ski was going to make me a powder hound.

My confidence lasted about as long as it took to make the six-minute journey from the heart of the resort to the top of the Grande Motte funicular railway at 3,000m. With the Grand Motte glacier towering above us, my guide stopped and pointed his skis in the direction of what looked to me like a vertical face of snow. "This looks OK," he said. I sidled up to the edge, gulped, and sidled back again. "Do you know, I think I'll just warm up my legs a bit with a run down here," I said, pointing at the groomed piste that gently made its way down the side of the mountain. By the time we reached the bottom, he had me sussed. We made our way to the other side of the valley and a gentler slope.

That is the thing about Tignes - it may not be the prettiest resort in the Alps, but for the skiing purist, it is hard to better. Jointly marketed with Val d'Isère as "L'Espace Killy", after its most famous son, Tignes and Val d'Isère offer almost unlimited powder fields, loads of on-piste cruising for all levels, as well as several snow parks.

Arriving in the resort can be a bit of a shock. Instead of the pretty Alpine villages we passed through during the four-hour drive from Lyon airport, Tignes looks like a piece of Benidorm stuck on to the side of a mountain, with ugly 1960s blocks making up much of the accommodation.

But the town planners have tried hard to rectify past sins. The resort is split into three levels and has undergone a multi-million-pound facelift over the past five years. Roads that used to run through the resort have been buried in underground tunnels and an enormous new reception chalet has been built from where you can do anything, from buying your ski pass to booking next year's chalet. New developments are also on the way, including sticking wooden cladding on the hotels in an attempt to make them prettier.

A free bus service runs between the three levels of the resort that will take you back to your hotel if you have misread your piste map and find yourself at the wrong end with the lifts just closed for the night.

The buses run until late in the evening and can also be used to get home from the bars at night, although to be honest if you are more interested in après-ski than enjoying a day out on the slopes, Tignes is probably not the resort for you. Harry's bar is probably the pick of the bunch, with beer prices similar to the UK (about £2) and a live band on Thursday nights. If you want to eat out, a fondue with wine costs around £12 at L'Eterlou.

But while Tignes might not be pleasing to the eye, the surrounding scenery certainly is. The mountain cirque - offering a 360-degree panorama - provides spectacular views both from the resort and the slopes.

As we made our way across the valley, up above the professional freeriders were still doing their stuff on the face of Les Tufs, where the freeride world championships were held this week. Previously the world championships have been held in Alaska, but variable snow conditions saw the event move to Europe for the first time in its history this year. Watching the competitors hurtle down the slope made me more determined to find my feet, or should that be skis, on powder.

As I pushed my way off the piste everything went well for about 10ft, until a fatal flaw in my skiing resurfaced - at the first sign of trouble, my instinct is to lean backwards. I dug myself out of the snow, and gingerly picked myself up, my guide generously blaming the conditions for my inability to stay upright. I was feeling a bit pathetic, but after speaking to Guerlain Chicherit, until this week at least the reigning freeride world champion, I strangely felt a good deal better. He told me that once he has finished freeriding his ambition is to break the world in-line skating record by being towed behind a car at more than 300mph. I might not be able to ski down Les Tufs, but at least I'm not certifiable.

Way to go

Jamie Wilson's trip to Tignes was organised by the Ski Club of Great Britain (www.skiclub.co.uk 020-8410 2000) and Virgin.net (www.virgin.net/travel) with flights from Stansted to Lyon on Buzz (www.buzzaway.com). A Ski Club rep is based in Tignes and holidays start from £495 a week, graded by skiers' standards. Membership to the Ski Club costs £45 individual, £66 family and £10 under 24s.

fields.headline: Tracklite Tracker
fields.standfirst: Practical and comfortable new-age sandals
fields.trailText: Practical and comfortable new-age sandals
fields.body:
These new-age looking sandals seem popular. What they lack in style they make up for in practicality and comfort. They have great gripping soles, are breathable and go for miles.

I've seen people jogging down the street for coffee and croissant in them, but surely you can't use them for serious hiking? You'll be amazed. They're light, have great traction, you shouldn't get blisters because they have adjustable straps for a snug fit, and they work on a variety of terrain. The cushion midsole contains air bubbles to provide shock absorbtion. They have a neoprine lining and anti-clogging rubber sole with lamb's cleat grip for control.

Now this techno-babble is what puts me off. OK then, you'll notice a big step-up from your flip-flops.

What's this "outer toe and heel wall"? It protects your toes from getting stubbed on a rock or being injured when walking on rough ground.

They sound good for travelling when it's hot, walking around cities, by the beach and for something more serious. What do they cost?

There are two styles of Traklite sandals available for both men and women. They cost £55 or £60 and have a two-year guarantee. Further information and orders from The Brasher Boot Company on 01524 841000 (www.brasher.co.uk).

fields.headline: Foot & mouth
fields.trailText: With regard to the current outbreak of foot and mouth disease in the UK, it is important to note that there is no ban on the movement of people between Britain and Ireland. However, the Irish department of agriculture has asked visitors to "postpone their visit unless absolutely necessary".
fields.body:
With regard to the current outbreak of foot and mouth disease in the UK, it is important to note that there is no ban on the movement of people between Britain and Ireland. However, the Irish department of agriculture has asked visitors to "postpone their visit unless absolutely necessary".

Visitors who do travel will encounter disinfectant procedures at air and sea ports and many other locations around the country. Policy regarding deferring of travel, cancellations, refunds etc, can vary between different carriers and operators. Visitors are advised to check their particular position, as this situation may not be covered by normal travel insurance.

Regrettably, as a precautionary measure, a number of tourist facilities have been temporarily closed and a number of events and activities have been postponed or cancelled. The situation is subject to change, so it is best to check specific facilities before travel.

For the latest advice and and update on postponed or banned events and activities, visit www.irelandtravel.co.uk, or The Irish Times site at www.ireland.com

The situation is subject to change, so it is best to check specific facilities before travel. For the latest advice and and update on postponed or banned events and activities, visit www.irelandtravel.co.uk, or The Irish Times site at www.ireland.com

fields.headline: Shamrock rovers
fields.standfirst: Joanna Israelsohn finds herself spoilt for choice when planning a trip to the Emerald Isle
fields.trailText: Joanna Israelsohn finds herself spoilt for choice when planning a trip to the Emerald Isle
fields.body:
Landscape and the people are what bring most visitors to Ireland, and few are disappointed by the reality: green loughs, rolling plains, wild coastline, mystical lakes, and cosy pubs. What is more of a surprise is how much variety this small island manages to pack in on both sides of the border.

Horsing around

The sport unites two great Irish passions, horses and betting, and is carried out with a relaxed good humour. On Course Travel (01372 451910) offers packages to all the major fixtures, including the Irish Derby on June 29 at the Curragh. Three-night breaks cost from £365, including flights, B&B accommodation, car hire and three days' admission to the races.

If you'd rather ride than watch, In The Saddle (01256 851665, www.inthesaddle.com) offers a range of riding holidays in Ireland. Seven-day trail ride packages in County Down cost from £725 including full board accommodation in a country house hotel. Experienced riders can hit the road on an unaccompanied seven-day break in County Sligo, riding across long sandy beaches and grassy moors with overnight stops at B&Bs along the way. Irish Country Holidays (01502 560688) features seven-night breaks travelling through County Kerry by traditional Romany caravan. From £438, including caravan and car ferry.

Teeing off

Ireland has some of the best golf courses in Europe. Golf Par Excellence (01737 211818) covers clubs on the south-east coast, from Dublin to Cork, where the green fees are a fraction of those in the south west. A three-night break at the Portmarnock Links Hotel in Dublin costs £370, including a round each at Portmarnock Links, Portmarnock and Royal Dublin.

Take a hike

With four great mountain ranges, spectacular loughs, miles of wild coastline and 31 waymarked trails, walking holidays are understandably popular. Waymark Holidays (01753 516477) offers four guided walks, including a seven-night break covering the country's 11 Munros - peaks of over 3,000ft - and based at guesthouses in Kerry and Wicklow. From £580 half-board, including flights and guide. For more information on walking in Ireland, visit www.walking.travel.ie.

Pedal power

Cycling is a hugely popular sport in Ireland, partly due to the success of home-grown heroes Stephen Roche and Sean Kelly. Bike Tours (01225 310859) offers nine cycling holidays on the island, including the Connemara, Galway and Mayo tour, cycling along the quiet backroads of Westport, heading south through the Delphi valley and continuing along the coast road to Galway. Seven-night packages cost £385, including B&B accommodation, bike hire, luggage carrying, tour guide and maps. If you want to up the pace, try a motorbike tour; you bring your own bike and Leisure Breaks (0151-734 5200) supplies route maps, B&B accommodation and ferry crossing. From £120 for four nights.

Current account

With its 9,000 miles of rivers and streams, 600,000 acres of lakes and 3,000 miles of coastline, Ireland is an angler's paradise. Anglers World Holidays (01246 221717, www.anglers-world.co.uk) offers fishing breaks throughout the country, from holidays for the serious angler to relaxed family stays. Seven nights' self-catering at Ballyscullion Park, a favourite of Chris Tarrant, costs from £140pp (high season) £94pp (low season), prices based on four sharing and including ferry transport.

Stepping out

Virtually every town and village in Ireland has a festival of some kind or other. The Fleadh Cheoil na hEireann (pronounced fla hewel na hern), which includes the finals of the All Ireland music and dance contests, is the mother of them all. It takes place this year in Listowel, County Kerry, on August 24-26. A four-night B&B break in Listowel costs from £185 with Irish Ways Holidays (01536 724226) including five days' car hire. For more information, call the Fleadh office on 00353 68 23036.

Other musical highlights include the Wexford Opera Festival, celebrating its 50th anniversary this year. JMB Travel (01905 830099) offers two-night breaks to the Wexford Opera Festival (October 18-November 4) from £295 including B&B accommodation, ferry crossing and opera tickets for two performances. Prospect (020-7486 5705) is offering six days in Bantry with tickets for four West Cork Chamber Music Festival performances departing on June 23 for £995pp.

Self-catering

Shamrock Cottages (01823 660 126) has more than 300 rentals, including a converted signal box and a cottage on the uninhabited Mason Island in Galway, reached only by the owner's curragh and visited with provisions every two days or so. From £206 a week including ferry crossing. Alternatively Rural Cottage Holidays (028-9024 1100) has over 200 properties in Northern Ireland

On stream

Be your own skipper for a week on the river Shannon, home to the largest collection of inland waterways in Ireland and Britain with more than 300 miles of inter-connected rivers, lakes and canals. Shannon Castle Line's (00 353 61 927 042) two- to eight-berth motor cruisers come with dinghies, binoculars, central heating, showers and cooking facilities, and all breaks begin with navigation and handling tuition. From £95 per person per week.

Drive Ireland (0151-231 1480) offers watery pursuits including windsurfing, canoeing, sailing, and raft-building at the Carlingford Activity Centre, at the foot of Sleive Foy mountain. Four-night breaks cost from £432, including flights, B&B and all activities.

Bar hopping

Belfast's Baileys Historical Pubs Walking Tour (028 92683665) includes visits to the National Trust-owned Crown Liquor Saloon and Kelly's Cellars, the oldest continuously-licensed premises in the city and a popular haunt of Henry Joy McCracken, leader of the 1798 rebellion. Visitors to Dublin should try the Jameson Literary Pub Crawl (00353 1 670 5602), taking in bars made famous by Oscar Wilde, James Joyce and Brendan Behan among others.

Heritage trail

Shearings (01942 824824) offers a variety of coach tours exploring Ireland's culture and heritage. The price for the 12-day Best of Enchanting Ireland break, taking in Waterford, Blarney and Knock among others, starts from £599 including half-board accommodation, coach travel and guide.

Capital idea

Dublin has firmly established itself as one of the top European weekend destinations, and it's not hard to see why. Stay at the super-stylish Clarence Hotel (00353 1 407 0800), owned by U2 members Bono and The Edge. Chic, comfortable rooms with soft brown leather chairs, mosaic-tiled bathrooms and white oak furniture start from I£210 for a double/twin (no singles available); for a cheaper option, try Harding Hotel (00353 1 679 6500) in the Temple Bar area, singles I£45/doubles I£65. Eat at the ultra-fashionable Michelin-starred Peacock Alley in the Fitzwilliam Hotel (00353 1 478 7015). It might put a dent in your wallet, but the modern Irish food is seriously worth it. If you're after pub grub, the popular Oliver St John Gogarty on Fleet Street serves Irish stew, bacon and cabbage etc. The Front Lounge on Parliament Street attracts the beautiful people, while the Stag's Head in Dame Court serves a great pint of Guinness.

How to get there

Air: Aer Lingus (0845 9737747) to Cork, Dublin,Galway, Kerry, Shannon and Sligo; Air Wales (0870 0133151) to Cork; British European (0870 5676676) to Belfast, Cork, Dublin and Shannon; British Airways (0845 7733377) to Cork, Dublin, Shannon and Waterford; British Midland (0870 6070555) to Belfast and Dublin; easyJet (www.easyjet.com, 0870 6000000) to Belfast; Keen Air (0151 4480606) to Cork; Manx Airlines (0845 7256256) to Belfast and Dublin; Ryanair (www.ryanair.com, 0870 1569569) to Dublin, Kerry, Shannon, Cork, Knock and City of Derry. Go (www.go-fly.com) to Belfast.

Sea: Stena Line (0870 5707070) from Fishguard to Rosslare, Stranraer to Belfast, and Holyhead to Dublin or Dún Laoghaire; Irish Ferries (0870 5171717) from Holyhead to Dublin, and Pembroke to Rosslare; Sea Cat (0870 5523523) from both the Isle of Man and Liverpool to Dublin; Norse Merchant Ferries (0870 6004321) from Liverpool to Dublin and Belfast; P&O Irish Sea (0870 2424777) from Liverpool to Dublin; Swansea Cork Ferries (01792 456116) from Swansea to Cork.

Bus and ferry: Eurolines (0870 5143219) operates daily coach services from London and many regions in the UK to Dublin, Cork, Galway and over 100 destinations throughout Ireland.

fields.headline: Aruba soul
fields.standfirst: Jon Axworthy doesn't need to take a raincoat to this quiet backwater of the Dutch Caribbean
fields.trailText: Jon Axworthy doesn't need to take a raincoat to this quiet backwater of the Dutch Caribbean
fields.body:
Next time you can't face another day at work, try ringing your boss and telling him that it's raining, so you're not coming in. Sound far-fetched? Not to your opposite number on the island of Aruba, who won't think twice about placing such a call on witnessing an early morning downpour and whose boss will completely understand.

So rare is it for the locals to come into contact with greasy roads that it's accepted they should stay at home rather than face treacherously wet Tarmac. It's lucky then for the island's economy that such conditions are so uncommon that the local newspapers rarely need to publish a weather bulletin - the Dutch dependency is virtually guaranteed an average rainfall of less than 20 inches a year.

Tucked out of harm's way in the Dutch Caribbean, south of the hurricane belt, you'd be forgiven for a string of wild guesses as to Aruba's exact whereabouts. It's actually 15 miles off the Venezuelan coast, and it has never been a target for the Caribbean-bound Brit due to a perennial low-profile in travel agents' windows and the fact that, at present, you can't get a direct flight from the UK. The only way to get there is via Amsterdam with KLM, or Boston or Miami with American Airlines.

This means that it's a hot spot for Americans fresh from the captain's table and wedding service. And although cruise-junkies and honeymooners may sound like strange company to keep if you're not partial to the former or party to the latter, you don't have to worry because the island has a sponge-like ability to soak them up and secrete them away on beaches, on the water, or in the desert-like interior.

Arriving in peak season, which runs from January to April, when all the hotels are 80% to 100% full, you'd be forgiven for believing you'd arrived out-of-season, which is an admirable characteristic for an island that only takes up 70 square miles of the Caribbean Sea. Your choice of accommodation is confined to the white beaches and placid waters that line the southern side of the island, in contrast to the "wild side" to the north, which can only offer rocky coastline and choppy waters to those who fancy a change of scenery. Your options on the southern side are either to stay in Oranjestad, the old Dutch capital, or go further up the coast where a string of resorts stretch out to the western tip of the island.

I stayed at the Aruba Sonesta Beach Resort in Oranjestad, which is at the heart of the Seaport Village just over the quiet main road from the cruise liners' disem barkation point. Unfortunately, the contribution of the cruise ships isn't limited to the ever-changing view they provide from the sea-facing hotel windows. The highly commercial nature of the sea-front "strip" - called L G Smith Boulevard - is dictated by the shopping needs of the cabin-fevered passengers that the vessels regularly disgorge. And Aruba obliges gratefully. Exclusive jewellers, outlets of Italian fashion houses, shopping malls and 24-hour casinos dominate the sidewalk.

There isn't a great deal of nightlife on the island, and this puts the pressure on the restaurants to deliver something different, which, thankfully, they do. There are enough fast-food joints on the strip to trap the cruise crowds and keep the restaurants in the town at a suitably relaxed level. A good example is Le Dme, run by a group of Belgian visitors who were so impressed by Aruba that they transported a restaurant, brick-by-brick, over to the island and then installed themselves to cook their nation's cuisine to a very high standard for tourists and locals alike. There is an extensive selection of imported Belgian beers on offer, although you shouldn't dull your senses too much as the restaurant offers a fantastic atmosphere.

Chez Mathilde, just a short walk away from the Sonesta resort, is a little more formal - an immaculately-decorated 19th-century homestead renowned for its seafood and imported beef.

The only real disadvantage of staying in Oranjestad is that you're not directly on a beach and have to rely on pools and terraces to cool off. The big advantage of being a resident at the Sonesta, however, is that you have the exclusive use of a private island between 8am and 6pm. Water taxis dock in the elaborate lobby of the hotel every 15 minutes to take you out to the 40-acre retreat . It has been converted from an uninhabited reef island into a resort hideaway complete with gym, tennis courts, bar, restaurant, and "family" or "adult" lagoon beaches.

Both beaches are attended by a team of waiters who seem to know instinctively when you are ready for a drink and are more than willing to save you the walk across hot sands to the bar. I saw more wildlife on this one island than I did anywhere else on Aruba, with iguana, flamingo, parrots and parakeets all helping to maintain the island 's fantasy feel. It's almost like a mini-holiday and, as such, I found it surprising that the place wasn't mobbed on a daily basis. One day I overheard two friends on board the last motor launch back to shore marvelling at how they had both spent the entire day on the island and hadn't seen each other once.

Not that Aruba's public beaches could be called crowded, as you will see if you hire a car or take a taxi to any one of the seven miles of pure white sands that line the south coast.

Of course, at some point you will feel the need to shake the sand from your crevices and find some action. A good way to do this is by exploring the island's interior by Land Rover, on one of De Palm Tours' safaris, a title that they can just about qualify by the dusty, desert-like terrain - complete with cacti and horse ranches - that you will drive through on one of their excursions. All they require is proof of a current driving licence and a few whoops of enthusiasm in a gung-ho briefing, and you'll qualify to fall in behind your guide as a convoy of 4x4s leave daily.

After the usual adjustment to driving on the right, your guide will waste no time in hitting the island's dirt tracks and back roads that constitute the shortest route between the natural landmarks that make up the focal points of the tour - the California lighthouse, Bushibirana gold mill ruins and the natural bridge, all of which you would probably have driven past if the Aruban tourist board weren't there to give them a little bit more weight.

The other way to avoid going sand-silly is on one of the many snorkelling or diving tours that operate from all the resorts and beaches on the island. Aruba has some of the best wreck diving in the Caribbean, which I considered useless information as my snorkel was destined for the sandbanks. However, a lot of these wrecks lie in waters shallow enough for snorkellers to explore, which is great for those of us who have looked enviously through our masks at the "diver down" flag and wondered what excitement and danger lay beneath.

I wasn't disappointed as I snorkelled around the wreck of the Antilla - known locally as the "ghost ship" - which lies in 60ft of water and allows you to within a barnacle's reach of an immaculately preserved German freighter, the largest wreck in the Caribbean. Heading for home, I learned that the ship's fate was sealed in 1941 after the Germans invaded Holland. There was no loss of life, just a tense stand-off between the Dutch gun placements on shore and the Antilla's captain who eventually decided to scuttle his vessel and see out the rest of the war on Aruba. Given a similar excuse to stay, I would have done the same.

Way to go

KLM (0870 5074074) flies London Stansted to Aruba, via Amsterdam from £553 return. An Ocean room (double) at the Sonesta Resort (002978 36000, www.arubasonesta.com) costs $265 a night until April 20, $200 a night April 21-Dec 21. De Palm Tours safaris cost $69, snorkelling cruises $29.50. Dinner at Le Dme costs $60 a head, plus drinks.

All they require is proof of a current driving licence and a few whoops of enthusiasm in a gung-ho briefing, and you'll qualify to fall in behind your guide as a convoy of 4x4s leave daily. After the usual adjustment to driving on the right, your guide will waste no time in hitting the island's dirt tracks and back roads that constitute the shortest route between the natural landmarks that make up the focal points of the tour - the California lighthouse, Bushibirana gold mill ruins and the natural bridge, all of which you would probably have driven past if the Aruban tourist board weren't there to give them a little bit more weight. The other way to avoid going sand-silly is on one of the many snorkelling or diving tours that operate from all the resorts and beaches on the island. Aruba has some of the best wreck diving in the Caribbean, which I considered useless information as my snorkel was destined for the sandbanks. However, a lot of these wrecks lie in waters shallow enough for snorkellers to explore, which is great for those of us who have looked enviously through our masks at the "diver down" flag and wondered what excitement and danger lay beneath. I wasn't disappointed as I snorkelled around the wreck of the Antilla - known locally as the "ghost ship" - which lies in 60ft of water and allows you to within a barnacle's reach of an immaculately preserved German freighter, the largest wreck in the Caribbean. Heading for home, I learned that the ship's fate was sealed in 1941 after the Germans invaded Holland. There was no loss of life, just a tense stand-off between the Dutch gun placements on shore and the Antilla's captain who eventually decided to scuttle his vessel and see out the rest of the war on Aruba. Given a similar excuse to stay, I would have done the same. Way to go KLM (0870 5074074) flies London Stansted to Aruba, via Amsterdam from £553 return. An Ocean room (double) at the Sonesta Resort (002978 36000, www.arubasonesta.com) costs $265 a night until April 20, $200 a night April 21-Dec 21. De Palm Tours safaris cost $69, snorkelling cruises $29.50. Dinner at Le Dme costs $60 a head, plus drinks.

webTitle: Carnation, Lily, Lily, Rose, John Singer Sargent (1885-86)

fields.headline: Carnation, Lily, Lily, Rose, John Singer Sargent (1885-86)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: John Singer Sargent (1856-1925) was born in Florence, trained in Paris and died in London, but his modern sense of glamour, as well as his parentage, makes him an iconic American artist. His life as a society portraitist and an American in Europe could be out of the novels of his friend Henry James. This painting dates from a period of social withdrawal for Sargent, when he stayed with the painter FD Millet in the Cotswolds village of Broadway in 1885. Broadway was an artistic haven and Sargent must have found it a welcome retreat after leaving Paris in clouds of scandal following the exhibition of his portrait Madame X the previous year, the sensation that kickstarted his career.

Subject: Dolly, aged 11, and Polly, 7, the daughters of the illustrator Frederick Barnard, who lived in Broadway.

Distinguishing features: This is a painting that sets out to make us see through childish eyes. Everything is big, colourful, new, in Sargent's subtly shifted perspective. In the gallery, this large painting performs a trick of scale: suddenly we feel the same size as the children, in a remembered reality in which flowers are taller than we are.

The portrait was painted over two months of autumn evenings in 1885, and then again in late 1886; the writer Edmund Gosse, who was there, recalled how Sargent arranged all the Japanese lanterns and posed the girls at the start of each session. It is a fictive rather than naturalist painting, a distillation of pastoral fantasy, with a monumentality that belies its Impressionist method. Sargent makes this a mythic garden idyll, in contrast to his urban portraits of worldly people. This is a scene at dusk; the girls' downcast eyes, golden hair and identical dresses give them a dreamy appearance. The portrait is a record of their childhoods, done with deliberate decorum, making their inner lives - suggested by their rapt involvement in what they are doing - visible yet mysterious.

Sargent was a great portrait artist because everyone he painted became a character in a novel. Madame X (1884) amplifies the reputation of the society beauty Madame Gautreau by depicting her as a femme fatale, in a black dress, with revealing decolletage. His men are scary, such as the daunting Lord Ribblesdale at the National Gallery, dressed for the hunt and flaunting his riding crop as if about to thrash a servant. This painting is the antithesis of those portraits.

Sargent's paintings can be compared to the novels of James, whose portrait by Sargent is in the National Portrait Gallery. James was fascinated by the contrast of adult corruption and childhood innocence, explored in What Maisie Knew (1897) and The Turn of the Screw (1898). In this painting, Sargent creates a similarly powerful portrayal of childhood. The children are solemn about their lantern lighting. Sargent portrays them lost in their activity, as if they were lighting church candles; their white dresses give them a religious quality.

The scale of the painting makes us register these globes of fiery light as magical presences in the garden; we are drawn to the light and, like the children, find ourselves entirely enclosed. The garden surrounds the girls totally; the lilies and carnations shelter them and us. This is a moment of pastoral escape, but Sargent has no illusions about its permanence. The lighting of the lanterns is a defence against evening coming on, time's intrusion, of which the children are unaware.

Inspirations and influences: Impressionist portraiture began in the 1860s as an attempt to capture the person in the flux of life. French paintings anticipating this scene include Monet's double portrait Bazille et Camille (1865), of a man and woman talking in a brightly lit garden. Sargent's style looks forward towards Symbolist art. The use of the garden anticipates Monet's late Symbolist paintings, with their endless meditation on reflections in a lily pond.

Where is it? Tate Britain, Millbank, London SE1 (020-7887 8008).
