fields.trailText: The British Snowboarding Championships, incorporating the Music in the Mountains Festival 2001, takes place in Mayrhofen, Austria, from March 28 - April 7. Thomson Snowboarding (www.thomson-snowboarding.co.uk, 020-8939 5466 ) is offering seven-night packages starting at £375. The price includes return flights from Gatwick or Manchester, transfers to/from the resort, B&B in two-star accommodation, a six-day local lift pass covering the Mayrhofen ski area and airline board carriage. The self-drive price is £260pp. For further details on the event itself, visit www .snowsport.uk.com.
fields.body:
The British Snowboarding Championships, incorporating the Music in the Mountains Festival 2001, takes place in Mayrhofen, Austria, from March 28 - April 7. Thomson Snowboarding (www.thomson-snowboarding.co.uk, 020-8939 5466 ) is offering seven-night packages starting at £375. The price includes return flights from Gatwick or Manchester, transfers to/from the resort, B&B in two-star accommodation, a six-day local lift pass covering the Mayrhofen ski area and airline board carriage. The self-drive price is £260pp. For further details on the event itself, visit www .snowsport.uk.com.

Skiers and snowboarders desperate for one last blast on the snow - and prepared to arrange their own transport to the Alps - could take advantage of some short breaks from self-catering specialist Interhome (020-8891 1294, www.interhome.co.uk). Between March 17 and April 14, it is offering accommodation at Siviez in Switzerland's Four Valleys, which has lift access to the slopes of Verbier . Three nights' rental of a studio for two people starts at £114. And, if you can get to the French resort of Chamonix in the next week or so, the firm has breaks of similar length available in two-room apartments from £134 for up to four people. Seven nights for the price of six are also on offer until the end of April elsewhere in France. A two-room apartment in Alpe d'Huez costs from £215 and a studio for 2-4 people in the Trois Vallées resort of Les Menuires starts at £331. None of these prices includes flights or Channel crossings.

Holidays in the French Alps, Norway and Switzerland are still available from Crystal (0870 8487000) - provided you don't mind waiting until you arrive to be told which resort you are skiing in. The firm is offering one-week self-catering deals in the French Alps for £199 a head - with flights from Gatwick on March 24 and 25. The Norwegian packages are either in Geilo or Hemsedal . A week's half-board with departures - also from Gatwick - on April 1 or 8, costs £349. And Swiss holidays are available for a week starting on April 7 or 14. They cost £269 if you drive or £299 if you go by train from Waterloo to Lausanne.

Last week's big snowstorms in New England have ensured good spring conditions and look likely to have extended the season in some resorts. For those able to book by Monday (March 19), Trailfinders (020-7937 5400) has a return fare of £239 from Heathrow to Boston, which comes with a £25 car rental discount. For those who can't, the same firm can offer a round trip with Northwest Airlines from Gatwick for £207. Both deals are valid for departures until April 5 and you must stay at least one Saturday night.

Méribel specialist Meriski (01451 843100) has lopped up to £150 off the price of some late-season chalet holidays. One week deals with departures from Heathrow on March 25 now cost £749 or £799 - down from £849 and £989 respectively. Packages starting on April 8 have been reduced by £125 to £799 or £899. For skiers able to get away next weekend, Mark Warner (020-7761 7002) is also discounting last-minute packages at its "Chalethotels" in Méribel. A week at the Bellevue costs £444 against the original price of £604. At the Rosablanche, the price has been cut from £584 to £434. Flights are available from Heathrow, Gatwick or Manchester on March 25. As the name suggests, these properties aim to combine the feel of a chalet with the amenities of a hotel. Deals include breakfast, afternoon tea and wine with dinner.

fields.headline: An online lifeline
fields.standfirst:
Confine livestock sales to the internet. It's cheaper, kinder and much more hygienic
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
More net news
fields.trailText: Confine livestock sales to the internet. It's cheaper, kinder and much more hygienic
fields.body:
Sometimes a national crisis overshadows the scoring of points in the world of party politics. This is just such a time. I believe that the Labour government has handled the foot and mouth epidemic very efficiently to date.

They reacted immediately to the situation, following the precedent set in 1967, by moving into infected farms and slaughtering the sheep and cows carrying the disease. They did this in the face of criticisms born of ignorance. Immunisation was said to be a kind answer to the problem but it would have wrecked our reputation overseas and, consequently, would have destroyed our export market.

The same critics fail to mention that reimmunisation has to take place every six months. That would have made the idea economically unviable. So I support government policy, but in the near future Tony Blair must take action of a more dramatic nature to save our agriculture industry.

I am concerned that, in times of plenty, governments forget about foot and mouth and its potential to break out without warning. It is such a virulent disease - communicable even by air - that it is ever present in different parts of the globe. Our last major outbreak was 34 years ago when dead meat from Argentina was the carrier, although the Isle of Wight was hit in 1981, when the virus came from Brittany.

It is therefore inevitable that we will be struck by another outbreak in the future and we must learn the lessons of today.

In the short-term, the government must release funds as quickly as possible to compensate the farmers, some of whom are in desperate straits. The European Union is showing the way by making 180m euros available and Westminster must act with similar urgency.

When the current crisis subsides, a clearly defined financial mechanism should be set up to save the farmers from future ruin and intolerable stress. The common agricultural policy has historically created an artificial marketplace which rewards over-production. Reforms should bring farming in line with consumer demand. This will release funds and allow a financial cushion for the inevitable future outbreaks of this horrific disease. This will work to the benefit of British farmers. New Zealand has successfully followed a similar policy.

In the longer-term, I have a suggestion that will, doubtless, offend everyone with a sentimental yearning for the James Herriot days of farming, when market day was followed by a convivial few drinks in the Drovers' Arms. I believe that the trading of livestock must be conducted by computer. This is how it will work.

Westminster should immediately provide farmers and auctioneers with laptops and the appropriate software to commence trading. Then, information technology training classes should be laid on at rural colleges with lesson times to suit the busy farmers. Investment from Westminster will be negligible but the impact on farming will be dramatic. On the websites, information about the size, carcass weights, dimen sions and ancestry of livestock will be available and the details will be verified by the auctioneer. He will go to the farm, instead of the animals travelling to him.

The risk of disease if farmers buy and sell over the internet will be minimal because they will not infect one another. The closure of small abattoirs in 1995 and the growth of larger markets caused animal movement to increase dramatically. By internet trading the animals will be less stressed from repeated transportation and the quality of their meat will, consequently, be better - benefiting both the animals and the consumers.

From an animal welfare viewpoint, small abattoirs are also much less frightening to the beasts than the huge ones and the quality of staff is often better. It will also be an environmentally friendly system. We will see fewer livestock trucks travelling the motorways, with their terrified cargoes. Many don't realise that animals are shunted around the country by people who are traders, not farmers at all. Animals now move from a small market such as Hatherleigh in Devon to a mid-level market a hundred miles away before being transported again and slaughtered. This is what happened when William Cleave transported sheep from his 11 farms for trading purposes - thereby unwittingly contaminating innumerable others. Computerised auctions will short-circuit this cruel and expensive practice.

It will also will cut down costs in other ways. Consider how many man-hours are lost by farmers and their stockmen on market days and think of the travelling expenses involved in transporting these beasts from one auction to another. All that will be in the past.

Most crucially, however, electronic trading will enable British farmers to reach a wider market. These skilled and undervalued professionals have a high quality product. Computerisation will enable them to sell at higher prices. The initial investment will be repaid 10-fold and they will reap the rewards they deserve.

These long-term measures must be taken if we are to save our farmers from ruin. And I write these words not as a distant MEP with an interest in new technology, but as one who was raised on a small farm and who once represented West Devon and Torridge - the largest agricultural constituency in the UK.

A pilot project, along the lines described, was started in Dartmoor by a farmer, John Dawe, some years ago but nobody picked it up. I tried to promote it at the time but the Conservative government was not interested. This time we must follow through the idea.

If we do then small markets, market towns and rural communities will thrive again. If we do not, I dread to think of the consequences.

Emma Nicholson is a Liberal Democrat peer.

webTitle: Schools to have veto over mobile phone masts

fields.headline: Schools to have veto over mobile phone masts
fields.standfirst:
Special report: mobile phone fears
Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Schools will have an effective veto on the siting of mobile phone masts and councils will have to go through extended planning procedures before they are erected, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Schools will have an effective veto on the siting of mobile phone masts and councils will have to go through extended planning procedures before they are erected, it was announced yesterday.

The environment minister, Nick Raynsford, said there was no evidence of masts posing a health hazard. "People want mobile phones. They like their children to have them so they can contact them in an emergency.

"Nearly 40m people - around 60% of the population - use them. Mobile phones save lives. None of this could happen without the masts and other infrastructure which enable the service to be delivered."

The number of phone masts is expected to double in the next two years, from 24,000 to 50,000, to meet demand. However, there have been mounting complaints about potential health risks and the limits to planning powers which prevent councils withholding permission because the masts are unsightly.

The planning guidance, which ensures that school governors are consulted on the siting of masts under 15 metres and allows for more extensive public consultation, follows a report from a government task force .

The report found that masts meeting international standards on radiation protection were safe but criticised the lack of consultation.

Mr Raynsford said it was not for local councils to make judgments about health safeguards, but all proposed developments would have to meet government and internationally-approved guidelines.

Mr Raynsford said he would be calling in mobile phone operators to discuss plans for a map showing the position of all masts which would be made available on a website.

The government has also invited schools with masts to register for an audit of mobile phone base stations and masts to assess emissions.

Yesterday the minister said that the first 20 audits showed that the highest level of exposure to radiation was a tiny fraction of the maximum permitted by international standards.

fields.headline: Bad report for the Bard
fields.trailText: The immortal Bard was given the bird yesterday as an aid to career-minded students, on the grounds that iambic pentameter is not much use in job applications.
fields.body:
The immortal Bard was given the bird yesterday as an aid to career-minded students, on the grounds that iambic pentameter is not much use in job applications.

Too much time spent on Shakespeare and other classic "canonical literature" is forcing out humbler but more useful studies, such as lessons in writing CVs or formal letters, according to research by academics and local education authority staff.

"We rushed in too quickly in 1993, when we made it a requirement of the national curriculum to have Shakespeare given such prominence," said Sig Prais, professor at the National Institute of Social and Economic Research, who led the research team.

The study blames the over-emphasis on classic writers for under-achievement in less academic pupils, who struggle with gender-swapping Tudor nobles when they could be acquiring "transactional" language skills. These would encourage simple, clear expression and fluent letter-writing.

Working with staff from Dagenham and Barking council in east London, Prof Prais compared local 14-year-olds' language skills with counterparts in Switzerland, and found that Shakespeare's countrymen and women were lagging three years behind.

"The study is really about what are the factors in English schooling that lead to a longer tail of lower achievers which we originally noticed in maths but also appears in literacy," he said. "This was one of the factors, among others, which led to a greater proportion of youngsters simply not coping with what is put before them."

On the Continent, the report says, the shadows of Goethe or Molière fall less heavily. Prof Prais said: "It's not that they don't study their literary canons, but more time is devoted to the requirements of life - for example, how to write letters of application to employers or landlords."

The report is not entirely damning of Shakespeare, however, and is unlikely to revive calls made last year for the Bard to be dropped as part of the English core curriculum. The government has made it clear that this will not happen; but anyway, the playwright would agree with many of Prof Prais's views on taking the pomposity out of English.

Shakespeare's spelling, for instance, was often phonetic, and the professor is a member of the Simple English Society which believes in spelling enuf like that. The great playwright also clicks with most children who discover lines like "his breath stinks with eating toasted cheese" (Henry VI, Part 2).

Or, as Shakespeare might say in reply to Prof Prais, "You scullion! You rampallian! You fustilarian! I'll tickle your catastrophe!" (Henry IV, Part 2).

webTitle: After 533 days, head's ordeal is over

fields.headline: After 533 days, head's ordeal is over
fields.standfirst:
Marjorie Evans, the teacher accused of hitting pupils, is free to return to work

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Marjorie Evans, the teacher accused of hitting pupils, is free to return to work
fields.body:
It has taken 539 days, suspension from work, two police investigations, a trial ending in a guilty verdict (subsequently overturned), and a marathon disciplinary hearing, but Marjorie Evans's "recurring nightmare" finally came to an end at 4.45am yesterday.

The south Wales headteacher, who left her desk one Friday in September 1999 expecting to return after the weekend, was given the all-clear by governors to return to work at St Mary's junior school in Caldicot.

A three-person panel, which had been in session for 19 hours on the last day, found there was "no credible evidence" to support seven allegations of violence and inappropriate behaviour. Mrs Evans was the last of 22 people to give evidence, from 10pm to midnight on Wednesday. "We had the option to stop but we wanted to get it over with and we just went for it," she said.

Fortified by water and coffee, Mrs Evans, 56, stayed at the venue into the early hours with colleagues and representatives from the National Union of Teachers, led by its Welsh secretary, Gethin Lewis. And then it was back into the room where she had given evidence and heard evidence, to hear the decision of the chairman of governors, Rob Gibb, and two other governors, Joy Scott and David Ashwin. "We went in and they told us. I just looked up and said thank you and threw my arms round Gethin."

Yesterday morning, after 50 minutes sleep, an "exhausted but delighted" Mrs Evans, back at home in Usk, Monmouthshire, found that there were still problems to iron out. But they are problems of a less drastic order to the ones which confronted her in July last year when stipendiary magistrate Vivian Manning-Davies gave her a three-month suspended jail sentence after finding her guilty of slapping a 10-year-old boy with special needs. Or when, two months later, she was cleared by a high court judge only to find the police on the steps of the Cardiff court announcing that they were investigating a new allegation against her. "They trawled for evidence and I don't think they played a very splendid role," Mrs Evans told the Guardian.

But Gwent police, who were not commenting on the case yesterday, are not the only ones who face difficult questions.

The details are shrouded in legal mist, but her accusers included a special needs teacher, Sandra Cutler, who gave evidence at the original trial, another teacher, two dinner ladies, a nursery nurse and her secretary.

The panel heard evidence against Mrs Evans from 10 people; in support of Mrs Evans from 12. The seven charges included another alleged slapping incident, two of shouting loudly at pupils, two of alleged rough handling of pupils and one of putting a girl in a small room to quieten her down. "I can't understand it," Mrs Evans said yesterday. "I find it very difficult because we worked as a team: that was the atmosphere we had in the school. I was captain of the ship, we professionally got along very well and had the best interests of the school and the children at heart. I am finding it extremely difficult having sat through two days of people recounting what in effect seemed like a rerun of the trial in Abergavenny - accusations of slapping, accusations that they'd overheard supposed conversations.

"One of the phrases that kept cropping up was that I ran a school that was like a concentration camp, that I wanted total silence in the dinner hall until I could hear a pin drop. I just didn't know the school I heard about on those first two days [of the hearing]. It was totally alien to the kind of school I thought we worked in. The majority of staff have been extremely supportive and yesterday they gave evidence for me and it restored my faith in human nature. They were talking about the school that they knew."

Grievances

Her accusers are still employees of the school. This is one of the headaches facing the governing body. But Mrs Evans says she is prepared to work with them if she has to. "I'm a very professional person and for the sake of the children and their education in the school I will do it. I've got every confidence that the governing body will discuss this matter and something will be resolved even if it is sitting round the table and thrashing out people's discontent and people's grievances."

Mrs Evans says she understands that the governors, who were meeting again last night, had to investigate the allegations. "I don't bear grudges - I'm not really angry with anyone. I haven't got any criticism of the governors." But her union, for whom the resolution of the case is a triumph, is unhappy that, until the final stages of this drama, the governors allowed themselves to be guided by a "zealous" local education authority, spearheaded by Philip Cooke, the director of lifelong learning.

Although Monmouthshire council issued a statement yesterday welcoming that "after a long and difficult period ... the doubts surrounding the future of the headteacher have been dealt with", that won't be enough to appease Mrs Evans. She and her union are planning to seek compensation for her ordeal.

And while the Welsh assembly investigates the LEA handling of the case and the government in England plans new guidelines for governors, Mrs Evans - though there was a detectable flicker of doubt in her mind - is planning to go back to school. Not on Monday, but soon.

"That's been my main aim all the way through. I can't wait to get back and plot for the future ... Let's put it like this: I am going to have to see aren't I? I want to go back and I want to see what happens. It's been my life, I'm a dedicated teacher, I have been for 35 to 36 years and I want to be able to finish my career as I want to finish it."

She is already thinking about the next big challenge. In the autumn, the school inspectors are due.

Teacher's toughest test

September 1999

Marjorie Evans, headteacher at St Mary's school, Caldicot, is suspended after allegations that she dragged a boy of 10 with learning difficulties out of the classroom when he refused to do as he was told. She said the boy had tried to push, punch and headbutt her

May 2000

She appears before Abergavenny magistrates charged with assault

July

Found guilty by stipendiary magistrate Vivian Manning-Davies: given a three-month suspended jail sentence, ordered to pay prosecution costs of £2,250 and told: "You failed the complainant, the school, your honourable profession and the community"

September

Cleared on appeal by Mr Justice McKinnon at Cardiff crown court. He says she "administered the entirely appropriate form of restraint hold". Gwent police tell her further allegations are being investigated and her suspension extended for a month

October

Police say they will not charge her

December

Mrs Evans says she is going to return to work. Education authority and governors decide to hold disciplinary procedure into new allegations

January 2001

NUT begins legal action claiming she should be allowed back to work

March 9

Cardiff crown court judge says school disciplinary procedures were inadequate

March 13

Three governors begin the hearing that clears her of seven allegations of inappropriate emotional response

March 16

Cleared on all charges

I was captain of the ship, we professionally got along very well and had the best interests of the school and the children at heart. I am finding it extremely difficult having sat through two days of people recounting what in effect seemed like a rerun of the trial in Abergavenny - accusations of slapping, accusations that they'd overheard supposed conversations. "One of the phrases that kept cropping up was that I ran a school that was like a concentration camp, that I wanted total silence in the dinner hall until I could hear a pin drop. I just didn't know the school I heard about on those first two days [of the hearing]. It was totally alien to the kind of school I thought we worked in. The majority of staff have been extremely supportive and yesterday they gave evidence for me and it restored my faith in human nature. They were talking about the school that they knew." Grievances Her accusers are still employees of the school. This is one of the headaches facing the governing body. But Mrs Evans says she is prepared to work with them if she has to. "I'm a very professional person and for the sake of the children and their education in the school I will do it. I've got every confidence that the governing body will discuss this matter and something will be resolved even if it is sitting round the table and thrashing out people's discontent and people's grievances." Mrs Evans says she understands that the governors, who were meeting again last night, had to investigate the allegations. "I don't bear grudges - I'm not really angry with anyone. I haven't got any criticism of the governors." But her union, for whom the resolution of the case is a triumph, is unhappy that, until the final stages of this drama, the governors allowed themselves to be guided by a "zealous" local education authority, spearheaded by Philip Cooke, the director of lifelong learning. Although Monmouthshire council issued a statement yesterday welcoming that "after a long and difficult period ... the doubts surrounding the future of the headteacher have been dealt with", that won't be enough to appease Mrs Evans. She and her union are planning to seek compensation for her ordeal. And while the Welsh assembly investigates the LEA handling of the case and the government in England plans new guidelines for governors, Mrs Evans - though there was a detectable flicker of doubt in her mind - is planning to go back to school. Not on Monday, but soon. "That's been my main aim all the way through. I can't wait to get back and plot for the future ... Let's put it like this: I am going to have to see aren't I? I want to go back and I want to see what happens. It's been my life, I'm a dedicated teacher, I have been for 35 to 36 years and I want to be able to finish my career as I want to finish it." She is already thinking about the next big challenge. In the autumn, the school inspectors are due. Teacher's toughest test September 1999 Marjorie Evans, headteacher at St Mary's school, Caldicot, is suspended after allegations that she dragged a boy of 10 with learning difficulties out of the classroom when he refused to do as he was told. She said the boy had tried to push, punch and headbutt her May 2000 She appears before Abergavenny magistrates charged with assault July Found guilty by stipendiary magistrate Vivian Manning-Davies: given a three-month suspended jail sentence, ordered to pay prosecution costs of £2,250 and told: "You failed the complainant, the school, your honourable profession and the community" September Cleared on appeal by Mr Justice McKinnon at Cardiff crown court. He says she "administered the entirely appropriate form of restraint hold". Gwent police tell her further allegations are being investigated and her suspension extended for a month October Police say they will not charge her December Mrs Evans says she is going to return to work. fields.headline: Snow show
fields.trailText: Temperatures in many European resorts have been spring-like, which has led to a depletion of snow on the lower slopes. Some new snow has fallen at altitude. New snow for Colorado and Utah has created some excellent conditions, while many of the Canadian resorts would benefit from a huge dump.
fields.body:
Temperatures in many European resorts have been spring-like, which has led to a depletion of snow on the lower slopes. Some new snow has fallen at altitude. New snow for Colorado and Utah has created some excellent conditions, while many of the Canadian resorts would benefit from a huge dump.

Austria

Fresh snow for Soll (***) and St Anton (***) has created some excellent conditions above the mid-station. Mayrhofen (***) has had rain on the lower slopes, although snow above, and new snow in Obergurgl (****) has created some excellent off-piste conditions.

France

In general, the lower slopes are slushy and heavy-going. The best ski/board conditions can be found in the high resorts of Val Thorens (****) and Tignes (****) and also Serre Chevalier (****) and Montgenevre (****).

Switzerland

Temperatures have finally fallen, bringing much-needed fresh snow to the upper slopes of Gstaad (**), Wengen (***) and Murren (***). Good skiing can still be found in Saas Fee (****), Zermatt (****) and Verbier (***).

Italy

Excellent conditions in most resorts. Heavy snow in Cortina (****) has created some fantastic off-piste powder. Conditions are excellent on- and off-piste in Madonna di Campiglio (****).

Andorra

Soldeu (***) has been enjoying some sunshine after some new snow at the beginning of the week. The lower runs are slushy but some good conditions can still be found on the upper slopes.

US

A new dump has created knee-deep powder on the upper slopes of Breckenridge (****) and Aspen (****). Fresh powder can also be found across Utah. Excellent on- and off-piste conditions exist in Alta (****) and Deer Valley (****).

Canada

Banff (***) has some good on-piste skiing, although the off-piste is still patchy and would benefit from a huge dump. Fernie (***) also needs new snow, with icy conditions in the morning turning to slush by the afternoon. On-piste conditions are hard in Whistler (****), but softening during the day.

No snowflakes = a serious lack of snow - no lifts open.
* = poor snow conditions, very few lifts open.
** = conditions reasonable, some slopes in poor condition.
*** = plenty of good skiing.
**** = good conditions.
***** = fantastic on and off piste.
For the latest snow conditions in more than 250 resorts, check out www.skiclub.co.uk

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Foot and mouth
fields.body:
Foot and mouth

All passengers travelling out of Britain are being disinfected and warned not to carry any food, particularly meat and dairy products, or animal skins to avoid spreading foot and mouth disease. All carriers - ferry, Eurotunnel, train and plane services - are providing disinfected mats for people and cars. Operators are continuously monitoring the spread of the disease and further measures will be imposed on incoming and departing travellers as further outbreaks in Britain or in Europe demand. None yet report any downturn in the numbers travelling, nor are travel bans yet contemplated. The US, Australia and New Zealand in particular, as well as Continental Europe, are asking incoming passengers who have been on farms to notify immigration. So far no operator is refusing to carry pets - an obvious source of cross infection if allowed exercise in country areas - but check before you travel.

Oxford amble

Frustrated walkers can join a literary amble through Oxford, taking in scenes immortalised by Auden, Betjeman, Waugh, Murdoch and Inspector Morse creator Colin Dexter. The walks take place on March 31 at 10.30am and 3pm and are part of the Oxford Literary Festival, which runs from March 28-April 1 at the Oxford Union, St Michaels Street, Oxford. Brochure of events and tickets available from the Oxford Playhouse, tel: 01865 798600.

Exploring issues

Tourism Concern is organising a Young Travellers' conference for 18 to 26-year-olds preparing to go travelling. Called Exploring the Issues of Exploring the World, it will take the form of a weekend of workshops and talks highlighting issues such as sensitive photography; limiting the impacts of trekking in fragile environments; the cost to locals of us travelling on the cheap; the ethics of travel to countries with oppressive regimes; plus practical workshops on teaching English abroad, survival and safety, and travel writing. The conference is being held at Manchester's Hulme Hall on April 7 and 8. Tickets cost £15 for the whole weekend. Accommodation is also available (£15). Contact: Tourism Concern, Stapleton House, 277-281 Holloway Road, London, N7 8HN, tel: 020-7753 3330, e-mail info@tourismconcern.org.uk and, for more details, visit www.tourismconcern.org.uk.

Kiwis flying high

Air New Zealand is the airline most likely to be recommended by its customers, according to a survey of Holiday Which? readers. Singapore Airlines had held the top spot for the past three years.

webTitle: The Independent Hostel Guide Britain and Europe, The Backpackers Press, £4.95

fields.headline: The Independent Hostel Guide Britain and Europe, The Backpackers Press, £4.95
fields.trailText: If you are planning a trip in Britain on a limited budget this book is a must. The Independent Hostel Guide is packed with fun and affordable places to stay that you don't have to join an association to use
fields.body:
If you are planning a trip in Britain on a limited budget this book is a must.

The Independent Hostel Guide is packed with fun and affordable places to stay that you don't have to join an association to use.

The book is divided into geographical regions - mainland Europe, England, Wales, Scotland, and Ireland - with each section complete with a map that shows the location of the hostels and the relevant page number.

The entries are short and many have been written by the hostel owners, ensuring an insight into the character of the establishment and its proprietor rather than a dry evaluation.

It claims to be "the ultimate reference to the independent hostels of Britain" - and the sections on England, Wales and Scotland back this up with maps peppered with page references. Most of the hostels cost less than £10 a night for a dorm bed, and some are less than £5.

The coverage of Ireland is patchy, but the guide is particularly useful for budget travellers and outdoor enthusiasts, particularly if they holiday in Britain.

fields.headline: The middle way
fields.standfirst: Far from the tourist trail but only an hour from Dublin,  Roly Smith  explores the Irish Midlands and finds his perfect home in the hills
fields.trailText: Far from the tourist trail but only an hour from Dublin, Roly Smith explores the Irish Midlands and finds his perfect home in the hills.
fields.body:
Once again I think I've found my dream home in Ireland. But this time, it's not on the fashionable West Coast in Connemara or Galway. I came across it just an hour away from Dublin in the beautiful Wicklow mountains, surprisingly wild country where craggy summits and deep blue loughs have been glacier-carved from granite mountains six times older than the Alps.

The isolated whitewashed and slate-roofed cottage stands on the golden, gorse-clad banks of the Cloghoge River, just where it spills into the crystal waters of Lough Dan. The deserted cottage was sheltered by a spreading sycamore and seemed to have no services to it, but a more idyllic spot would be hard to find.

We'd walked down from the Sally Gap road that leads up from Roundwood, descending steeply to the shores of Lough Tay through a violent hailstorm to emerge ruddy-faced into the bright sunlight of a perfect day as we strolled around the lough through banks of heady, coconut-scented gorse to end the walk at Oldbridge. Such is Irish weather; if you don't like it, wait a few minutes and it'll change.

Looking down on Lough Tay just before the storm broke, our genial walking guide, Christopher Stacey of Footfalls Ireland, pointed out the imported white sandy beach in front of the Guinness family mansion of Luggala Lodge at the head of the black waters of the lough. The comparison to a cream-headed pint of the famous family stout was temptingly obvious.

Further down the valley of the Cloghoge, Christopher showed us the sad but evocative overgrown remains of a "township", like so many that feature in the Irish rural landscape. These ruins may have been abandoned after the 1798 uprising, when the valley's nationalist rebels were massacred and their houses burnt down. Or they may simply have been deserted during the dark days of the potato famine of the 1840s.

It's strange how, as in the deserted crofts of the Scottish Highlands or the slate villages of Snowdonia, places that once rang with the sound of human voices seem so much more lonely now than real wildernesses. Only deer from the adjacent forest inhabit these largely unfrequented ways, where you are constantly walking in the footfalls of history.

Wicklow, the East Coast and the Midland counties of Louth and Meath lie at the heart of a different Ireland from the better-known destinations over in the West. In many ways, they represent the real heart of Ireland, largely untouched by mass tourism yet rich in wonderful landscapes, a lively culture, and a history that stretches back 5,000 years to the first megalithic builders in European history.

The region's best-known prehistoric site is Newgrange, one of Ireland's top tourist attractions. But to visit the impressively-restored Neolithic passage tomb, you'll have to queue and wait on a timed ticket to experience the reconstruction of the winter solstice sun flooding into the inner chamber.

Instead, go to the Loughcrew cairns near Oldcastle in County Meath, where nearly 30 almost identical tombs are scattered over four green hilltops, each commanding superb 360-degree views over the lush countryside. You'll be able to walk in solitude from cairn to cairn, marvelling at the superb "rock art" engravings on the walls of the tombs, which are every bit as intricate and fascinating as those at Newgrange.

Our guide here was local auctioneer and enthusiastic amateur archaeologist Oliver Usher, of Kelltic Walking Holidays, based in nearby Kells. As we stood outside the padlocked gate (you get the key from a local farm) to the Slieve na Callaigh (The Hag's Hill) tomb, Oliver enthused: "Every time I come here, there's a different light and the carvings take on a different aspect. Beautiful is not an adequate enough word to describe it."

Once inside the tomb, we saw exactly what he meant. As our eyes became adjusted to the soft natural light flooding in through the entrance, the swirling patterns of spirals, cups, rings, zig-zags and floral designs seemed to move and come to life. We suddenly felt very close to that prehistoric past, in an almost spiritual experience which could be savoured and enjoyed.

We also found the real Ireland alive and well in the thatched Sheeran's Inn in the tiny hamlet of Coolrain, in County Laois. The legendary Chieftains have performed here, and the members of the Half Door Club wholeheartedly throw themselves into the intricate steps and whirling gigs of traditional set dancing. This owes nothing to the highly-commercialised Riverdance-style of Irish dancing but is a vital, vigorous and highly-orchestrated "set" of steps, involving much noisy stamping of feet and twirling of partners.

Live music is a tradition at Sheeran's, but what impressed me most was the age range of the dancers. Sprightly pensioners and portly farmers joined the bright young things of the village, including a nimble-footed 16-year-old lad who you'd have thought would have been more likely to be found on the front row of a Corrs concert, not dancing the night away with the old fogies in the local pub.

Earlier, our explorations had taken us on an arduous traverse of 1,932ft Slieve Foye on the Cooley peninsula overlooking Carlingford Lough, with the blue shapes of the Mountains of Mourne peeping over the hills across the water.

This area is famed in Irish mythology as the main setting for Tain Bo Cuailgne, or the Cattle Raid of Cooley, when the legendary Queen Maeve attempted to capture the Brown Bull of Cooley so that she could prove she was wealthier than her husband.

You can follow the Tain (pronounced "Torn") Way, a 25-mile walking route around the sites of their momentous battles, or cycle or drive the 350-mile Tain Trail Touring and Cycling Route from Roscommon to the scene of the final bloody denouement on that wild and rocky Cooley peninsula.

From near here, we looked down on the volcanic Ring of Guillion across the border in County Armagh, a famous example of a caldera, or collapsed volcano, where army helicopters now haunt the skies like great prehistoric pterodactyls.

We also walked along part of the 43-mile circular Slieve Bloom Way, a disappointing route which mainly treks through vast blocks of uniform conifers, rather than sticking to the boggy summits above. In our efforts to escape from the claustrophobic conifers, we foolishly forged ahead of our guide, completely missed the yellow Slieve Bloom Way signs, and got hopelessly lost before coming down on a road three miles from where we were supposed to be. Only the magic of the mobile phone reunited the party.

But there was beauty in the steep-sided coombes and the waterfalls of Glenbarrow, and an early-morning excursion to the misty 1,729ft summit of Arderin, once known as "the Height of Ireland" because it was thought to be the country's highest point, was rewarded with fine views which justified its ancient title.

Another unheralded gem was the tiny township of Fore in Westmeath, famed for its Seven Wonders. One of the most amazing is the 2€-ton stone lintel said to have been raised by the local saint, Feichin, by the power of prayer to its position above the doorway of his now-ruined church.

The superstitious or desperate still hammer coins into the trunk of a sacred ash tree (another wonder because it won't burn), or attach rags or ribbons to its branches.

There are many fairy trees in this part of Ireland, usually gnarled and twisted old hawthorns which local people refuse to disturb for fear of upsetting the "little folk". Needless to say, there were several of these trees on the way down to my cottage by the Cloghoge. I hope at least one of them will see fit to grant my wish.

Way to go

Aer Lingus (0845 9737747) flies to Dublin from Manchester from £92 return including tax, and from London Heathrow from £95 return. Roly Smith stayed at B&Bs booked through East Coast and Midlands Tourism, Dundalk (00353 44 48761), including The Ivy House, Blackrock, Co Leath (00353 42 93 21753); White Gables, Headfort Place, Kells, Co Meath (00353 46 41097); Beech Hills Lodge, Mounthrath, Co Laois (00353 502 35097); and the Derrybawn Mountain Lodge, Glendalough, Co Wicklow (00353 404 45644). His walking trips were led by Cadger's Rambling of Ivy House, Blackrock (see above); Footfalls Ireland, of Trooperstown, Roundwood, Co Wicklow (00353 404 45152); and Kelltic Walking Holidays, of White Gables, Kells (see above). Best maps: Ordnance Survey of Ireland 1:50,000 Discovery Maps No 36, Armagh, Down, Louth, Meath and Monaghan; No 42, Meath and Westmeath; No 54, Laios, Offaly and Tipperary, and No 56, Wicklow, Dublin and Kildare.

webTitle: A life in writing: David Starkey

fields.headline: The spinner of fine yarns
fields.standfirst: David Starkey tells John Cunningham why history should be thrilling
fields.trailText: David Starkey tells John Cunningham why history should be thrilling
fields.body:
Among specialists toiling their lives away on the restoration of the dense, dynastic tapestry of the Tudors is an historian whose tongue is as sharp as the needle he plies to recreate the triumphs and shames of Henry VIII, his heirs and ill graces.

It's David Starkey: expert on all things Tudor and meddler in public issues - "treading on toes" is how he puts this interest. So he's as unlikely to get lost in Henry's Hampton Court maze as he is to be stumped for an instant solution to a conundrum when he appears as a panelist on BBC radio's The Moral Maze .

It is more than 30 years since Starkey as an undergraduate moved in - academically -with Henry, three Caths, two Annes, one Jane, and their kids. He is best known as a narrator of sumptuous spectacle and intricate intrigue on Tudor telly sagas; but among fellow historians, he is rated as a digger and delver into the 17th-century royal court and constitution. Yet though he has authored and edited several books, there has been a long wait for the big one that would crown him as an outstanding academic and a first-rate communicator.

So is his life of Elizabeth I as a young woman meant to be his thunderous man-o'-war, launched to conquer the catty seas of historical scholarship? A crisp "No". "Let's call things by their proper names," Starkey says. "The book was a spin off [from last year's Channel 4 series]. I don't think that's a bad thing. If you make a book which is little more than putting a television script on the page, and add a few pictures, that would be a bad thing.

"But I would never do that because I happen to be very interested in language, in writing. Although the book was stimulated, and indeed financed, by the television series, it quickly took on a life of its own." Reviewers called it a real page-turner. Almost a bodice-ripper, they might have ventured, for Starkey reveals the "slaps and tickles" in the canopied four-poster when Eliza's step-father, Lord Seymour, crept into her early-morning bedchamber.

His magnum opus will be his life of Henry VIII; it has been interrupted over the years by several other projects, including Elizabeth . It will be finished within two years and should be weighty enough to get him a professorial chair. But he no longer wants one: he has cut down his teaching commitments, and is impatient with many aspects of academic life.

It is easy to caricature Starkey, researching away in the seclusion of a crenellated Cambridge tower; pausing only to lob a barb onto the grey pate of a critic or rival. After all, he once said: "High malice is almost inherent in the profession of historian." And he memorably proved it, in his riposte to a "poisonous" review by his old mentor and friend, G R Elton. "You didn't bludgeon Elton," agreed the editor of the journal where the spat between the two historians occurred, "you lowered him into an acid bath. Slowly." Starkey giggles as he recalls it, and adds that Elton "deserved it".

Starkey manages all his writing, TV and lecturing projects like an efficiency consultant rather than a scatty academic. No apology for being intensely practical. Elizabeth took him just six months. This meant the first hardback edition appeared without footnotes; they are there, copious and revised in the paperback. "To footnote properly takes time. I had to finish the book to coincide with the television programmes. Writing is a real activity conducted in real time." He says this so firmly that you feel he should be running a course for constipated academic writers.

Finishing the book speedily was no great feat, he suggests: his mind has been marinating the Tudor period for many decades. The best way to cater for the continuing interest in Elizabeth, he says, "isn't to do [a book on] the problems of women rulers, or the sexuality of suppressed virgins", but to tell it straight. No new sources, then? A burst of withering impatience: "What else could it be for a century where everything that matters has been published for 200 years? Journalists have a notion that history consists of discovering a new source, and waving it around like a mouse discovered in the soup."

OK, so what about the wealth of detail he has included? Rich fabrics, for instance: would the Tudors have been the number one shopaholics at Liberty's if it had existed then? It sounds like it: "I happen to have edited the inventory of Henry VIII: a complete list of the king's possessions. On the one hand, this can seem like history by a couturier, or the worst sort of Roy Strongery; but the Tudors spent hugely, heavily, on the apparatus of magnificence. Henry's collection was worth one year of the national income."

Starkey is really a merchant - of words - himself: he trades in bolts and bales of them; his prose comes in all designs, patterns, lengths, and widths. Elizabeth has short, bold chapters and longer, complex ones. He conceived it as an historical thriller, and purrs that it has been praised as such. Included are allusions to Elizabeth's court as a proto-Open University; to Clinton's dalliance; to Mary Tudor being wrongly perceived as "a bit of a goer".

But he also revels in the serious stuff of beheadings and theological disputes; on virginity as a tool of queenship. You can imagine him saying to a literary editor or a TV producer: "Here's a nice bit of cloth-of-gold prose I can let you have. No seconds; it's the real stuff." Starkey is an old pro at producing fine knacks for readers.

fields.headline: Biology in progress
fields.standfirst: Jon Turney gets a glimpse of science's blind spots in Investigations by Stuart Kauffman
fields.trailText: Jon Turney gets a glimpse of science's blind spots in Investigations by Stuart Kauffman
fields.body:
Investigations
Stuart Kauffman
287pp, Oxford, £18.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

How did everything get to be so complicated? For most people, a rueful exclamation; for Stuart Kauffman, the most interesting question about the universe. And although Darwin gave a pretty convincing answer a century and a half ago, it doesn't meet Kauffman's demands. He badly wants a more general account of how complex creatures can emerge from much simpler origins - and not only endure but give rise to yet more complex ones. Investigations is his ambitious, idiosyncratic but fascinating record of where he has got to.

One necessary trick is to channel energy in ways that help build more elaborate structures. Most of the light and heat from the sun that beats down on the Earth's surface bounces back into space, or gets re-radiated as low-grade heat. If that were all that happened, though, it would make for a pretty dull planet. More interesting things begin when molecules arise that can trap this energy, and use it to drive chemical cycles which build cells. Plants grow. Animals prowl. Neurons fire. Eyes and brains decode text.

Kauffman's approach to explaining how such things can be is unconventional. A philosopher turned doctor turned theoretical biologist, he works out of the Santa Fe Institute in New Mexico, where the house style is computer simulation of just about anything. In his last book, At Home in the Universe , he outlined the power of self-organisation, arguing that there are laws that can generate order where we don't expect it. In Kauffman's computer-generated universe, stable structures appeared where intuition predicted a mess. Wherever he looked - in networks of interacting genes, in vats of chemicals or in the patterns of decision that tie producers to consumers in the marketplace - he saw "order for free".

In Investigations , one puzzle he wants to cast in a new light is how to read the energy exchanges that underpin all these processes. In his earlier probing of the origins of life, for instance, he claimed that if you put enough chemicals of the right kind together and some react to generate products that can catalyse further reactions, then stable self-catalysing networks emerge of their own accord. Now he is worrying over the fact that such networks won't do anything more than cycle drearily on unless something gives them a shove. At the most general level, he wants to explain the existence of what he calls autonomous agents - defined as "an autocatalytic system carrying out one or more work cycles".

"Work" is one of the ideas Kauffman badly wants to reinvent. It is a physicist's word that cloaks some of the deep problems of biology. A work cycle is a constrained release of energy: you make a series of them happen every time your car engine turns over. The constraints on the release of energy that enable organisms to do things have to be contrived very precisely to fit their purposes.

Intriguingly, this view challenges the assumptions of biology for the last half century. After decades teasing out the biochemical details of energy transfers in cells, the ascent of DNA signified that information stood for all that was interesting about the inner workings of life - hence the headline hype about the human genome project. Now, in pursuit of new ways of understanding the meaning of organisation, Kauffman wants to bring energy back in. He is not giving up on information, but he wants a more complete picture of how it is used. DNA is information on the inside, but a bacterium swimming in the direction of a stronger sugar concentration, for example, is using information from outside to direct its motion in pursuit of more energy.

The ultimate goal is a biology that would describe the conditions for creating a biosphere, in all its teeming variety, anywhere in the universe. At the moment, Darwinism is the nearest biology gets to a theory of everything. But it is not nearly enough. "I hope there may be general principles governing the self-consistent construction of any biosphere," says Kauffman. It is not clear yet exactly what these are, but that is part of the fun.

As he ponders the connections between energy, information, organisation, reproduction and evolution of new constraints, he spells out his own intuitions while admitting: "I find it delightful that we hardly have the concepts to state these issues." Even more delightfully, his ideas about the evolution of complexity may also turn out to apply to the economics of technology and even to cosmology, as he outlines in closing chapters.

Reading about concepts that are not yet quite developed produces fun and frustration in roughly equal measure. The book is undeniably heavy going in places. Some of the chapters take for granted science that another writer would explain at length. Although there are plenty of concrete examples, much of the core argument keeps trying to turn back into mathematics. Yet Kauffman's obsessive probing of the limits of understanding is pretty gripping, in its way. The book may be science. It may be, as he suggests hopefully, proto-science. It is certainly a crash course in how to think like Stuart Kauffman, which is a great way to see blind spots in the science that already exists.

Jon Turney teaches science communication at University College London.

webTitle: Review: Reading Pictures by Alberto Manguel

fields.headline: Blurred vision
fields.standfirst: Reading Pictures by Alberto Manguel asks the question: can we ever articulate a painting? by Michael McNay
fields.trailText: Reading Pictures by Alberto Manguel asks the question: can we ever articulate a painting? by Michael McNay
fields.body:
Reading Pictures: A History of Love and Hate
Alberto Manguel
337pp, Bloomsbury, £30
Buy it at a discount at BOL

One forgets that Roger Fry, who more than anyone educated his countrymen into an appreciation of the "formal relations" in painting, wrote almost equally of their literary power. Of the Arena chapel, Padua, Fry wrote: "Giotto has touched a chord of feeling at least as profound as can be reached by the most consummate master of the art of words." So why not read pictures?

In the case of Alberto Manguel, the answer might be that he seems ill-equipped as a guide because of an incapacity to do the other part of the job. One example will serve: discussing Picasso's paintings around Guernica , he writes of the "haphazard canvases" portraying Dora Maar, Picasso's muse for the weeping woman with baby in Guernica ; but in all art history there are no portraits less random than these cubist-based paintings. At a guess, Manguel means to describe the way Picasso fractures and reformulates his sitter's features; but that's not what he says.

Haphazard might better describe his own loosely linked series of essays dressed up as chapters. But if this is a book with almost nothing useful to say about painting as such, it is full of suggestive ideas about social forces and their effect on art. Manguel's passage on the supreme difficulty of producing an art of the Holocaust is as good as anything on the subject; although it seems a shame that it is based on the memorial project for Berlin rather than the completed piece in Vienna by the sculptor Rachel Whiteread. I have seen only photographs of this, but they seem to bear out Adrian Searle's verdict in the Guardian : "The building's emphatic muteness and silence is the appropriate response to the enormity of its subject."

Manguel might not have been convinced, for he has his own experience of the immutability of evil, at school in an Argentina under the yoke of the military junta. "Each instance of evil exists in its own terms," he writes. "The Holocaust, for instance, is its own paradigm; each other instance of evil - the torture of Argentine children by the military or the ethnic cleansing in former Yugoslavia - is only equivalent to itself. We don't need to assemble them to have a gestalt portrait of evil. Evil, like God, is in the details." But then he also writes, beautifully, "absence too can be a monument"; and maybe the silent voice of Whiteread's Judenplatz memorial meets his argument.

The two central chapters concern image-making and iconoclasm, ideas that, as the actions of the Taliban remind us, are always current. Manguel is fond of faintly opaque Biblical quotations, and on the difficulties of art turns to Ecclesiastes (1:8): "All things are full of labour; man cannot utter it; the eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing." But he does not quote the more transparent and utterly central justification of the iconoclasts: "Cursed be the man that maketh any graven or molten image, an abomination unto the Lord" (Deuteronomy 27:15). Indeed, he is more interested in the multiple meanings of images than in the impulse to absolute prohibition.

His starting point is the sixth- century Pope Gregory's justification of pictures in churches: that for the illiterate they are the equivalent of reading. Manguel traces the development of imagery from the strictly controlled content of early Christian portrayals to modern figurative art, in which, "Since the artistic language of our time is not specific in its connotations, our interpretation remains private, one of many, a story added to the private story of the painting itself, a second or third or tenth layer of meaning that grows not from the original skin of the painting but from our own time and place."

Every portrait, Manguel argues, is a self-portrait because "we [the viewers] bring to a portrait our perceptions and our experience. In the alchemy of the creative act, every portrait is a mirror." But: "In order to know objectively who we are, we must see ourselves outside ourselves, in something that holds our image but is not part of us . . . as Narcissus did when he fell in love with his image in the pool." Perhaps; but perhaps, too, this analysis is over-subtle. Does it help us to understand Rembrandt by himself, or the self-image of the aged Titian peering yearningly into the face of the dead Christ? Only darkly. When it comes to words seeking to unravel the innermost content of painting, we are thrown back on the preacher: "vanity of vanities; all is vanity" (Ecclesiastes, 1:2).

of European high culture. Maya Jaggi reports
