webTitle: Jobs under threat at the Mail

fields.headline: Jobs under threat at the Mail
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Daily Mail & General Trust has become the latest newspaper group to tighten its belt due to rising newsprint costs and an uncertain economic outlook.
fields.body:
Daily Mail & General Trust has become the latest newspaper group to tighten its belt due to rising newsprint costs and an uncertain economic outlook.

Finance director Peter Williams said the company which publishes the Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday was "undergoing an overall health check".

He denied that targets had been set for savings but said: "In line with every other business in the UK, we are having a look at costs."

Staff at rival Express Newspapers yesterday agreed to hold a ballot for industrial action after the group's 542 editorial staff received letters informing them of owner Richard Desmond's plans to cut 145 jobs.

The letter said "costs associated with the publication of the titles are not being met by income".

It identifies duplication of jobs across the papers suggesting there will be further sharing of resources between the Daily Express and Daily Star.

webTitle: No-sex magazine for girls outlaws boys

fields.headline: No-sex magazine for girls outlaws boys
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: A publisher best known for its twee newspapers and children's comics is leading a clean-up of the youth market with a "no-sex" magazine for girls.
fields.body:
A publisher best known for its twee newspapers and children's comics is leading a clean-up of the youth market with a "no-sex" magazine for girls.

Cool magazine, which targets seven to 11-year-olds, makes a virtue of its innocence: the cover strapline reads "Boys Keep Out".

DC Thomson, which publishes the Beano comic, People's Friend magazine and the Sunday Post newspaper in Scotland, has spent two years researching the market.

Each issue of the fortnightly magazine will feature photo stories, quizzes, "funky things to make and do" fashion and makeup advice and articles on TV and pop stars.

But there is no chance that it will emulate other teen magazines with "boy trouble" features. A number of magazines have been criticised for overt sexual references.

The editor, Anne Kemp, a former editor of the Bunty comic, said that her readers "do not need to be introduced to the concept of dating at such a young age".

Ayshea Scharf, the magazine's chief sub-editor, said: "We tested this magazine with girls all over the country. The one thing we found is that they are just not interested in boys. When it comes to Westlife or A1, it's another story."

The editor, Anne Kemp, a former editor of the Bunty comic, said that her readers "do not need to be introduced to the concept of dating at such a young age". webTitle: BT says it has to cash in on Comic Relief

fields.headline: BT says it has to cash in on Comic Relief
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: BT yesterday admitted it was making a fortune by taking a cut from the Comic Relief telephone lines, but the company claimed that regulations meant it could not provide the service for free - even for charity.
fields.body:
BT yesterday admitted it was making a fortune by taking a cut from the Comic Relief telephone lines, but the company claimed that regulations meant it could not provide the service for free - even for charity.

The BBC, which broadcast last night's eight hour comedy marathon, was inundated with calls from outraged viewers demanding to know why the phone company was taking such a large slice of the revenue from premium rate calls.

The television and radio spectacular included a number of premium rate phone-ins to raise money for Comic Relief, from the phenomenally successful Celebrity Big Brother eviction telephone lines to Radio 4's The Funniest Thing I Ever Heard poll. Every vote to evict a celebrity from the Big Brother compound cost 25p - of that money 15.5p went directly to Comic Relief, with the other 9.5p going to BT and the tax man.

It is estimated that the Big Brother project will have generated around £720,000, of which £280,000 will go to BT before VAT is deducted.

An astonishing 742,885 calls were made the night Chris Eubank was evicted, raising £115,147 for Comic Relief and £70,574 for BT. The eviction of Vanessa Feltz raised £108,857 for the charity and £66,719 for BT while Anthea Turner's goodbye contributed £112,651 to the charity and £69,044 to BT.

A similar number of calls were expected for last night's final vote which decided who won out of comedian Jack Dee, Keith Duffy from the band Boyzone and Claire Sweeney from Brookside.

A spokeswoman for BT said that under the terms of the company's licence with Oftel, the telephone regulator, they have to charge a minimum amount for every call.

"We are just not allowed to give anything away free at all," she said. "I suspect the amount we are charging comic relief is the minimum."

An Oftel spokeswoman said that because of BT's monopoly it must treat all users the same and exceptions could not be made for good causes.

In a statement Comic Relief defended BT, saying the company had a duty to all its customers to continue to carry normal traffic without disruption. "Comic Relief recognises the disruption that such an appeal can have on the network and that significant resource and expense is incurred by BT."

According to the charity, this year BT has donated £65,000 directly to Comic Relief as well as making other donations in kind and helping employees to give their time in taking calls on the day. The statement added that the company had bought 36,000 vehicle red noses - at a cost of £25,000 - proceeds of which go directly to the charity.

webTitle: Business: Opec cartel's risky price rise

fields.headline: Opec may pay for being in the driving seat
fields.standfirst:
Cartel's risky price rise
Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Cartel's risky price rise
fields.body:
Is Opec back in the driving seat? The cartel has had remarkable success in fine-tuning oil prices since it announced its policy of targeting an average price of $25 a barrel for its crude. So far this year, the Opec crude basket has averaged $24.65.

After the rollercoaster ride of the last few years, which saw prices collapsing to below $10 a barrel in 1998 and then rising to nearly $35 a barrel last summer, the cartel's new approach has been welcomed in western capitals.

But peace in the oil market never lasts for long. This weekend's production cut has alarmed the EU, which believes it is badly timed in view of the present turbulence in world markets. Forecasting is always a mug's game - and particularly now, when the global impact of the US slowdown is still unclear.

Moreover, the cartel's success in controlling prices has been based on an unusual level of political harmony between the big three producers, Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Iran. Cheating by members seems to be less of a problem, although Iraq's decision to withhold oil in protest at western sanctions is giving the cartel extra leeway. Should Iraq resume exporting at full capacity, Opec could once again be riven by infighting.

In the short term yesterday's production cuts will send prices higher. But the longer term is more uncertain. The cartel has added to pressures on the global economy by raising energy prices at such a sensitive moment. If the economy collapses, they will pay the price.

Penalty shot

The ability of the glorious and historic Equitable Life Assurance Society to both irritate its policyholders and damage the name of the wider fund management industry knows no bounds.

Yesterday, it cited the recent market shake-out as an excuse for raising from 10% to 15% the "financial adjustment" - i.e. penalty - imposed on customers who want to get their own money out of this incompetent institution.

The FTSE 100 has fallen 9% since December 8, when Equitable had to admit effective insolvency and was forced to close its doors to new business, having lost its attempt to deny holders of guaranteed annuity policies the investment terms promised. Equitable now argues that, since with-profits policies are "smoothed" over time, the value of a policy may from time to time exceed the underlying investment value. So letting policyholders flee while the overall market is low might penalise policyholders who stay in.

Back in December, when the balloon went up, Equitable said it was switching its funds from the equity market into less risky assets such as gilts so as to avoid just this sort of calamity. But we now learn that the switch was halted when Halifax arrived with its rescue bid. Equitable thought it was business as usual - which it clearly was not.

Another worrying aspect here is that Equitable feels it has to take such emergency action in the wake of the greatest equity bull market on record - especially when, by its own admission, policy surrenders have halved over recent weeks. This is further evidence that, having sailed too close to the wind in the past, this society is still struggling to get a grip in the present.

Nobody should forget - especially the regulators - that Equitable is still holding £26bn of the public's money. The move to hike withdrawal penalties smacks of fresh panic.

On the ball?

Daniel Levy, the chief executive of leisure group Enic, is developing a reputation as something of an enigma.

Having walked away from bids for Wembley plc and sports betting firms Victor Chandler International and Sporting Index, the Arsenal season ticket-holder has finally landed himself the chairmanship of arch rival Tottenham Hotspur - just as shares in football clubs have reached a nadir.

Yesterday, less than a month after taking charge and just three weeks before the club's hugely important semi-final against - yes, Arsenal - Mr Levy fired team manager George Graham for al legedly blabbing confidential details about Tottenham's finances to the press.

Mr Levy has said he is trying to bring a bit of commercial discipline to the club, but if yesterday's action really was spurred by a simple bust-up over a leak, it points to a worrying lack of understanding about the game and its money.

Leaks and gossip are a way of life. Business is more often conducted through the back pages of the tabloids than in the quiet of the boardroom.

For the notoriously publicity shy Mr Levy, that could leave a bitter taste. But swallow it he must, because he needs this deal to work. Enic's shares stand at less than a fifth of the level they touched a year ago. Shareholders are getting impatient.

Unless things improve soon, his best bet would be to take the company private. Then at least he might have some chance of conducting his battles beyond the media's glare.

fields.headline: Motorists face new petrol hike
fields.standfirst:
Global economic slowdown prompts Opec to cut oil production in attempt to force up prices

Special report: the petrol war
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Global economic slowdown prompts Opec to cut oil production in attempt to force up prices
fields.body:
Motorists in Britain face the prospect of new rises in petrol prices after oil exporting countries yesterday agreed to cut production, sending crude prices spiralling.

The Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) will slice around a million barrels a day from world oil supply in response to the slowdown in the global economy. Ministers from the 11-nation cartel, meeting in Vienna, are expected to announce the exact figure today.

Opec hopes to push the average price of its exports back to around $25 a barrel. The average price slipped to $22.77 this week.

But the European commission warned last night that the move was poorly timed and could increase volatility during a turbulent period in the global economy.

Earlier in the day, North Sea oil prices rose by 83 cents a barrel to $25.84 after the Opec secretary general announced that the cartel was discussing reducing its exports to the west considerably.

Insiders said mounting concern about slowing demand for petrol and this week's fall in crude prices had pushed Opec toward tough action on supply. It began restricting production in January with a 1.5m barrel a day cut in an attempt to revive crude prices which have dropped by a third from the peaks of last summer.

But the threat of rising prices is worrying western governments which faced motorists' revolts last year when crude prices hit a 10-year high of $35 a barrel. The government was forced to offer con cessions to motorists and truckers after fuel protesters brought the country to halt.

"If Opec forced oil up by $5 a barrel, that would wipe out the chancellor's 2p cut on fuel duty," said Ray Hollaway, from the petrol retailers' association, which represents independent sellers. "Oil companies will come under immense pressure ahead of the election to make sure prices don't rise again."

Opec members argue that demand for oil will fall once winter ends in the Northern hemisphere.

"We believe it's necessary to do something because there's a huge amount of overproduction in the market," Iran's oil minister, Bijan Namdar Zangeneh, said.

Fallout from economic deterioration in the US has hit oil demand in Asia, one of Opec's key markets. But this week's global stock market slump underscores the cartel's dilemma. The slowdown in the world economy is reducing demand for oil, but if the cartel succeeds in sending energy prices higher, this will add to the factors choking off growth.

The president of Opec, Chakib Khelil, said it would balance its needs with those of its customers. "We want to meet the demand for countries who are in big economic trouble, and we don't want to create any more pain for these countries in releasing less [crude] than is needed," he said.

Opec's quota is 25.2m barrels a day. If it trims much more than 1m from that amount, it might cause prices to "slingshot" higher, said Mike Rothman, head of energy research at Merrill Lynch in New York.

fields.headline: Ubon, London E14
fields.standfirst: If Ubon and its like really do represent the future of the dining experience, then Matthew Fort wants nothing more to do with it
fields.trailText: If Ubon and its like really do represent the future of the dining experience, then Matthew Fort wants nothing more to do with it.
fields.body:
Telephone: 020-7719 7600
Address: 34 Westferry Circus, Canary Wharf, London E14
Rating: 13/20

Back at Canary Wharf again. Crisp spring day. Light on river. Sky full of promise overhead. Made for what could have been Stage 3 of Babylon Film Studios. Actually, it was Ubon, younger sibling to Nobu (full title: "Ubon by Nobu"), on the fourth floor of Westferry Circus.

Slightly disconcerted by raising the average age in a room by 20 years by entering. Not many people wearing jackets and ties. No one, in fact. State-of-the-art youth. Young, hip and hipless. Curiously conservative. Perhaps that's what working in a material world does for you.

Probably only person old enough to recognise the reference points for the design. Very 50s. Strings of amber beads drizzling down in front of the windows and from the lights. Very, very 50s. Cream-coloured light shades. Echt 50s. Chocolate-coloured kibbled covers to banquettes and chairs. Ultra 50s (only it would have been on the floor). Dark chocolate parquet flooring. Sooooo 50s (only it would have been veneer on the sideboard or table).

Decide on Martini to while away time waiting for Hortense. Was Martini very 50s? Can't remember. Don't suppose Martini-lovers would have approved much of this one, anyway. Sent it back. Asked for a twist. Got an olive. Two olives, stuffed, to be precise. Got second Martini. No delicate shaving of lemon peel, just twisted to release oils, but two strips of thick peel bearing pith. And it was warm. Not the silver bullet whistling through the rigging, as it should be.

Hortense appeared. She lowered the average age back down to normal levels. She did not drink Martini, but took with gusto to Dr Loosen's Riesling, which we managed to winkle out of the waitress at the second time of asking. We got down to serious business of food. Or not very serious business of food, depending on your point of view.

My view is that Ubon caters for people who aren't serious about food. It's food for our time; food as fashion accessory. It's about style over substance. It's a bit Californian-Japanese, with the emphasis firmly on the Japanese, with a touch of South America thrown in for good measure: tomato rock shrimp ceviche, yellowtail tartar with caviar, tuna tataki with ponzu, spicy seafood soba, oyako donburi, anti-cucho Peruvian style spicy salmon skewer, et al.

To be honest, I studied the menu for some time and wasn't much the wiser. Rather than display my ignorance, I ordered omakase, the chef's choice, at £40, and what I hoped would be a magical mystery tour of the founding father chef Matsuhisa's culinary oeuvre. Hortense set her sights on the In & Out Bento Box, the 45-minute business special. She had, she said, been bemoaning that she hadn't had a decent hit of sushi in recent weeks, and was curious about the Ubon version.

The bento box turned out to be a bit of a happy turn-out in terms of value for money. For £25, it comprised sashimi salad with Matsuhisa dressing, rock shrimp tempura with ponzu, the celebrated Nobu black cod, oshitasi, vegetable spicy garlic, assorted sushi and miso soup. In terms of quality, however, it was another matter. The batter on the shrimp was greasy, the cod appeared to have been coated in a thick, black, sweet varnish, and the salad with the tuna sashimi merely confused the elegant texture of the seared fish. Only the miso soup and sushi seriously passed muster.

My misgivings about the Ubon/ Nobu approach to raw fish cookery were born out by my own first dish, a ceviche, in which all flavour of fish was comprehensively mugged by the savage intensity of the dressing. You might argue that this is the point of ceviche - the technique of effectively curing fish in lime or lemon juice - but I would not agree.

This set a pattern for six successive dishes, all of which were pretty as pictures, not to mention bedecked with more flowers than a Mafia coffin, but all of which were also napalmed by their accompanying sauces. There is nothing accidental about this. As I once remarked of Nobu, the concept underlying the dishes is to take a delicate or tasteless piece of lightly cooked or raw protein and douse it in some superior tasting flavouring agent, marinade, sauce, dipping sauce or whatever. It certainly makes for easy eating, for nice clean flavours, for a sense of refined and healthy aesthetic, but personally I find it disappointing and one-dimensional. It westernises Japanese food, taking out all the difficult bits and rounding off the edges, distracting from the play of textures and the subtleties of flavours. I know that I am virtually the only person in the world who thinks this, but there you go.

I should add that my sense of disappointment was sharpened a notch or two when a sudden flurry of dishes followed hard on the heels of one another, and then, with the appearance of the last one, we were told that the kitchen was closing (it was about 2.30pm). I was finally brought to a keen edge when presented with a bill for £117.50, on which the box suggesting a "gratuity" was left open, even though the total already levied a toll of 12.5% "autoservice". Tsk, tsk. Greed added to incompetence is quite a tough combination to get away with.

fields.headline: The horrors of war films
fields.standfirst: Who wants 'realistic battle footage' when it shows only death, destruction and savagery without the smallest moral justification?
fields.trailText: Who wants 'realistic battle footage' when it shows only death, destruction and savagery without the smallest moral justification?
fields.body:
Enemy At The Gates, a new film about the battle of Stalingrad, had its London premiere last night. I saw it earlier in the week at a charity performance, and would not recommend it. Antony Beevor, the author of a bestselling book about the legendary German-Soviet battle, has complained in a newspaper about the film's indifference to historical accuracy. Its plot centres around a duel between a Russian and a German sniper that Beevor says never took place. Beevor also objects to a supposed romance between the Russian sniper (played by Jude Law) and a Russian Jewish girl (played by Rachel Weisz), who has taken up sniping at the enemy, too, in revenge for the murder of her parents by German soldiers. Beevor admits that such a love affair could have happened, but complains that, in the film, "it obstructs any serious examination of the basically psychotic character required in an outstanding sniper".

I do not share these objections. By Hollywood standards, it is not an inaccurate film. The Russian sniper, Vassili Zaitsev, did exist, and really was turned into a hero by the Soviet propaganda machine, which liked his good looks and humble background as a shepherd boy from the Urals. The sharp-shooting German major dispatched from Berlin to eliminate this popular Soviet icon may not have existed, but so what? His participation in the person of an excellent actor, Ed Harris, helped make the film bearable. Without him and his tense duel with Law, who was only occasionally distracted by his passion for the lady sniper, the film would have sunk into a mire of chaos and futility.

For this very reason, Beevor's book, Stalingrad, was difficult to read. In its rigorous adherence to historical accuracy, it portrayed the German invasion of Russia, ending with defeat at Stalingrad in 1943, in all its real-life depravity and squalor. The film does this, too, when not focusing on its central human drama. Costing around £60m, it is reportedly the most expensive film ever made in Europe. And much of that money has been spent on conveying as realistically as possible the horrors of war.

Beevor notes in his article that "there has been a great leap forward in special effects and computer-generated imagery" that "can create realistic battle footage unimaginable a decade ago". But who wants "realistic battle footage" when this shows nothing but death, destruction and hideous savagery without the smallest moral justification? In a conflict between Stalin and Hitler, I find it impossible to care who wins.

War films have lately become so horrific that they should be censored at least as rigorously as pornography. You would indeed have to be some kind of psychotic to enjoy all of the scenes from Enemy At The Gates. There are people who welcome the new realism as an antidote to cinema's past glorification of war, and I must admit that films such as this bring out the pacifist in me. But it is neither pleasant nor fruitful to dwell unduly on the barbaric aspects of mankind.

The charity for which the screening was held is the World Monuments Fund, created in the 60s to "safeguard the heritage of mankind by encouraging the conservation and preservation of culturally and historically significant works of art and architecture worldwide". The choice of film was fortuitous. Stalingrad was destroyed, but there was never anything culturally or historically significant about it. The WMF would have viewed its ruin with equanimity. But it cares desperately about a more recent act of destruction: that by Afghanistan's Taliban rulers of the Great Buddhas of Bamiyan.

These huge Buddhist statues, which survived bombardment by Genghis Khan 800 years ago, have been dynamited out of existence by the Muslim fundamentalists of the Taliban, who regard all statues as idolatrous. The WMF, in adding its voice to a worldwide chorus of protest, coined a new phrase, cultural terrorism: "A new form of terrorism - cultural terrorism - is being unleashed against the world through the systematic destruction of ancient sculptures by Afghanistan's Taliban government," the WMF said.

"Cultural works represent humankind's highest aspirations. By violently destroying unique, irreplaceable works that have inspired people for millennia, they are attacking the fundamental belief that our shared cultural heritage unites us. The nations of the world must be prepared to combat this new form of terrorism that has surfaced in Afghanistan today."

The Taliban are, indeed, attacking the idea that Afghanistan is united with the rest of the world by a "shared cultural heritage". They regard the fate of the statues as nobody's business but their own. Given that their actions have neither been directed against anybody else, nor linked to any kind of blackmail or extortion, it seems quite wrong in this instance to accuse them of "terrorism". The WMF, in summoning the nations of the world to prepare for combat, sounds rather more warlike than the Taliban are.

fields.standfirst: Ron's in the dugout... and he's shooting from the hip!
fields.trailText: Sshhh ... it's the return of the quiet man of the "Crazy Gang" ... isn't it? ... the one-time Wimbledon wonder now Wycombe Wanderer Wally ... sorry, Lawrie Sanchez ... nickname Pancho! Head honcho! tilting at windmills! er, leaning on a lamp-post! Wombling free! I was born under a wandering star er, no, I actually was! where am I? er, can I start this again?
fields.body:
Sshhh ... it's the return of the quiet man of the "Crazy Gang" ... isn't it? ... the one-time Wimbledon wonder now Wycombe Wanderer Wally ... sorry, Lawrie Sanchez ... nickname Pancho! Head honcho! tilting at windmills! er, leaning on a lamp-post! Wombling free! I was born under a wandering star er, no, I actually was! where am I? er, can I start this again?

Leicester 1 Wycombe 2 a fairytale ending for Lawrie Sanchez! ... "He stamped his foot so hard he was never seen again!" ... ho ho! ... not Lawrie! ... he's done his pieces and got banished to the tunnel! ... can hardly bear to watch the tense finale on television ... "GOOOoaaal! ... by Essandoh! ... "Eh? ... 'Oo? ... 'ave we lost?" ... "Nah Lol ... you remember! ... that Irish-Ghanian geezer ..."

... From the Emerald Isle via the Gold Coast ... a priceless goal and a win bonus! They might say they're only in it for the glory ... but in my day 130 nicker was 130 nicker! ... marvellous!

So the man from the internet's put it inta the net! ... ho ho! ... is that funny? ... er, ho ho ho! And all because his agent was watching teletext! ... Not the first time that's happened ... Peter Reid tells me that's where he was alerted to the availability of *#@!%#'n Quinn! ...

But a fearless giant-killing for Wycombe against the might of the Premiership! ... The day the Chairboys became, er ... Chairmen! ... ho ho! ... there's a dream team for you! ... imagine finding yourself facing Deadly Doug! ... Ken Bates! The mysterious Enic ... put the willies up anybody! ... er, must stop eating cheese at bed-time!

But the worldwide web! isn't it? ... that's the game nowadays ... buying and selling players on the internet ... technotechnotechno ... hmm? ... That's where you find the talent these days!

Big Norm tells me he's discovered a Scottish-Nigerian laddie ... er, not on the internet ... intriguing? isn't it?

... So it's off to one of those cyber-cafes to peruse the footie websites! ... and there's Gordon Strachan@ wewizrrrubbish.com ... still looking for that one last throw of the dice.

Can Gordon do his Houdini act? ... and I don't mean paddle a barrel blindfold across Niagara Falls in skimpy trunks ... Enduring image?... hmm? ... ho ho! ... If anyone can avoid the drop you can bet your life it's Gordon! ... pound to a penny Coventry get relegated, mind! And blow me! ... it's not just football on the web! ... Norm knows all the saucy sites as well! er, don't bother with "butch"@shagslikearabbit.com it's just a picture of a man with a baldy head ho ho! Rightho! time for ... a reader's letter! from, er ... bit difficult to read ... looks like a photocopy ... A Mr Wenables, of Deesside? ... writes: "In 1996 I lost my job, and just when I was at rock-bottom, I had a great idea! The last few months I've earnt a million pounds, doing nothing! And it's so simple, you could too! Just follow these instructions "

Er ... hang on ... this is one of those chain letters, isn't it ... hmm? Where was I? Yes! Television! the silver screen!

Just when I'm wondering whether it's time to change my agent he's secured me some work! tearful farewell to Mrs Manager and packed off on the train to East London! ... and not to watch the quarter-final!

Ho ho! off to spend the week on Celebrity Big Brother ... looking forward to rubbing shoulders with the delightful Anthea Turner ... only to discover I've been turfed off the team at the last minute ... gazumped! ... by Vanessa Feltz! ... apparently her agent had been throwing his weight around ... and managed to pitch her in at the last minute!

So find myself sitting glumly at Upton Park ... still clutching the new pyjamas And there's Chris Eubank! Ho ho! ... ithn't it? ... He's been voted out of "The House" before he could get his kit off! ... er, for the fifth time ... Well at least he's got some clout! tells me "hith" agent'th that Athole Thtill! ... how did Chris get on the show then? ...

Still at least we get a feast of goals and a great victory for Spurs! If George doesn't take them all the way to Cardiff, my name's not Ron Manager Eh? What?

Everyone thought West Ham's name was engraved on the trophy! ... ho ho! ... they'll be out re-rubbing the plinth tonight! ... "ho! marvelloth" ... er, says Chris.

And a reader's letter! from Mark Pitts of Chiswick! "Ron, if that Sven Gordon Erriccsson really wants to manage England, he wants to start going to a few games. He can afford it! I can't."

Mark ... I too have been on my uppers ... so I'm forwarding a you an interesting letter! ... all you have to do is send me and the others a pound ... add your name to the top of the list ... and when the money rolls in look out for Sven! ... he'll be sitting in front of you at every bloomin' game ... can't get rid of him ... there he was on Sunday with Harry Redknapp bending his ear! ... enduring image isn't it?

So, let's have another Peek at Sven's notebook! ... hmm? "3.30 Kempton: Money for old Rope ..."

And finally, another reader's letter! Callum Iain McFheargus of Aberdeen writes: "So they want to resurrect the fixture between "the auld enemies"! Whit dae ye think aboot that, pally-boy?" ... ho ho! ... the old enemy ... er, the Welsh, isn't it? ... er Goodbye!

Not Ron Manager was chatting online at ron@smallboysinthepark hmm?isntit?beansontoastfortea lookoutit'sparkie.leggit.com © Paul Whitehouse and Jim Reilly 2001

RON'S TOP TIP No34 Catch 'em young! The future generation? small boys, hmm? Early exposure to the nastier elements of the game can be educational as well as enthralling! I remember watching my father coaching his works team! 'When all around are doing their pieces' ... he'd be doing his pieces big time! Ho ho, bag of chips and a thick ear on the way home! marvellous!

webTitle: Joe Queenan on You Can Count On Me

fields.headline: We are family
fields.standfirst:
Absentee fathers, too much dope, and a chronic
inability to cope - these are the ties that bind, as
Joe Queenan discovers in the acclaimed but
flawed indie You Can Count On Me
fields.trailText: Absentee fathers, too much dope, and a chronic inability to cope - these are the ties that bind, as Joe Queenan discovers in the acclaimed but flawed indie You Can Count On Me
fields.body:
Because low-budget films are made for people who dislike big-budget films, they are generally held to a different critical standard. Their lack of car chases, floods, avalanches, plane crashes or tiger-enriched gladiatorial combat is interpreted as a sign of sophistication, depth, wisdom. Modest in scope, austere in execution, lacking in Demi Moore, they are the kinds of films that always run off with the big prizes at Cannes, Sundance, Gdansk.

You Can Count On Me is the latest in this series of modest, thoughtful films that film critics adore because they are modest, thoughtful and were not produced by Jerry Bruckheimer. Laura Linney and Mark Ruffalo play siblings whose parents were killed in a car crash when they were quite young. Still living in the drab village in rural New York where she was born, Linney has grown up to be a pillar of the community, a lending officer at the bank, a respected member of the church. The only crack in this facade of stability is her status as a single mother; her husband has long since been sent packing, and her eight-year-old boy is just reaching the point at which fatherless sons begin to idolise the slobs who deserted them as babies.

One day, Linney's ne'er-do-well brother (Ruffalo) returns to town. From the moment we meet him, one thing is clear: Mark is not lending-officer material. Perpetually stoned, generally unkempt, unable to maintain eye contact with adults, not especially articulate and a woefully ineffective handyman, Ruffalo has been everywhere from Alaska to Miami, and has not yet landed on his feet. His rap sheet includes a three-month stint in a Florida jail; most recently he has impregnated a teenage girl who then tried to take her own life. He also scowls a lot and bears a worrying resemblance to Erik Estrada, star of the 70s TV show CHiPs. He does not have his act together.

It soon becomes evident that Ruffalo's visit does not stem from any desire to see his sister; he simply needs cash to pay for the abortion. Linney is crushed to learn this, but she soon gets over it, as this is obviously not the first time Mr Useless has put the squeeze on her. Moreover, even though her brother is a stoner, a wastrel, a loser and very possibly a statutory rapist, Linney loves him dearly. She encourages him to bond with her son, played by the cataleptic Rory Culkin, the younger brother of Macaulay, who, in an ominous development for all of us, makes his screen debut here.

Ruffalo immediately screws up by wrecking the upstairs plumbing, forgetting to pick up Rory after school - leaving him stranded in the rain - and taking the kid to play pool in a seedy bar on a school night while Mom is out on a date. The pièce de résistance occurs when Ruffalo takes his nephew to the trailer park to visit his long-lost white-trash father. The get-together does not go well; Ruffalo smashes his brother-in-law's face in, and ends up spending the night in jail. Culkin, holding out for someone like Prince Valiant or James Bond, steadfastly refuses to believe that he is related to such Grade-A swamp trash as his father, though he doesn't seem to have any trouble believing that he's related to his swamp-trash uncle.

While Ruffalo is introducing his nephew to rural New York's coarse demi-monde, Linney is busy wrecking her own life. First she sleeps with her boss, a pernickety twit played by Matthew Broderick, who had the same role in Election. It does not help that Broderick's wife is six months pregnant. Nor that he is pernickety. Next she breaks up with her steady, a thoroughly decent sort played by John Tenney. Tenney's big mistake was in asking her to marry him. Via Linney's rebuff, the movie seems to be suggesting that Ruffalo is a carrier of the dreaded Jerk Virus, and that anyone with whom he comes into contact will immediately start engaging in prodigiously self-destructive behaviour. Either that, or Linney is a tramp.

Linney, honoured with an Academy Award nomination for her work here, does a fine job as the harried mother of a whiny, obnoxious child and sister of a zonked low-life. But the movie itself is a bit slight. The message seems to be that children who undergo youthful traumas together will always feel a special bond that time and distance cannot rupture. The audience is therefore invited, and even expected, to feel sorry for Poor Little Brother, who cannot get over the hump emotionally. But at the same time, director Kenneth Lonergan (who wrote the screenplay for Analyze This) argues that there is a thin line between bank lending and drug addiction, and that if Linney is not careful she could end up going right down the tubes as well.

Like the whimsical Chocolat, You Can Count On Me haughtily ridicules organised religion and relies heavily on an overbearing soundtrack to achieve emotional effects it cannot achieve through the camera or the people in front of it. It misuses Bach, a non-low-budget film composer if there ever was one, and overuses hillybilly rocker Steve Earle, whose haunting I Am Just A Pilgrim On This Road ends the film, laboriously hammering home the point that Ruffalo will always be a vagabond.

More jarring still is Culkin's casting as Linney's son. Yet another assembly-line tyke from the Hollywood Charm School, it is fair to say that Culkin, at this early stage in his career, lacks range. He falls into the same category as Bruce Willis's delicate son in Unbreakable (who also played Joaquin Phoenix's delicate nephew in Gladiator) and Will Patton's maddeningly precocious daughter in Remember The Titans: porcelain dolls who could not possibly be genetically linked to anyone else in the film. If the movie industry can't come up with any better child actors than this, it should start using computer-generated kids.

It misuses Bach, a non-low-budget film composer if there ever was one, and overuses hillybilly rocker Steve Earle, whose haunting I Am Just A Pilgrim On This Road ends the film, laboriously hammering home the point that Ruffalo will always be a vagabond. More jarring still is Culkin's casting as Linney's son. Yet another assembly-line tyke from the Hollywood Charm School, it is fair to say that Culkin, at this early stage in his career, lacks range. He falls into the same category as Bruce Willis's delicate son in Unbreakable (who also played Joaquin Phoenix's delicate nephew in Gladiator) and Will Patton's maddeningly precocious daughter in Remember The Titans: porcelain dolls who could not possibly be genetically linked to anyone else in the film. If the movie industry can't come up with any better child actors than this, it should start using computer-generated kids.

webTitle: Polly Vernon on makeovers in the movies

fields.headline: Counter culture
fields.standfirst: As Miss Congeniality proves, there's nothing the public likes more than a geek-to-chic beauty story. Polly Vernon gets her tweezers out and waxes lyrical about the makeover
fields.trailText: As Miss Congeniality proves, there's nothing the public likes more than a geek-to-chic beauty story. Polly Vernon gets her tweezers out and waxes lyrical about the makeover
fields.body:
On paper, Miss Congeniality might seem like the mousy wallflower amongst this spring's movie releases, destined to languish on the sidelines of big box-office success, its corsage wilting on its wrist, whilst The Gift and Proof Of Life get to waltz into the sunset with major multiplex audience figures in bad tuxedos. Sandra Bullock stars as daggy FBI agent Gracie Hart - a woman plagued by open pores, a monobrow and absolutely no kind of depilatory regime to speak of - who is required to go undercover as a contestant at a Miss United States beauty pageant in order to foil a terrorist plot. To make her guise more convincing, styling supremo Michael Caine is drafted in to take her dagginess in hand, and wax and tweeze her into a vision of fragrant, groomed loveliness. It is, in many respects, the Hollywood equivalent of Stephen Tompkinson getting greasier and more unkempt than usual in an effort to merge convincingly with a gang of marauding fascist porn peddlers for a BBC1 Crime Double.

Yet despite this uninspiring-sounding premise, Miss Congeniality has already taken $100m in the US and will do big business here. Not because it fits snugly into that optimistic, frolicky rom-com spring flick niche, and will subsequently make solid in-flight entertainment fodder. Not even because it features that defining example of the modern freak show, the American beauty pageant. But because it has as its central device a makeover. An epic makeover. A makeover under pressure - Gracie has to be transformed from fumbling, stumbling plainness into the epitome of prom queen perk in a mere 48 hours. A makeover realised against the makeoveree's will - Gracie claims at one point that she doesn't know what to do with a bikini. A makeover, moreover, performed in the name of combating terrorism.

The cinema-frequenting, soap-watching, department store beauty counter-stalking element of society have a terrible passion for the makeover. I know this, because I am amongst them. I have absolutely no capacity for makeover fatigue. I am eternally enchanted by the possibility that a crack collective of hairdressers, stylists, personal trainers and nail technicians might transform me - or my friends, or some fictional character - for the better, help us realise a physical potential we never even dreamed we possessed. It is my opinion that makeovers (and their hipper, high-fashion equivalents, the "reinvention") are an essential dynamic of our time. A recent GMTV report estimated that some 87% of us are on a constant mission to improve our physical appearance. Frankly, I was staggered to learn that 13% of people aren't. Vicarious or first-hand, in literature, on telly, between the print-sticky pages of Chat, makeovers obsess, inspire and motivate us. The makeover is about changing for the better, the prettier, the glossier. It's about changing from the outside out.

Popular culture doesn't let us ever give up hope that, one day, our makeover will come. That's one of the truly significant functions it performs. And the current zeitgeist is, if anything, more preoccupied with makeover propaganda than ever. A fortnight ago, Martine McCutcheon opened as Eliza Doolittle in the National Theatre's revival of My Fair Lady, the musical version of Pygmalion - the original makeover tale. McCutcheon is an appropriate choice of heroine, given that many of us have been fixated by her real-life transformation from blowsy post-Tiffany power-ballad peddler to svelte, gamine-haired wearer of one-shoulder glitter tops. A makeover in motion is Martine. Similarly, when Geri Halliwell took to the stage at the Brits, all buffed and toned, honey-golden and prettily peroxide, we were all allowed an insight into what a makeover can do for the average saggy-jowled, badly dyed, sluttily dressed one-time girl band hellcat.

Two major magazine launches in the space of six weeks also championed the individual's right to reinvent. Time Warners' InStyle, which is entirely dedicated to teaching the nation to transform itself in the image of Gwyneth/Angelina/Sarah Jessica Parker, and Conde Nast's Glamour, whose brief may be broader, but whose cover lines are all: "Oscar Worthy Hair: Hollywood styles to inspire your new look", and "Victoria Beckham writes: My 10 unbreakable style rules". The celebrity makeover is clearly considered the major readership draw. The anti-makeover, coincidentally, is also proving quite a talking point. Renee Zellweger's intensive programme of un-grooming and weight gain for the Bridget Jones role has attracted a level of public attention which testifies to that.

If I have learned anything from the last 20 years of consciously consuming popular culture, then it's this: there is a makeover to suit every moment, every agenda, every prospective lover, and only a fool doesn't take this on board. In Grease, Sandy shows us that, to snare the wayward bad boy, you must first dress like a slapper. Plain Jane Super Brain of Neighbours fame (who was a makeover waiting to happen from her very earliest scenes, and who, accordingly, brought to the makeover genre a thrilling sense of destiny realised) demonstrated that it is important to be as pretty as you possibly can be for its own sake. Ally Sheedy's character in The Breakfast Club taught us that 30 minutes in a broom cupboard with Molly Ringwald and her lip liner can transform anyone from dandruff-shaking school pariah to essential in-crowd component. And Julia Roberts' Pretty Woman discovered that, by losing the PVC mini and the obvious wig, gaining some Versace and a French pleat, social elevation, an escape from a vice-filled life and the opportunity to diss shop assistants can be yours. That's without even touching on Melanie Griffiths' makeover in Working Girl (from New Jersey white trash to power-dressing Manhattan exec), and Rachel Leigh Cook's geek-to-homecoming-queen manoeuvre in She's All That.

And yet, and yet - the makeover movie genre is clearly not exhausted. Box-office takings and viewing figures confirm that. There are infinite unexplored variations on this theme trembling in the wings, and crowds of makeover acionados waiting, breathless, for their next fix.

Which is just as it should be. Because if makeover obsession is beginning to seem like a uniquely inconsequential girlie concern, think again. Quite apart from the kergillions of men who furtively long to be made over too, not to mention those that publicly go for it (Robbie Williams, David Beckham, Nicky Haslam), makeovers also perform a social and financial function. They power our economy, keep us spending in the vague hope that this moisturiser coupled with that shirt will equal makeover heaven. They provide us with a common end, a joint sense of purpose, and a conversation point that can unite strangers in bus queues.

Ultimately, makeovers give us hope for a better-styled tomorrow. Now, if someone would be so kind as to make this clear to The Makeover That Never Quite Happened - more widely known as Anna in Hollyoaks, sole remaining female brunette cast member who staunchly refuses to ditch her daughter-of-a-vicar aesthetic definitively, even though she's clearly a honey underneath it all - I would be most grateful.

Miss Congeniality is out on Friday

webTitle: Julie Burchill: Why do we care what Eminem says?

fields.headline: Why do we care what Eminem says?
fields.standfirst: Was he really worth all those acres of protesting print? Wasn't it like getting upset at something untoward said by Elmer Fudd?
fields.trailText: So, Eminem is to be a dolly. Yes, a dinky little dolly, complete with tiny mask and chainsaw, and a neck tattoo saying - sigh! - "CUT HERE". One hundred thousand of them, with the stamp of approval of Marshall himself, up there with the new Barbies and the Hear'Say muppets by summer. Nine inches, too - and can't we just guess what use a good number of our gay brothers, with their passionate love/hate relationship with Mr Mathers, are going to put this effigy to. Best place for it, really. But, to quote Nigel Tufnel, it does give the whole furore a bit of perspective - too much bloody perspective, in fact. In winter, a threat to/the saviour of western liberal civilisation; by summer, a bendy bit of plastic destined to end up being forced into sexual slavery for Buzz Lightyear.
fields.body:
So, Eminem is to be a dolly. Yes, a dinky little dolly, complete with tiny mask and chainsaw, and a neck tattoo saying - sigh! - "CUT HERE". One hundred thousand of them, with the stamp of approval of Marshall himself, up there with the new Barbies and the Hear'Say muppets by summer. Nine inches, too - and can't we just guess what use a good number of our gay brothers, with their passionate love/hate relationship with Mr Mathers, are going to put this effigy to. Best place for it, really. But, to quote Nigel Tufnel, it does give the whole furore a bit of perspective - too much bloody perspective, in fact. In winter, a threat to/the saviour of western liberal civilisation; by summer, a bendy bit of plastic destined to end up being forced into sexual slavery for Buzz Lightyear.

Looking back, it's hard to say who was the silliest: those who came to bug Eminem, or those who came to praise him. The broadsheet apologists were certainly silly enough. All those soft boys (and the usual sad-sack suck-up contingent of girls who can't get boyfriends and will do anything to make men like them), educated beyond all instinct and honesty, piping on about how the Angry Blond was the best thing since Shakespeare. In truth, of course, it was the Dr Johnson line about a woman preaching being like a dog walking on its hind legs; the fact that it could do it was impressive enough, never mind whether it did it well! And to the chattering, would-be splattering class boys whose one experience of the American working class was bunking off lectures to watch Jerry Springer, the idea that a piece of white trash could string three words together - even if they were faggot, bitch and dick - was obviously deeply impressive.

But you expect people who didn't leave school until they were 24 to be pretty naive and credulous. What I can't get over is how silly the Sisters were, myself included - and we're so much smarter than the aesthetes, so should have known better. Yet we ran around throwing up our hands in horror and having a good old fit of the Victorian vapours, acting for all the world like the girls out of the Georgy Porgy nursery rhyme: "Cussed the girls and made them cry," indeed. Looking back, why in the world did we give any credence whatsoever to the views of a man who's so dumb that he didn't know Elton John was gay, such a wimp that he sleeps with the light on and such a square that, given all the Cornucopian horn of exotic drugs that must be available to him, he's reported to have ended up addicted to a prescription drug, Vicodin, that is principally used by Americans to fight period pains? Was he really worth all those acres of protesting print? Wasn't it just a little like getting upset over, say, something untoward said by Elmer Fudd?

The sad fact is that we Sisters thought we knew it all, and therefore ignored the top piece of advice that our mothers gave us all those years ago as we bleated about our woes re the Big Playground: sticks and stones may break my bones, but names will never hurt me! Over the years, this prime bit of wisdom evades us; only young women, being closer to it, bear it in mind. And only young women had the right attitude to Eminem, be it Christina and Britney not dignifying his smutty slander with a response; the 13- to 16-year-old girls, who made up the majority of his British audience, giggling that they didn't pay any attention to the words, they just thought he was so cute; or the ever-brilliant Evening Standard journalist Zoe Williams, who stated the absolute obvious - don't let him see you're looking, girls, he just wants to get a reaction. Of all the scribbling sisters, only young Zoe saw Eminem for what he is: the modern equivalent of the protagonists of the Flanders & Swann song, "Ma's out, Pa's out - let's talk rude: pee, po, belly, bum, drawers."

Why on earth did we mind what Eminem said about women? Who cares? If only the Welsh had learned from our mistake. Without doubt the Welsh are the sexiest, best-looking and cleverest people in Europe, yet time and time again they let ignorant munters like Anne Robinson, AA Gill and Jeremy Clarkson wind them up. Yet just one look at any of this trio - Robinson with her sour little mug, Gill with a voice that makes me sound like Mariella Frostrup, or Clarkson, who single-handedly made blue jeans beyond the pale to youth, such is his repulsiveness - and you can tell immediately why they don't like the Welsh. Their bitching tells us nothing about the Welsh, and everything about them.

I have a real problem with the idea of caring what strangers think about you. Or rather, not a problem at all, because I don't. Apart from my talent and my big green eyes, I am sure that being born with this advantage has been the making of me, and for years I believed that when people did appear to care whether people approved of them or not, they were putting it on. Obviously you care about what the people you love think of you - but anyone else? Why? Performers in particular, who need the world to love them, strike me as being very strange people. We hear a lot about the madness of those who stalk the famous, but what about the insanity of people who court mass love? And they don't get any wiser as they get older, either. The other day Steven Berkoff said that, as he put out "so much love" in his plays (would that be "Shit", "Piss" or "Fuck", the one with all this love in it, I wonder?), he felt that he had a right to demand love back from the public. How much weirder is it to offer love to strangers, as stalkers do, than it is to demand it from strangers, as performers do? Seems a match made in heaven to me.

But while men may demand approval, women seek it desperately, and it doesn't seem to be getting any better. In fact, as women gain more power in the public realm, they seem hell-bent on sabotaging themselves in their private lives. The Bridget Jones phenomenon, "Does my bum look big in this?", the fact that 90% of women are "unhappy" with their bodies, the rise in casual "lunchtime" cosmetic surgery: all these indicate a people very ill at ease in their own skin. Worse, it is widely accepted that such neurosis is loveable, attractive even, and that imperviousness to the opinions of others is somewhat monstrous in a woman. "What woman is pleased with her looks?" said the actress Zoe Wanamaker recently. "If they are, I wouldn't want to know them."

But why wouldn't one want to have friends who were comfortable and content with themselves? When did discontent and insecurity become the norm? Forget Bridget Jones. The fictional heroine who most depended on the approval and kindness of strangers was Blanche DuBois. And look how she turned out.

webTitle: Delicate star of the show is really a hardy perennial

fields.headline: Delicate star of the show is really a hardy perennial
fields.trailText: A garden from a hundred packets of seeds
fields.body:
What really gets a regular garden going is not so much a plan as a craze, or a series of overlapping crazes. And when we are in the grips of the craze we want to know everything there is to be known about a plant - how it appears in every variant, what can be done with it, what will make it happy. When the craze subsides, it may be that we can begin to think the unthinkable: to admit, for instance, that we are going to have to live without azaleas, or cut down on our hydrangea habit.

Something will normally survive these crazes, and whatever it is that survives them - whether it is a single species or a group of plants - should take its place among our permanent affections. Maybe a flower does not agitate us any more in the way it used to, but that does not mean we have forgotten it, or become indifferent.

When I first began to put my garden together it seemed to me that, within the garden, there should be a rose garden, and that somewhere around there should be as many types of iris as could be accomodated. And furthermore, so it seemed to me, there should be lilies in abundance. Obviously roses, irises and lilies were the essential constituents of a flower garden.

So it seemed to me, and so it still seems! But it is years since we added a rose to the mixture, or even looked seriously at the rose catalogues. Irises and lilies are a different matter, for we keep adding to their number and varying the approach to growing them: sometimes they have been scattered to all corners of the garden, sometimes grouped together, particularly if they are being grown to be cut.

Propagation by seed is not the first consideration in either case, although given a little patience and space, and given the desire for a large number of lilies, some species are worth growing in this way. That great star of the genus Lilium regale (no 67) sows itself around in my garden to a modest degree, but in a manner that seems to suggest that one would be foolish to throw away the ripe seed-heads. The Chiltern catalogue says it may flower in the second year from seed. But not nearly at full strength, in our experience. In three years, however, there it is.

A more prolific self-seeder, on a raised bed where we grow it (for it is a small thing, best grown among small plants such as alpines), is L formosanum pricei . This is a short-stemmed version of plain L formosanum , which others recommend as a biennial, although we have yet to do well with it. Among several lily seeds, Chiltern offers L formosanum Little Snow White (no 68) which must be the one we grow.

Still, in a garden envisaged as grown from a hundred packets of seed, neither lilies nor irises will be the star performing genera. The poppies have far more to offer - fragile though they may sometimes seem. That fragility is an illusion. The Spanish poppy (no 69) Papaver rupifragum , in what I call pale orange, may seem of feeble constitution, but it just hangs around the back door, returning year after year, looking after itself. We grow P sendtneri ( no 70) in paving: it is pure white and miniature, and it does not insist on its native limestone (or that altitude of 9,000ft which is sometimes inconvenient to arrange).

The field poppy P rhoeas mentioned last week earns an honoured place in the garden in the strain called the Shirley poppy, which, to be what the Reverend William Wilks had in mind when he selected it, ought to be a single flower in white, pink or salmon. Modern versions delight in their doubleness.

This kind of annual makes itself a perennial feature of the garden by reliably re-sowing its own patch, as does the tall, incomparable opium poppy, (no 71) P somniferum , which comes in so many forms, single and double. Black peony is one I would choose - almost at random. Nothing hangs on your decision, in choosing between the opium poppies. The foliage will all be the same handsome glaucous blue-green. The range of colours - from white through red, pink and purple - seems entirely appropriate to the plant. One is not more virtuous, or more likely to go to heaven, for preferring singles to doubles, or plain to cut-edged petals.

More and more often seen on sale is the Iceland poppy (no 72) usually listed as P nudicaule . Its popularity represents a further triumph for the colour orange, for orange is what it does best - a deeper, warmer orange than the Californian poppy, which I listed as no 4.

The white version, and the intermediate pastel shade, and the yellow, are pleasant variants on the essential orange, the thing itself. This is a flower which astonishes us by being good for cutting, when you would think that it would wilt straight away. (Dipping the cut ends in boiling water is the trick.)

One associates poppies with full sunlight and the heat of early summer, but their range includes the cool and shady. Meconopsis cambrica , the yellow Welsh poppy (no 73), and its orange and scarlet variants, are self-seeders for shade; flowers that, like the Chelidonium (which is also a kind of poppy), are expected to get on with it, furnishing shady walks and gravel paths. I would rave about the blue Himalayan meconopsis , if I honestly - or plausibly - could claim to have grown it. Instead, on the blue theme, let me mention Corydalis linstowiana - for corydalis is often listed as a member of the Papaveraceae , an annual or biennial which has seeded itself under our roses, with pale blue flowers. You would have to buy a plant to start it off.

Two prickly Mexican poppies, Argemone mexicana (no 74) and A pleiacantha (no 75) the first with yellow, the second with white flowers ( A grandiflora White Lustre is its name in Chiltern's list), suggest themselves as candidates for a hot Mediterranean-style garden. Yet we grow the white one among our roses, which is where I first saw it at Mottisfont. No doubt in Mexican rose gardens they curse it as a weed.

fields.headline: The number's up
fields.standfirst: Jeremy Lee thought he'd have his work cut out devising menus of six main ingredients per dish. He's a chef, after all, and not used to scrimping and saving. But now, he finally admits: how wrong can a guy be?
fields.trailText: I am a little disconcerted by this "keep it simple" business. The more I delve into recipes that are constructed of no more than six main ingredients (excluding store cupboard staples such as seasonings, oil, garlic, onions and the like), the more I come across. It's a thrilling revelation - and, I must admit, not an inconsiderable surprise. Being a chef who wholeheartedly advocates "faites simple" and who cannot clear the vicinity fast enough whenever "cuisine deluxe" is the bill of fare, I am chuffed at just how many dishes in the restaurant kitchen actually fit this particular bill.
fields.body:
I am a little disconcerted by this "keep it simple" business. The more I delve into recipes that are constructed of no more than six main ingredients (excluding store cupboard staples such as seasonings, oil, garlic, onions and the like), the more I come across. It's a thrilling revelation - and, I must admit, not an inconsiderable surprise. Being a chef who wholeheartedly advocates "faites simple" and who cannot clear the vicinity fast enough whenever "cuisine deluxe" is the bill of fare, I am chuffed at just how many dishes in the restaurant kitchen actually fit this particular bill.

Mind you, it's also a shock to realise just how many of those dishes require a quite awesome amount of preparation, marinating, cooking and, occasionally, saucing. But that's chefs for you. The sheer scale of restaurant cooking does not readily translate to hearth and home, which is why chefs' recipes that fire up the home cook are those that are familiar with an allure and flavour more in keeping with nature than with fancy.

An obvious influence guiding us towards simpler foods of a more regional flavour is the quality of produce now available. As our awareness of once elusive varieties of beasts, leaves, fruit and vegetables increases, so does their availability.

All recipes serve six.

Turbot with artichokes

Turbot is a real treat, not least because of its price. Use another fish by all means - mackerel, in particular, is splendid, and has the added advantage of not (so far) giving you a guilt trip the size of an empty Atlantic Ocean. It's worth noting that the farmed turbot I have tried makes a considerably better argument for farmed fish than does the frightful salmon. I am hugely fond of artichokes, and though they're quite a chore to prepare, they more than pay you back for the effort in the eating. The lemon juice will keep the artichokes a brilliant colour, but its acidity will savage their delicate flavour, so err on the side of caution when applying the juice.

12 baby artichokes

1 lemon, juiced and zested

1 bayleaf

3 cloves garlic

1 small sprig fresh thyme, tied

6 150-180g fillet turbot

Olive oil

Sea salt and black pepper

2 tbsp chopped parsley

1 clove garlic

Very good extra-virgin olive oil

Pare away the outer leaves of the artichokes, and trim the tops and around the stems. In a bowl, wash the artichokes in lemon juice to prevent them discolouring, then tip out the excess lemon juice and place the artichokes in a pot.

Add the bayleaf, garlic and thyme, barely cover with water and pour on a thin film of olive oil. Add a little salt, and cook gently over a mild heat for 30-40 minutes, until cooked through but still firm. Set aside to cool, then store in a sealed container: they keep very well for several days in the fridge.

Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/ gas mark 6. Cut each artichoke into three slices, lay these on a roasting sheet and bake for 10-12 minutes, until beautifully browned with little flecks of black here and there. Set to one side, and keep warm.

Next, make the gremolada garnish. Chop together the parsley, oil, lemon zest and garlic.

Cut the fish into 1cm thick slices, lightly oil each piece and season generously. Make a griddle very hot, have warm serving plates standing by, then grill the fish for a minute or so on each side, until cooked through. Lay the turbot slices on the plates, scatter a few slices of artichoke over the top, then strew with the gremolada and serve.

Chicken liver paté

Hoummos last week, now this: I seem to be in nostalgic mood, with such recipes from way back that nowadays seem rarely to figure except in the supermarket chill cabinets and on the menus of a few retro-restaurants. Considering our adoration of roast chicken - not to mention those countless other dishes in which the fowl is reduced to unrecognisable pieces of boneless and skinless matter, and the sheer volume of these birds consumed here - it is quite extraordinary that there is very little or no reference to chicken livers in the British culinary repertory. The Italians cook them with pasta, the French put them in warm salads and terrines, and Jewish cookery boasts an exceptionally good chopped liver. Chicken livers make good kebabs, too. I have acquired a small collection of cherished pté recipes, of which this one requires little labour for so subtle and unusual a flavour.

500g very fresh chicken livers

1 medium onion, peeled and chopped

250g unsalted butter

6 anchovy fillets

1 tsp fine capers

3 cloves garlic

4 tbsp brandy

Pinch dried thyme

Sea salt and black pepper

Scrupulously clean the livers of any green bits or white, fatty attachments. Gently fry the onion and anchovy fillets in the butter until soft but uncoloured. Raise the heat, stir in the livers and fry until they colour lightly but remain firm to the touch. Add the brandy, thyme, garlic, salt, pepper and capers, and fry for several minutes more.

Place the contents of the pan in a liquidiser and blend until very smooth - you may have to do this in batches. Pour into a pretty bowl, cover and refrigerate. Serve with slices of hot toast and a bowl of gherkins.

A salad of leaves

A salad is just a salad, isn't it? The modern unnatural obsession for side orders (of which, spuds aside, I rarely approve) has helped put salad in the shade. Salad leaves are as seasonal as vegetables - Jane Grigson's seminal work on the subject has John Evelyn's Salad Calendar, a quick glance at which will give you all you need to know before nipping to the shops. The leaves you choose will depend solely on what is available - the heart of a cos lettuce will be more delicious by far than some shallow character imported in the dead of winter.

1 big bowl mixed salad leaves

6 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil

2 tbsp walnut oil

2 tbsp good red-wine vinegar

1 tsp Dijon mustard

Sea salt and black pepper

Put the red-wine vinegar in a bowl, add the salt and pepper and whisk until the salt is dissolved. Add the mustard and walnut oil, whisking all the while. Add the olive oil, whisk until the vinaigrette has emulsified, then dress the salad leaves.

Apple Tarts

An enduring classic of that marvellous chef, Michel Guérard. It is also the simplest of desserts, and easy to put together and cook as and when required. I am not sure - as a matter of fact, I really do not want to know - how many of these tarts I made when working as the pastry chef at Bibendum. That feeling of waiting for the last dessert order at half-past midnight, when everyone else in the kitchen had long since gone home and the waiting staff have neglected to tell you that the last two tables only wanted coffee, is a memory that I still carry. Conscience and time will decide whether to make or buy the pastry, as will the decision whether to serve a great bowl of cream alongside - though I would urge you to do so. The amounts given will make one large tart or six small ones.

600g puff pastry

1.5kg apples, peeled and cored (8-12 fruit, depending on their size)

1 lemon, juiced

100g melted butter

120g caster sugar

Lots of cream (optional, but highly recommended)

Preheat the oven to 225C/425F/gas mark 7. Roll out the pastry evenly, and leave intact if you're making one large tart, or cut into six even-sized pieces. Place the pastry on a baking sheet and refrigerate.

Cut the apples in half through the core and then into thin slices. Lay the slices, overlapping generously, around the pastry, and brush with lemon juice and then melted butter. Strew with caster sugar.

The tarts may now be baked straight away, but I prefer to chill them for half an hour or so before cooking. They are always better when prepared well before the meal and put in the oven only half an hour before required at table. Just before cooking, dust with a little more sugar. If the tarts take on too much colour, reduce the temperature slightly. Cook for a further 15-20 minutes until coloured a beautiful mahogany. Serve at once.

Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1

fields.headline: Cue jumping
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... the hunt for the real Fast Eddie - if there was one
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... the hunt for the real Fast Eddie - if there was one
fields.body:
Early last month we carried an obituary of an American pool player who called himself "Fast Eddie" Parker, describing him, with no beating about the bush, as "the man who inspired the film, The Hustler". Just to remind you, The Hustler, released in 1961, was directed by Robert Rossen, and starred Paul Newman as the hustler of the title, Fast Eddie Felson.

A hustler in pool parlance is a gambling player prepared to lose a few games to increase the odds before he and his backers make their killing. We explained that while Fast Eddie Parker claimed to be the model for Fast Eddie Felson, he was not a hustler but a straight player who played his best in all circumstances.

We left no doubt, however, that he regarded himself as the main, or even the only, real contributor to the character of Fast Eddie Felson. A heading on his obituary read: "Professional pool player who was the inspiration for Paul Newman's role in The Hustler."

We said he had met Walter Tevis, the writer of the novel, The Hustler (1959), when the latter "was working his way through college" and that "Tevis borrowed one of Parker's aliases to create Fast Eddie Felson" - he claimed on other occasions that he had inspired Tevis to create first the character and hence the novel that was then adapted for the film.

Finally, we said that Parker had produced instructional books and videos that Paul Newman had used when preparing to revive the character of Fast Eddie Felson in Martin Scorsese's The Color of Money, 1986 (the screenplay written by Richard Price after the novel, The Color of Money, 1984, by Walter Tevis).

A few days after this obituary appeared I had a call from Eleanora Tevis, the widow of Walter Tevis (he died of lung cancer in August 1984), the first of a number of exchanges by phone and fax, essentially making the same point: "Since The Hustler's publication in 1959 and the film's release in 1961, many pool players have claimed to be Fast Eddie Felson. Walter consistently stated that The Hustler was a work of fiction and the characters therein were fictitious."

The exasperation Tevis felt is very well expressed in an article by Roy McHugh that appeared in a newspaper in Pittsburgh in 1983. McHugh said that people kept asking Tevis, in relation to another character in The Hustler, "When did you first meet Minnesota Fats?" McHugh said Tevis cringed and wondered whether they would have asked Walt Disney, "When did you meet Donald Duck?" (The person referred to here was Rudolf Walter Wanderone Jr. He had been playing under the name of New York Fats, in tribute to his birthplace, but changed his name to Minnesota Fats after Jackie Gleason created the part in The Hustler - see Britannica.com.)

This article was headed: "All 'Fast Eddies' say they're Hustler." The piece was prompted by the death of a pool player called Edward "Fast Eddie" Pelkey, and the agency wire at the time began: "Edward 'Fast Eddie' Pelkey, the famed pool shark portrayed by Paul Newman in the movie The Hustler, has died . . ." Tevis told Roy McHugh: "I'm weary of explaining this. Nobody believes you when you keep telling them you invent your own characters."

In 1987, after Eddie Parker had returned to live in his home territory of the Missouri Ozarks, he was interviewed by Bill Maurer from the local newspaper, the News-Leader. His report contains this sentence: "Parker said he's been reluctant to acknowledge his role [the role he claimed as the model for Tevis's Fast Eddie] until recent years."

Even more to the point, Maurer contacted four important people: the editor of a leading billiards magazine, the vice-president of the Professional Billiards Association, a professional pool player who had been active in the area where Parker said he met Tevis, and finally Tevis's boyhood friend who taught him to shoot pool. Maurer wrote: "All four said they've never heard of Parker and questioned his role, if any, in influencing Tevis."

To return to the instructional manuals and videos by Parker that Paul Newman is supposed to have used when preparing for The Color of Money. Mrs Tevis corresponded with Newman. She says he told her: "Regardless of anything you've seen in the press, I didn't use any instructional books or tapes. Willie Mosconi taught me everything I knew and was my instructor during the entire film, as well as the technical director." Willie Mosconi (see Britannica.com again), an American pocket billiards player, was world champion 15 times between 1941 and 1957. He died in 1993.

We carried the obituary because of the connection with the character of Fast Eddie Felson, a connection, wouldn't you agree, that the most generous person would describe as extremely tenuous?

 The Hustler is published in Britain by Bloomsbury (which also publishes Tevis's novel, The Man Who Fell to Earth, filmed with David Bowie). Fax 020-7239 9897.

We left no doubt, however, that he regarded himself as the main, or even the only, real contributor to the character of Fast Eddie Felson. A heading on his obituary read: "Professional pool player who was the inspiration for Paul Newman's role in The Hustler." We said he had met Walter Tevis, the writer of the novel, The Hustler (1959), when the latter "was working his way through college" and that "Tevis borrowed one of Parker's aliases to create Fast Eddie Felson" - he claimed on other occasions that he had inspired Tevis to create first the character and hence the novel that was then adapted for the film. Finally, we said that Parker had produced instructional books and videos that Paul Newman had used when preparing to revive the character of Fast Eddie Felson in Martin Scorsese's The Color of Money, 1986 (the screenplay written by Richard Price after the novel, The Color of Money, 1984, by Walter Tevis). A few days after this obituary appeared I had a call from Eleanora Tevis, the widow of Walter Tevis (he died of lung cancer in August 1984), the first of a number of exchanges by phone and fax, essentially making the same point: "Since The Hustler's publication in 1959 and the film's release in 1961, many pool players have claimed to be Fast Eddie Felson. Walter consistently stated that The Hustler was a work of fiction and the characters therein were fictitious." The exasperation Tevis felt is very well expressed in an article by Roy McHugh that appeared in a newspaper in Pittsburgh in 1983. McHugh said that people kept asking Tevis, in relation to another character in The Hustler, "When did you first meet Minnesota Fats?" McHugh said Tevis cringed and wondered whether they would have asked Walt Disney, "When did you meet Donald Duck?" (The person referred to here was Rudolf Walter Wanderone Jr. He had been playing under the name of New York Fats, in tribute to his birthplace, but changed his name to Minnesota Fats after Jackie Gleason created the part in The Hustler - see Britannica.com.) This article was headed: "All 'Fast Eddies' say they're Hustler." The piece was prompted by the death of a pool player called Edward "Fast Eddie" Pelkey, and the agency wire at the time began: "Edward 'Fast Eddie' Pelkey, the famed pool shark portrayed by Paul Newman in the movie The Hustler, has died . . ." Tevis told Roy McHugh: "I'm weary of explaining this. Nobody believes you when you keep telling them you invent your own characters." In 1987, after Eddie Parker had returned to live in his home territory of the Missouri Ozarks, he was interviewed by Bill Maurer from the local newspaper, the News-Leader. His report contains this sentence: "Parker said he's been reluctant to acknowledge his role [the role he claimed as the model for Tevis's Fast Eddie] until recent years." Even more to the point, Maurer contacted four important people: the editor of a leading billiards magazine, the vice-president of the Professional Billiards Association, a professional pool player who had been active in the area where Parker said he met Tevis, and finally Tevis's boyhood friend who taught him to shoot pool. Maurer wrote: "All four said they've never heard of Parker and questioned his role, if any, in influencing Tevis." To return to the instructional manuals and videos by Parker that Paul Newman is supposed to have used when preparing for The Color of Money. Mrs Tevis corresponded with Newman. She says he told her: "Regardless of anything you've seen in the press, I didn't use any instructional books or tapes. Willie Mosconi taught me everything I knew and was my instructor during the entire film, as well as the technical director." Willie Mosconi (see Britannica.com again), an American pocket billiards player, was world champion 15 times between 1941 and 1957. He died in 1993. We carried the obituary because of the connection with the character of Fast Eddie Felson, a connection, wouldn't you agree, that the most generous person would describe as extremely tenuous?  The Hustler is published in Britain by Bloomsbury (which also publishes Tevis's novel, The Man Who Fell to Earth, filmed with David Bowie).
