fields.headline: Dangerous liaisons
fields.standfirst: Manon and Lulu are the original femmes fatales. But are they sexual predators or tragic innocents? As their stories come to the stage once more,  Michael Billington  investigates
fields.trailText: Manon and Lulu are the original femmes fatales. But are they sexual predators or tragic innocents? As their stories come to the stage once more, Michael Billington investigates
fields.body:
Sex is back on the London stage with the return of two famous female archetypes. On Monday Anna Friel struts her stuff as Frank Wedekind's Lulu in an Almeida production housed in a London bus station. The next night Alexandra von der Weth, a former Lulu in Alban Berg's opera, sings Manon Lescaut at the Royal Opera House - not in the familiar Puccini or Massenet versions but in Hans Werner Henze's 1951 opera set in post-war Paris. So, on successive nights, Lulu and Manon: classic examples of the femme fatale.

But what exactly is a femme fatale? Today the term has been appropriated, and debased, by movies, pulp fiction and pop journalism. In film terms it implies a sexual predator who drives men to distraction. In the 1940s and 1950s it was Jane Russell in The Outlaw posing with out-thrust bust, or Marilyn Monroe wiggling her knickerless rump in Niagara.

The true femme fatale, however, is more subtle than a straightforward man-eater. For a start, as Henze's opera and Wedekind's play suggest, she is defined by her lack of definition: she is a white screen on to whom we all, men especially, project our fantasies. She is also a victim of society who suffers not just for her own but for everyone else's sins. And she is amoral rather than immoral.

To prove the point you have only to go back to the start of the Manon myth. In 1730 the Abbé Prévost, who combined the careers of monk and soldier, wrote a book whose full title is Histoire du Chevalier des Grieux et de Manon Lescaut. It is this provocative volume that has spawned six operas, one operetta, four ballets, 11 musicals and the Henri-Georges Clouzot film that first caught the young Henze's attention. Beyond that Prévost's Manon provides the prototype for a whole raft of 19th-century heroines, including Carmen, Marguerite Gautier and Lulu. By coincidence, one of Prévost's lovers was a widow who also went by the name of Loulou.

Read Prévost, however, and what do you find? The first shock is the age of the protagonists. When they first meet, des Grieux is a 17-year-old putative priest and Manon a 15-year-old girl destined for a convent. As a result there is something innocently youthful about their passion: des Grieux recalls, "We dispensed with the rights of the church and found ourselves man and wife without having given it a thought." Des Grieux's problem is that his passion is absolute: Manon's is that she loves him but loves money even more. Three times they set up house together; and three times she deserts him for a richer benefactor.

Prévost establishes the template of the true femme fatale. We, as readers, create our own idealised Manon and, in postmodernist style, become part-authors of the story: as many commentators have pointed out, we have no idea of the colour of Manon's hair or eyes, the shape of her face or figure. But she is also the product of a corrupt society. On first leaving des Grieux, she swears undying affection but asks, "Do you think one can make love when one has nothing to eat?" In a Paris where sex is the currency, she goes off to raise money in the only way she knows.

But the brilliant insight at the heart of Prévost's novel - and what links it to the world of Wedekind, Berg and Henze - is that fidelity is a relative virtue and that character is created by circumstance. Reading the third of Manon's farewell love notes, des Grieux concludes: "She was sincere but she was fickle, or rather she ceased to be anything - she did not even recognise herself - when she saw other women living in wealth and herself in poverty and want." You can project it forward to Wedekind's Lulu, who is not some active monster of depravity but a passive creature defined by her environment.

Prévost creates the archetypal femme fatale: a tragic innocent who is not so much the destroyer as the destroyed (it is Manon who finally dies in Louisiana, not des Grieux). But once Manon is translated into an operatic heroine she changes. For practical reasons she can no longer be a teenager. Prévost's plot is also condensed so that it loses its element of rhyming compulsion: the sense that the characters are victims of larger forces. And,fascinating as both Massenet's and Puccini's late 19th century variations on the Manon myth are, they invite moral judgment. Shaw praised Massenet's music but claimed that "no art can quite redeem the later scenes from the repulsiveness of their moral infamy". Even today, in English Touring Opera's new production, Manon's social downfall is symbolised by ever more incarnadine costumes.

Each age, however, creates its own Manon; and each artist finds personal resonances in the story. With Henze's Boulevard Solitude, set in the Paris of Jean-Paul Sartre and Jean Cocteau and with musical echoes of the Second Viennese School, we seem to have moved a long way from Prévost. This is a work that clearly deals with the condition of post-war Europe: the loneliness of the city, the difficulties attendant on freedom, the existential aimlessness of the individual. It is no accident that Nikolaus Lehnhoff's Royal Opera House production is set within the framework of a railway station, which becomes a symbol of urban frenzy and anonymity.

And yet, from reading Grete Weil's libretto, it seems that Henze's opera is in some ways closer to Prévost than it is to Puccini or Massenet. In the novel the hero, a lightly disguised version of Prévost, tells his story to the so-called Man of Quality; in Henze's autobiographical opera the focus is similarly on Armand and his sense of alienation. And, in place of the 19th-century vision of Manon as a tart with a heart, she becomes a more mysterious figure first seen heading off to finishing school in Lausanne and finally imprisoned for murder. She doesn't change or develop. She leaves us, as it were, to complete the picture.

That is the true essence of the femme fatale. The Oxford Dictionary's definition is simply "a dangerously attractive woman". And in popular culture the term is promiscuously applied to anyone from Mandy Rice-Davies to Monica Lewinsky. But the fascination of the truly fatal woman stems from an innocent amorality. She is obviously a male construct and, at a subconscious level, probably represents a deep-seated fear.

But the simple truth is that, when you read the Prévost novel, you can't help falling headlong for Manon. Like all great femmes fatales, she has a shadowy allure that lies beyond reason; and it is that very calculated indefiniteness that makes her as potent a symbol for a radical composer such as Henze as she was for a libertine cleric such as Prévost.

 Henze's Boulevard Solitude is at the Royal Opera House, London WC2 (020-7304 4000), from Tuesday until April 4. Wedekind's Lulu is at the Almeida at King's Cross, London N1 (020-7359 4404), from Monday until May 12. English Touring Opera's production of Massenet's Manon is at Poole Arts Centre (01202 685222) on Tuesday and then tours to Jersey, Leicester, Truro, Exeter and Lincoln.

fields.headline: Give! Give! Give!
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
What was the rest of the world doing while BBC viewers were engaged in an orgy of giving? Watching soaps, just as they should be. While BBC1 was given over to Comic Relief, other channels served up lavish helpings of their usual dramas. Who needs starving people in Africa, or Posh, Becks, Robbie, Westlife and co when you can watch Deirdre Rachid getting jiggy on the sofa with Dev Alahan?

This scene in Coronation Street (ITV) evoked more pity and terror than the whole of Comic Relief put together, and made one want to give, give, give. Anything to help that poor woman, who found herself spurned after an ill-advised kiss on the lips. And it had all looked so promising. She'd served up a tasty meal ("It's just a casserole!") and listened to Dev's pedestrian musings on sex ("What do women want? A hairy chest? A nice smile? A big house?"). She'd posed kittenishly on the sofa while he rolled and stretched on the rug. And then - bang, he was off to do the washing-up, leaving her chastened and in need of help.

Charity was more in evidence elsewhere on the Street. Alma turned up just in time to see Ken having an emotional crisis, although how she could tell is a mystery. Sad Ken looks and sounds the same as Happy Ken, so perhaps he smells upset. Alma (Amanda Barrie) took him to a pub and came over empathetic, doing that thing with her eyes and mouth that made her the screen's greatest Cleopatra. "How's your chicken?" asked Ken over lunch. "Well," replied sphinx-like Alma, "it's in a basket." This might have been the start of something beautiful (have Ken and Alma ever... you know? One forgets) but instead they returned to Weatherfield after a friendly hug.

In fact, nobody seems to be getting laid in any of the non-BBC soaps at the moment, apart from studly Christy on Brookside (Channel 4), whom we saw zipping up after delivering what can only have been a perfunctory performance to Leanne, the barmaid. "I'll get ya some pork chops and a couple of racks of ribs," he promised, bestowing a final, patronising kiss. Leanne beamed. Has the meat crisis brought us so low?

Meanwhile Mike Dixon was still languishing in the hozzie, in scenes reminiscent of Marlon Brando in The Men (1950). Quite why Mike has always been such a weak, doomed character is one of the great soap mysteries: with his looks he should be aheartthrob, and doubtless would be if he was American. But men in British soaps must all be undergoing some crisis of masculinity, or just be utter bastards (or, if they're in Brookside, foaming nutters). It's only the women who are allowed any pluck.

Pluck there was aplenty in Emmerdale (ITV), where Viv and Carol got down to some serious name-calling. "That Carol's as rough as a bear's behind," said Viv, who wore a leopard-print blouse that probably still signifies feistiness in backward rural communities. And later: "She'd be after anything in pants, that slapper." Then came the lingerie-throwing stage: Viv pelted Carol with bras and G-strings from an upper window, while Edna (the great Shirley Stelfox) looked on with lemon-sucking satisfaction. Less exciting was Jack Sugden's dark night of the soul in prison, where he languished, a suspected wife-murderer. "Prison in't all table tennis and colour telly," said his cellmate, while Jack wept in the lower bunk. By the end he was contemplating suicide, which puts him at the bottom of the soap despair ladder for this month, even lower than Mike "Marlon" Dixon on the other side of the Pennines.

By the time all this suffering was over, Comic Relief was a relief indeed, and the canny BBC husbanded its jewels (One Foot in the Grave, Ali G with the Beckhams, Robbie Williams in the Fast Show) until the soap threat had been well and truly seen off. Cat Deeley and Dermot O'Leary were due to present from a sauna at 1.30am, which may have encouraged a late spurt of charity among insomniac viewers.

fields.headline: 100 years of attitude
fields.standfirst: Jackson Pollock, Robert Rauschenberg, Mark Rothko... the Whitechapel Gallery taught Britain how to love modern art.  Jonathan Jones  reports
fields.trailText: Jackson Pollock, Robert Rauschenberg, Mark Rothko... the Whitechapel Gallery taught Britain how to love modern art. Jonathan Jones reports
fields.body:
The Whitechapel Art Gallery in east London is celebrating its centenary with an exhibition, parties and a publication. Why all the fanfare? This is where our love affair with modern art began. The gallery's first 50 years were notable enough, withexhibitions that reflected the political passions of the pre-war East End, such as Picasso's Guernica in 1939, but it is the last 50 years that have been most extraordinary. Before Tate Modern was a glint in Nicholas Serota's eye, the Whitechapel put on shows that made other British galleries look tame.

Serota was the Whitechapel's director between 1976 and 1988; this was where he made his name. He built on the work of Bryan Robertson (1952-68), who set out to make what was thought of as a local gallery into a national stage for modern art. Almost all the most influential modern art exhibitions in post-war Britain happened here: Jackson Pollock's first British show in 1958, Mark Rothko's in 1961, Robert Rauschenberg's retrospective in 1964. Most famous was 1956's This Is Tomorrow, which explored architecture, technology, sci-fi and consumerism. Richard Hamilton's poster for the show, featuring a TV-age interior in which a bodybuilder wields a phallic lolly that says POP, is the mythic founding moment of pop art.

In Serota's era came exhibitions whose influence can still be felt: Gilbert and George, the post-minimalist American sculptor Eva Hesse and Bruce Nauman, not to mention key shows of 1980s painters such as Julian Schnabel, Georg Baselitz and Anselm Kiefer. The current director, Catherine Lampert, who leaves at the end of the centenary show, has continued the mix of big names and experimental shows, from the Gary Hume retrospective in 1999 to last year's acclaimed Live in Your Head. Her replacement, Iwona Blazwick, one of the team who launched Tate Modern, looks back at the shows Serota put on as her introduction to art. This is how she and her predecessors view the Whitechapel_

Mark Glazebrook

Director, 1969-71

I was only there for three years but they were so turbulent they have stayed etched in my memory. Before I got there the gallery had one of its frequent periods of financial crisis. I thought it would be easier to raise the money than it was. I had seen the Jackson Pollock exhibition and I had always admired my predecessor, Bryan Robertson, and the Whitechapel, but the reality was very different.

One always had to be very entrepreneurial. I was preparing this David Hockney show, which was a terrific success. Hockney did a special print in aid of the Whitechapel and we sold it at the door. Some people objected to the gallery taking money from an artist, but I found this had always happened through [its] history.

Tower Hamlets and Hackney had cut off the grants, because Bryan had made the Whitechapel such an international sensation they no longer felt it was a local gallery. In fact it has always been both - only when funds are really low does it sink back to folk art from Stepney Green or whatever.

I was very proud of my Hockney show, the Modern Chairs design show, the Donald Judd show. Gilbert and George [who live nearby] asked me, "Can we do an exhibition?" I said, "Yes - what's it going to be?" They said, "Ourselves asking ourselves questions in the gallery." I said, "Do you want to get me the sack?"

I [liked] Bryan very much and have the greatest appreciation for his achievement - he had done Turner, he had done Malevich, as well as the contemporary British and American shows. The great thing is that, with blips, the show has gone on.

Nicholas Serota

Director, 1976-88

There were moments in the late 1970s when it was thought that the Whitechapel no longer had a place - for example when the Hayward opened - but we showed that it does. I first went there in 1964 when I was 18; I saw the Rauschenberg show. I went there the next year to see Franz Kline. I remember being knocked out by the darkness of these paintings.

Following Bryan Robertson's departure, there was a decade that was difficult for the Whitechapel, though Mark Glazebrook [who ran the gallery before a series of caretaker administrations] did a couple of very good things. I think what I was trying to do when I got there was to restore its national and international reputation and its link to the local community.

I had only been at the Museum of Modern Art, Oxford, for three years and I hesitated. But I went because the Whitechapel had a lot of problems and I thought, "If I don't go now, maybe it won't be there." I saw it as an opportunity to do something different: the Eva Hesse show, the Kiefer show, the Kounellis exhibition. Also one or two important historical shows [such as] the Beckmann triptychs. The following show, 20th Century British Sculpture, was absurdly overambitious but a success. The Carl Andre show was also very beautiful. The Gilbert and George show certainly made people in Britain sit up.

The gallery feels as though it's close to artists; when I did an auction to raise money in 1987, their donations raised a lot of money. Director designate

Before Tate Modern was a glint in Nicholas Serota's eye, the Whitechapel put on shows that made other British galleries look tame. fields.headline: How I found 'Mozart' in Halifax
fields.standfirst: Rachel Cowgill  on a musical detective story
fields.trailText: Rachel Cowgill on a musical detective story
fields.body:
This has been quite a week for musicologists, with the first performance of the newly authenticated Handel Gloria at the Royal Academy of Music on Thursday, coinciding with news of a second find, at Calderdale record office in Halifax, West Yorkshire - a manuscript of a hitherto unknown arrangement of Handel's oratorio Judas Maccabaeus (1747), attributed on the title page to WA Mozart. Such rare events inevitably lead to more questions, painstaking research, and sometimes few conclusions.

This is certainly true of the Halifax score, which I called up from the vaults of the record office at the end of last summer. While researching musical life in Halifax, I had come across William Priestley (1779-1861), a local wool clothier, whose personal library housed many unusual items of German choral music, which had formed much of the early repertory of the Halifax Choral Society - still performing today and thought to be the oldest choral society in Britain.

Trying to reconstruct Priestley's library had led me to York minster library and Halifax parish church. I was going through the musical scores kept at the record office to see if any of Priestley's volumes had found their way there. Among these scores was a manuscript full score of Handel's oratorio, but on opening the first volume, and seeing the phrase "with additional wind and brass parts by WA Mozart" on the title page, I realised this was a very unusual score indeed. I knew Mozart had arranged four of Handel's choral works between 1788 and 1790, for a circle of Handel enthusiasts in Vienna headed by Baron Gottfried van Swieten; but here, apparently, was a fifth, something on which the standard reference works I consulted could shed no light.

Rumours that Mozart had arranged Handel's Judas Maccabaeus were clearly circulating in Europe shortly after his death, to judge by reports in early 19th-century German periodicals; but these were scotched by early Mozart scholar Leopold von Sonnleithner, who concluded that they must refer to an anonymous arrangement, probably by the composer Josef Starzer, which had been performed by the Vienna Tonkünstlersozietät in 1779. This arrangement appears to have survived in the Osterreichischen Nationalbibliothek in Vienna, where it can be viewed today. However, the Halifax arrangement differs from this in several ways and while the Starzer arrangement features about two-thirds of Handel's original work, the Halifax arrangement includes much more.

Mozart did not list this work among the Handel arrangements in the notebook he used to keep track of his compositions. And the handwriting in the Halifax score is that of an unidentified copyist, whose style suggests he was probably north German rather than Viennese. But a study of the paper type, ink, handwriting and provenance of the manuscript sug gests it may date from the late 18th or early 19th century, and the confident attribution on the title page certainly merits careful investigation.

The Halifax score is a beautiful piece of work - a fair copy, with scarcely any erasures or crossings out. There are additional markings made at a later date, giving dynamics, cues and pencilled translations of the German words back into the original English, probably added in the 1850s, when the Halifax Choral Society is known to have performed the arrangement at least six times. The score was presented to the society by William Priestley in May 1850, and Priestley said it had come via one of the Moravian settlements in Germany.

The Moravians, protestant missionaries with their headquarters in Saxony, had a strong presence in Halifax, and Priestley had musical links with the nearby Moravian settlement of Fulneck, near Pudsey, Leeds. One distinguished and well-travelled Moravian clergyman, Christian Ignatius Latrobe, is known to have regularly carried newly published music from the continent to England during the early 19th century. He had introduced English musicians to many of Mozart's and Haydn's masses in this way. In 1817, Latrobe bought a considerable number of "manuscript music scores and some very good German oratorios" from Breitkopf & Härtel in Leipzig, near Niesky, who had abandoned their attempts to publish a complete edition of Mozart's works around 1808 through lack of demand. If this Judas Maccabaeus arrangement was among those scores, it seems possible that Latrobe passed it to Priestley. How the score got to Breitkopf & Hartel is hard to say. One of the early 19th-century Brietkopf & Hartel catalogues did indeed list a Mozart arrangement of Maccabaeus, but since no exemplar of this edition has survived, it is assumed that it never materialised.

It is possible that the Halifax score was the source of an edition for voices and piano of Judas Maccabaeus apparently also "as arranged by Mozart", which was published by JA Böhme in Hamburg in 1820, a copy of which is in the British Library. (The Halifax score differs from this one in that the orchestral parts are detailed fully, allowing us to see clearly the changes made by the arranger.) Again, Latrobe was also a customer of Böhme.

So much, then, for the history of the manuscript, but what of the arrangement itself? Stylistically, there are many features that support the attribution of the arrangement to Mozart. In his Handel arrangements, Mozart filled out Handel's orchestral textures, which to late 18th-century Viennese audiences must have seemed sparse and primitive. In particular, the addition of clarinets and trombones made the most of these relative newcomers to the orchestra. See the Conqu'ring Hero Come, which is more familiar to us as the hymn Thine Be the Glory, was already colourfully orchestrated by Handel, so not much has been changed. There are particularly beautiful moments, however, in the slow, solo numbers, such as the soprano's Ah! Wretched Israel, where the clarinet and flute are given new counter-melodies to the vocal line over Handel's string textures.

It will always be difficult to say for sure whether these touches are truly Mozart's, or to what extent he had a hand in this arrangement, but this is an accomplished piece of work. If it is by Mozart, this suggests that Mozart's studies and modernisations of Handel's oratorios were more extensive than previously thought, and it adds another episode to what we know of his musical activities in the later 1780s - a time when his popularity in Vienna was at its height, three or four years before his death. Further, the score adds detail to our understanding of Mozart's response to an early 18th-century master such as Handel, and while modern audiences may find the notion of Mozart modernising Handel distasteful, in view of our pursuit of "authentic" performances, this is a fascinating document which merits continuing research.

More detailed discussion of this manuscript will appear in a future edition of the Musical Times, and we are currently looking into the possibility of a performance by Halifax Choral Society. Given this manuscript's history entwined with that of the Choral Society, Priestley, we hope, would have approved.

fields.headline: Hard jaws
fields.trailText: Not for the first time - not even, he poignantly mused, for the 101st - young Alaric Widdecombe shuddered as he saw his father's jaw harden.
fields.body:
Not for the first time - not even, he poignantly mused, for the 101st - young Alaric Widdecombe shuddered as he saw his father's jaw harden. "Listen to me, my boy," the beetle-browed authoritarian roared. "Have you not heard me say, more times that I care to remember, that emollience is the sanctum sanctorumx of the congenitally vapid? If I ever again..."

Realist (Haddenham) writes: What is meant by the expression "his jaw hardened"? I have never seen a jaw harden. Tense, certainly; clench, quite probably; drop, just about. But harden? As if it were some form of drying cement?

Smallweed concedes with vapid emollience: Of course you are right. These phrases are often tossed about with scant regard for their meaning. Take the expression "a can of worms". Do people who use it stop to think of its derivation? Presumably it has something to with fishing: anglers use worms as bait, and a can of them must be a somewhat unsavoury sight in the eyes of any non-angler. The other day on the radio I heard some rabbi being denounced for "airing a can of worms".

Perhaps he had in mind the Diet of Worms, that famous theological gathering, which no doubt, given the number of disputants present and the nature of their proceedings, would have become frightfully stuffy at times. There is also the expression "a worm's eye view", which I thought was as old as - well, let us innovatively say, as old as the hills; yet the Penguin Dictionary of Quotations attributes it to H de Cronin Hastings, who it says used the expression in a caption he wrote for the Architectural Review in the early 1930s.

Talk of worms leads us effortlessly on to the question of referees. The Sri Lanka test series has by common consent been all about umpires, but Premiership football seems nowadays by the same test to be largely about referees. Where once the Monday morning accounts of Saturday's matches pulsated with news about how ace striker Bill Stooks had thundered the leather past aghast custodian Bill Snooks, now they are chiefly concerned with the thoughts of manager Andre Heinrich Sven Gonzalez de Madriaga about the refereeing of David Elleray or whoever. But I think I have discovered the solution to that. It is to keep referees not just off the pitch, but out of the stadium.

Under Smallweed's plan, the day's officiant would sit at a desk 100 miles from the ground surrounded by experts facing bank upon bank of TV cameras who would help him make the essential decisions. Their representatives on the pitch, issuing grating instructions and interposing themselves between combatants squaring up to each other, would be robots, tough enough to reduce even the most hardened jaw to a state of vapid emollience. I visualise some kind of Dalek. Like all other Daleks, they would come equipped with spiteful guns sticking out of them at all levels. These guns would be primed with tranquilising darts which, on an order from central control, they would fire into the midriff of anyone misbehaving or showing cheek, thus putting the offender out of commission for a time proportionate to the offence. As the Marquis of Vauvenargues once asked in a totally different context, who could possibly quarrel with that?

And so to the 1946 movie Don't Take It to Heart, my recollections of which have produced many helpful messages. Most of these say: yes, do try to see it again, it is wonderful, why is it so neglected, and don't worry, I've got it on tape and can send you a copy. It is also available from Carlton Classics and quite recently was shown twice in one week on Carlton Cinema. Those who have seen it recently have corrected and amplified what I wrote. The driver of the rickety-rackety bus was not eating an apple; he was munching a succession of sandwiches and using both hands - not one - to do so. Only when disaster was imminent did he condescend to finger the steering wheel.

The cast included Wylie Watson (who was Mr Memory in the Hitchcock 39 Steps), Joan Hickson, Ernest Thesiger and the old Will Hay stalwart Moore Marriott as well as those I've already mentioned. Patricia Medina was what was known in those days as the love interest. I'm especially asked to mention Esma Cannon, who played a maid. Could I possibly publish a photograph? Sorry, no space. One writer only says: keep your illusions and do not see it again. It's partly the way the countryside leaps about during the bus ride, showing the use of back projection in not entirely competent hands. But given the general weight of enthusiastic testimony I doubt if that is a deterrent.

Which sweeps me refulgently on to another sanctum sanctorum of British movie-making: Irthlingborough, Northants, just over the bridge from "that beautiful place" (Arthur Mee) Higham Ferrers. It's the latest in Smallweed's series formerly known as Places to Visit this Summer, but now retitled Places to Visit when this Foot and Mouth Problem Abates. As I understand it, Irthlingborough has at least three notable claims to touristic attention:

The battle of Waterloo was fought there in 1913. A director called Charles Weston enlisted large numbers for its re- enactment in his film of this name. Three were modestly injured. Later an Irthling called Cliff Warren wrote a film called The Poacher's Sweetheart, about which I have discovered nothing at all.

It has a splendid tower right beside, but not part of, the church of St Peter, the legacy of some people called Pyel, who built it in the 14th century as part of a college. Irthlingborough, as Wordsworth says in his famous poem, has nothing to show more fair.

It is also known for its Diamonds. There is a football team pressing for admission to the Nationwide League known as Rushden and Diamonds - a pretty odd name, but not when you know that it sprang from the merger of Rushden with Irthlingborough Diamonds, on whose ground they still play. Originally there was an Irthlingborough United, but the club was so entranced by the visit of Moscow Dynamo after the second world war that it chose the name Diamonds as an echo of Dynamo. In any case, why shouldn't you have a Club called Diamonds when for years there has been one called Hearts?

Where once the Monday morning accounts of Saturday's matches pulsated with news about how ace striker Bill Stooks had thundered the leather past aghast custodian Bill Snooks, now they are chiefly concerned with the thoughts of manager Andre Heinrich Sven Gonzalez de Madriaga about the refereeing of David Elleray or whoever. But I think I have discovered the solution to that. It is to keep referees not just off the pitch, but out of the stadium. Under Smallweed's plan, the day's officiant would sit at a desk 100 miles from the ground surrounded by experts facing bank upon bank of TV cameras who would help him make the essential decisions. Their representatives on the pitch, issuing grating instructions and interposing themselves between combatants squaring up to each other, would be robots, tough enough to reduce even the most hardened jaw to a state of vapid emollience. I visualise some kind of Dalek. Like all other Daleks, they would come equipped with spiteful guns sticking out of them at all levels. These guns would be primed with tranquilising darts which, on an order from central control, they would fire into the midriff of anyone misbehaving or showing cheek, thus putting the offender out of commission for a time proportionate to the offence. As the Marquis of Vauvenargues once asked in a totally different context, who could possibly quarrel with that? And so to the 1946 movie Don't Take It to Heart, my recollections of which have produced many helpful messages. Most of these say: yes, do try to see it again, it is wonderful, why is it so neglected, and don't worry, I've got it on tape and can send you a copy. It is also available from Carlton Classics and quite recently was shown twice in one week on Carlton Cinema. Those who have seen it recently have corrected and amplified what I wrote. The driver of the rickety-rackety bus was not eating an apple; he was munching a succession of sandwiches and using both hands - not one - to do so. Only when disaster was imminent did he condescend to finger the steering wheel. The cast included Wylie Watson (who was Mr Memory in the Hitchcock 39 Steps), Joan Hickson, Ernest Thesiger and the old Will Hay stalwart Moore Marriott as well as those I've already mentioned. Patricia Medina was what was known in those days as the love interest. I'm especially asked to mention Esma Cannon, who played a maid. Could I possibly publish a photograph? Sorry, no space. One writer only says: keep your illusions and do not see it again. It's partly the way the countryside leaps about during the bus ride, showing the use of back projection in not entirely competent hands. But given the general weight of enthusiastic testimony I doubt if that is a deterrent. Which sweeps me refulgently on to another sanctum sanctorum of British movie-making: Irthlingborough, Northants, just over the bridge from "that beautiful place" (Arthur Mee) Higham Ferrers. It's the latest in Smallweed's series formerly known as Places to Visit this Summer, but now retitled Places to Visit when this Foot and Mouth Problem Abates. As I understand it, Irthlingborough has at least three notable claims to touristic attention: The battle of Waterloo was fought there in 1913. A director called Charles Weston enlisted large numbers for its re- enactment in his film of this name. Three were modestly injured. Later an Irthling called Cliff Warren wrote a film called The Poacher's Sweetheart, about which I have discovered nothing at all. It has a splendid tower right beside, but not part of, the church of St Peter, the legacy of some people called Pyel, who built it in the 14th century as part of a college. Irthlingborough, as Wordsworth says in his famous poem, has nothing to show more fair. It is also known for its Diamonds. There is a football team pressing for admission to the Nationwide League known as Rushden and Diamonds - a pretty odd name, but not when you know that it sprang from the merger of Rushden with Irthlingborough Diamonds, on whose ground they still play. Originally there was an Irthlingborough United, but the club was so entranced by the visit of Moscow Dynamo after the second world war that it chose the name Diamonds as an echo of Dynamo. In any case, why shouldn't you have a Club called Diamonds when for years there has been one called Hearts?

webTitle: After the storm, exotic shores beckon again

fields.headline: After the storm, exotic shores beckon again
fields.trailText: Emerging markets are not for the faint-hearted. Investors have had to grapple with Asia's tiger economies and brave Brazilian downpours, only to see a negative return.
fields.body:
Emerging markets are not for the faint-hearted. Investors have had to grapple with Asia's tiger economies and brave Brazilian downpours, only to see a negative return.

But with the UK market falling and technology shares in the doldrums, investors may look to more exotic shores again. A new poll this week shows that serious investors are considering the move towards less well known markets.

Some 78% of people polled by Brunswick Direct, an emerging markets online broker, said emerging markets will outperform "emerged" markets in 2001. Two out of five think emerging markets will rise 10% to 20% in US dollar terms this year, while 28% expected returns in excess of 20% in the year. China is expected to be the best performer in 2001, Turkey the worst.

Brunswick's Willem De Geer says: "The results confirm that investors are be coming positive about emerging markets after a difficult year. I think it is very significant that China topped the poll as the market with the most upside in 2001. Its upcoming entry into the World Trade Organisation will be a milestone in the history of emerging markets."

Investing in emerging markets is like buying houses in grotty areas around the world and hoping they will become the next Chelsea or Islington. But Mark Dampier, head of research at the independent financial adviser Hargreaves Lansdown, says: "Emerging markets have had awful returns over the past five years. Like technology, it was the final frontier experiencing very high growth."

Investment trusts aimed at emerging markets are now at a 20-year record discount, after trading at a premium. They have suffered as big international investors stuck with the familiar rather than going to less well-known regions. In the investment trust sector, funds are nursing losses of up to 30%. Average returns are down 15.7%. Unit trusts are no better; returns average a negative 22.1% over the past year. Baillie Gifford did best, with its emerging markets growth fund and Latin American fund coming first and second over three years.

Mr Dampier can see light at the end of the tunnel. He says: "If you are a contrarian investor, and providing the US market does not have a hard landing, emerging markets are very well priced. Templeton's investment trust was trading at a 15% premium and is now at a 20% discount."

Jeff Chowdry, investment manager at Foreign & Colonial, is also looking positive. He says as a result of the Asian crisis a lot of currencies are now floating, exports are much cheaper and economies are looking better. The one region that seems to offer the greatest hope to investors is Latin America. Latin American unit trusts have had the best year so far, finding the top three places in the sector.

fields.headline: Berkshire to Beijing
fields.standfirst: Stanley Spencer, that most English and eccentric of painters, visited Chinal just before the Cultural Revolution. Patrick Wright on a trip that mixed high art with low comedy and personal tragedy
fields.trailText: Stanley Spencer, that most English and eccentric of painters, visited Chinal just before the Cultural Revolution. Patrick Wright on a trip that mixed high art with low comedy and personal tragedy
fields.body:
He is one of the most original and accomplished painters of the 20th century, and yet he is also synonymous with a peculiarly English eccentricity. He is the artist who treated Cookham, the little Thameside village where he lived, as the measure of all experience. He is the prophet of divine sexuality who, at the second post, fell humiliated victim to a fortune-seeking lesbian. When Timothy Hyman and I set out to curate Tate Britain's new exhibition of Stanley Spencer's work, we realised that we would have to fight our way through the bizarre collection of fragmentary anecdotes that now shape his memory.

Many concern Spencer's chaotic sex life, but the one that I found most enigmatic was different. It is recorded, in various memoirs, that in the autumn of 1954, this most English of painters left his home in Berkshire to visit Beijing, where he would inform Chou En-lai, the communist premier, that "I feel at home in China because I feel that Cookham is somewhere near, only just around the corner".

The very idea of Spencer in China seems inherently unlikely. Indeed, it has been suggested that he was almost certainly invited by accident, after the authorities got him muddled up with the then radical poet, Stephen Spender. That theory can now be discounted, even though Spender himself apparently described being mistaken, while in China, for both Spender and the Elizabethan poet Spenser. Behind this curious anecdote lies an unexpected story, which can be reconstructed with the help of Spencer's previously unexamined notebooks, photographs and letters, and also the recollections of John Chinnery, who joined the Beijing-bound delegation as translator and "sinologue".

He now dismisses the Spender story as "absolute rubbish" and remarks that, whatever his reputation as an idiosyncratic Englishman, Spencer knew a lot about China and its art: partly through his leftwing friend and brother- in-law, Richard Carline, who was associated with the Britain-China Friendship Association; and partly through his close friendship - since written out of Spencer's known biography thanks to the dominant cult of Cookham - with the London-based Chinese artists, Fei Cheng-wu and Chang Chien-ying.

The story of Spencer's visit to China is characterised by the combination of high art, low comedy and personal tragedy that marked much of his life. It took place in September 1954, before Chairman Mao's industrialising "Great Leap Forward" of 1958, and when Beijing was still largely a medieval city. Spencer was 63, a celebrated senior artist, with most of his major work behind him. Along with more than 600 other figures in the arts and sciences, he had signed a statement of goodwill towards the Chinese people, instigated by a small group of communist sympathisers loosely associated with the Britain-China Friendship Association.

The Chinese authorities offered to pay for five signatories to attend the celebrations of the fifth anniversary of the communist liberation in Beijing. Spencer was selected along with Hugh Casson, the architect and exponent of postwar American mass housing; Rex Warner, a novelist, poet and classicist who had been head of the British Institute in Rome; and the philosopher AJ Ayer, who accepted the invitation as an "astonishing windfall" though he was puzzled as to why he had been picked. The delegation was headed by Professor Leonard Hawkes, an elderly geologist, who was also president of the Mineralogical Society and, as Chinnery laughingly suggests, the only safe pair of hands in the party.

The delegation flew from Heathrow to Amsterdam and then Prague, where they boarded a plane for the Soviet Union. On the way, Spencer drew the wing of the plane as it looked from his porthole, and scribbled a note in praise of the entrancing - and, thanks to the Iron Curtain, now also forbidden - world that could be glimpsed through a fleeting break in the clouds. At Minsk, they were put up in a collective dormitory.

Chinnery remembers Spencer looking around and asking: "Do you think it is time for me to go to byes?" Surprised, Chinnery said yes, and Spencer duly put himself to bed. Casson was tolerant of the English painter's quirky observations. In Casson's record of the journey, Red Lacquer Days (Lion and Unicorn Press, 1956), he describes Spencer comparing the party to a group of "deathwatch beetles" condemned only to go forward, as if they were munching their way through the roof-beams of an old English church rather than traversing the communist world. AJ Ayer was less patient. This eminent logical positivist and campaigner for secularism confessed to being infuriated by his strange, self-educated companion, whose outlook was, as Chinnery agrees, "highly illogical".

In his autobiography, More of My Life (Collins, 1984), Ayer would declare himself "repelled by the "eroticism and religiosity" of Spencer's paintings, even though he did not question his technical skill. He conceded that Spencer's "gnome-like appearance was not unappealing", and he was prepared to tolerate "minor eccentricities" such as his habit of wearing his pyjamas as underclothes (Chinnery confirms that Spencer's pyjama cord was, indeed, often to be seen dangling down in front of his trousers).

But Spencer's conversation was too much for the philosopher. When he was not repudiating Spencer's pronouncements on art and religion, Ayer took refuge behind the defensively raised covers of Gibbon's Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire. As the party proceeded across the Soviet Union, he took up a position close to Rex Warner, who happily launched into scholastic disquisitions on ancient Greece, while also taking a low-key approach to the whole adventure - epitomised by his habit of asking, "Where's the bar?" at every new point of arrival.

Ayer described Spencer as "the most self-centred man I have ever met", mocking his incessant allusions to Cookham and his habit of "referring to various women by their Christian names and recounting episodes in his biography as if we had taken part in them".

As Chinnery recalls, the women on Spencer's mind were his two lost wives: Hilda Carline, whom Spencer had married in 1925; and Patricia Preece, for whom he had left Hilda disastrously in 1937, giving her his house, showering her with expensive gifts, and then, very shortly after they married, finding himself kicked out so that Preece could resume her now financially improved relationship with her lover, Dorothy Hepworth.

Spencer loved Moscow, writing to friends that his long-standing desire to tread on Russian soil, so long imagined through the works of Dostoevsky, Chekhov and Turgenev, was now completely fulfilled, and that "politics has nothing to do with it". They saw new skyscrapers going up like rockets, thanks to the women labourers who, as Ayer noticed from his hotel window, "tossed bricks around from dawn to dusk". They visited the Kremlin, where Spencer, as he wrote in a letter to Dickory Frank, felt tears in his eyes as he admired the Cathedral of the Annunciation and the Cathedral of the Assumption, both within the Kremlin walls and distinguished by their medieval icons.

They twice attended the Bolshoi theatre, where they saw Verdi's Aida ("simply magnificent") and Prokofiev's Cinderella ("very lovely music with great, sweeping themes'"). One evening, while visiting an agricultural show, they came across some prodigious rams. Chinnery was surprised when Spencer pointed to their huge dangling testicles and remarked that, with equipment like that, he might have done better with Patricia Preece.

Airborne again, Spencer sketched a little boy asleep in the arms of his mother, praised the scent of wild thyme in Siberia, and imagined that he and his fellow delegates were a party of "unborn kings in the body of the plane", waiting to be "baptised" before emerging into the world outside.

For Ayer, Spencer only brought further irritation in Beijing. He remembered him sitting at the breakfast table in the Foreign Delights hotel, berating the waiters in pidgin French when they failed to supply him with bacon and eggs. In fact, as Chinnery recalls, that bad- tempered outburst actually occurred when the waiters brought the customary three boiled eggs rather than the single one the painter had requested. Spencer was there with the other delegates when they presented their statement of goodwill to the Chinese People's Association for Cultural Relations with Foreign Countries; and he attended the reception with the premier, Chou En-lai.

Chou informed the visitors that the Chinese were a home-loving people: "So am I," said Spencer. "It took China to get me away from Cookham." (Gilbert Spencer recounts this moment in his book, Stanley Spencer By His Brother, 1961). But Spencer was not at ease with China's surging blue-clad masses. He managed the banquets and receptions, at which the visitors ate sea slugs, fish lips and Beijing duck. He saw the young Dalai Lama, then being toured round the People's Republic in a "gesture of friendship", and witnessed the formal election of Mao Zedong as chairman. Spencer admired the temples, gardens, pavilions and soon-to-be- demolished wall of old Beijing, and also the magical courts of the Forbidden City. He visited the Great Wall of China, sketching Buddhas and distant views in his notebook, alongside gnomic thoughts such as "wandering people cease their steps".

But stately military parades offered no attraction for the artist of the Sandham Memorial Chapel at Burghclere, who had gone to such lengths to find a vision of peace and resurrection in his memory of the first world war. Casson records Spencer ducking out of the National Day parade on October 1, pleading his dislike of the crowds as he left the others, including Ayer, to stand there for hours watching "the military ironwork clattering by".

While Ayer lectured Chinese philosophers on logical positivism and Rex Warner entered and won a drinking competition with the famously bibulous translator Yang Xianyi, Spencer drew in the studio allocated to him at the art school and met Chinese artists, including the great nonagenarian painter, calligrapher and seal carver, Qi Baishi (Chi Pai-shih). He left some money with an official of the Chinese People's Association for Cultural Relations with Foreign Countries, asking him to buy some of Qi's works and mail them on to him in Cookham.

Yet, in a deeper sense than was intended by Ayer, Spencer was indeed a peculiarly "self-centred" visitor to China. When all the official business was over, he found his own uses for the trip as an autobiographical artist who, in a note written 20 years previously, had recorded his wish to write the story of his life as if it were a wandering existence, both physical and mental, like "a journey to China".

During the course of the visit, Spencer found it impossible to combine sightseeing with painting. So, in October, after Ayer and the other British visitors had returned to their teaching jobs in Britain, he stayed on with Chinnery for 10 days and, in his own words, "did a little oil painting" in the valley of the Ming tombs near Beijing. These famous antiquities are approached via an avenue of stone figures, starting with animals - elephants, horses, dragons and camels - and then proceeding to the officials or ministers. Here he painted two oils: one, showing the stone camels, called Ming Tombs, Peking [Beijing], the other of the officials, called The Ministers, Peking.

Spencer surveyed all Russia and China in a strange spirit of recognition: "As I drove along the roads from the airports to the towns it was almost comic to see these dreams of mine coming true on either side of the road."

He provided some definition of these "dreams" he had seen in the valley of the Ming tombs shortly after returning to Cookham from China. In November 1954, he wrote a letter to Hilda Carline, who had divorced him in 1937 as he took up with Patricia Preece, wishing that she had been with him on the journey.

Transposed to the Mongolian steppe, she would have been surrounded by "hundreds of miles of nowhere", in a world where "the only happening is yourself". Spencer also reminded Hilda of a comparison he had made some years before his trip to China. Writing to her in 1948, he had recalled how they had longed for marriage in the 1920s. They had once glimpsed a great plain through an opening in the road at Wangford - the Suffolk village where Hilda had served as a land girl in the first world war - and imagined this "vast Gobi desert of you" as the prospect of their future togetherness, its distant "shapes and forms" suggesting "various parts" of the life they would share.

On returning from China, Spencer wrote to Hilda again. reminding her that the plain at Wangford had been their "place of the Ming tombs". They had seen photographs of these great imperial statues, and had felt that "our together selves was like the remoteness of these animals".

As these letters suggest, Spencer's paintings of the Ming tombs are strangely autobiographical images. They show the enigmatic remnants of a lost age and its promises: cracked and abandoned in an apparently parched and desertified landscape. They are regretful images of the "shapes and forms" that might have lived, had Spencer's first marriage lasted, or had his attempted rapprochement with Hilda Carline ever come off.

It is characteristic of Spencer that he could journey to the other side of the world and still find himself curiously at home. Sadly, Hilda Carline would never receive her former husband's explanation of his Chinese paintings, nor any of the countless letters that he continued to write her. She had died in 1950.

© Patrick Wright, 2001. The Stanley Spencer exhibition opens at Tate Britain, Millbank, London SW1 next Thursday.

So, in October, after Ayer and the other British visitors had returned to their teaching jobs in Britain, he stayed on with Chinnery for 10 days and, in his own words, "did a little oil painting" in the valley of the Ming tombs near Beijing. These famous antiquities are approached via an avenue of stone figures, starting with animals - elephants, horses, dragons and camels - and then proceeding to the officials or ministers. Here he painted two oils: one, showing the stone camels, called Ming Tombs, Peking [Beijing], the other of the officials, called The Ministers, Peking. Spencer surveyed all Russia and China in a strange spirit of recognition: "As I drove along the roads from the airports to the towns it was almost comic to see these dreams of mine coming true on either side of the road." He provided some definition of these "dreams" he had seen in the valley of the Ming tombs shortly after returning to Cookham from China. In November 1954, he wrote a letter to Hilda Carline, who had divorced him in 1937 as he took up with Patricia Preece, wishing that she had been with him on the journey. Transposed to the Mongolian steppe, she would have been surrounded by "hundreds of miles of nowhere", in a world where "the only happening is yourself". Spencer also reminded Hilda of a comparison he had made some years before his trip to China. Writing to her in 1948, he had recalled how they had longed for marriage in the 1920s. They had once glimpsed a great plain through an opening in the road at Wangford - the Suffolk village where Hilda had served as a land girl in the first world war - and imagined this "vast Gobi desert of you" as the prospect of their future togetherness, its distant "shapes and forms" suggesting "various parts" of the life they would share. On returning from China, Spencer wrote to Hilda again. reminding her that the plain at Wangford had been their "place of the Ming tombs". They had seen photographs of these great imperial statues, and had felt that "our together selves was like the remoteness of these animals". As these letters suggest, Spencer's paintings of the Ming tombs are strangely autobiographical images. They show the enigmatic remnants of a lost age and its promises: cracked and abandoned in an apparently parched and desertified landscape. They are regretful images of the "shapes and forms" that might have lived, had Spencer's first marriage lasted, or had his attempted rapprochement with Hilda Carline ever come off. It is characteristic of Spencer that he could journey to the other side of the world and still find himself curiously at home. Sadly, Hilda Carline would never receive her former husband's explanation of his Chinese paintings, nor any of the countless letters that he continued to write her. She had died in 1950. © Patrick Wright, 2001. The Stanley Spencer exhibition opens at Tate Britain, Millbank, London SW1 next Thursday.

fields.headline: Yorkshire
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
There is an eerie feel about the countryside, one cloaked in fear and foreboding. In the Yorkshire Dales, near Hawes, a pall of smoke drifting across the hillside reminds everyone that foot and mouth has struck a local dairy herd. Each TV and radio bulletin is monitored for news and the latest actual or suspected outbreak. The media is watched more carefully than the weather; every phone call is answered with hesitation. There is a feeling of impotence and helplessness.

By and large the public have heeded requests to stay away, whilst local people walk their dogs along the roads, avoiding footpaths and tracks. Every farm drive has "Keep out" signs and straw soaked in disinfectant is strewn across all entrances. Almost as important as information on the disease's progress across the countryside are the latest details of possible licences to move stock around. Pregnant ewes need to be brought in for lambing; pastures are becoming overgrazed. Routine maintenance work has been postponed. Contracts to erect fencing, lay hedges or rebuild walls have been halted. No one is going to risk transporting the disease around.

It is a different story in East Yorkshire, however. Here one farmer told me that he thought there were more cyclists, walkers and horse riders out last weekend than at any time in the past three months. Landowners have witnessed people tearing down official footpath closure signs and blatantly walking across their land. I have been told of two incidents of farmers being assaulted when they asked people to respect the footpath closures and the foot and mouth precautions.

There have been no confirmed outbreaks in East Yorkshire at time of writing, but there are reports of a suspected infection in sheep near Driffield. Everyone waits for the results of tissue tests with bated breath. One farmer's wife told me that even though the disease had not reached them, near Hornsea, most daily contact with the outside world had ended. No one stops to chat over the farm gate and feed company salesmen no longer call, but take orders by telephone instead.

webTitle: Isa special: Watch out for last-minute bargains

fields.headline: Watch out for last-minute bargains
fields.standfirst: Even if you wait until the deadline you can still find the right fund, says Pamela Atherton
fields.trailText: Even if you wait until the deadline you can still find the right fund, says Pamela Atherton.
fields.body:
Leaving your Isa application to the last minute is generally not a good idea. If you did so last year, you would have invested near the top of the market, but with recent stockmarkets falls, this year's laggards may benefit from their tardiness.

Most investment groups have arrangements in place to accept forms right up to the end of the tax year - midnight on April 5 - if you agree to waive your right to a seven day "cooling off" period.

Cooling off means you can cancel within seven days of signing your application form and be reimbursed the full amount of your original investment. But don't confuse cooling off with "cancellation rights" whereby your money is invested as soon as your cheque has cleared. This means that if you want to exit from the fund within 14 days, you will be reimbursed at the prevailing unit price and will have to bear any losses if the market has fallen.

If your application is received by the close of business on March 28 or March 29, it will normally be accepted on a cooling-off basis.

But if you want to submit a last-minute application by phone, by hand or over the internet on April 5, you automatically waive your right to the seven day cooling-off period and will be eligible for the 14-day cancellation rights instead.

Some groups such as Fidelity and Gartmore have arranged a number of drop-off points where you can submit last-minute applications. Fidelity's offices at Tonbridge in Kent, Lower Kingswood in Surrey and its Lovat Lane offices in London will be open on April 4 from 9am to 9pm and on April 5 from 9am to midnight. For details ring 0800 414 161 between 9am and 6pm (open seven days a week).

Gartmore will accept hand delivered forms until midnight on April 5 at its Brentwood administration offices and its two City offices at Gartmore House, 8 Fenchurch Place and 43-44 Crutched Friars, London EC3. Its Glasgow office at 125 West Regency Street will be open until 6pm.

For postal applications, Gartmore recommends posting forms by April 3 to reach its Brentwood office by April 5. Alternatively, Gartmore will take telephone applications up to midnight on April 5 on 0870 601 6103. Be sure to have your National Insurance number and a debit or switch card (but not credit card) to hand. You should also check that you have sufficient cleared funds in your account on the day of application when making telephone, fax or internet applications.

Groups such as Chase Fleming and Stewart Ivory distinguish between existing and new clients. Chase Fleming will accept postal applications from existing clients until 5.30pm on April 5. But for new subscribers the deadline is 5.30pm on March 28.

Similarly, for those applying for a Scottish American Investment Trust Isa with Stewart Ivory, the deadline is 12 noon on April 5 for existing customers, but March 29 for new subscribers.

Baillie Gifford will not accept postdated cheques for postal applications. It also reminds investors that a new application form is required each year for its lump sum Oeic Isa.

Invesco, Henderson Investors and Deutsche Bank, which manage both unit and investment trusts, have an April 5 deadline for unit trust Isas but a March 29 deadline for Oeic and investment trust Isas. But if your application form is stamped by an IFA to allow for cooling off rights, you must meet the earlier deadline of March 28 or 29.

Web applications can be made until 11.30pm on April 5 with Aberdeen (aberdeen-asset.co.uk), M & G (mandg.co.uk), Jupiter (jupiteronline.co.uk) and Gartmore (gartmore.co.uk).

With all online applications, investors must confirm that they have read the "key features" pages and insert their national insurance number and IFA agency code number (where applicable) to the on-screen application form. A successful online application will be acknowledged with a date/ time stamped receipt confirming all the details sent, which you can then print off.

With manual applications, be sure to complete all sections of the form, sign and date it, and attach your cheque, usually made out to the investment group. If in doubt ring the helpline.

webTitle: Low cost funds: The Cats stroll into the lead

fields.headline: The Cats stroll into the lead
fields.trailText: As stock markets show that those risk warnings on investment fund adverts are more than just a regulatory formality - you can lose money as well as gain - investors can at least ensure the odds are as favourable as possible.
fields.body:
As stock markets show that those risk warnings on investment fund adverts are more than just a regulatory formality - you can lose money as well as gain - investors can at least ensure the odds are as favourable as possible.

Cat-marked funds ensure Isa buyers keep more of their own money rather than hand it over to advisers and fund management companies. A government scheme to recognise financial products, the Cat mark stands for fair charges, easy access anddecent terms.

A Cat mark - funds, cash accounts and insurance Isas can all carry the tag - means you will not be hit by hidden charges.

But while only a few Isa funds have Cat marks, they are making more positive returns than their rivals, according to the latest index from Norwich Union and trust measurement firm Fitzrovia.

To qualify for the mark, share Isas must not charge more than 1% a year, or set a minimum investment level higher than £50 per month or a £500 lump sum. They must also invest predominantly in mainstream stocks in the UK or European Union. Apart from Norwich Union, top companies with Cat-marked funds include Fidelity, Legal & General, and Standard Life.

Daniel Longden, the communications manager at Norwich Union, says: "The Cat increases real returns to the investor and guarantees a head start to the investment. Active management further enhances returns, with the average active Cat fund in the UK All Companies sector outperforming its non-Cat counterpart by nearly 17% since the launch of Isas."

Anne Davis, executive director of Fidelity Investments, says: "We do believe that Cat standards have a very important role to play, particularly for new investors as a first step into the stockmarket. Fidelity has been offering low-cost, value-based funds through its no-load MoneyBuilder range for a number of years. This range aims to offer first-time investors the basic funds within a balanced portfolio of investments."

Catmarked funds do offer a simple, sleepless-night-free option for many people. But having a Catmark is not a government "guarantee" of a good or even superior deal. There may be better deals around.

Investors can create many Cat-style attributes from non-Cat funds. Discount brokers such as Torquil Clark rebate some or, in certain cases, all of the upfront fees on a variety of funds and only keep the annual "renewal fee" for themselves. But trusts paying renewal commissions tend to be more expensive.

According to Norwich Union, non-Cat standard funds still show no signs of catching up with the Cat standard headstart, which stands at 4.07% 20 months after the scheme started.

In the European sector, the average active Cat fund has outperformed its non-Cat counterparts by 17.95%.

In the UK All Companies sector, the average active Cat fund has outperformed its non-Cat counterparts by 16.54%. In real terms, this means that a £7,000 investment into the average active Cat fund in this sector would now be worth more than £8,500, while its non-Cat equivalent would be worth just £7,424.

webTitle: Listed buildings: dream home or a money pit?

fields.headline: Restored to  your own place in history
fields.standfirst: A listed building in need of work can become a dream home or a money pit, says Elizabeth Langton
fields.trailText: A listed building in need of work can become a dream home or a money pit, says Elizabeth Langton
fields.body:
Wanted: carer for poor old girl in need of love and attention. Would suit someone with time on their hands and an interest in preserving old wrecks. Not the kind of advert that would appeal to everyone, but then, according to campaigners for preserving historic buildings, it takes a certain sort of person to buy and restore a property under threat.

Architect Neil Worrell is looking for a kindred spirit to take on a building that captured his heart back in 1995. The Bluecoat Brewery in Hertfordshire, a sand-coloured brick building with a weatherboard top, is the sort of project that the renovation enthusiast would adore. The brewery was built in 1875 by Henry Baker and the beer produced there was sold from a roadside pub. It operated until 1935 when it became a storage depot and thereafter slipped into disrepair.

"The owner was about to demolish it," Mr Worrell says. "When I took it on it was practically derelict. The upper storey had all but collapsed. And five tons worth of roof was about to fall into the neighbour's garden." Emergency surgery means the building has now been made safe. Mr Worrell carried out urgent structural repairs and obtained planning permission and listed building consent for its conversion into a three-bedroom house - it is only 30 minutes by train to London's Liverpool Street station.

"The Bluecoat is off the critical list, but there's still an awful lot to do," Mr Worrell says. He is now selling the building, which still needs complete renovation, with the plans he has drawn up for the conversion. It's on the market for £200,000. Other projects mean he no longer has the time to carry out the work himself.

He is looking for a buyer with the help of Save, a charity that campaigns to protect Britain's heritage. Save runs a register which matches would-be renovators with historic, crumbling buildings. "The charity began its life campaigning for the preservation of country houses, which 25 years ago were being demolished at an alarming rate," says Adam Wilkinson, Save secretary. More recently, campaigns have focused on preserving the country's industrial heritage, such as northern mills, and Victorian asylums vacated by the NHS, he explains.

Mr Wilkinson says the charity sets out to ensure the buildings have a future. This almost always involves a battle, he adds. In recent times the government's enthusiasm for regeneration means hundreds of industrial buildings have now been converted into trendy shops and homes. As a result, the emphasis has shifted to protecting smaller, individual properties at risk rather than fighting for specific types of building, says Mr Wilkinson.

Although not an estate agent, through its register Save advertises buildings at risk in the hope of finding someone willing to take them on. Unlike the Bluecoat Brewery, few are for sale and the first hurdle for a renovator to leap is persuading the owner to part with it. Sadly, many owners are not only reluctant to maintain their property, but also refuse to sell it to someone who can.

However, the register gives contact details for the local authority and the local conservation officer who will be able to give some information about a building at risk. If the owner is not known they can be traced via the Land Registry for a small fee. It is then up to interested buyers to contact the owner and persuade them to part with their property.

The register contains a wide range of buildings, from country houses to tiny cottages and town houses. In Lincolnshire, there's the Thatched Cottage at Lowthorpe Road, Soutrey - a tiny Grade II listed property. The main part of the house, which dates from the 17th century, is made of Lincolnshire mud and stud. Save says the property would make an ideal holiday cottage and it is thought likely that the owners will consider selling.

Access to the Save register costs £15 for 12 months. Information about other buildings at risk can also be found via the English Heritage online register, which contains Grade I and II* buildings in England and Grade I, II* and II listed properties at risk in London.

Restoring a historic building is not for the faint-hearted. Owners will need planning permission and/or listed building consent for some of the works. Local authority conservation officers will be able to advise whether your plans are likely to be acceptable and will help owners navigate their way around the planning system. Councils can get tough and, if they need to, invoke statutory powers to order an urgent works notice. These are usually served when part of a building becomes dangerous. Councils can also serve a repairs notice to order specific work to ensure that the building is preserved. If this notice is ignored, the ultimate sanction - a compulsory purchase order - can be issued.

Most owners will be prompted by the repairs notice to either sell or fix the property, says Save. Needless to say, saving buildings costs large amounts of money and, although grants are on offer for some parts of the work, buyers should research the support available before embarking on a purchase. Sympathetic lenders such as the Ecology Building Society (0845 674 5566) and the Norwich and Peterborough (01733 372 372) offer mortgages for renovation projects. There are grants from English Heritage and its Welsh equivalent for Grade I and Grade II* buildings. Some councils also offer grants, although budgets are limited.

Anyone interested in Bluecoat Brewery should contact Save 020 7253 3500.

webTitle: Fair day's housesitting for a fair day's minimum wage

fields.headline: Fair day's housesitting for a fair day's minimum wage
fields.trailText: The task of looking after a property in the owner's absence - deterring burglars, watering plants and feeding cats - might not, in most eyes, constitute work.
fields.body:
The task of looking after a property in the owner's absence - deterring burglars, watering plants and feeding cats - might not, in most eyes, constitute work. Nonetheless, the Inland Revenue has ruled that housesitters employed by a Hertfordshire agency are workers and therefore entitled to the minimum wage of £3.70 per hour, shortly rising to £4.10.

Although it has been suggested that this ruling could make all housesitters prohibitively expensive, it is in fact likely to have more impact on agencies' profitability than on sitters themselves. The National Minimum Wage Act 1998, in anticipation of shady employers looking for loopholes in the legislation, was one of the most tightly drafted acts of parliament there has ever been. "Agency workers" are expressly protected by the act. The fact that what housesitters do may not seem to amount to work, makes little difference. Any task, however pleasant or undemanding, that a person contracts to do is work.

There is some relief for agencies from regulations which allow employers to not pay for hours when em ployees are asleep. Making an allowance for sleeptime, and because most housesitters are allowed out for a little while during the day, the Revenue has ruled that only 12 hours per day need to be paid for. A deduction of £2.85 per day can be made because living accommodation has been provided, but this still requires a payment of £41.55 per day, over £290 per week.

Agencies typically charge home owners £200 to £250 per week, and might pay their sitters £80. An agency able to supply 50 sitters at a time makes a very substantial profit. If agencies retain their massive mark-up and pay the minimum wage, the cost of a housesitter could rise to £500 per week.

Not surprisingly, the industry is outraged by the Revenue's ruling, and eight agencies have clubbed together to fight it at an employment tribunal. They will claim that most housesitters, particularly retired people, regard it primarily as a free holiday in pleasant surroundings.

There may be a lot of common sense in the argument that paying such housesitters less than the minimum wage does not amount to the form of exploitation the legislation was intended to end, but that will not sway a tribunal, bound by the words of the act.

Individuals who engage sitters directly are less likely to fall foul of the minimum wage legislation. There is an exception where the person providing the services does so for a client or customer of their business. Most housesitters would no more think of themselves as a business than they would workers. However, those who wish to do the work and are prepared to charge less than the minimum wage, can contract in that way, describing themselves as "Jo Bloggs Homeminding Services", or whatever.

Housesitters employed by agencies will usually have been vetted, something which it may not be practical to do when employing someone who advertises in a local newspaper. Nonetheless, taking references and checking that the person really lives where they claim should be sufficient. Of course, using a sitter recommended by a friend may be even safer.

In either case, the homeowner not only seems to avoid having to pay the minimum wage, but is saved the agency fee.

Richard Colbey is a barrister
