fields.headline: Capital letters
fields.trailText: Got a problem? We want to hear about it. Get in touch with us here at Jobs & Money and we will try to help.
fields.body:
Beware advice that comes in the post

I started using Young, Ridgway & Associates, an independent financial adviser, last summer. While I am happy with the face-to-face relationship with my personal adviser, I am unsure about the information I regularly receive from the firm's head office. These letters take the form of promotional fliers for investment products on the IFA's headed notepaper. These include standard warnings, but I have doubts about the extent to which these letters are objective and independent. Is this practice consistent with IFA status?
LP, Glasgow

 You have run into a yawning gap in IFA regulation and a practice that sits uneasily with independent advice. IFAs must offer personalised advice based on your individual needs and best advice. But when it comes to mailshots, all this goes out of the window.

The IFA can send anything which may or may not be suitable for your needs. Best advice is no longer relevant - the IFA is selling commission paying products as fast as possible.

In this case, YRA is pushing typical mailshot fodder - the Abbey National Income & Growth plan which features a large print 10.25% tax free income for three years. It is only later on that there is a wealth warning under the ambiguous "variable capital return" heading.

You wiil not get all your money back if Japan's Nikkei 225 index falls by more than 20%, and then fails to recover to at least the starting level on April 5, 2001. The letter states: "It would have to fall to levels not seen for 16 years for the capital to be reduced." Since the leaflet was produced, the Nikkei has nosedived 15%. It may recover or go down.

YRA, the firm you use, is far from the only IFA to exploit this loophole. It does, as it must, offer a "personal consultation".

Called to account over US cheque

My mother was sent a US cheque - her share of a bequest - for $10,000 in November. It was paid into the West Ealing branch of the NatWest. But despite several attempts to track the money down, involving long and laboured conversations with call centre people, the money has not been credited to her account some three months later. What can I do? The call centre refuses to reveal the ex-directory branch number.
NJ, West London

 You have been a model of patience given that £6,750 is at stake. And as Capital Letters started to ask questions, the bank decided to credit the account. But it admits it still has no idea where the cheque ended up.

It makes matters worse that while you got no help from NatWest's call centre, one phone call to the Bank of New York - the originating bank for the cheque - produced a sensible reply and a fax of the paid cheque full of NatWest stamps.

Very few foreign currency cheques go through the system. And it is clear that the call centre had little clue of how to deal with the enquiry. NatWest is trying to trace the cheque through its New York agent. It admits it should have been more "pro-active" to the error. It will pay the lost interest and send £50 as recompense.

I need a strategy for retirement

I am a headteacher who desperately wants to retire next year when I will be 55. However, I cannot afford to take my pension before 60, as it will mean a substantial reduction for the rest of my life. I would like to leave my pension untouched and work part-time in education supplementing my salary with investment income. My wife and I have Peps, Isas, Tessas and unit trusts. Can you recommend a strategy? What about with-profits bonds?
R M, Kent

 Before looking at your investments, calculate how much you will need - you may already have some income from your existing investments. With-profits bonds are the first choice for many advisers because they pay commission of up to 6% - and can be portrayed as "tax free" - which they are not.

Rather, use the annual capital gains tax exemption (£7,500 for each of you from April 6) and consider low risk zero dividend investment trust shares. These can give a tax free income of around 7%. Try a specialist broker such as Goy Harris Cartwright in Leicester or Williams de Broe in London.

What is the society's address?

I read your informative and high quality supplement every Saturday, but have one small quibble! I recently searched in vain for the email or any other address of the Monmouthshire Building Society. Can you help?
DC, Liverpool

You can contact the society on 01633 8444 or the head office, Monmouthshire House, John Frost Square, Newport, Gwent NP20 1PX.

Downturn brings Isa worries

I am concerned about my mortgage Isa with the current downturn in the stock market. I have a £50,000 loan backed by a Legal & General tracker fund which is not performing well. I have to pay off my mortgage in 19 years time. What should I do?
JM, West Midlands

 Decide whether the Isa dividends and growth will produce more than the interest rate you pay over the long term. If you are unsure or negative, stop the investment now and use the Isa money and future payments to reduce the loan. Unlike an endowment, you will not be penalised for stopping or encashment. As a top-rate taxpayer, the Isa tax freedom is valuable - switching to another investment is pointless.

We welcome letters but cannot answer individually. Write to: Capital Letters, Jobs & Money, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER or email jobs.and.money@theguardian.com. Do not send original documents but do enclose a daytime phone number. Information is general and offered without any legal responsibility. Always take professional advice if in doubt.

fields.headline: Carpetbagger launches latest campaign
fields.trailText: A full-scale battle over Nationwide building society's future could be just a few months away after carpetbagger Andrew Muir officially launched his conversion campaign this week, writes Rupert Jones.
fields.body:
A full-scale battle over Nationwide building society's future could be just a few months away after carpetbagger Andrew Muir officially launched his conversion campaign this week, writes Rupert Jones.

Mr Muir aims to force Britain's biggest building society to convert to a bank and pay windfalls he claims could average between £700 and £1,000 to its 10m members.

The Berkshire recruitment firm boss has set up a website, nationwidewindfalls.com, to preach his carpetbagging philosophy and is calling on members who support his cause to print out, complete and return the conversion resolution form included on the site.

If his resolution is declared valid, and he can rustle up enough eligible members to back it, a vote will take place early this summer on whether the society should stay member-owned or convert.

Mr Muir, 36, says he wants to ensure that the 2 million members who have signed away their right to a windfall to charity will also be included in the possible multi-billion pound giveaway. On his website Mr Muir, who claims to have 1,500 supporters already, states: "This may be your only chance to claim a windfall that is rightfully yours ... Nationwide is a huge organisation, a bank in all but name, and will convert at some point. It is better to do it now, while the business is doing well, to get maximum value for members."

The issue was last put to the test in 1998 when Nationwide defeated by the slimmest of margins a conversion campaign mounted by the eccentric butler Michael Hardern. The society has been immune from another challenge until now.

There are several hurdles that Mr Muir needs to jump. He needs the backing of 500 members for his conversion resolution, and the backing of 250 for his nomination for election to the board, and he only has a few weeks to achieve this because the deadline is April 5. And it's not just any old members who can back the resolution - they must have either had £100-plus in a Nationwide savings account or have owed at least £100 on a mortgage, in both cases continually for at least two years. Also, the resolution must be judged valid. The society is likely to go through the wording of the resolution and will reject it if it doesn't stand up to legal scrutiny.

Provided Mr Muir - who stood unsuccessfully for election to the society's board three years ago - can overcome all these obstacles, Nationwide has said members will be able to vote on his resolution at the annual general meeting on July 19.

Pro-mutuality campaigners point to Bradford & Bingley, which floated on the stock market in December, as an example of why it is important for claims made about potential windfalls to be taken with a pinch of salt.

Two years ago Stephen Major, the man who led the campaign to force B&B to convert, said windfalls to members would average £2,000. But when B&B floated last December, the handouts of 250 shares each ended up being worth only £610 at the end of the first day's trading.

fields.headline: Foot in mouth
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: I predict that it won't be long before hoteliers, rugby players, jockeys, canoeists, anorak makers, mountaineering boot retailers and mystery tour coach drivers mobilise and march on Downing Street demanding compensation
fields.body:
Sunday, March 11, Ashby-de-la-Zouch

Vince Ludlow, my next-door neighbour, has got a new job. He calls himself an Animal Incineration Operative. He is uniquely qualified for this gruesome employment, having served several sentences in youth custody for arson, and actively disliking animals, claiming, "They spoil the countryside." He is the only person I know who is hoping that the foot-and-mouth crisis worsens. He is eagerly awaiting a state of emergency to be declared. He is planning to buy his council house on the overtime heês earning.

I was disturbed to hear that he was in the Lamb's Head car park on Saturday night selling cheap cuts of beef from the back of his van.

Monday, March 12

Peter Mandelson sounds increasingly like Joan of Arc. One can practically see the burning faggots under his feet. I saw him on the news a few days ago, handing out apples to schoolchildren in Hartlepool. He looked vaguely sinister. I was reminded of Snow White, whose simple, trusting nature was taken advantage of by the hag at the window proffering Coxês Pippins.

Pamela Pigg's surname has been causing her considerable distress. A woman in Sketchley's openly sniggered when Pamela gave her name. She made a crass joke about foot and mouth and cloven hooves. Pamela fled the shop in tears and drove to my house, where she distracted me just as I was about to finish the first paragraph of my latest novel, Krog Of Gork. I made Pamela a cup of the dandelion tea she is so fond of and tried to listen sympathetically as she recounted the many humiliations she had suffered due to her unfortunate name. However, my thoughts kept straying to Krog Of Gork.

As Pamela sobbed at the memory of her first day as a trainee teacher, I mentally composed the second paragraph of Krog . . .Krog climbed to the brow of the hill. He looked down to the mouth of the cave. His woman was poking the fire with a twig. Krog sighed deeply. He wished his woman was beautiful, but make-up and hair dyes had not yet been invented. And neither had Immac. Krog picked a handful of red berries and loped down the hill towards the fire and the woman he loved. Language had yet to be invented but he grunted a greeting to his woman and she grunted back. Krog offered her the berries, she snatched them from his hand and crammed them into her black-toothed mouth. 'here should be something called manners,' Krog thought, as he watched the juice from the berries spray from her lips. A dinosaur brayed in the distance, the sound echoed across the Neanderthal landscape. Krog picked up his spear and put his arm protectively around his woman. She turned her face towards him, her lips were stained red. 'My God, youêre beautiful,' grunted Krog. His loins stirred. He led his woman into his cave.

Pamela Pigg stayed the night, but intimacy did not take place. At 11pm, I suggested that she change her name by deed poll. She said it would kill her father. The Piggs went back to the Plantagenets. She said that her only salvation was to change her name by marriage. She looked pointedly at me. I turned away and feigned sleep.

Tuesday, March 13

There was a farmer called Brown on Midlands Today, tonight, claiming that he was forced to feed his livestock antibiotics and British Airways leftovers, and to keep them in cages in darkness because the public demanded cheap food. Strange, but I do not recall the citizenry rioting outside Parliament for the cause of 5p off a pound of beef. However, I predict that it won't be long before hoteliers, rugby players, jockeys, canoeists, anorak makers, mountaineering boot retailers and mystery tour coach drivers mobilise and march on Downing Street demanding compensation.

webTitle: Talking heads: Gillian Wilmot, Managing director, Royal Mail

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst:
Gillian Wilmot
Managing director, Royal Mail
fields.trailText:
Gillian Wilmot
Managing director, Royal Mail
fields.body:
What was your first career aspiration?

To go into marketing.

What has been your best moment in management?

Launching the Next Directory.

And your greatest mistake?

Not resisting command and control management styles earlier in my career.

How would you describe your management style?

"Work hard - play hard."Enjoy work and achieve results.

Which deal would you most like to have done?

Owning some of the brands I've successfully launched and relaunched.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

Assuming that the boss is always right!

Does your organisation have a glass ceiling?

My appointment is proof that it doesn't.

What management wisdom is most overrated?

"If it ain't broke don't fix it."

What is the biggest challenge facing Royal Mail in the new millennium?

Becoming a truly commercial and innovative organisation.

What single lesson would you pass on to budding managers?

Create a vision and persevere, persevere, persevere, until you achieve it.

Which management guru do you believe in?

I prefer top flight business schools such as INSEAD and great books such as Even More Offensive Marketing, by Hugh Davidson.

Who is your management hero?

Sir John Harvey-Jones - down to earth and a great character.

Who is your favourite politician?

Nancy Astor.

If you could change one aspect of British business, what would it be?

Risk assessment - doing nothing is often the riskiest strategy.

Do you have a view on the British membership of the EMU?

No comment.

What phrase or saying do you most overuse?

"Yes, it can be done."

Apart from quality time with your family, what else makes you happiest in life?

Achieving results and confounding the sceptics.

What annoys you most?

Negative people.

How do you relax?

Sports, books and socialising with family and friends.

What was your last cultural experience?

The Brit Awards!

What is your favourite city?

New York.

Do you have a favourite web site?

Ft.com

What is your greatest regret?

Not doing law as a first degree.

What is your biggest fear?

Failure. I can't and won't accept it.

What would you really like to have been?

I love my job, but I would also have enjoyed being a barrister in commercial law.

Ft.com What is your greatest regret? Not doing law as a first degree. What is your biggest fear? Failure. I can't and won't accept it. What would you really like to have been? I love my job, but I would also have enjoyed being a barrister in commercial law.

webTitle: Don't just keep the books - read some

fields.headline: Don't just keep the books - read some
fields.standfirst: Companies are discovering that creativity means profitability. WH Smith boss Beverley Hodson gives chapter and verse
fields.trailText: The productivity of modern corporations at the dawn of the 21st century no longer depends on well-oiled machines. People are the powerhouses of successful organisations, their creativity and innovative thinking drives profitability. And what better way to stimulate their intellect and imagination than through reading books?
fields.body:
The productivity of modern corporations at the dawn of the 21st century no longer depends on well-oiled machines. People are the powerhouses of successful organisations, their creativity and innovative thinking drives profitability. And what better way to stimulate their intellect and imagination than through reading books?

Arts & Business, an organisation that develops creative partnerships between business and the arts, has been doing just this. In an association with the London Libraries Development Agency and The Reading Partnership its campaign Books & Business is an initiative to use the power of the written word to motivate and develop staff. The lessons from literature for the workplace cannot be overestimated, as research undertaken for Books & Business shows.

I am one of around 700 senior business leaders who contributed to a survey about which book had most inspired me and influenced my career.

I picked EM Forster's Howard's End, which explores the literal and figurative marriage between "masculine" qualities of progress and control and "feminine" qualities of empathy and emotional intelligence. For me, management in the new millennium is also about balancing these two themes - meeting functional targets of production, while connecting with staff and customers. As Forster himself put it, "only connect".

I am not alone in citing fiction as a catalyst for my professional development; 55% of us chose fiction or poetry as literature which had most influenced our careers, while barely 40% went for management or business books.

Successful managers in today's business environment clearly need to be well-rounded people with active imaginations. Interpreting fictional scenarios is a creative, active process, rather than a passive one. The reader uses a fine interplay of imaginative faculties combined with critical and analytical skills. In scientific terms, reading stimulates both sides of the brain. The logical left brain interprets the language, while the creative right side relishes in the imaginative forms of expression. The left analyses the intricacies of plot as the right absorbs the emotional relationships between characters.

Books & Business campaign explores how this process can directly benefit business. Creative ideas can give businesses a competitive edge, and the need for inspired and innovative employees has never been greater. Literate, articulate and imaginative employees are also more productive, and shared reading experiences in the workplace can markedly improve communication, motivation and morale.

At WH Smith, books and words are used to create a workplace environment which stimulates lifelong learning and creativity. For example, poems and quotations on the walls and above desks encourage innovation and risk-taking: "Avoiding the danger of life is no safer in the long run than outright exposure ... life is either a daring adventure or nothing".

Orange, the mobile phone company, has found that reading expands linguistic and interpersonal skills developing an articulate workforce.

Orange Talk Books at Work is a project which has impressed Marks & Spencer and the Institute for Cancer Research, among others, to establish similar reading groups that cut across functions, departments and organisational hierarchies. Reading group participants connect with their colleagues through debate and discussion of books, a shared experience that improves working relationships and internal business culture.

Other enlightened organisations such as Lever Brothers have introduced workshops led by writer Will Self and appointed Jackie Wills as poet in residence to stimulate creativity in the workplace.

At WH Smith, employees are also encouraged to take their enthusiasm for books into the community. Working directly with schools on literacy programmes, our staff volunteers visit local primary schools to help hard pressed teachers with children's reading.

Full marks for those of you who spotted that today's young readers are our book-buying customers of tomorrow. So, in our bid to foster an enlightened and rational world it is, in the end, "profit that is the spark" - as Adam Smith points out in The Wealth of Nations.

Profit alone, however, would not suffice. As WH Smith's loftier interests flag without the lure of profit, so does the profit motive wither without some nobler reason to continue, creating a whole greater than its parts. That's what modern stakeholder capitalism is about, groups of like-minded individuals giving their corporations a greater social expression while creating wealth for the common good.

Beverley Hodson is Managing Director of WH Smith.

Contact Arts & Business at Nutmeg House, 60 Gainsford Street, Butler's Wharf, London SE1 2NY or www. AandB.org.uk

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: Two business transformation movements are converging: sustainability development and organisational learning. The initial bridge was provided by Peter Senge and his Society for Organisational Learning (SoL), formed in the wake of the extraordinary   success of Senge's book The Fifth Discipline.
fields.body:
Two business transformation movements are converging: sustainability development and organisational learning. The initial bridge was provided by Peter Senge and his Society for Organisational Learning (SoL), formed in the wake of the extraordinary success of Senge's book The Fifth Discipline.

Recently SoL launched a Sustainability Consortium to help spur the process of convergence. Its first European event focused on the social dimensions of sustainability's "triple bottom line". BP co-hosted the event, using it to share some of the dilemmas it faces in developing oil production operations in war-torn Angola.

One characteristic the sustainability and organisational learning communities have in common is their interest in stakeholder engagement. At its best, this involves bringing the outside world in to an organisation's strategic thinking.

A whole series of new questions surfaced at the BP event, but four echoed in my brain afterwards. First, we were asked, what is this triple bottom line - or TBL? Different professional communities have different jargons. The basic idea, however, is simple. Governments and businesses will need to focus not just on the traditional financial bottom line, but also on economic prosperity, environmental quality and social equity. European companies, business organisations and accountancy bodies have picked up on the TBL language and agenda faster than their US counterparts, but the trend is also now building in the US.

Second, what does the social dimension of the TBL agenda look like? Here the waters get muddier. The environmental debate may be complicated, but at least science can often be brought to bear. The ethical, social and political debates tend to be less amenable to science. But one thing is clear: the social bottom line is not just an issue for corporate philanthropists. Companies working on social performance indicators are focusing on such areas as ethics, employee and community relations, human rights, the quality of stakeholder engagement, and the emerging priorities of the socially responsible investment (SRI) community.

Third, why do the social dimensions matter? There are many reasons, but one is that the best economies and companies make the best use of people. If you can't engage the right people in the right ways, your chances of success plummet, whatever you are trying to do. In a world with a population of 8-10bn, people are going to be even more important. We need switched-on psychologists, anthropologists, sociologists and economists to help us work out how to make the world of 2050 sustainable, not just ecologically but also socially, economically and politically.

And then, fourth, do Europeans and Americans see eye-to-eye on all this? No, not yet: we still view the sustainability agenda through different lenses. But in the end what stayed with me was something that happened late in the meeting. Jean Horstman, the director of SoL, became concerned that the debate about Angolan oil isn't simply for Europeans and Americans, however professional or concerned they may be. Among the voices missing at the session, she argued, were those of native Angolans. A few phone calls later, she had found a community of Angolan exiles living a few city blocks away. Too late to engage this time around, but an important lesson for us all. Sustainability may be a global issue, but it's going nowhere if it can't be brought down to earth for those whose lives are directly affected.

John Elkington is chairman of SustainAbility and co-author of The Global Reporters: The First International Survey of Corporate Sustainability Reporting. For more on SoL, visit www.solonline.org

webTitle: Cheers & jeers: The best and worse job creators.

fields.headline: Cheers & jeers
fields.trailText:
Cheers: Shell, Amec, Toyota
Jeers: Cable & Wireless, Motorola, IMI, Synstar
fields.body:
This week's three cheers are shared between oil company Shell and engineering firm Amec which together will create thousands of jobs in the north-east. Amec has won a contract to design and build the production facilities on board a 300,000-tonne floating oil platform destined for Shell's offshore oil-field in Nigeria. Amec's Wallsend yard on Tyneside will create 1,000 jobs and another 1,100 platers, pipefitters, welders, electricians and instrument technicians will be employed by subcontractors in the north-east, including up to 750 skilled technicians at Heerema's shipbuilding yard in Hartlepool.

And sound your horns in praise of Japanese car maker Toyota, which is to boost production of engines at one of its UK plants, creating up to 250 jobs. The factory at Deeside in north Wales will produce 400,000 engine units a year by 2003, more than double the present output. Employment at the factory is expected to increase from 350 to 600.

Finally, applaud the efforts of the more than 1m workers in our creative industries who chip in around £112bn to the economy, according to the government's sector-by-sector "snapshot" of the UK's creative industries.

 Boycott phones and the internet this week, as a gesture of solidarity with workers at telecom firms. Cable & Wireless is making its worker's pay the price of the decline in the value of its stock, which dived 20% earlier this week. It plans to cut more than 4,000 jobs from its global business division, which provides services to commercial customers around the world. Global's main UK bases are in London, Birmingham, Warrington, Bracknell and Milton Keynes.

And up to 700 jobs could be lost at the UK base of the mobile phone firm Motorola, the company confirmed this week. The possible job losses will be in Swindon, where network base stations are produced.

Jeers for Birmingham-based engineering group IMI, which is shedding more than 1,200 jobs following a review of its operations. IMI, which employs 19,000 people worldwide, said it plans to focus on a smaller number of businesses with higher growth potential.

Jeers, too, for computer services company Synstar for making 70 staff redundant at its offices in Bracknell, Bristol, Birmingham and Livingston in Scotland.

webTitle: My big break: Holidays are out when you conquer the world.

fields.headline: Holidays are out when you conquer the world
fields.standfirst: Lois Sealey found swapping homes a daunting task, reports Martyn Seal. So she decided to set up her own listings firm
fields.trailText: Lois Sealey found swapping homes a daunting task, reports Martyn Seal. So she decided to set up her own listings firm.
fields.body:
Home exchanges are a disarmingly simple idea. You find the country and town you want to visit and then exchange homes with a resident. There are little problems, like cleaning up your home and making it presentable. And there are big problems, like not knowing the people you're dealing with and making sure their home is suitable.

This is where Lois Sealey could help. She's been running her home exchange business, Home Base, for the past 16 years and knows all the advantages of such an organisation since it was a home exchange in Canada that first planted the seed of such a business in her head.

"Someone my husband had met happened to have this empty cottage in Ontario and said we could use it," she recalls. "It was idyllic. We couldn't have afforded to rent that kind of place as it was so expensive to get over there. We'd also been concerned about leaving our home in London empty for three weeks. We'd started letting relatives stay while we were away and that's when the idea really gelled. When we got back I started doing research."

She looked through travel articles and the back pages of newspapers. "I was gradually building up quite a folder of information, enough so that I felt confident within a few months to launch my own agency."

Ms Sealey spotted what she thought was a gap in the market for exchanges to Canada and North America. "Because I was raised in Canada I felt I could concentrate on this area. I felt I had specific knowledge, I could offer a more personal service and advise people about parts of the country."

Looking back, she thinks her expectations were naive. "I thought I could conquer the world - just me sitting in my little office in north London. I was going to have members from everywhere instantly. Well of course that didn't happen.

"My biggest break came after about 18 months when I'd built up contacts with several similar small agencies world wide. We found that there was enough interest to form an organisation, The First Home Exchange Alliance, a group of agencies like Home Base that share listings. That gave us a lot of security and was when my idea took off."

While growing up in Canada Ms Sealey had never thought she was the type of person who would run her own business, but her parents, who were farmers in Ontario, influenced her in her chosen career.

"There was no clear line between work and just living. My parents worked very hard but they also got a lot of enjoyment out of what they did. So I think I always had it in mind that you have to find something to do that you enjoy so much you don't think of it as work."

She went to university, did what she describes as 'a useless degree in sociology' - "my mother always points out 'you never did use that degree, did you dear'" - and met her English husband who was doing a Masters degree. "We moved to England in 1968 with no clear idea of what we were going to do," she recalls.

She started working in publishing, but gave up her job when her children were born. Eventually she found a part-time job in a shop. But with school age children she ideally wanted to work from home, which added to the appeal of setting up an agency.

So with the idea in place, what were the difficulties getting it started? "They were partly self-imposed. I didn't have the sort of personality who could comfortably take on a large loan in order to launch business in a big way," she explains. "Because of this the first few years were a slog."

But joining other agencies and reaching more customers via the internet meant the business flourished. It also presented new challenges.

Ms Sealey continues: "Sometimes when I look at all the other agencies that have started up in the last few years I find it rather scary. I have to keep thinking of new ways of marketing the business. But on the other hand, that's what still makes it interesting all these years on."

Although she enjoys her work, she's found that the best thing about it also presents her with its biggest drawback.

"It's difficult to step back from it and take holidays, ironically, so what's good about something can also be bad in the sense that it ties you to it," she says.

webTitle: All stressed up and no place to go

fields.headline: All stressed up and no place to go
fields.standfirst: Some 187m working days and £12bn a year are lost through illness brought on by pressure of work. Liz Stuart reports on a condition that many are forced to endure and takes part in three different kinds of therapy to deal with it
fields.trailText: Stress in the workplace accounts for more days off than the common cold. More than one in 10 senior executives seek medical help because of stress at work and, according to the CBI, stress-related absence accounts for the loss of 187m working days a year in the UK, costing the country £12bn.
fields.body:
Stress in the workplace accounts for more days off than the common cold. More than one in 10 senior executives seek medical help because of stress at work and, according to the CBI, stress-related absence accounts for the loss of 187m working days a year in the UK, costing the country £12bn.

The causes of these crippling levels of stress are by now well known: increased casualisation resulting in the constant need to prove oneself; corporate expansion pushing workers further away from an end product, squashing the satisfaction of productivity; heightened awareness of profitability meaning employees have to work harder and longer; and ownership structures across national boundaries, giving individuals less control over their environment.

The symptoms are also easy to spot: behavioural ones include constant irritability with people, difficulty in making decisions, suppressed anger, loss of sense of humour, feeling unable to cope and wanting to cry at the slightest problem, according to Cary Cooper and Jill Earnshaw, in their book Stress and Employer Liability. Physical symptoms are lack of appetite or craving for food when under pressure, indigestion, insomnia, headaches and a tendency to sweat.

What is more difficult is what to do about it. Legally, following a court case in the 1980s involving a social services officer who suffered a mental breakdown through stress, it is now clear that the employer has a duty to provide a reasonably safe system of work, and employers have recognised that this implies mental as well as physical safety, and have implemented stress management programmes.

However, a report issued late last year by Rob Briner, senior lecturer in organisational psychology at Birkbeck College, London has criticised these programmes.

"Much of what is done in the name of stress has become habitual, knee jerk, uncritical, lacking in innovation and, most importantly, not as helpful as it should be in dealing with the real problems employees and organisations face _ People pathologise ordinary responses to work, like getting depressed or angry. If you go on a course that says these things are killing you, it could make things worse."

In other words, stress is often caused by the structure of a company and it is this problem that needs to be addressed first, rather than the mindset of the employee. But these systemic problems take time to be resolved, and many people are finding their levels of stress intolerable today.

There are some forms of stress management which allow the employee to take the matter into their own hands, and which try to give practical solutions, as well as an opportunity to air negative emotions: the difference between stress coaching and stress counselling.

The International Stress Management Association refers individuals to stress coaches, depending on the person's personality. "Some people may need to play more sport, while others need tangible methods to relax. We vet coaches and refer people to someone who will suit them," says a spokesman. These coaching services may still be paid for by the employer.

The Independent Counselling and Advisory Service has more than 150 corporate clients on its subscriber list, and it offers both a sympathetic ear and practical help. Therapists will talk to clients for as long as is required, and if counselling is not sufficient, pragmatic solutions are also offered. For instance, if the employee is concerned about a relocation, ICAS will help find accommodation in the new town and look up sports facilities or other social outlets. In other words, the support is practical as well as emotional.

Alternative therapists may also offer practical mental and physical exercises to dispel existing stress and avoid it in the future, although their qualifications may not be recognised by the British Psychological Society.

Andy Smith, a London-based therapist, offers some simple tips. "Stress is all about the gap between the demands you perceive are being made on you and your perceived resources to meet those demands. You can manage the demands by saying no to extra work, managing your time better or even downshifting to a less demanding job. Another method is to increase the resources available to you. This can be done by cutting down on caffeine - for many people this is all they need to do. Caffeine mimics adrenaline and raises background stress levels. Cutting it out brings an enormous return for very little effort, as does eating more healthily and learning new skills.

"Finally, you can also change your own perceptions. You respond not to external reality, but to your internal representation of that reality. If you don't like the world as you perceive it, then change your perceptual filters: if you believe you can't do something, you are far less likely to be able to do it," he says.

If you experience panic attacks in the office, this can be dealt with by reducing adrenaline, by cutting the coffee or cigarettes and breathing more calmly. You also need to relax: adrenaline is re- absorbed by the body in two minutes, so relaxing deeply every day allows the adrenaline to drain away and the rest of the day to flow more easily, he adds.

But if you still want to find a traditional therapist who will help deal with stress which has already built up, burrowing its way into your psyche, contact the British Association for Counselling and Psychotherapy.

Counselling on the phone

All the counsellors working for the Independent Counselling and Advisory Service have been approved by the British Association for Counselling and Psychotherapy. Although her tone was perfectly encouraging - and at no time did she indicate that it was time to end the call - I found it difficult to articulate my problem without being able to see her face, and I felt very concerned that I would be boring her. I also feel it would be difficult to call this number from an office: a phone call made at home would have been easier, although this tends to distance you both physically and mentally from the problem. It is, however, a quick, efficient and spontaneous way of countering stress. Contact ICAS on tel: 01908 281 138 or www.icasgroup.com

Counselling online

Online is the logical extension of phone-based counselling and CyberAnalysis, which operates from its premises at www.cyberanalysis.com, where seven UK-trained doctors await your emailed call for help, says that the internet is the ideal medium for therapy, because it allows for regular client and therapist exchanges between the scheduled regular sessions.

It is also easier to email from your desk when a specific issue arises which you feel you need to talk about, rather than whispering down a telephone. The organisation adds that most people find it easier to discuss deeply personal issues when they cannot see their interlocuter. "Using internet chat, the clients are able to set the pace of exchange themselves. It has often been said that clients feel freer to spend some time in between responses to mull over them, often to re-read the therapist's last entry. This enables the client to consider suggestions and interpretations in a little more depth without feeling they have to respond immediately. It also encourages role play as the lack of visual clues serves to enhance the reality of the experience.

The client is given a pseudonym and a password to access the sessions. Homework is given: the clients usually send their e-diary to the therapist every day. Contact CyberAnalysis on www. cyberanalysis.com

Andy Smith decided to retrain as a stress counsellor and success coacher after being "rumbled" as an IT expert. "I had been working as a systems analyst and a consultant, but I was incredibly stressed: I just felt that I didn't know what I was doing. One day it did all go wrong and I felt that I needed to get out of the industry." Clients would normally be seen for three face-to-face sessions (£85 each, plus £5 for a relaxation tape) or are offered a telephone counselling service at £120 a month for three calls of 30 minutes each.

Contact Transformational Training on tel: 020 8743 3064 or www.trance.dircon.co.uk

webTitle: Discount game can offer double benefit or double jeopardy

fields.headline: Discount game can offer double benefit or double jeopardy
fields.standfirst: Jenne Mannion reports on a cheap option for building a portfolio and making capital gains
fields.trailText: Buying shares in an investment trust trading at a wide discount to its net asset value can be a cheap way to hold a portfolio of investments this Isa season.
fields.body:
Buying shares in an investment trust trading at a wide discount to its net asset value can be a cheap way to hold a portfolio of investments this Isa season. If you believe discounts will narrow, there is a capital gain to be made on the share price, which is likely to be advancing.

This double benefit - or double disaster if the reverse happens - is a unique investment trust feature.

And because Isas offer freedom from capital gains, large slices of big wins need not be handed over to the taxman.

Unlike unit trusts, which are priced according to the value of their underlying assets, investment trust shares are affected by supply and demand and do not necessarily reflect the value of the underlying assets.

They usually sell at a discount - for less than the portfolio's total breakup value. The sectors where trusts trade on the widest discounts-to-net asset values are emerging markets (19%) and Japan (13%), a reflection of poor conditions and a lack of interest in owning trusts focusing on these areas.

Other sectors trading on wide discounts are UK smaller companies, now on a natural average discount of 15-17%, excluding unusual circumstance trusts like Eaglet, which is on a premium. Although the UK smaller companies' sector doesn't have a dismal recent performance record, there is an oversupply of trusts in this sector (16 trusts with average assets of £205m), leading to the wide discount.

The global growth (formerly called international generalist) trusts are now trading on an average discount of around 12%.

Nick Greenwood, investment trust analyst at brokers Christows, is confident most discounts on trusts will narrow. The global growth sector was, for example, trading at an average discount of around 20% at this time last year, and is down to 12%. One reason is that managers of these trusts bought back and cancelled some of the shares.

"Vast consolidation in the fund management sector over recent years has led to fewer fund management groups managing funds that are much larger in size," Mr Greenwood says.

"Larger fund sizes mean that managers have no choice but to track some of the bigger companies on the UK market, meaning they are forced to hold some of the bigger investment trusts which are listed on the FTSE 250, such as Foreign & Colonial, Witan and Scottish Mortgage. This demand pushes up the price and sends the discount down," he adds.

Among the global growth trusts generalist Ptarmigan, managed by Colonial First State, is the best buy, trading on a 16% discount, which is wider that most of its peers. Ptarmigan has a broad UK and global exposure, and could sit well as a core portfolio holding. The trust is small, with gross assets of around £24m and has a lot more flexibility than some of the bigger generalists such as Foreign & Colonial and Witan.

There are exciting opportunities in the Japan and global emerging market sectors, but these are very high-risk areas, so investors should hold these trusts only as part of a much wider portfolio.

Aberdeen Emerging, which trades on a 19% discount, is managed by an experienced team at Aberdeen Asset Management. An emerging debt team was recently appointed, which is proving useful. Performance has been good but the discount has not yet narrowed.

There is some speculation that Aberdeen may convert all its conventional investment trusts to split capital trusts (trusts that involve several classes of share). These trusts generally tend to trade on par with their net asset value, so this would abolish the discount.

Meanwhile, GT Japan is trading on a 13% discount. This trust is managed very cautiously, and therefore it could prove a sensible Japanese holding, given the current nervousness in the market.

But trusts in market sectors that are in favour can trade on a premium to net asset value. In the European sector, many of the trusts are trading on a premium, and the average discount is now only 4%.

And more trusts could shrink their discounts if the move by corporate raiders to break up trusts continue.

Scottish Mortgage ran into criticism when it made a deal with predators. Foreign & Colonial has also reacted to rebellious investors but with a more general buyback offer.

Go for a fix

Fixed rate cash mini-Isas are as rare as hen's teeth. But now Portman Building Society has joined the handful with a 6% return for one year. Investments must be £3,000 and no withdrawals are allowed. At the end of the year, the branch based account automatically converts to a variable rate Isa.

Other cash mini-Isa fixed rates include Birmingham Midshires and Norwich & Peterborough.

webTitle: Advisors' forum: Caution can reap rewards.

fields.headline: Caution can reap rewards
fields.standfirst: Teri Harman finds out how to avoid nest-egg disappointment
fields.trailText: Teri Harman finds out how to avoid nest-egg disappointment.
fields.body:
Over the last year UK equities have been volatile, and compared with 12 months ago both the FTSE All Share and the FTSE 100 have fallen sharply - by up to 10% for many investors. If you invested in an Isa last year, particularly a tracker fund, you may be disappointed with its performance and think twice about committing up to £7,000 more of your savings this year.

But what do the financial advising experts think? Spinning a yarn about how I'd got my fingers burnt in a tracker fund last year, I set out to take a straw poll among independent financial advisers chosen at random.

The general consensus is that Isas are still a must if you have the cash. Ian Williams, of Marshall Williams in Horsham, was bullish. He said: "The fact that the stock market is currently volatile is really irrelevant. An Isa is a tax wrapper, and it's important that you obtain and hold onto this wrapper, because if you miss the opportunity in any given tax year, it's lost for good".

Opinions were divided on where I should put my money. Joanne Russell, of Alexander Forbes' Croydon office, understood my disappointment with last year's tracker, suggesting that I put £3,000 into a cash mini-Isa with the Nationwide, currently paying 6.2%.

She faxed me a list of low-risk equity options for another £3,000, including Aberdeen Asset Management's fixed-interest Isa, Newton's High Yield Bond and Norwich Union's insurance mini-Isa, into which I could put the last £1,000.

Colin Larkin, of Metcalf Moat in Orpington, advised against another tracker fund. He called them "a high-risk option because of the dominance of high technology shares in the FTSE".

A managed fund, despite higher charges, is a better option; the stock market fall means now is a good time to invest. Isas are ideal for a 10-to 15-year period, he said, and now we are in a global economy a "themed" fund would be a good option.

Judith Kirk, of Partridge Muir & Warren in Tolworth, Surrey, also stressed the tax advantages of Isas and said I would be wrong to be put off by the short-term volatility of equities. She thought I should opt for a "more conventional growth fund to balance the volatility of the tracker fund" I said I'd bought last year.

She favoured either Jupiter's, Deutsche's or ABN Ambro's UK Growth funds, or Fidelity's Wealthbuilder.

Colin Peck of Berry Birch & Noble in West Wickham, Kent, sensibly suggested that a good way to invest, if I was slightly cautious, was to choose an Isa fund manager that allows you to "drip feed" the money in. As long as you hand over the full £7,000 to the fund managers before the end of the tax year, it counted as this year's allowance.

They hold the money in a deposit account, earning a modest rate of interest, and pay into your Isa in regular instalments, so not all the money is invested when prices are high.

All agreed that no one can predict with certainty how the stock market will perform over the next year, but most said "City experts" were predicting a rise of around 7%. We'll see.

fields.headline: Fear stalks the markets
fields.standfirst: Wall Street in the grip of 'triple witching' effect as London sees its fifth-biggest drop
fields.trailText: Wall Street in the grip of 'triple witching' effect as London sees its fifth-biggest drop.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York, and  Larry Elliott
fields.body:
Stock markets on both sides of the Atlantic ended a miserable week last night with further declines as disappointing earnings figures and downbeat economic data from the US increased fears of recession.

London's FTSE 100 index suffered its fifth biggest points fall on record, dropping 166.4 points to 5562.8, a decline of more than 350 points on the week.

In New York, where the markets are hoping for a hefty cut in interest rates from the Federal Reserve next week, the Dow Jones Industrial Average of blue chip stocks lost 152 points, or 1.5%, to fall below 10,000 within an hour of opening.

Although around half the loss had been recouped by the early afternoon, the index of blue chip shares has declined by over 6% since the start of the week. The Nasdaq composite index of largely hi-tech shares fell to well below 2,000, a decline of 62% since last March.

Several traders believe that US stock markets have further to fall. Art Hogan, chief market analyst at brokerage Jefferies & Co, said: "Nobody really feels in any great urgency to go back in and bottom fish."

Robert Shiller, professor of economics at Yale University, pointed out that even after this week's declines, both the S&P and the Nasdaq were trading well above historic averages. In the 98 years to 1995, the S&P traded on an average price to earnings multiple of 14. Yesterday, the index was still trading at more than 20, according to Prof Shiller, who last year wrote Irrational Exuberance, about the stock market bubble.

He said there was unlikely to be a specific catalyst for a continued slide. "The market doesn't need any news. All it needs is no further good news."

Yesterday's economic data provided little good news. The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index increased slightly to 91.8 from 90.6 in February. It showed that two-thirds of Americans believe the economy is in a recession.

US wholesale prices, measured by the Producer Price Index, increased only 0.1% last month. Stripping out volatile food and energy costs, the PPI fell 0.3%, the steepest decline since a 1.2% drop in August 1993.

Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, said the figures showed "some evidence of the beginning of deflation pressure in the economy".

Some of yesterday's volatility was caused by the so-called "triple witching" effect - a quarterly stock market event that sees the simultaneous expiration of futures, options and index contracts.

fields.headline: Vosper vessels save 450 jobs
fields.trailText: Vosper Thornycroft yesterday said 450 jobs have been safeguarded for at least two years after the Ministry of Defence awarded the company a £60m contract to build three new vessels.
fields.body:
Vosper Thornycroft yesterday said 450 jobs have been safeguarded for at least two years after the Ministry of Defence awarded the company a £60m contract to build three new vessels.

The offshore patrol vessels will be built at Vosper's Southampton shipyard and will replace ships used to protect fishing grounds and oil and gas installations. Vosper will support the ships and keep them in service for five years. Shares in the company reacted positively rising 40p to £11.65.

Vosper chief executive Martin Jay said he was thrilled to win the contract. "It provides the bridge we need to keep our highly skilled workforce together while we finalise matters on the Type 45 [destroyer] and hopefully win new export work," he said.

Vosper warned at the end of last year that it would have to cut 650 jobs because of a lack of short term work. A spokesman said 73 workers had left the company at the end of last year and without additional contracts another 70 jobs will go during 2001.

The long term future of Vosper remains uncertain. The MoD announced plans to award contracts to build 12 Type 45 destroyers last summer and the first three were to have been shared by BAE Systems and Vosper, with construction due to begin in 2003.

At the end of last year BAE launched a sole bid for all 12 vessels to be built in its northern shipyards. John Weston, BAE chief executive, has argued that the company's yards in Scotland and Cumbria are better suited than Vosper to handle the work.

Vosper in turn has told the government it would be "turning its back on competition" if it awarded the entire contract to BAE.

The MoD is expected to make its decision in the next few weeks.

 Armoured vehicle maker Alvis announced record order intake during 2000 and a better than expected full year profit of £13.4m. The group, which builds the 27-tonne Warrior vehicles used by the British army in the Gulf War and the Balkans, cautioned that sales and operating profits for the current year would not match 2000 levels.

webTitle: Comment: Blair 's bay of pigs (and sheep)

fields.headline: Blair 's bay of pigs (and sheep)
fields.standfirst:
Where JFK had a nuclear stand-off, Blair has an election date crisis

Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: election countdown
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Where JFK had a nuclear stand-off, Blair has an election date crisis.
fields.body:
In the movie Thirteen Days, which opened yesterday, lookalikes of Jack and Bobby Kennedy avert the third world war during the Cuban missile crisis of 1962. It's a long, slow film - and has been criticised for this - but uses the time and space to illustrate something rarely seen and crucial: the agonising and treacherous process of political decision making. Caught between a war-hungry military and civilian aides wary of reducing their own and other countries to charred rubble, JFK, not yet two years a president, must make choices which will shape the future.

The film sentimentalises Kennedy - ignoring, for example, historical suggestions that his nuclear-powered libido may not have been confined to its silo even as the world faced armageddon - but it serves as a timely corrective to current thinking. We live in a time when it has become standard to regard politicians as venal or idiotic figures, largely ceremonial leaders steered through their displays of fakery by spin doctors. Thirteen Days reminds us of what democracy may come to: a leader alone in a room, knowing that going with Plan A or B may affect the lives of millions or hundreds of millions of people; it manages to depict the process of political thinking.

Watching Bruce Greenwood's imitation of JFK, I thought frequently of Tony Blair. The comparisons were not those for which Alastair Campbell might hope - boyish grin, charisma, rich wife, indelible place in history - but rather the feeling that Blair is fast approaching the decisions on which his career and eventual reputation depend. Where Kennedy had Bay of Pigs and the 1962 nuclear stand-off, Blair faces his Bay of Cows and Sheep and the election date crisis.

Media election coverage frequently makes use of the phrase "decision day". But there is compelling evidence that the decision day that really matters is the one when the leader comes to a verdict which overshadows the rest of his or her administration.

John Major's premiership was effectively over when he spent the national financial reserves on supporting the pound against George Soros and other financial speculators. After that, he was politically a dead man waiting for a grave. Jimmy Carter was sealed as a one-term leader when he agreed to a botched rescue mission for the hostages in Iran. Leadership consists of thousands of decisions and signatures but, finally, a single one of them can topple you.

Sometimes, the dangerous call is the one that looks easy. Margaret Thatcher survived the hardest decision a leader can make - the commitment of your troops to war - but ensured her removal from office by making the wrong choice over a replacement for the rates. Even someone so certain must, when sleepless in the jet speeding between highly paid speeches, replay in her head with a different outcome the moment when she agreed to the poll tax.

Tony Blair's decision day is looming and I don't mean May 3. While still leader of the opposition, Blair gave an intriguing interview to an Easter Sunday newspaper about his religious beliefs. He explained that the historical figure with whom he most identified was Pontius Pilate. Blair saw Christ's reluctant judge as representing the ultimate political dilemma: the leader agonising between the right decision and the popular one. What seems to be a brilliant tactical move (offering the mob Barabbas as an alternative candidate to the maverick preacher) goes wrong. There weren't tabloids in Palestine but the broad outlines of a political crisis remain recognisable.

In the four years since May 1997, Blair must have wondered when his own Pilate night would come. He most feared, we can suppose, a collapse of the pound, a total breakdown of the Irish peace process or a new war in the Gulf. He avoided these and his moment of decision comes down to the lives of sheep and cows and the timing of his plea for another shot of power. Does he risk being seen as a man who put his own political life before the countryside? What might be the political consequences?

William Hague isn't Khrushchev and foot and mouth is no nuclear winter: it's unlikely that, in 39 years' time, Hollywood will make a movie called 28 Days about the British meat crisis, but Blair will come to understand in the next two weeks the truth contained in Thirteen Days: that politics finally comes down to deciding between alternatives which, in the end, determine your journey through history.

The opinion polls (the latest suggesting that Hague has the political bounce of a burned cow) will give Blair hope but he must worry about the possibility of the 1992 effect: when voters were too embarrassed to admit to pollsters that they planned to vote Tory. No recent leader has seemed as dependent on advisers as Blair, but this is a room that the prime minister enters alone.

At the point of decision, polling data and history books and Alastair Campbell will count for nothing. Not even the inevitable sneaky little phone call to Peter in Hartlepool or Notting Hill can help. (Mandelson, we may remember, was codenamed "Bobby", after Robert Kennedy, during a previous spell in exile.) Blair has to close his eyes and jump, trusting his own judgment.

After his own moment of decision, Pontius Pilate called a photo-op in which he wiped his hands of the whole business but that won't wash for Blair. Quite unexpectedly, his premiership has entered its critical period.

webTitle: Panic is the wrong stock response

fields.headline: Panic is the wrong stock response
fields.standfirst: Taking a Big Brother view of the crisis could lead to a lemming-like rush for the precipice
fields.trailText: Taking a Big Brother view of the crisis could lead to a lemming-like rush for the precipice
fields.body:
As light relief from the traumas of the stock market, I've turned to a racy account of an infamous fracas between the philosophers Ludwig Wittgenstein and Karl Popper in 1946, and Celebrity Big Brother in 2001. Both, inadvertently, have much to tell us about the perils of financial forecasting.

A new book called Wittgenstein's Poker seeks the truth behind the famous argument between the two philosophers at their only meeting. There were few witnesses, but there are many versions of events. A poker was brandished, but was it red hot? Were insults thrown to face, or muttered to a retreating back?

Authors David Edmonds and John Eidinow rummage through the memory banks of the surviving witnesses but understandably fail to establish a definitive version of events. Perspective is a personal thing and can be impervious to the enquiries of those armed with alternative versions of events.

All investors would do well to keep this in mind as they apply their own experiences to the current conundrums posed by markets. Expletives aside, "what do you think?" must constitute the most heavily used phrase among stockbrokers and their clients at present. Exactly what one thinks must be heavily influenced by personal history and current circumstances.

I've worked through a couple of bear markets - the world in 1987-88 and Japan from 1989 to date - and a handful of bear snaps. These short sharp corrections include those triggered by the Gulf war, sterling's final unhappy months in the ERM, the surprise rise in US interest rates in 1994 and the Russian-LTCM crisis.

When I'm feeling at my most insecure, I can't decide whether this is too much or too little experience. And of course I've all the memories of the great bull markets between these bear phases swirling around my mind too.

Conventional wisdom would have it that one can't have too much experience when share prices are falling, but that the reverse is true when prices are rising. As if to support this view, Warren Buffett is once again being hailed as the world's greatest investor, only a year after being derided for missing out on the dot.com boom.

Length of experience is not all, however. Very recent experience, innate ability, and the character one was born with all play parts in shaping attitudes to investment crises. This is particularly true of the current collapse. The most bearish market players currently are those who - for whatever reason - got carried away in the preceding boom.

My intuition today is to begin to buy equities. But you need to know that this is the opinion of a man who missed out on the opportunities that abounded in the boom - missed out because he's too cautious/lazy/cynical to be a good personal investor.

Just as dentists suffer halitosis, so stockbrokers can be notoriously bad at deploying their private funds. In some cases this takes the form of avoiding the market, in others of paying insufficient attention to it and, as a result, timing purchases and sales poorly.

A quirky buy signal for me this week was the lemming-like rush of a number of my colleagues to liquidate vast tracts of their investment portfolios. On Wednesday, with the UK market down more than 3%, they dashed for cash. Too busy advising clients, it had taken a precipitate drop in share prices to focus their attention closer to home. When the last bull turns bearish...

Statistics and charts are the traditional refuge of investment strategists at times such as these.

Historical averages for valuations, market levels and movements can constitute a welcome respite from emotionally charged commentary. However, they can also carry a dangerously spurious air of authority.

Stock markets are rarely fairly valued. Averages are merely arithmetical observations - they are not prescriptive. Last year share prices were sustained for a prolonged period at valuations significantly above long term trends. Now values are marginally below the historical averages. This does not necessitate rising prices.

The fragile state of equity markets is undeniable. But the state of real economies is moot (leaving aside the basket case that is Japan). Quoted companies are falling over themselves to get bad news into the markets, but this may tell us more about the black arts of expectations management than about the state of economies.

From my perspective, with my fingers unsinged, it seems that the realisation that economies are slowing not collapsing will, in due course, turn the market tide. Finessing this turn will prove as difficult for investors as all turning points are. But I'd rather begin to be a buyer now than when the lemmings are all scrambling to climb back up the cliff.

Remember that this is a view from the inside and, rather like that of the Big Brother celebs, it reflects a reality that might appear very different from a detached outsider's perspective. Sometimes one can get too close to the action. And, as Vanessa Feltz demonstrated, just a little unhinged too.

Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities


edmondw@omsecurities.co.uk

webTitle: Bidder balks at 60p share price for Clubhaus

fields.headline: Bidder balks at 60p share price for Clubhaus
fields.trailText: Golfing and country club business Clubhaus, which revealed in December it was in £60m takeover talks, said yesterday the potential bidder was refusing to pay the expected 60p a share to ordinary shareholders.
fields.body:
Golfing and country club business Clubhaus, which revealed in December it was in £60m takeover talks, said yesterday the potential bidder was refusing to pay the expected 60p a share to ordinary shareholders.

Clubhaus is still in talks with the proposed buyer, understood to be American venture capital firm Compass Partners, but was also in discussions with several other parties.

Clubhaus, which owns clubs in Britain, Germany, France and Spain said the bidder has "indicated a willingness" to make an offer for the company, but at a lower level. The reduction is partly due to the company's debt situation.

Clubhaus raised £60m through bonds in 1999 but because of a complex series of agreements Compass would have been required to pay a "higher than expected price" to the bond holders. Compass therefore reduced the amount it is offering ordinary shareholders.

Shares in Clubhaus, which have fallen 50% in the past 12 months, dropped 3.5p to 43p yesterday after the company said that a bid at a reduced level was not "in the best interests of the ordinary shareholders".

Clubhaus has asked the bidder to "re-jig their package", Charlie Parker, Clubhaus's managing director said.

A source close to the negotiations said: "Compass was keen on the deal and the management team at Clubhaus but the bond holders simply asked too much."

Clubhaus emphasised it is in talks with a number of other parties which if "successfully concluded would involve Clubhaus acquiring or, if more beneficial to Clubhaus shareholders, being acquired by another substantial UK based leisure business".

Mr Parker said the preferred option would depend where the value lies for the ordinary shareholders.

"I am confident that there will be a successful outcome," Mr Parker said.

Rival leisure group Crown Sport has bought 3.86% of Clubhaus, but is not believed to be one of the companies Clubhaus is talking to.

fields.headline: Caffe Nero says it still has the taste for a float
fields.trailText: Caffe Nero, the high street coffee bar chain, yesterday said it would brave the turbulent market conditions by pressing ahead with its listing on the LSE.
fields.body:
Caffe Nero, the high street coffee bar chain, yesterday said it would brave the turbulent market conditions by pressing ahead with its listing on the LSE.

The company is making its stock market debut at the end of next week after raising £9m to fund further expansion; the firm plans to open more than 40 coffee bars over the year.

One of a number of branded coffee chains mushrooming on Britain's high streets, Caffe Nero said the fundraising valued the group at £33.7m.

It is placing 18m ordinary shares of 0.5p each at a price of 50p per share.

"Over the past four years, we have established a distinctive Italian brand that has proven the potential of the Caffe Nero format," said Gerry Ford, Caffe Nero's chairman and chief executive. "With rapid growth in the UK branded coffee bar market, now is the time to capitalise on our success to date and use the proceeds of our flotation to accelerate our expansion plans."

He said the group was going ahead with its float despite the present uncertainty because it wanted to pursue its expansion programme.

Caffe Nero, which sells an Italian blend of coffee and Italian food including pasta and sandwiches, was founded in 1997 with five sites and now has 58 branches. It is opening new cafes at a rate of three to four a month, and is considering accelerating its expansion of divisions to up to four or five a month.

According to a recent report by Allegra Strategies, a management consultancy, the UK market for gourmet coffee is growing rapidly. The number of cups of espresso-based coffee served in branded chains is expected to rise from 3.9m in 2000 to 7.2m in 2003.

The consultancy estimated that the total revenue of branded chains such as Caffe Nero, Coffee Republic and Costa Coffee, reached £544m last year and predicted the UK market would grow by 6.3% annually between 2000 and 2003.

fields.headline: Dolly the sheep firm seeks £45m
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: PPL Therapeutics, the company that cloned Dolly the sheep, yesterday said it would brave the turbulence of the stock markets by initiating a £45m fundraising.
fields.body:
PPL Therapeutics, the company that cloned Dolly the sheep, yesterday said it would brave the turbulence of the stock markets by initiating a £45m fundraising.

The Edinburgh-based firm said the cash would be used to develop new products, fund further clinical trials and provide further working capital until its main drug hits the market in 2004. It will also enable PPL to buy a second farm in New Zealand and expand its production of sheep flocks.

PPL is trying to raise money at a tricky time for biotech firms. Scottish heart valve firm AorTech was last week forced to pull a £64m share issue but gene therapy firm Oxford Biomedia has said it will press ahead with plans to raise up to £37m. "The markets are difficult but we wouldn't have launched this if we weren't confident of getting there," managing director Dr Ron James said.

"The fundraising has been flagged to the market for some time and investors know we need more money. They're saying that they'd rather we just got on and raised the cash, rather than hang around."

Shares in PPL slipped 8.5p to 148p. PPL has just £2.45m in the bank and analysts have long expected PPL to launch the fundraising. webTitle: Hartford changes menu as losses double

fields.headline: Hartford changes menu as losses double
fields.trailText: Restaurant group Hartford is likely to move down market to capture diners, after a set of disappointing results from its London eateries.
fields.body:
Restaurant group Hartford is likely to move down market to capture diners, after a set of disappointing results from its London eateries.

Best known for its fashionable Pharmacy restaurant in Notting Hill - and celebrity backers including shark-pickling artist Damien Hirst - the group announced £3.2m operating losses - doubling the £1.6m losses it recorded during 1999.

Turnover improved slightly to £7.25m in 2000, compared with £6.9m the previous year. The company's shares, listed on the Alternative Investment Market, were unchanged at 6.25p.

"We strongly believe that the future of the group will be secured through the adoption of a less elitist approach to the eating and drinking market, coupled with a more rigorous, commercial approach," said Stephen Thomas, the company's recently appointed chairman.

The new-look operations are likely to be a far cry from the supermodel-infested bars of Pharmacy. The model will be the company's gastro-pub in Ascot - with a second opening by Easter in Loughton, Essex - similar to the successful All Bar One chain operated by Bass, offering restaurant meals and a range of wines as well as beer by the pint.

The repositioning comes after the company's troubles last November, when the group's high-profile backers - including corporate spin-doctor Matthew Freud and property tycoon Nigel Wray - stepped down after Hartford's market value slumped from £20m to £2.5m in just eight months.

They were replaced by a new team led by Mr Thomas, who operates the nightclub company Luminar, and Sheila McKenzie, best known for founding the Pitcher and Piano bar chain, who joined as chief executive.

Ms McKenzie said the results from the pubs in Ascot and Loughton will be monitored for several months before going ahead with further sites. "We'll probably stay away from the high street, where rents are very high, so we are looking for something less expensive than the Slug and Lettuce or Pitcher and Piano," she said.

Ms McKenzie agreed that the company's showbiz status - Hirst owns a 5% stake - had been a burden to its restaurants' finer points. "Pharmacy is a great restaurant, but no-one ever mentions that because of the celebrity stuff," she said.

fields.headline: M&S gets a lift
fields.trailText: It was not reports that it is considering closing seven of its 38 European outlets that sent Marks & Spencer shares up 9.25p to 222.25p yesterday. The rise was due to an 83-page research note from Deutsche Bank, in which the German broker lifted its rating to "buy" and set an optimistic 290p target.
fields.body:
It was not reports that it is considering closing seven of its 38 European outlets that sent Marks & Spencer shares up 9.25p to 222.25p yesterday. The rise was due to an 83-page research note from Deutsche Bank, in which the German broker lifted its rating to "buy" and set an optimistic 290p target.

Deutsche believes the probability of a recovery in the next 12 months is higher than it was a year ago. It thinks the radical shake-up of M&S's internal operations and the restructuring of the British clothing market could lead to a recovery in pre-tax profits from an expected £452.7m this year to £540m in 2002.

It says there is a technical reason why the shares should advance. With 30 of the City's biggest institutions either non-holders or underweight in M&S stock, it reckons they will need to consider increasing their holdings should the retailer begin to show signs of a recovery.

fields.headline: At this price?  RMC
fields.trailText: To say 2000 was an annus horribilis for RMC, the construction materials group, is probably understating things. Everything that could go possibly wrong did so.
fields.body:
To say 2000 was an annus horribilis for RMC, the construction materials group, is probably understating things. Everything that could go possibly wrong did so.

Rugby, the cement group it acquired for £896m in 1999, turned out to be in much worse shape than it imagined. Atrocious weather affected demand for building materials in Europe, while the recession in the German building market resumed and fuel costs shot up.

Analysts had to downgrade their forecasts on at least three occasions last year and RMC developed a reputation as a serial profits warner.

It was hardly surprising, therefore, that RMC delivered a set of lacklustre figures yesterday. Pre-tax profits before exceptionals in 2000 fell 32% to £208.3m. Germany, which accounted for around 25% of revenue, saw earnings slump by 35%.

The figures do not tell the full story. In the past six months Stuart Walker, RMC's newish chief executive, has been busy licking the business into shape.

Jobs have been cut, exposure to Germany reduced. The integration of Rugby is complete and its DIY operation, Great Mills, was off-loaded for a profit of £228m.

Mr Walker says the job is only half done. In the coming year he plans to reduce group debt to £1.3bn through the sales of non-core assets. The company is already in talks to sell its German-based subsidiary, Ytong.

With the £30m of synergies from the Rugby acquisition coming on stream, RMC seems to have turned the corner. Analysts expect the company to make around £275m of profits this year, which after yesterday's fall of 45p to 635p, puts the shares on a price-earnings ratio of 10. This is cheap compared to its sector rivals.

Of course the company remains a major cyclical play and investors should remember that 20% of sales come from the slowing north America economy. For those prepared to take the long view the shares are a buy.
