fields.headline: Software stocks hit hard
fields.trailText: Another day, another victim. Yesterday it was the turn of Sage , the accountancy software company, to feel the consequences of the slowdown on the other side of the Atlantic.
fields.body:
Another day, another victim. Yesterday it was the turn of Sage , the accountancy software company, to feel the consequences of the slowdown on the other side of the Atlantic.

Sage dropped 41.5p to 260p as investors dumped the stock after hearing that Intuit, a rival US accounting software vendor, had warned of slower than expected revenue growth.

Noting that Intuit had cited weaker than expected demand at Quickbooks - the main competitor to Peachtree, one of Sage's US divisions - analysts at ABN Amro immediately lowered their rating on the company to "hold" from "add". They also expressed concern at Intuit's intention to move up the value chain and compete with Sage's other US subsidiary, Sage Software.

The news rekindled fears that Sage will miss its earnings forecasts this year. Over the past few months, several analysts have expressed concern about Sage's exposure to the slowing sales cycles in the US. Paradoxically, Sage was forced to expand in North America after cornering the British market.

Sage was not the only software issue to suffer yesterday. Autonomy , down 171p to £10.19,Logica , off 174p to £11.51 and Misys , 50p worse at 560p, were all marked sharply lower following gloomy comments from Oracle.

Predicting a flat performance in its traditionally strong fourth quarter, the world's second largest software group said the slowing US economy had hit database and application software sales hard.

The sell-off in software stocks, combined with weakness in the telecoms and banking sectors, helped to drive the leading shares to a fresh 27-month closing low.

The FTSE 100 fell 166.4 points - the fifth biggest one- day drop on record - to end at 5,562.8, extending this week's losses to 354.5 points.

Meanwhile, the FTSE TechMark 100 fell 103.32 points to close at 2,068.93.

The fuel for the decline came from another weak showing on Wall Street. Rocked by a profits warning from computer maker Compaq and a surprise rise in US consumer sentiment - which dashed hopes of a jumbo rate cut at next week's Federal Reserve meeting - the Dow Jones industrials and the tech-heavy Nasdaq opened lower.

Telecoms stocks were among the hardest hit by the gloomy sentiment. BT fell to below 500p at one point before recovering to close down 27p at 505p. Vodafone shed 8p to 200p, Colt Telecom fell 101p to 895p and Marconi lost 35p to close at 392p.

Lower down the market, traders were scrambling for stock ahead of the changes to the FTSE indices, which take effect on Monday.

Most of the action focused on web analysis group Eyretel , up 17.5p to 111.5p, pub company Regent Inns, 28p higher at 202p, and MacDonald Ho tels , 6p stronger at 183.5p. All three were kicked out of the All Share index at the last review in December for not providing adequate information relating to liquidity.

Following an appeal, they will be re-admitted on Monday, and this has meant institutions which track the All Share index have been forced to buy to maintain an accurate weighting.

Elsewhere, traders were keeping a wary eye on Kidde , the fire protection company spun out of Williams.

The stock has fallen sharply for the past three sessions and the gossips in the City suspect that a profits warning could be on the way.

Analysts were not so sure, but noted that as Kidde makes about 60% of its profits in North America, it is probably vulnerable. Kidde closed 1.5p weaker at 71p.

Software group Recognition Systems fell back 20p to 110p on speculation that it has failed to close two major deals, while support services group Andrew Sykes improved 8.5p to 87.5p on rekindled management buyout speculation. Dealers noted that Jacques Murray, Sykes's chairman, holds a 55.6% stake.

fields.headline: Prices fall for second year as Japan slides into deflation
fields.standfirst: Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: Japan yesterday woke up to the news its policymakers had been dreading for years with a government warning that the country was infected with deflation.
fields.body:
Japan yesterday woke up to the news its policymakers had been dreading for years with a government warning that the country was infected with deflation.

For the first time in the postwar era, the government recognised the presence of this disease in its monthly health check of the world's second largest economy, which has been weakened by a vicious circle of sluggish spending, falling prices and shrinking corporate profits.

Japan's consumer price index fell 0.4% in 2000 after a 0.3% fall the previous year - meeting the international definition for deflation, which is two consecutive annual declines in prices.

Taro Aso, state minister for economic and fiscal policy, said the condition was "mild", but he warned that its psychological impact could grow.

No other developed economy is suffering from deflation, which was last seen on a global scale during the great depression of the 1930s.

"Internationally and historically, it is very rare for the consumer price index to fall for two years in a row," said cabinet office economist Haruhito Arai, who diagnosed the trend as "virulent."

The cabinet office downgraded its assessment of the economy, which is bigger than the rest of Asia combined, for the second consecutive month.

Its monthly report said Japan had "paused" - a term last used in January 1998, shortly before a currency, stock market and banking crisis that threat ened to undermine the global financial system.

While insisting that the economy was still on a long-term course towards growth, the cabinet office report blamed downward pressure on external factors such as the slowdown in the United States and many export-dependent Asian economies.

But it could not entirely ignore domestic factors. A combination of rising un employment and renewed concerns about the banking sector is dampening consumers' urge to splurge.

The sharp decline of share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange since the start of the year has raised doubts about the health of many banks, who need unrealised gains on their stock holdings to write off an estimated 30 trillion yen (£171bn) in non-performing loans.

fields.headline: Window on history
fields.standfirst:
Canterbury's glass glory restored
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Canterbury's glass glory restored
fields.body:
Two stained glass windows at Canterbury Cathedral dating from shortly after the death of Thomas Becket have been returned to their former glory following three years of restoration work.

The windows, among the oldest to survive intact, are also the most ancient part of the cathedral above ground level only the crypt is older. They were originally made by men who would have seen Becket alive.

They were installed within a few years of the archbishop's assassination by four knights in the cathedral in the winter of 1170 and have survived not only nine centuries of English weather but assaults by Puritans and Victorian attempts at restoration.

Only 33 panels of an original 208 showing scenes from the Old and New Testaments survive, most of the rest have been smashed in the religious upheavals of the 17th century.

The windows were made during rebuilding work after the old cathedral was burned to the ground shortly after Becket's death. Canterbury Cathedral spends more than £500,000 a year on maintenance and restoration. Both windows now shine with bright greens, yellows and reds.

They include a panel showing the clean-shaven young Christ, crowned with a bright red halo, disputing with the baffled and bearded doctors in the temple at Jerusalem. Another shows the three kings - who were warned in a dream not to give away the whereabouts of the baby Jesus to Herod - innocently snuggled up in bed together, still wearing their crowns, while an angel hovers by the bedpost to make sure they get the message. The windows were taken down for restoration in September 1998 and have been cleaned with de-ionised water, their lead-work repaired and paint pigments consolidated.

They are to be protected from the elements by exterior double glazing.

Sebastian Strobl, the director of the cathedral's restoration studio said: "To be allowed to return one of the cathedral's chief glories to its former beauty is something very special."

fields.headline: White farmers denounce ANC 'land grab'
fields.standfirst: South Africa is accused of following Zimbabwe's example after a farm is returned to its original black owners
fields.trailText: South Africa is accused of following Zimbabwe's example after a farm is returned to its original black owners
fields.body:
Several hundred South African farmers yesterday denounced the government's expropriation of a white-owned farm as the start of a Zimbabwe-style "land grab".

In the first seizure of its kind since the end of apartheid, the state will take over Willem Pretorius's 1,200-hectare (3,000-acre) cattle ranch on Tuesday, after he turned down an offer of compensation he claims is too low. The land, near the eastern town of Lydenburg, will be returned to the Dinkwanyane community which was driven off it by force in 1961 as the apartheid regime stole black-owned property and sold it to whites.

White farmers - already embittered by the murder of more than 100 of their number across South Africa last year - crammed Lydenburg's church yesterday to hear leaders of the Transvaal Agricultural Union condemn the expropriation.

"The monstrous way in which land is taken from whites and given to others is blatant discrimination and racism and is precisely what Mugabe has done in Zimbabwe, only in a concealed form," the union's president, Gert Ehlers, said. "[The union] confirms its support of Willem Pretorius and will as far as possible resist this process of land theft."

But for all the union's excitable claims, there are few parallels with Zimbabwe.

There is a growing demand from dispossessed black peasants for land, and occasional threats by them to follow the Zimbabwe example by occupying white-owned farms, which still account for most arable land in South Africa. But the government has said it will not tolerate occupations. It has followed a clear legal process in redistributing land; no one has invaded Mr Pretorius's farm and those claiming his property did once live on it.

The land claims commission has already settled more than 11,000 cases by mutual agreement on compensation. Even Mr Pretorius's neighbours, the Jouberts, whose farm also once belonged to the Dinkwanyane, are taking the money and moving out.

But Mr Pretorius, 49, says that while he believes his farm should return to its former owners, he wants what they did not get 40 years ago - the full value of the property. He argues that the farm he bought from the apartheid regime in 1982 is worth four times what the present government is offering.

"There was nothing here, nothing at all. I built this house. I built every fence, everything," he said. "I've got nothing against blacks owning land but they must buy it. There are plenty of farms for sale. Why didn't they buy one?"

The Dinkwanyane community did buy a 4,000 hectare farm called Boomplaats in 1906. By all accounts it thrived, mainly growing fruit, and grazing cattle, which is probably why it caught the apartheid government's eye in the mid-1950s and was declared to be "whites-only" property.

The Dinkwanyane were at first offered other, poorer qual ity, land 30 miles away, taken from a white farmer who received proper compensation.

fields.headline: Scientific elite put under microscope
fields.standfirst: Moves to open Royal Society to more women and computer technologists
fields.trailText: Moves to open Royal Society to more women and computer technologists
fields.body:
Even in the hoariest circles of the British establishment, clubs do not come much more exclusive than the Royal Society. Its very name speaks of prior claim. Not the Royal Society of anything. Money or looks will not buy membership of this elite academy of science, an honour so craved that distinguished researchers have been reduced to nervous wrecks in anticipation.

Peerages can be bought. Good connections can open many doors. But only brains can get you the right to put the magical letters FRS - Fellow of the Royal Society - after your name. So it was thought. Now the venerable institution is aquiver from the suggestion that even brains may not be enough.

It is a difficult accusation to ignore: it comes from the new president, the outspoken former government chief scientist Sir Robert May. He is asking, clearly and publicly, why the society has only 44 women out of 1,200 fellows; whether there is a bias towards Oxford and Cambridge; and why some of the highest achievers in non-traditional disciplines, such as information technology, have been passed over. He cited Tim Berners-Lee, the Briton who invented the internet in the form we use it today. Last year the society gave him a medal, but it never occurred to anyone to suggest he be made a fellow.

"That's a concrete example of somebody who, while working in a powerhouse of mainstream science - the European particle physics laboratory, CERN, in Switzerland - was doing something that wasn't in the mainstream," said Sir Robert. "So nobody thought to nominate him. People do slip between the cracks."

Sir Robert will not be drawn on other specific omissions. But it is striking how few of the British scientists whom the public have heard of are fellows. The astrophysicist Stephen Hawking is a fellow. So is Sir John Sulston who led the British end of the international project to sequence the human genome. But Richard Dawkins, the biologist and author of The Selfish Gene and The Blind Watchmaker, is not. Nor is Susan Greenfield, the distinguished pharmacologist and broadcaster. Nor is the in vitro fertilisation guru Lord Robert Winston.

Public forum

Sir Robert, who took over as president in December, promises to take forward reforms quietly set in motion by his predecessor, Aaron Klug. He wants to bring back an old rule whereby popularisers of science, such as David Attenborough, could be made fellows. "We need to create an additional mechanism that recognises that as one of the legitimate categories for inclusion to the society." "

He wants to turn the society from a decorous, aloof body of the wise into the leading public forum of scientific debate. "I'm unhappy, as many of the fellows are, about the small number of women in the society. There are only 16 under the age of 65 who live in the UK, compared with about 400 men. Are we being aggressive enough in nominating women, or people from universities that aren't Oxford and Cambridge?"

Founded in the 17th century, the Royal Society has had Samuel Pepys, Christopher Wren and Ernest Rutherford among its past presidents. Isaac Newton was president for 24 years. It occupies one of the grandest addresses in London, a palatial building near Pall Mall which housed the pre-war German embassy.

Joining the Royal Society is hard. When Dorothy Hodgkin discovered the structure of penicillin, an eminent male colleague, John Bernal, told her she would win the Nobel Prize. She said she would rather be an FRS, like he was. "That's more difficult," said Bernal.

Eventually Hodgkin won both honours, but waiting to be elected takes its toll on the scientific elite. "There is a disease called FRSitis, in which people become absolutely twitchy, because it's seen as a matter of such great prestige," said one female fellow. "There really are people who worry about it terribly. They make themselves quite ill; they become anxious, depressed, miserable, impossible to live with."

Sir Robert is familiar with the condition: "The initials do carry a huge prestige. And in Britain, which is very good at creating snobby hierarchies, they're probably invested with more psychic significance than is healthy," he said. "But they do that because they stand for a society that articulates the highest standards of science."

Steve Jones, professor of genetics at University College London and a high-profile writer and broadcaster on evolution, said he was "too thick" to be elected an FRS, but was grateful to the society for giving him his first research grant. "A fellowship of the Royal Society is a genuine scientific honour," he said. "I think everybody in the society more or less deserves to be in it." He added that the Royal Society was less stuck in the mud than the equivalent US or French academies. "Any organisation that elects its members is bound to have a time lag before it catches up with changes in society. It went through a phase of being, 'Look at me, I'm in the Royal Society!', and it wasn't clear what it was for. But it really has got away from that now."

Reforms under way are likely to bring in scientists well known to the public who would in the past have fallen below the bar of exceptional achievement set by traditional fellows. Electing more women will be harder, say insiders, because so many drop out before reaching the big league. They fall victim to abysmal child care facilities and the reluctance of British husbands to follow wives to new academic posts. One female society fellow said: "What we have to do is increase the proportion of women who persist in the system long enough to reach the level of seniority and distinction where they are eligible to be elected."

The society, which is funded by the government, has little in common with a London club; its Carlton House Terrace base has a restaurant but no bar, and its small fellows' room is usually empty. It hands out research grants and awards (Greenfield and Jones have won medals for contributing to the public understanding of science) and increasingly tries to get parliament and the public to understand the science behind explosive issues such as stem cell research.

Sir Robert argues that if the Royal Society is to take the role as the key voice of science in public debate it has to broaden its membership. "The society needs to look at a larger role in the dialogue between science and the world, in the discussion of the way science offers possibilities to shape the world we want."

webTitle: Death in 24 hours or a new life in the promised land

fields.headline: Death in 24 hours or a new life in the promised land
fields.standfirst: Hundreds of Mexicans have lost their lives trying to reach the US across treacherous terrain
fields.trailText: Hundreds of Mexicans have lost their lives trying to reach the US across treacherous terrain
fields.body:
Xico is just twelve inches away from the promised land. He is 24, moustachioed and wearing a small backpack. Below him twinkle the lights of San Ysidro in the United States. Behind him are hills of northern Baja California and some 100 other young men also intent on making their bid for the border.

"I have been caught six times," says Xico, who reaches across the fence to write his name down in a notebook to ensure the spelling is correct. "But I always say to the border patrol - I will be back!" Two US border patrol officers are observing nearby and another is scooting up the hill on a noisy ATV (All Terrain Vehicle) that allows them to catch would-be immigrants in areas that their other vehicles cannnot reach. Xico is camping in the hills, waiting for the right conjunction of moonlight, shift changes and luck that will take him over the border to San Diego or Los Angeles and a job in construction that will pay him 10 times what he can earn in his own country. The mood is relaxed and the patrol officers chat across the fence. Xico knows that tonight is not the night, shakes hand and bids farewell, laughing at a suggestion that the next meeting will be on an LA street.

This is Smuggler's Canyon, on the outskirts of Tijuana, the world's busiest border crossing. But although the mood on this clear night may be amiable enough both Xico and the border patrol know that hundreds of others like him have died trying to cross the border. Next week, in what could herald the most dramatic shift on border crossing policies for decades, the President of Mexico, Vicente Fox, will meet legislators in California. He will seek an acknowledgement that the current US policies are "intolerable" and he will be setting in motion a bid to change the rules in what is fast becoming one of the main sources of international tension: immigration between rich and poor countries. For while the majority of those who have perished on the border are Mexicans, a growing number come from everywhere from China to Guatemala, Iraq to India.

Last week, the US census showed that for the first time the Hispanic or Latino population in the US makes up the largest of the minorities. Never before have they enjoyed such political clout. In Mexico, Vicente Fox broke the stanglehold that the old corrupt PRI party had when he won the presidential election last year and now he intends to use his own political clout and his friendship with President Bush to end what many see as a form of border war.

"The violent deaths of my countrymen on the border are simply intolerable," said Fox after his election last July. He went on to propose "new and imaginative mechanisms" for the reduction of tension on the border. Next week, when he addresses the Californian state assembly and senate in Sacramento, his aims are likely to be spelled out. They will involve a "guest worker" programme which would allow hundreds of thousands of Mexicans to enter legally, work for months at a time and return home.

A hundred miles along the border line, the night after Xico has made his abortive bid, David Abegglen, a patrol agent, is standing in the desert at one of the favoured crossing points north of Mexicali. Again the lights twinkle beckoningly in the distance but for many of the crossers they are a mirage. "I've seen people die," says Abegglen. "It gets to 115, 120 degrees here and a person can't carry enough water to last a day. Once they stop sweating, death comes very quickly."

Abegglen, whose own family were originally from Switzerland, and his colleagues are used to finding dehydrated migrants who have underestimated the water they will need and the difficulty of the terrain. Since the introduction in the nineties of Operation Gatekeeper, which tightened up border controls, migrants have been driven into the more dangerous desert and mountain regions.

"Unfortunately we had 22 people die of thirst last year," says his collegaue Manuel Figueroa - Latinos make up around 40% of the patrol. "Our job is to protect the border of the United States but we're also human." His colleague Richard Ransdell, says: "I can't imagine anyone not having sympathy for them. In El Salvador, they've just had an earthquake and whole towns wiped off the map, where are they going to go? You've got to feel for them."

Of the different nationalities that have attempted to cross into the US via the Californian border, agent James Garvey says: "You name them, we've seen them." There have been Irish, Chinese, Iraqis and, most recently in large quantities, Russians. Some pay the normal fee of around $1,500 to $2,000 (about £1,030 to £1,380) although one Chinese caught had paid $35,000. "Most of them are decent folks and if you tell them to stop they stop," says Garvey.

Some do not. One technique is known as "banzai" in which up to 100 would-be migrants gather and rush the border. They know that seven or eight will be caught but the majority will get through, at least as far as the first roadblock. Every night, the border patrol skirt the area in their vehicles dragging a tyre to smooth over the sand so that they can spot any footsteps later. The migrants try to combat this by wrapping their feet in carpet material or foam. It is one of the many ironies that the "sign cutting" technique of Native Americans is used to stop migrants.

"The desert is large and many times we just find bones," said David Dhillon, a council member in El Centro, the nearest town to the desert, and the founder in 1998 of Project for Immigrant Lives. "It's unbelievable the amount of deaths we have seen." Dhillon says: "The American people need a lot of education about this issue. Fox calls these people (those who die on the border) 'heroes' and when he says 'you're driving my people to their deaths,' he's saying 'let's not keep it a secret any more'." Of Fox's guest worker aims Dhillon says: "it's going to happen." He commends Canada which has operated such a system on a minor scale since the seventies.

Paul Ganster, the director of the Institute for Regional Studies of the Californias, likens the Mexican/American border to the German/Polish border in terms of the temptations offered by one side to the other. "This is one of the fastest-growing regions in the entire world," says Dr Ganster. Of the suggestion made by many economists that the pool of cheap undocumented labour in the US has helped to fuel the boom years of the nineties, he says: "The one certain thing in American politics is that, in times of expansion, authorities have looked the other way in terms of undocumented labour."

Marco Firebaugh, the young Democrat chairman of the Californian state assembly's select committee on US/Mexican affairs, says of Operation Gatekeeper: "This is the single largest tragedy that came out of the nineties. Our national borders ought to look more like the European Union national borders."

On the other side of the border, Baja California congressman Sergio Gomez Mora says that the US now has 1.9m Mexican agricultural workers of whom around half are illegal. Smuggling migrants was now one of the largest businesses in the region, generating around $600m in fees to the "coyotes" or smugglers.

Back at Tijuana, Xico and his companions head into the hills for the night. They live to cross another day. But next Tuesday what Vicente Fox manages to accomplish by appealing to a mixture of American economic self-interest and international concern could mean that next year Xico and his friends will be walking through the control point at downtown Tijuana at mid-day rather than leaping a fence at midnight and making a break for the border.

"It gets to 115, 120 degrees here and a person can't carry enough water to last a day. Once they stop sweating, death comes very quickly." Abegglen, whose own family were originally from Switzerland, and his colleagues are used to finding dehydrated migrants who have underestimated the water they will need and the difficulty of the terrain. Since the introduction in the nineties of Operation Gatekeeper, which tightened up border controls, migrants have been driven into the more dangerous desert and mountain regions. "Unfortunately we had 22 people die of thirst last year," says his collegaue Manuel Figueroa - Latinos make up around 40% of the patrol. "Our job is to protect the border of the United States but we're also human." His colleague Richard Ransdell, says: "I can't imagine anyone not having sympathy for them. In El Salvador, they've just had an earthquake and whole towns wiped off the map, where are they going to go? You've got to feel for them." Of the different nationalities that have attempted to cross into the US via the Californian border, agent James Garvey says: "You name them, we've seen them." There have been Irish, Chinese, Iraqis and, most recently in large quantities, Russians. Some pay the normal fee of around $1,500 to $2,000 (about £1,030 to £1,380) although one Chinese caught had paid $35,000. "Most of them are decent folks and if you tell them to stop they stop," says Garvey. Some do not. One technique is known as "banzai" in which up to 100 would-be migrants gather and rush the border. They know that seven or eight will be caught but the majority will get through, at least as far as the first roadblock. Every night, the border patrol skirt the area in their vehicles dragging a tyre to smooth over the sand so that they can spot any footsteps later. The migrants try to combat this by wrapping their feet in carpet material or foam. It is one of the many ironies that the "sign cutting" technique of Native Americans is used to stop migrants. "The desert is large and many times we just find bones," said David Dhillon, a council member in El Centro, the nearest town to the desert, and the founder in 1998 of Project for Immigrant Lives. "It's unbelievable the amount of deaths we have seen." Dhillon says: "The American people need a lot of education about this issue. Fox calls these people (those who die on the border) 'heroes' and when he says 'you're driving my people to their deaths,' he's saying 'let's not keep it a secret any more'." Of Fox's guest worker aims Dhillon says: "it's going to happen." He commends Canada which has operated such a system on a minor scale since the seventies. Paul Ganster, the director of the Institute for Regional Studies of the Californias, likens the Mexican/American border to the German/Polish border in terms of the temptations offered by one side to the other. "This is one of the fastest-growing regions in the entire world," says Dr Ganster. Of the suggestion made by many economists that the pool of cheap undocumented labour in the US has helped to fuel the boom years of the nineties, he says: "The one certain thing in American politics is that, in times of expansion, authorities have looked the other way in terms of undocumented labour." Marco Firebaugh, the young Democrat chairman of the Californian state assembly's select committee on US/Mexican affairs, says of Operation Gatekeeper: "This is the single largest tragedy that came out of the nineties. Our national borders ought to look more like the European Union national borders." On the other side of the border, Baja California congressman Sergio Gomez Mora says that the US now has 1.9m Mexican agricultural workers of whom around half are illegal. Smuggling migrants was now one of the largest businesses in the region, generating around $600m in fees to the "coyotes" or smugglers. Back at Tijuana, Xico and his companions head into the hills for the night. They live to cross another day. But next Tuesday what Vicente Fox manages to accomplish by appealing to a mixture of American economic self-interest and international concern could mean that next year Xico and his friends will be walking through the control point at downtown Tijuana at mid-day rather than leaping a fence at midnight and making a break for the border.

fields.headline: Vietnam rescue reunion
fields.trailText: Do Ba is 42, but to Larry Colburn he will always be the nine-year-old boy he saved from the most notorious massacre of the Vietnam war.
fields.body:
Do Ba is 42, but to Larry Colburn he will always be the nine-year-old boy he saved from the most notorious massacre of the Vietnam war.

Yesterday, 33 years to the day after a company of US soldiers ran amok in the central Vietnamese village of My Lai, killing some 500 people, the two shared an emotional day of reunion and remembrance.

Mr Ba was one of 11 Vietnamese villagers that Mr Colburn - then 18 - and two fellow servicemen from an American army helicopter risked their lives to save on March 16 1968, after a search-and-destroy mission by Charlie company had degenerated into a mass murder of civilians, 123 of them children under five.

Mr Colburn and pilot Hugh Thompson were reunited with Mr Ba on Thursday at a ceremony at My Lai.

"After 33 years of thinking of him every day, it's extraordinary to see him again, truly extraordinary," said Mr Colburn, who was with his wife and his own nine-year-old son.

During the rescue, Mr Thompson landed his helicopter between a group of soldiers and the civilians they were about to shoot. He ordered Mr Colburn, a door gunner at the time, to open fire on the marauding GIs if the massacre continued.

Mr Colburn said their commander, Glenn Andreotta, got out into a ditch to look for survivors. "Glenn Andreotta went straight to the ditch and handed the boy to me," he said. Andreotta was killed in action three weeks later. Reuters

"We don't just show you people fucking," said a Features executive. "We show you why they're fucking." These movies are allegedly aimed at the "couples market". But then humourlessness, universal and institutionalised humourlessness, is the lifeblood of porno. Films like Flashpoint go out to the video stores and, in the soft version (where the hard action is partly obscured by some stray object - a fireman's hat, say, or a fireman's boot), are sold to cable and to hotel chain franchises, and so on. Features owes the humiliating fatuity of its conventions to an old legal precedent called the "Miller Test".

Miller v California (1973) established that a dirty movie was obscene if it was "utterly" without social, literary, artistic, political or scientific "value". In juridical terms, the key word here, of course, is "utterly" and millions of dollars have been spent on its definition.

With a wife like Hillary, Bill Clinton could never be a true pal of porno, but he largely left it alone on First Amendment grounds. Now porno is tensed and braced forchanges. It feared Gore. It dreaded Bush. Gonzo porno is also known as "wall-to-wall". My lunch with Temptress was a relatively sedate affair. At first I was reminded of the time I interviewed Penny Baker, a Playboy Playmate of the Year: within a minute I had run out of questions. fields.trailText: The joint managing director of one of Britain's largest recruitment websites yesterday resigned following allegations that he had falsified his own CV to hide a criminal conviction.
fields.body:
The joint managing director of one of Britain's largest recruitment websites yesterday resigned following allegations that he had falsified his own CV to hide a criminal conviction.

Peter Trowell, 47, handed in his resignation from Ofex-listed Cityjobs.com after being suspended by the company earlier in the week pending an investigation into allegations made in the Sunday Times.

Mr Trowell denies reports that he was convicted of pirating videos in breach of copyright laws, that he spent time in prison as a result and then failed to disclose the information in his CV, said joint managing director Paul Jenkinson.

"Peter denies the allegations but resigned during the week," Mr Jenkinson said. "Our investigations are ongoing but internally we are confident that there was no wrongdoing at the company."

Mr Trowell joined City jobs.com as sales and marketing director in February last year. He was appointed to the £75,000 per year post of joint managing director in June.

In a recent interview he stressed that "these days, honesty and integrity are near the top of any job specification".

Mr Trowell has also resigned his position as a director of European Career Systems, a jobs site specialising in the public sector in which Cityjobs.com has a 39% shareholding. He could not be reached for comment.

Cityjobs.com shares first started trading on Ofex at 50p each in December 1999 but now change hands for just 3p. The fall in the share price has stalled plans for a move up to the AIM market.

In the six months to the end of July 2000 Cityjobs.com recorded a turnover of £69,213 and a pre-tax loss of £858,726. It focuses on the IT, banking, legal, accountancy and media sectors.

fields.headline: Chirac faces judgment of Paris
fields.trailText: President Jacques Chirac has faced a close race or two in his career, but with the right four percentage points behind, tomorrow's local election run-off in Paris could mark the end of an era.
fields.body:
Rarely can the old war horse have been so worried. President Jacques Chirac has faced a close race or two in his career, but with the right four percentage points behind, tomorrow's local election run-off in Paris could mark the end of an era.

While votes for the feuding and scandal-hit right have held up well in the provinces, the capital is a different matter, and its loss will deal a body-blow to the man who was its mayor for 18 years, and whose chosen successor, Jean Tiberi, has run it since 1995.

The battle is not yet lost. Last Sunday's first-round gave the left - Socialists, Greens and Communists - a total of 43.6% and the rival conservative lists headed by Mr Tiberi and the official candidate of the right, Philippe Seguin, 39.6%.

Whether Paris elects a its first leftwing council and mayor for 130 years depends on how middle-of-the road voters respond to this week's botched and ill-tempered attempt by the right to field a single list in each of the 20 arrondissements .

Mr Tiberi is standing an an independent after being ditched by Mr Chirac's RPR because of sleaze allegations.

But even though he has publicly insulted Mr Seguin as "an irresponsible and lamentable man", he has agreed to withdraw his lists in the 12th, 13th and 14th arrondissements, where a divided vote would be fatal to the right's chance of retaining power.

The low-polling Mr Seguin, who refused Mr Tiberi's invitation to join forces and called his 40% vote in the 5th arrondissement "a reward for dodgy dealings", has withdrawn his lists in six others.

In the 9th they have merged in a mood of ill-disguised mutual loathing.

But that still leaves 10 districts where centre-right voters have a choice of rival conservative slates.

And where there is a single list it is impossible to say, after so much mud-slinging, how many will vote for what hitherto a rival camp.

"Both Tiberi and Seguin are ridiculous," said Henri, a stu dent in the 5th. "They are putting their own personal ambitions ahead of the interests of their party. We really do have the stupidest right in the world."

Antoine, 44, a social worker in the 10th, said: "It's absurd ... It's not good for anybody - not for the candidates, nor the voters, nor for Paris."

Behind the scenes Mr Chirac has been trying to impose some show of unity on the RPR's warring factions, to keep control of the city hall he ran from 1977 to 1995 and which propelled him to the presidency.

He knows that a win for the Socialist candidate, Bertrand Delanoe, could only be seen as an indictment of his already sleaze-tainted record as mayor, and could prove a big setback to his hope of retaining the presidency next year.

In a last-ditch attempt to build bridges, Mr Tiberi and Mr Seguin reluctantly agreed yesterday to meet.

But even if the right does somehow pull through, winning 82 of the 163 council seats needed to appoint the next mayor, Mr Chirac's problems will not necessarily be over.

No one would put it past a vengeful Mr Tiberi to block Mr Seguin's appointment as mayor.

If that happened the Gaullist RPR party, which Mr Chirac founded, would face the humiliating task of finding an acceptable second-string candidate - possibly the former prime minister Edouard Balladur or the former deputy mayor Françoise de Panafieu.

Savouring the prospect of what the Paris right have taken to calling "the election from hell", Mr Delanoe said yesterday that it was too early to be sure of a historic Socialist win.

"But on one side you have a project, unity, a real team, a single candidate," he said.

"On the other sleaze, compromises, horse-trading, rivals. One side has shown respect for Paris. The other hasn't."

As he nervously awaits the outcome of the vote that may determine his political future, even Mr Chirac would have to agree with that.

Additional reporting by Pablo Lafuente

webTitle: Israeli 'relaxation' fails to soften Palestinian day of rage

fields.headline: Israeli 'relaxation' fails to soften Palestinian day of rage
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A Palestinian man was shot dead by Israeli soldiers in the Gaza Strip and at least 12 others were wounded as clashes erupted throughout the Palestinian territories yesterday.
fields.byline: Virginia Quirke  in Jerusalem and agencies
fields.body:
A Palestinian man was shot dead by Israeli soldiers in the Gaza Strip and at least 12 others were wounded as clashes erupted throughout the Palestinian territories yesterday.

The man was named as Mohammed Abu Awn, 20, and said to have been shot in the chest while sitting near protesters hurling stones at troops guarding the road to the Jewish settlement of Netzarim.

In the West Bank troops fired rubber bullets and teargas at hundreds of Palestinians throwing stones in protest at the Israeli encirclement of Ramallah.

In Gaza city young children enacted a suicide bombing: a boy of 10 went on stage in a white shroud and climbed into a coffin-like box covered with an Israeli flag as another boy threw a firecracker to mimic the sound of an explosion.

Palestinian groups had called a "day of rage" to maintain pressure on Israel to relax the restrictions imposed on the Palestinian people since the intifada began in September.

Israel says it has begun to relax the clampdown, but Palestinian leaders say the changes are inadequate.

The defence ministry said it would open both the Allenby bridge between the West Bank and Jordan and the Gaza-Egypt border during daylight hourts, and ease restrictions at Karni to allow raw materials in and out of the West Bank.

A statement said the minister, Binyamin Ben-Eliezer, "expects that these steps will encourage the Palestinian economy and says that every drop in the level of violence will enable Israel to provide greater easings to the Palestinian population".

Late on Thursday Israel said it had arrested three members of the Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat's guard on suspicion of trying to explode a bomb near the West Bank military headquarters.

Military sources said the three-man cell was involved in attacks in which eight Israelis were killed and 20 wounded.

They include the December 31 ambush in the West Bank which killed the son and daughter-in-law of the late Meir Kahane, the rightwing extremist rabbi. The Israeli authorities have justified the closure of Ramallah as an attempt to foil attacks by the cell, said to be headed by the Ramallah commander of Force 17, an elite Palestinian security unit.

The news of the arrests, and the suspects' close connection to the Palestinian Authority, was expected to back up the prime minister Ariel Sharon's decision not to renew peace talks with the Palestinians immediately.

Meanwhile the spiritual leader of the militant Hamas group, Sheikh Yassin, has threatened to carry out big attacks on Israel.

He predicted "better, bigger and greater" bomb attacks in the coming days.

In recent months Hamas has stepped up its campaign against Israel and has been responsible for numerous attacks, including a recent bomb in a taxi and the Netanya bombing, which killed three Israelis.

In the Palestinian-controlled city of Nablus, in the north of the West Bank, 2,500 people held a peaceful protest

"Lift the closure. Sharon lift the closure, this is the last time," they shouted.

They said they planned more demonstrations on Saturday, and would march on the Israeli checkpoints on the outskirts of the city: an action likely to cause clashes with the Israeli soldiers posted there to enforce the closure.

Brigadier-General Benny Gantz, the commander of Israeli forces in the West Bank, said in an interview published yesterday that the uprising was not conducted by ordinary people but organised from above.

He told the newspaper Ma'ariv that he did not believe Yasser Arafat had made a major effort to halt the violence, in which at least 346 Palestinians, 13 Israeli Arabs and 65 other Israelis have been killed.

The Palestinians want the UN to send an observer force to help quell the violence in the West Bank and Gaza.

All the security council members support the call, except the US, but some western ambassadors say their support is conditional on Israel's approval.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Gusinsky ruling
fields.body:
Gusinsky ruling

A Spanish court ruled yesterday that the Russian media magnate Vladimir Gusinsky, wanted in Russia for alleged fraud, should remain in custody until it decided on his extradition.
AFP, Madrid

Ex-PM injured

The former Russian prime minister Viktor Chernomyrdin was injured yesterday in a snowmobile accident, NTV television reported. Mr Chernomyrdin, 62, lost control of his snowmobile at the launch of a round the world expedition near Murmansk, NTV said.
AFP, Moscow

Pension protest

Some 1,500 Bolivian pensioners braved nose-bleed altitudes and cold rain in a 120-mile protest march to La Paz in demand of higher pensions this week. "We'd rather die from the effort than from hunger," one of the leaders said on Thursday.
AFP, Panduro

Bubonic deaths

An outbreak of bubonic plague in eastern Zambia has killed nine people in the past month and put scores in hospital, Dr Ben Chirwa of the Zambian central board of health said yesterday.
Reuters, Lusaka

fields.headline: Forest carve-up unites Kenya
fields.trailText: Environmentalists have won a stay of execution against Nairobi's plan to give away 10% of its remaining forests.
fields.body:
Environmentalists have won a stay of execution against Nairobi's plan to give away 10% of its remaining forests.

The plan to parcel off 67,000 hectares (170,000 acres) of forest reserve has united a normally split tribal society and brought environmentalists, farmers, journalists and opposition politicians together in horror and disbelief.

Yesterday, the last day for public objections to the plan, the Centre for Human Rights and Democracy won a three-week stay in court in Eldoret, central Kenya, forcing a government rethink of the plan.

The environment minister, Francis Nyenze, defended the project as an attempt to redefine forest boundaries in areas occupied by squatters and to prevent further encroachment. But aerial surveys by the Kenya Wildlife Service show that most of the forest is unsettled.

Opponents claim the resultant deforestation would have a catastrophic effect on Kenya's water supply because of the finely balanced ecology.

The vast majority of Kenya is either semi-arid or desert, and dependent on water from a few scattered catchments in the mountainous areas .

About 15% of the Mau forest reserve in western Kenya is scheduled for clearance, despite its being the source of an estimated 40% of the country's water. Illegal logging to the east has already laid bare the source of the Njoro river, now dry for half the year.

The government giveaway, timber and all, would represent a capital loss of an estimated £1.7bn, even before the expected environmental costsare taken into account.

"It is very hard to see how the government can gain from the plan, unless there is a hidden agenda," said Michael Gachanja, coordinator of the Kenya Forest Working Group.

With a national election due next year, such an agenda is widely being interpreted as election largesse.

"Land is now the most valuable patronage resource available," said John Githongo, head of the anti-corruption watchdog Transparency International. "It's a safe assumption this is politically motivated."

webTitle: Crisis after crisis threatens whole of SE Asia

fields.headline: Crisis after crisis threatens whole of SE Asia
fields.standfirst: 'It's all being held together with chewing gum and sticky plaster': Indonesia and its ailing neighbours
fields.trailText: 'It's all being held together with chewing gum and sticky plaster': Indonesia and its ailing neighbours.
fields.body:
The economic and political shockwaves triggered by stockmarkets round the world plunging in value are likely to hit hardest in South-east Asia. The Indonesian president is already at war with parliament as communal conflicts rage unchecked in many areas, the Malaysian authorities are using oppressive sedition laws to prevent an escalation of the worst ethnic violence in 30 years, and the ousted Philippine president is refusing to retire quietly as the country's new government struggles to clear up the carnage he left behind.

In Thailand, the newly elected prime minister is struggling to stave off corruption charges that would force him from office, in Singapore ministers are panicking about China possibly filling the power vacuum left by America's new hands-off Asia policy, and East Timor is suffering the growing pains of a new country heading into an uncertain future.

Tiny Brunei is the only country in the region not making unsettling headlines.

Even in healthy economic circumstances, much of south-east Asia would be facing an extremely uncertain next few months with a potential for major social and political upheaval. But with the current collapse of global markets and parallel slowdown in developed nations' economies reverberating around the region, the ante has risen significantly.

South-east Asia is where the world's last major financial crisis kicked off in July 1997 with the collapse of the Thai baht, and most of the once loudly roaring tigers are still licking their wounds.

Storm clouds

With the exception of Singapore recoveries have, at best, proved patchy and, at worst, barely got off the ground, raising serious questions about the ability of the region's political and social structure to survive another major economic hit.

The Thai prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, was the first to admit storm clouds are gathering. On Wednesday he said the state of his country's economy was "worrying", with the budget deficit likely to be much higher than anticipated, exports falling so sharply that Thailand experienced its first trade deficit for 11 months in January, and little new foreign investment on the horizon.

But it is Indonesia that is likely to be the first serious victim. Its economy is already in turmoil - stalled economic reform, a spat with the International Monetary Fund, stagnating repayments on £180bn of debt and longstanding high-profile foreign investors halting operations are just four items on a growing list of crises.

"There are so many reasons to be negative about the economy and nothing really to be positive," said Sri Mulyani Indrawati, an Indonesian economist.

"History shows that the collapsing currency does not even help exports."

The extent of the crisis in the world's fourth most-populous nation is so great, however, that few ordinary Indonesians are focusing on the economy. The increasingly likely demise of President Abdurrahman Wahid is grabbing most attention.

This almost-blind Muslim cleric, who became the country's first democratically elected president in October 1999, is facing a rapidly rising tide of opposition to his erratic and ineffective rule.

As thousands of student-led protesters besieged the presidential palace on Monday, he refused to resign, claiming somewhat fatuously that the restive provinces of Aceh, Irian Jaya, the Moluccas, Madura and Riau would immediately declare independence.

There is no doubt that it is only the constitution which is keeping Mr Wahid in power. It states that impeachment proceedings can only be initiated against the president after he has been given three months to respond to a first formal warning and one month to a second. The first censure was issued on February 1 and all the major opposition parties confirmed this week that, barring a miracle, they would issue a second.

As Mr Wahid's party only controls 10% of parliament, a second warning is considered unstoppable.

On top of this is the mounting unrest in the provinces. Jakarta proved powerless, or unwilling, to prevent Dayak head-hunters in Kalimantan butchering almost 500 migrants from Madura and forcing out tens of thousands of others three weeks ago.

After a three-week hiatus, pro-Wahid mobs once again ran amok in East Java on Wednesday, vandalising opposition party offices, threatening to kill Wahid critics and blocking ferries to Bali.

The army was ordered this week to launch a formal operation against separatists in Aceh, while the military commander in the Moluccas admitted recently that there was no end in sight to the two-year-long sectarian conflict there.

With events running so out of control, total meltdown could well occur long before Mr Wahid is impeached. "Everything is being held together with chewing gum and sticky plaster," said one Jakarta-based security consultant. "Something is going to have to give soon; it's just a question of what and when."

Explosion

As crises converge, observers elsewhere in the region are starting to worry what the fallout might be. "The major regional risk... is undoubtedly Indonesia's deteriorating situation," said Steve Brice, an analyst with Standard Chartered Bank. "If the fabric breaks down the flow of people could become overwhelming."

They might not come just from Indonesia though. Many of the countries in the region built their post-1997 crash recovery efforts on tech-heavy industries. As the Nasdaq continues to freefall and tech companies downsize, south-east Asia could face an unemployment explosion.

"The labour sector will surely be very badly affected," said Rafaelito Santos, an investment risk analyst in Manila. "It's still too early to assess how bad it will be. It all depends on how governments can deal with the situation."

Congressional elections in the Philippines in May could well be a flashpoint. The wife of the ousted president Joseph Estrada is running for office to show how much support her husband still commands and, if mass lay-offs occur between now and then, her support base could swell significantly.

This would cause a headache for President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo - who swept to power in January in a political coup hidden by a people power movement - although it is unlikely to be fatal.

The same cannot be said for Mr Shinawatra's woes. If the constitutional court upholds the false declaration of assets indictment against him he will have to resign. This would throw the whole government into limbo as it is built around the personality and wealth of this billionaire telecoms tycoon.

Such doomsday outcomes might not transpire and the region could muddle through, mauled but not permanently maimed. But most people fear the region still has not seen the worst.

"It would be a very brave call to suggest that we're at the bottom," said Mr Brice. "Near, yes, but the magnitude and the timeframe of the remaining fall are impossible to gauge." So are the consequences.

The extent of the crisis in the world's fourth most-populous nation is so great, however, that few ordinary Indonesians are focusing on the economy. The increasingly likely demise of President Abdurrahman Wahid is grabbing most attention. This almost-blind Muslim cleric, who became the country's first democratically elected president in October 1999, is facing a rapidly rising tide of opposition to his erratic and ineffective rule. As thousands of student-led protesters besieged the presidential palace on Monday, he refused to resign, claiming somewhat fatuously that the restive provinces of Aceh, Irian Jaya, the Moluccas, Madura and Riau would immediately declare independence. There is no doubt that it is only the constitution which is keeping Mr Wahid in power. It states that impeachment proceedings can only be initiated against the president after he has been given three months to respond to a first formal warning and one month to a second. The first censure was issued on February 1 and all the major opposition parties confirmed this week that, barring a miracle, they would issue a second. As Mr Wahid's party only controls 10% of parliament, a second warning is considered unstoppable. On top of this is the mounting unrest in the provinces. Jakarta proved powerless, or unwilling, to prevent Dayak head-hunters in Kalimantan butchering almost 500 migrants from Madura and forcing out tens of thousands of others three weeks ago. After a three-week hiatus, pro-Wahid mobs once again ran amok in East Java on Wednesday, vandalising opposition party offices, threatening to kill Wahid critics and blocking ferries to Bali. The army was ordered this week to launch a formal operation against separatists in Aceh, while the military commander in the Moluccas admitted recently that there was no end in sight to the two-year-long sectarian conflict there. With events running so out of control, total meltdown could well occur long before Mr Wahid is impeached. "Everything is being held together with chewing gum and sticky plaster," said one Jakarta-based security consultant. "Something is going to have to give soon; it's just a question of what and when." Explosion As crises converge, observers elsewhere in the region are starting to worry what the fallout might be. "The major regional risk... is undoubtedly Indonesia's deteriorating situation," said Steve Brice, an analyst with Standard Chartered Bank. "If the fabric breaks down the flow of people could become overwhelming." They might not come just from Indonesia though. Many of the countries in the region built their post-1997 crash recovery efforts on tech-heavy industries. As the Nasdaq continues to freefall and tech companies downsize, south-east Asia could face an unemployment explosion. "The labour sector will surely be very badly affected," said Rafaelito Santos, an investment risk analyst in Manila. "It's still too early to assess how bad it will be. It all depends on how governments can deal with the situation." Congressional elections in the Philippines in May could well be a flashpoint. The wife of the ousted president Joseph Estrada is running for office to show how much support her husband still commands and, if mass lay-offs occur between now and then, her support base could swell significantly. This would cause a headache for President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo - who swept to power in January in a political coup hidden by a people power movement - although it is unlikely to be fatal. The same cannot be said for Mr Shinawatra's woes. If the constitutional court upholds the false declaration of assets indictment against him he will have to resign. This would throw the whole government into limbo as it is built around the personality and wealth of this billionaire telecoms tycoon. Such doomsday outcomes might not transpire and the region could muddle through, mauled but not permanently maimed. But most people fear the region still has not seen the worst. "It would be a very brave call to suggest that we're at the bottom," said Mr Brice. "Near, yes, but the magnitude and the timeframe of the remaining fall are impossible to gauge." So are the consequences.

fields.headline: My mission
fields.trailText: Yet again George Monbiot has chosen to propagate fantasy rather than fact. His allegations (Comment, March 15) are completely without foundation.
fields.body:
Yet again George Monbiot has chosen to propagate fantasy rather than fact. His allegations (Comment, March 15) are completely without foundation.

I have never visited the Toshka project in Egypt; my trade mission to Turkey in September 1999 was about earthquake reconstruction, not the Ilisu dam (I have had no involvement whatsoever in decisions taken on this project).

Far from undermining the government commitment to climate change, I have only last week published our proposals for significantly higher energy efficiency standards in buildings.I am very sorry that the Guardian gives space to these fantasies, innuendoes and half truths.
Nick Raynsford MP
Minister for planning

fields.headline: Party mood
fields.trailText: Your series (Election countdown, March 12-14) omitted the Green party.
fields.body:
Your series (Election countdown, March 12-14) omitted the Green party. Surveying our north London headquarters, you could have mentioned our three back rooms, which have just been repainted, the photocopier (which has not jammed for a week), our new sticky-tape dispenser and our two and a half staff members who will shortly become three to cope with the increasing workload.

Given these resources, your readers may be interested to know that the party will be producing an election broadcast to our usual exceptional standard as well as an attractive manifesto; we are somehow managing to fund 120 candidates, providing a serious and radical alternative to other parties. We have not (yet) been embarrassed by any donations of £2m and can confidently state that we will not be breaching the £15m limit on election spending.
Steve Lambert
Green party

fields.headline: Storm in a D-cup
fields.trailText: Three relatively small-titted women (Strip off your bra, G2, March 15) talk about what their breasts mean to them (all currently, or pre-surgery, smaller than the C-cup that is now average for British women). And surprise, surprise, it's all about self-image and sexuality.
fields.body:
Three relatively small-titted women (Strip off your bra, G2, March 15) talk about what their breasts mean to them (all currently, or pre-surgery, smaller than the C-cup that is now average for British women). And surprise, surprise, it's all about self-image and sexuality. Sagging is mentioned by only one and as something she won't suffer, a compensation. Another, for a short time during pregnancy, felt her breasts to be alien objects.

Well, try living with size D-plus breasts; having to wear two bras in order to exercise without pain; endlessly adjusting these "objects of desire" in order to sleep comfortably; being shouted at by strangers in the street; suffering the joys of recurrent back-ache. And that's without the cosmetic issues: clothes designed exclusively for small, or cosmetically perky, tits (how many "well-endowed" supermodels can you name?); poor posture, the result of an embarrassing adolescence spent hunched over, hiding your "assets". It's all very well to be happy with your body but, for a large percentage of women, breasts are actually a pain in the arse (to conflate body parts) and what they "mean" cannot be dissociated from this. I do not dislike my tits but they are often inconvenient.

I saw none of this reflected in the article. The interviews were with unrepresentatively shaped women and provided relatively monolithic responses; the "issues" raised, with their overwhelming focus on the visual, needlessly reaffirm tits as an observed rather than experienced body part and reproduce a singularly sexualised approach to both breasts and their possessors, women.

And by the way, is there a reason why women in their thirties are uniquely qualified to talk about tits?
Rachel Cohen
Sheffield

webTitle: Letters: Red Nose Day is pants

fields.headline: Red Nose Day is pants
fields.trailText: Has anyone noticed the similarity between celebrities giving up one night to help the world's less well off, and many of the same celebrities spending the rest of the year doing adverts for multinational companies which help to ensure the less well off stay that way?
fields.body:
Has anyone noticed the similarity between celebrities giving up one night to help the world's less well off, and many of the same celebrities spending the rest of the year doing adverts for multinational companies which help to ensure the less well off stay that way? Does no one else see the contradiction in Dawn French who advertises chocolate, which is based on exploitative trade practices, taking one day off to help save the world? Or will no one say? After all, as a celebrity says in his banking ad, "life's complicated enough".
Jim Duggan
London

 Red Nose Day is sad, as it is when we admit that the government has failed to tackle poverty. Isn't a just society one which redistributes money to those in need, rather than introducing regressive taxes which hit the poor disproportionately? Why do people clear their consciences with their credit card and then vote for poverty on election day? The government calls this era "a democracy of giving". What a pile of pants.
Benny Spooner
Roundhay, Leeds

 Not only was Julie Burchill wrong about Anthea Turner's first name in her article (So bad it's good, G2, March 14), she was also wrong about that of Vanessa Feltz. In 1713, Jonathan Swift wrote a poem entitled Cadenus and Vanessa. Possibly, he made up the name - but long before the 19th century, as la Burchill would have us believe!
David Girling
London

fields.trailText: Did Oliver Burkeman not realise that His Royal Wackiness (G2, March 15) was quoting from a classic work of that literary giant, the Venerable S Milligan. "Dig that crazy rhythm" is of course a direct quote from Milligan's seminal work, The Ying Tong Song.
fields.body:
Did Oliver Burkeman not realise that His Royal Wackiness (G2, March 15) was quoting from a classic work of that literary giant, the Venerable S Milligan. "Dig that crazy rhythm" is of course a direct quote from Milligan's seminal work, The Ying Tong Song.
Richard Addison
Strathaven, Lanarkshire

 Polly Toynbee generalises (Better than men, March 16): "Women in parliaments... do politics differently - and perhaps better." Ann Widdecombe, Margaret Thatcher, Winnie Mandela, Golda Meir?
Tony Augarde
Oxford

 Nigel Davies (Letters, March 16) will easily get work in further education where there is no ageism. The sector is so popular our principal offers £250 to staff recommending a teacher who fills a vacancy. I Should add our pay is now 13% lower than that of school teachers.
Jackie Lloyd
Rugby, Warwickshire

 Nigel Davies and Gail Robinson might take a leaf out of actors' books when applying for jobs: don't put your age or dates. I removed both from my carefully honed CV and got an interview. Later, I was told my CV was crap, but then, they gave me the job.
Tim Nelson
London

 Perhaps if Matthew Oglethorpe's software business (Letters, March 16) had developed a method for doing quick and easy back-ups of livestock, he might have a valid point about the provision of government subsidies.
Matthew Tucker
Newton St Cyres, Exeter

 It was heart rending to see your front-page picture of healthy new born lambs about to be culled (March 16), particularly when one realises that they would otherwise have been allowed to live to a ripe old age.
Ray Fitton
Lymington, Hants

fields.headline: Vaz: no case to answer
fields.trailText: Despite what some of your correspondents would have us believe, Keith Vaz was cleared by the Commons standards and privileges committee of all but one of the charges against him (Disgraceful and contemptuous, March 15).
fields.body:
Despite what some of your correspondents would have us believe, Keith Vaz was cleared by the Commons standards and privileges committee of all but one of the charges against him (Disgraceful and contemptuous, March 15). Although much has been made of the reservations which the committee expressed about some aspects of the investigation, the overall verdict must be viewed as an overwhelming exoneration. Comparisons between Keith and Jonathan Aitken, a convicted and jailed perjurer, are therefore viewed by many in Leicester, from all races and backgrounds, as deeply offensive.

Despite many pressures, the committee went to considerable lengths to produce a fair and balanced conclusion. Their report reveals what many in Leicester have known for some time: namely the existence of attempts over the past decade to discredit the CLP in general, and certain individuals, including both Keith and myself, in particular.

This small group of individuals, based around the offices of the city council, have gained media attention far in excess of their support and influence locally. They now hide behind the cloak of parliamentary privilege to make allegations of malpractice against CLP officers. Although, as Elizabeth Filkin was forced to conclude, no evidence was produced to her to substantiate these allegations, they had the effect of creating an extremely negative image of the CLP, and the city as a whole.

While I expected the usual garbage from certain tabloids, the attitude of the Guardian came as a considerable surprise. Contrary to the impression created, the allegations to which Claire Ward referred in her evidence to the commissioner were first brought to the attention of the party leadership in 1994. If the allegations, which have never been brought to the CLP's attention, were not acted upon then, could this have been because they might have been completely unfounded? Indeed, neither the commissioner nor the committee felt the need to follow them up.
Colin Hall
Chair, Leicester East CLP
chall@itslabtest-gbr.com

 Surely Martin Bell should wash his white suit in Daz and hotfoot from Tatton to Leicester East?
Dr Alan Bullion
Tunbridge Wells, Kent

 It's good news that PY Gerbeau wants to stay in Britain (Gerbeau drops dome bid to seek new role as fixer, March 16) With his endearing optimism, he seems the ideal candidate to become Keith Vaz's PR consultant.
Ivor Yeloff
Norwich

fields.headline: Pennine performers
fields.standfirst: Bands to the west - choirs to the east
fields.trailText: Bands to the west - choirs to the east
fields.body:
It had to be a work you could sing. The Mozart score that has been found in William Priestley's library in Halifax is an arrangement of Friedrich Handel's oratorio Judas Maccabeus (yes, the one that goes tum, ta, te, tum, tum) - Mozart added parts, including music for the clarinet, the then new instrument he loved. Priestley, a Victorian clothier, gave the piece to the choral society of which he was a proud member and it has now turned up in the Calderdale civic archives.

It does seem that on the eastern side of the Pennines they like to raise their voices together. Perhaps it is the drier air. There is no Royal Leeds Philharmonic Orchestra or anything approaching a Sheffield Hallé, but those cities, not to mention Halifax and (of course) Huddersfield, boast excellent choirs with deep local roots. The civic traditions in Liverpool and Manchester are bound up with symphonic music. For tykes you cannot beat a choral score.

The generalisation does not have to go too far. If they like to sing on the eastern side of the Pennines, they also love to blow: Huddersfield is also home to the brass players formerly known as the Hammond Sauce Works Band, nowadays the Yorkshire Building Society Band. Up the road in Bradford there is the Black Dyke Mills Band and down it is the pitscape that gave birth to what is now the Grimethorpe Colliery RJB band. Cornet players have been known to scale the Pennines - the secretary of the Brighouse and Rastrick band lives in Oldham.

And if the easterners like to sing Handel (or folk - think of the Waterson Carthy clan in Hull and the Yorkshire coast) westerners may have done better in modern idioms. The echo from Freddie Garrity, of Freddie and the Dreamers, to the Gallaghers off Lennon and McCartney seems more audible than the sound from Leeds and Sheffield (apart from the Cockers, Joe and Jarvis).

webTitle: Letters: Flak flies in press war

fields.headline: Flak flies in press war
fields.trailText: Conrad Black's intemperate intrusion into the columns of his magazine, the Spectator, (The Black arts leave writers riled, March 16) raises numerous issues
fields.body:
Conrad Black's intemperate intrusion into the columns of his magazine, the Spectator, (The Black arts leave writers riled, March 16) raises numerous issues, not least the unethical abuse of the proprietorial powers. He allowed himself the right to reply by rant on four occasions, mixing up unsubstantiated accusations of anti-semitism and factual inaccuracies.

Boris Johnson, editor of the Spectator, was scathing about alleged factual inaccuracies in a letter from William Dalrymple, AN Wilson and Piers Paul Read, yet was not prepared to point out his boss's own errors. For example, Black had castigated the Palestinians for not accepting Israel's right to exist, something they accepted as far back as 1993.

More seriously, Boris Johnson, having assured the authors, all distinguished contributors to the Spectator, that the letter would not be run because of a minor error, was humiliatingly forced by Black to break his word and publish the letter. Black then seized on the error that the authors had expressly dissociated themselves from to denigrate them in yet another letter.

As feared, he did not ex plain why the Daily and Sunday Telegraph, as well as the Spectator, have appeared more akin to campaign literature for Israel, devoid of the criticism found, for example, in international and Israeli human rights group reports. This is an example of interference and bullying by an owner perhaps unprecedented in modern British journalism.
Chris Doyle
Council for the Advancement of Arab-British Understanding

 The Telegraph under Conrad Black has ceased to be credible on the Middle East. The newspaper's reporting and editorial staff well know it is futile to defy Black by attempting to tell the truth - that is, that Israeli troops are besieging, terrorising, killing and maiming at will civilians who are protesting, as is their right under law, against the 34th year of Israel's military occupation of their lands. So they do not.

When the Spectator does publish the views of the likes of William Dalrymple and Lord Gilmour, these are accompanied by the proprietor's long diatribes, peppered with oafish personal abuse. The Telegraph may or may not be a rag, but Conrad Black has certainly lost his.
Tim Llewellyn
London

 William Dalrymple alleges that there has been in the Daily Telegraph "a notable absence of critical reporting of Israel's deadly methods of suppressing Palestinian dissent". In recent months, we have published the following reports which, among many others, speak for themselves.

October 12, 2000: "Death comes silently in Ramallah riots," half-page report on Israeli army's use of "silent" snipers against demonstrators.

October 31: "Israel launches undercover units to kill snipers," report on undercover operations to ambush Palestinian snipers.

December 13: "Israel steps up attacks on militant Palestinians," report on the "selective targeting" of activists.

February 14, 2001: "Arafat's aide killed in helicopter ambush," report on the rocketing of Massoud Ayyad, Gaza Force 17 commander, with Palestinian comment that that this was a "war crime".

March 9: "Israeli army blocks 'last road' into Ramallah," report on the blockade of Ramallah on Ariel Sharon's first day in office.

Our Jerusalem correspondent, Alan Philps, and his predecessors, Patrick Bishop and Anton La Guardia, are generally regarded by their peers as outstanding and independent journalists. So far as I am aware, no fair-minded observer has ever suggested any of them was toeing an Israeli or indeed any other line.

For the record, I have never discussed the Middle East with Mr Black and I certainly feel myself under no pressure to distort our coverage from the region to conform to our chairman's beliefs.
Stephen Robinson
Foreign editor, Daily Telegraph
