fields.headline: Cord Meyer
fields.standfirst: CIA chief behind clandestine funding of Encounter and Watergate break-in
fields.trailText: CIA chief behind clandestine funding of Encounter and Watergate break-in
fields.body:
Cord Meyer, who has died at the age of 80, was one of the Central Intelligence Agency's earliest recruits and figured in a number of the scandals that shook the organisation in the 1970s. Though given several awards and lauded for his contributions to US intelligence, his habit of attracting excessive public attention eventually saw him put out to grass as the agency's front man in London.

He was one of twin sons born to a diplomatic family in New York. Having been to the right schools and enrolled at Yale University in 1939, he broke off his English and philosophy studies in 1941 to join the US Marine Corps as a machine-gunner. He was soon involved in the Pacific campaign, where a grenade during an assault on Guam cost him his left eye. His brother was killed on Okinawa.

Against this background, Meyer emerged from the war with strongly pacifist views, which led him to help set up the United World Federalists, a body aiming for world government and general disarmament. He also joined Harold Stassen (Obituary, March 6 2001) as a senior staff member of the American delegation to the San Francisco conference, in which role he played a significant part in drafting the UN charter.

After the conference, he went to do postgraduate research at Harvard University, but became increasingly concerned about events in the wider world. He had already become disenchanted by communist efforts to take over the United World Federalists, and his political views were sharpened in the wake of the Soviet blockade of Berlin in 1948, Moscow's development of an atomic bomb in 1949, and North Korea's attack on South Korea in 1950. To the surprise of his friends, Meyer resigned from Harvard in 1951 to join the CIA's international organ-isations division.

Given his rightwing drift, he was stunned, in 1953, to be told that the FBI had refused him security clearance - because he had shared a platform with a "notorious leftist", that the lights in his college room had "burned all night" and that he had written letters supporting proscribed organisations.

Even in the paranoid atmosphere of the McCarthy years, these charges were so ludicrous that they were briskly dismissed at an internal inquiry. But the episode had a profound effect on Meyer. In the words of a colleague: "He turned into something of a fanatic, and became more Catholic than the Pope. From a commitment to peace and amity, he shifted toward anti-communist fervour".

One of his closest associates in the CIA was James Jesus Angleton, the fanatical anti-communist who nearly wrecked the organisation with his belief that most of its senior staff were Russian moles.

The friendship extended beyond working hours. In 1964, Meyer's divorced wife, the writer Mary Pinchot, was murdered as she walked along a Washington towpath. Shortly afterwards, her sister and brother-in-law, Ben Bradlee (later executive editor of the Washington Post), discovered Angleton trying to break into Mrs Meyer's home.

They frightened him off, but later found that he had been trying to steal Mrs Meyer's diary containing details of her sexual liaison with President John Kennedy. The assumption has since been that Angleton could only have learned of the diary from Meyer, though it was unclear why he wanted it. A workman hiding in nearby bushes was accused of the killing but acquitted. No other suspect has ever been found.

The work Meyer was then doing for the CIA remains shrouded in the usual mists, but the veil was briefly lifted by one of those cock-ups that occasionally enliven the spying business. When President Lyndon Johnson appointed Admiral William Raborn to head the agency in 1965, the swearing-in ceremony was attended by most of its leading executives, and the guest list inadvertently disclosed the name and position of everyone in the room. Meyer appeared as head of labour, student and education operations.

A couple of years later, the precise nature of this job was disclosed by Ramparts magazine. It found that Meyer had been distributing clandestine funds through a wide range of front organisations. It remains unclear whether such participants as the Ford and Rockefeller foundations knew what was going on. Others, like the Fairfield Foundation, were entirely CIA creations.

Their beneficiaries included the National Student Association and, wholly unknown to its staff, the cultural magazine Encounter. The object, according to Meyer, was simply to "make it possible for the American point of view to be represented".

The public and congressional row sparked off by these disclosures - and the legal constraints on the agency which followed - were further compounded in 1972, when Meyer asked a friend at the publishing house of Harper and Row for proofs of Alfred McCoy's impending book about south-east Asia's heroin trade. Tacitly acknowledging the CIA's probable involvement, Meyer demanded the book be officially vetted before publication. Not surprisingly, this unconstitutional attempt at prior censorship garnered huge headlines - and the book was issued unvetted.

Meyer blotted his copybook for a third time in 1972 during the Watergate scandal. Among those who burgled Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist in the hunt for evidence about the leaked Pentagon Papers was Eugenio Martinez, a Cuban activist retained by the CIA. When other staff questioned the agency's illegal involvement in domestic affairs, Meyer said it was authorised and warned them off.

By now indelibly marked in the public eye as the agency's head of dirty tricks, Meyer was wafted off to run the CIA London station, a largely administrative job. He retired in 1977 to write his memoirs and turn out exceedingly rightwing newspaper commentaries.

He is survived by his wife, Starke, two sons and two stepchildren.

Cord Meyer Jr, intelligence agent, born 1920; died March 13 2001

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Vodafone sells for less
fields.body:
Vodafone sells for less

Italian electricity company Enel is paying Vodafone €7.25bn (£4.3bn) in cash for telecoms group Infostrada, much less than the original €11bn price set late last year. Enel said that it would also assume €1.3bn of Infostrada debt. It expected to close the deal, already agreed by Vodafone, on March 29.

The 34 % reduction in the price came after Italian regulators ordered Enel to sell off extra generating capacity as a condition for its fresh expansion into telecoms through Infostrada's fixed-line network, Italy's second largest.

Daewoo cuts more UK jobs

South Korean car firm Daewoo is to cut another 90 jobs from its British technical centre. The site at Worthing, Sussex employed 750 workers before the parent company went bankrupt last year.

The latest cutback will leave 160 employees at the centre, which is expected to be sold next week. Daewoo has refused to confirm reports that the centre will be sold to engineering and motor racing group TWR.

Henlys backs US operations

Bus and coach builder Henlys said yesterday it was confident its important US school bus business could ride out any downturn in the American economy.

Georgia-based Blue Bird, acquired in October 1999, now accounts for 60% of sales and more than 80% of operating profits for the group, which announced pre-tax profits up 89.6% at £46m.

"When we acquired Blue Bird, it was larger than Henlys and we had to prove we could take up so large an operation," said chief executive Robert Wood.

Shell rivals in Woodside bid

Takeover target Woodside Petroleum of Australia said yesterday it was in talks with BHP and Santos over competing proposals to the takeover bid from Royal Dutch/Shell.

Woodside said since Shell's takeover offer in November, it had been talking to a number of parties about possible competing proposals. "A number of discussions were unproductive, but discussions are continuing with BHP and Santos."

Swiss link for Acambis

Biotech firm Acambis said yesterday that it had teamed up with a Swiss firm to develop its oral typhoid vaccine and work on a potential cholera and typhoid vaccine.

The company, part-owned owned by US health care group Baxter, saw its net loss narrow to £11.1m from £12.5m, taking the loss per share to 13.9p from 19p.

Analysts were positive over the Cambridge firm's results, though, and its collaboration with the Swiss Serum and Vaccine Institute Berne (Berna).

fields.headline: The news from Ground Zero: foot and mouth is winning
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Below the wooded hill known as Arthuret Knowes is a county council sign about the Battle of Aedderyd (AD 573). On this spot, it says, the pagans of Strathclyde were slaughtered by the Christians of Cumbria. Though the pagan king Gwenddolau had Merlin to encourage him, 80,000 humans were killed. The number seems unimaginable.
fields.body:
Below the wooded hill known as Arthuret Knowes is a county council sign about the Battle of Aedderyd (AD 573). On this spot, it says, the pagans of Strathclyde were slaughtered by the Christians of Cumbria. Though the pagan king Gwenddolau had Merlin to encourage him, 80,000 humans were killed. The number seems unimaginable.

From the sign, you look across to Howend Farm, where the mass graves have been alight for the past week, sometimes blazing, sometimes smouldering. More than 5,000 pagan sheep and cattle belonging to farmer John Fisher (with just Nick Brown to encourage him) have been slaughtered by a marksman sent by the Christians at the Ministry of Agriculture.

That is a tiny fraction of the animals killed in this small patch of Cumbria alone. The rest of the sheep will go in the next few days, the healthy as well as the sick: hundreds of thousands in all. The number seems unimaginable.

Howend is just outside Longtown, the small town fringing the Scottish border that constitutes Ground Zero in the war against foot and mouth, a war which the disease has been winning. Longtown (pop 3,500; Lang-toon to the locals) used to have a mild local celebrity thanks to John Graham's amazing ironmongery. Most non-Cumbrians had never heard of the place - unless they were farmers.

But Longtown also is - or was, three short weeks ago - a contender for Britain's biggest sheep market. Every Thursday up to 20,000 head of fatstock would be sold there. At this time of year, most would be hoggets: last year's hill lambs, reared on the lonely uplands of Scotland and Northumberland, destined to be killed and eaten further south. And it was here a month ago that an infected consignment arrived from Hexham and headed south, a process that silently and invisibly spread foot and mouth disease across much of Britain.

On Thursday, the gates to the market were shut with a rusty padlock. The pens were deserted. The town itself was not much different. Only the bar of the Graham Arms (the name Graham is everywhere here) was full, and that was because of a funeral. Longtown - static, ageing, a little melancholy at the best of times - always puts a lot of emphasis on funerals.

Longtown, however, is not just a prime source of the outbreak. It is also the very centre. Almost 10% of the farms affected nationally are in this vicinity. Up the A7 towards Canonbie on the Scottish side of the border, just about every farm is believed to be infected, and in the last few days the plague has been rippling out southwards towards Carlisle. Then on Thursday came the announcement that even healthy sheep would have to be "culled" within two miles of an outbreak. Everyone round Longtown is within two miles.

Normally on a Thursday the rumours get passed round, and maybe leavened with a grain of truth, at the market cafe. This time, with the cafe shut, they just jumped from farm to farm like the disease itself. Since even Mr Brown originally thought all cattle would be slaughtered too, it was hardly surprising that the farmers were confused - and more contemptuous of London than ever. At one time, people were imagining that dogs and cats had to go.

The big talk yesterday of rebellion and shotguns seemed almost as distant as Mr Brown's blandness. There is a stoic acceptance here that there are currently three sorts of farm animals: the dead, the sick and the soon to be one or the other.

The handful of farmers who have so far held off the plague listened jumpily each time the phone rang yesterday. They know the grim reaper from Maff will lay his hands on their shoulders some time in the next few days.

The Great Fire of Lang-toon has been alight all week. It is a little like the burning of the Kuwaiti oil wells in the Gulf war or an Australian bushfire. Nothing like it has been seen in the English countryside since stubble-burning was banned. Unless you have worked in a crematorium, there is no analogy for the smell. It is strange, unearthly: a mix of singed rubber and old socks. On Tuesday, the town stank terribly. On Wednesday, it hung in the fog all day.

However, the split between farmers and their neighbours, so visible elsewhere in the countryside, is almost non-existent in Longtown. Directly or indirectly, almost everyone depends on sheep. A handful of Carlisle commuters have been attracted by the rock-bottom house prices, but only a handful. No one from the tourist trade has been shouting the odds about the damage done by farming, because there is no tourist trade worth mentioning except from visiting sheep dealers. South of here are the Lakes; north and west are Gretna and Galloway. But hardly anyone stops in Longtown unless they are tired, confused or heading for the mart. For generations, everything here has depended on sheep farming. Within a few days there will be no sheep.

As Mr Brown made the announcement, I was with Bob Armstrong, the Longtown haulier who has been transporting animals to and from the mart since he took over his father's business in 1947. A third of his business was shut down overnight, and he has been left with 26 drivers who have nothing to do; the firm is desperately trying to avoid laying them off. He also runs a few hobby-sheep in the paddock behind his house. All perfectly healthy. "They'll have to go now," he said phlegmatically as he digested the news. "We had two little lambs born yesterday. Life can be cruel sometimes." The original announcement suggested that his milk tankers, another third of the business, would also have to go. He just shrugged that off too.

Those worst affected are invisible. Every farm gate for miles around is blocked off by cones, tarpaulins, plastic netting, police tape, baler twine, anything that reinforces the Go Away message. Farmers with diseased animals lurk behind them, relying on friends to drop off supplies at the gate.

John Fisher emerged briefly from his fortress at Howend and stood sentry in his flat cap and Barbour, without much purpose - but then, with no animals, he had nothing better to do. He seemed phlegmatic too, and even smiled wryly. "If I look upbeat, I don't feel upbeat," he said. "I've been having trouble sleeping."

Mr Fisher may be one of the luckier ones: he kept up his foot and mouth insurance, which many others did not. Farmers keep using the same words as the TV reporters: "devastating... terrible... heartbreaking... diabolical".

They are used to their animals being killed; they have become used to being sandbagged economically. It is not easy for them to disentangle their true feelings: how much distress is emotion; how much is about money. Some farmers will restock and start again; those with pedigree herds will lose bloodlines that go back generations. One sometimes suspects that those who show it least, like John Fisher, may actually feel it the most.

No one in Longtown is immune, however. John Graham sits among his boxes of single screws, pull-on pipe nipples, oil lamp parts, and brass coffin nails, saying that business is worse than at any time in 30 years. He's convinced it will pass. "People in a town like this have never expected a lot. North of Shap Fell, they can take bad times. What you've never had, you never miss." In Lang-toon the south means the softies sitting under palm trees in Preston and Blackburn.

Everyone is taking the hit except, so it is said, Tommy Norman, who sells the railway sleepers that go at the bottom of the funeral trenches below the coal to get the fires going. The trouble is that sheep hardly burn, especially at this time of year when they are thick with wool. "It's like putting a woollen jumper on a fire," explained Mr Fisher. "It would nearly put it out. It's not like nylon." That's why the burning takes so long. What no one can adequately explain is why the carcasses are allowed to be left before the pyre is lit, leaving the crows time to peck at them and fly off to spread the disease.

So the town shares the smoke, the pain, the grief and the grievances. But the grievances are unfocused. Is government policy too harsh or too weak? No one is certain, though they are instinctively convinced it must be one or the other. There seems no one in the area who can voice the farmers' feelings in a way that make them both coherent and audible. The town council offices had the blinds drawn and the door locked even during its opening hours. A French community of similar size would have an elected mayor. In Longtown, there is not even a vicar.

In the absence of an incumbent, the Rev John Smith, formerly Cumbria's chief librarian and now an unpaid curate, does his best, though he lives 10 miles away.

Tomorrow, there will be a special session before the normal Sunday church service. They will pray by name for each of the farmers affected and ring the bell like the Angelus. The church looks over to Howend too and if the wind is wrong, the congregation might catch the smoke.

As night falls, there are patches of what seems like thick fog on the A7. But this is no fog: it's smoke. The fires lit the night, as if it were Guy Fawkes or a jubilee. There is no laughter round these fires, however. Nor will there be, for some time.

It is a little like the burning of the Kuwaiti oil wells in the Gulf war or an Australian bushfire. Nothing like it has been seen in the English countryside since stubble-burning was banned. Unless you have worked in a crematorium, there is no analogy for the smell. It is strange, unearthly: a mix of singed rubber and old socks. On Tuesday, the town stank terribly. On Wednesday, it hung in the fog all day. However, the split between farmers and their neighbours, so visible elsewhere in the countryside, is almost non-existent in Longtown. Directly or indirectly, almost everyone depends on sheep. A handful of Carlisle commuters have been attracted by the rock-bottom house prices, but only a handful. No one from the tourist trade has been shouting the odds about the damage done by farming, because there is no tourist trade worth mentioning except from visiting sheep dealers. South of here are the Lakes; north and west are Gretna and Galloway. But hardly anyone stops in Longtown unless they are tired, confused or heading for the mart. For generations, everything here has depended on sheep farming. Within a few days there will be no sheep. As Mr Brown made the announcement, I was with Bob Armstrong, the Longtown haulier who has been transporting animals to and from the mart since he took over his father's business in 1947. A third of his business was shut down overnight, and he has been left with 26 drivers who have nothing to do; the firm is desperately trying to avoid laying them off. He also runs a few hobby-sheep in the paddock behind his house. All perfectly healthy. "They'll have to go now," he said phlegmatically as he digested the news. "We had two little lambs born yesterday. Life can be cruel sometimes." The original announcement suggested that his milk tankers, another third of the business, would also have to go. He just shrugged that off too. Those worst affected are invisible. Every farm gate for miles around is blocked off by cones, tarpaulins, plastic netting, police tape, baler twine, anything that reinforces the Go Away message. Farmers with diseased animals lurk behind them, relying on friends to drop off supplies at the gate. John Fisher emerged briefly from his fortress at Howend and stood sentry in his flat cap and Barbour, without much purpose - but then, with no animals, he had nothing better to do. He seemed phlegmatic too, and even smiled wryly. "If I look upbeat, I don't feel upbeat," he said. "I've been having trouble sleeping." Mr Fisher may be one of the luckier ones: he kept up his foot and mouth insurance, which many others did not. Farmers keep using the same words as the TV reporters: "devastating... terrible... heartbreaking... diabolical". They are used to their animals being killed; they have become used to being sandbagged economically. It is not easy for them to disentangle their true feelings: how much distress is emotion; how much is about money. Some farmers will restock and start again; those with pedigree herds will lose bloodlines that go back generations. One sometimes suspects that those who show it least, like John Fisher, may actually feel it the most. No one in Longtown is immune, however. John Graham sits among his boxes of single screws, pull-on pipe nipples, oil lamp parts, and brass coffin nails, saying that business is worse than at any time in 30 years. He's convinced it will pass. "People in a town like this have never expected a lot. North of Shap Fell, they can take bad times. What you've never had, you never miss." In Lang-toon the south means the softies sitting under palm trees in Preston and Blackburn. Everyone is taking the hit except, so it is said, Tommy Norman, who sells the railway sleepers that go at the bottom of the funeral trenches below the coal to get the fires going. The trouble is that sheep hardly burn, especially at this time of year when they are thick with wool. "It's like putting a woollen jumper on a fire," explained Mr Fisher. "It would nearly put it out. It's not like nylon." That's why the burning takes so long. What no one can adequately explain is why the carcasses are allowed to be left before the pyre is lit, leaving the crows time to peck at them and fly off to spread the disease. So the town shares the smoke, the pain, the grief and the grievances. But the grievances are unfocused. Is government policy too harsh or too weak? No one is certain, though they are instinctively convinced it must be one or the other. There seems no one in the area who can voice the farmers' feelings in a way that make them both coherent and audible. The town council offices had the blinds drawn and the door locked even during its opening hours. A French community of similar size would have an elected mayor. In Longtown, there is not even a vicar. In the absence of an incumbent, the Rev John Smith, formerly Cumbria's chief librarian and now an unpaid curate, does his best, though he lives 10 miles away. Tomorrow, there will be a special session before the normal Sunday church service. They will pray by name for each of the farmers affected and ring the bell like the Angelus. The church looks over to Howend too and if the wind is wrong, the congregation might catch the smoke. As night falls, there are patches of what seems like thick fog on the A7. But this is no fog: it's smoke. The fires lit the night, as if it were Guy Fawkes or a jubilee. There is no laughter round these fires, however. Nor will there be, for some time. What's going on? webTitle: 3 die as Saudis storm hijack jet

fields.headline: 3 die as Saudis storm hijack jet
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Russia
Special report: crisis in Chechnya
fields.trailText: The hijack designed to bring the continuing war in Chechnya to the attention of the world ended in bloodshed yesterday as three people were killed when Saudi anti-terrorist troops stormed the Russian aeroplane to free more than 100 remaining passengers.
fields.body:
The hijack designed to bring the continuing war in Chechnya to the attention of the world ended in bloodshed yesterday as three people were killed when Saudi anti-terrorist troops stormed the Russian aeroplane to free more than 100 remaining passengers.

One of the hijackers slit the throat of a female flight attendant as the Saudi soldiers burst into the plane. Saudi officials said the youngest hijacker had been shot dead in retaliation by the troops. A Turkish passenger was also killed in the crossfire and several others were injured.

The decision to storm the plane came after consultation with officials in Moscow after a tense night of fractured negotiations. Several dozen heavily armed Saudi soldiers used wooden ladders to scale the side of the airliner and ordered the terrified passengers to run from the plane. Many of the hostages who had spent the night waiting to be released were manhandled face down on the tarmac as troops tried to separate the hijackers from their victims.

"Moscow had offered to rush an anti-terrorist unit to Riyadh, which the Saudis categorically refused," a Saudi official said. "The assault was undertaken only by Saudi forces without help from any other party."

One Russian passenger said after being released: "I saw three hijackers. They treated us well, but sometimes they threatened to blow up the plane. We were frightened and worried."

The three men were armed with knives and claimed to be carrying a bomb.

The aircraft had been heading from Istanbul to Moscow on Thursday afternoon with 162 passengers and 12 crew on board when three hijackers forced their way into the cockpit and demanded that the plane be diverted to Syria or Egypt. Later the Vnukovo Airlines jet landed in the western Saudi Arabia town of Medina, where the men demanded that it be refuelled and requested to be allowed to continue to Afghanistan.

About 40 women, children and elderly passengers were released as talks began. Another group managed to escape through the rear exit. As dawn broke, a red, green and white striped Chechen national flag was visible, draped outside the main door to the plane. The organiser of the operation was reported to be the former general and Chechen interior minister Aslanbek Arsayev, with his brother, Supian, and Supian's son. But Chechen sources denied this last night.

During his time in power, Gen Arsayev promised to re-establish the rule of law amid mounting anarchy in the Chechen republic, with little success. He survived two assassination attempts, but stepped down in early 1999 citing ill health. He was wounded in fighting with Russian troops last year.

It was not clear whether the operation was sanctioned by the Chechen leader, Aslan Maskhadov, or if it represented an independent initiative by another rebel faction.

A Chechen rebel internet website quoted Mr Maskhadov as rejecting responsibility. "Taking hostages and blackmail is not how we lead our struggle," he was quoted as stating. But Mohammed Al Atafyev, describing himself as Mr Maskhadov's representative in Jordan, said the attackers were working for the good of the Chechen republic in the face of Russian "genocide".

webTitle: Foot and mouth news in brief

fields.headline: Foot and mouth news in brief
fields.trailText: Sandwich rise
fields.body:
Sandwich rise

The cost of pre-prepared sandwiches is likely to rise by 5% next week because of an increase in meat, poultry and dairy prices, the British Sandwich Association has warned.

£1m donation

The Royal Bank of Scotland Group is to donate £1m to charities working to help farmers hit by the outbreak.

Pigeon ban

The Royal Pigeon Racing Association has suspended training and racing for a month to help beat the disease. The season was due to open on April 7.

West Bank case

Thirteen infected sheep have been discovered in the West Bank. The disease may be more widespread but movement restrictions imposed by the Israeli military make a survey difficult.

Cull in UAE

Forty-five cattle have been destroyed and another 76 cases of foot and mouth reported so far in the United Arab Emirates.

fields.headline: Cost of outbreak put at £9bn
fields.standfirst:
Farmers step up calls for compensation

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Farmers step up calls for compensation
fields.body:
The outbreak could cost the economy £9bn in lost output this year, an economist predicted yesterday, as farmers and rural industries stepped up calls for compensation

Douglas McWilliams, of the London-based Centre for Economics and Business Research, calculated that the direct impact on farmers and their suppliers would be £3.6bn. The indirect effect on tourism could cost another £6.4bn.

These costs should be offset by a £1bn spending increase on urban entertainment as consumers stay away from the countryside but would still amount to 1.1% of GDP, he predicted. His calculations assume that the rate of new infections diminishes by the end of this month and that movement restrictions are relaxed in mid-April.

Prof McWilliams' predictions came as Ben Gill, the president of the National Farmers Union, met the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, to call for a compensation package worth hundreds of millions of pounds.

Mr Gill said compensation for slaughtered animals was insufficient because it was based on their market value. When farmers tried to restock, the surge in demand would cause prices to rise, he said. Other costs for farmers include extra food and housing for healthy animals which cannot be taken for slaughter, and outlay for disinfectant.

Mr Brown pledged yesterday: "We will not abandon [farmers], we intend to help the industry recover afterwards and that means financial assistance from the government."

The prime minister promised earlier in the crisis to consider "consequential losses" as well as compensation for animals slaughtered. Farmers will also receive £156m in extra aid from Europe. This was initially designed to compensate them for the effects of the strong pound but payments have been brought forward from June to March to help ease the cash flow problems building up because of foot and mouth.

Pig farmers are to receive a further £40m under an existing pig industry restructuring scheme, with payments again brought forward.

Meanwhile, tourist industry chiefs called yesterday for £10m extra funding to help promote the countryside as a destination and a moratorium on VAT, monthly PAYE charges and business rates due next month.

webTitle: 'Geezer girl' joins handful of females convicted of offence

fields.headline: 'Geezer girl' joins handful of females convicted of offence
fields.trailText: Claire Marsh, known in the Ladbroke Grove area as a "geezer girl" who tried to out-tough boys in her gang, earned a chill notoriety yesterday by becoming one of only a handful of women to be convicted of rape.
fields.body:
Claire Marsh, known in the Ladbroke Grove area as a "geezer girl" who tried to out-tough boys in her gang, earned a chill notoriety yesterday by becoming one of only a handful of women to be convicted of rape.

Technically deemed an impossibility by a woman, the crime is defined in law as "penile penetration of a vagina or anus without a person's consent or being reckless as to whether they consent."

Women, on the rare occasions they are involved in such attacks, tend to be charged with aiding and abetting, which carries the same sentence, yet in this case the crown successfully argued the definition should be extended since Marsh acted as a "principal" in a "joint enterprise".

The Home Office makes no distinction in its statistics between women raping and aiding and abetting the crime. Yet, even including both categories, the number of women accused of rape is tiny: between 1997 and 2000, 14 were charged in the Metropolitan police area. None is believed to have been convicted. Only 10 women have been found guilty of rape in England and Wales since 1995, compared with nearly 3,000 men.

When women rape, they turn almost exclusively on women: only one conviction, in 1999, related to a woman raping a man. In 1977, American drama student Joyce McKinney kidnapped her ex-boyfriend at gunpoint with an accomplice, chained him to a bed and forced him to have sex.

Of 10 cases unearthed by criminologist Amanda Matravers, of which one led to a woman being convicted of rape and nine to convictions for aiding and abetting, five involved a mother aiding and abetting her husband in incest, and five rape by gangs.

In contrast to the Marsh case, Dr Matravers found that the gangs always knew their victims, often ousted group members. "The motives were very much those of revenge," said Dr Matravers, of Cambridge University's Institute of Criminology. "Often the women in the gang would turn on a fellow group member because she had slept with their boyfriend.

"The women tended to be much more angry than the men in the group about this kind of transgression. They tended to say: 'She asked for it'."

All the women denied there was a sexual motive. "Culturally they couldn't accept it, but clearly there was a lot of excitement and a lot of encouraging."

Why Marsh - described by a former teacher as "a helpful pupil ... who was never excluded or disciplined and never involved in acts of aggression" - behaved like this to a woman she had never met and in a group she had only known a few days, one can barely imagine, but perhaps she saw it as the ultimate means of acceptance.

"I think everyone got swept along with it and perhaps as a new member of the group, she was showing off," said a senior detective.

As one gang member said: "She's a geezer bird. She'd easily beat you up: she can be soft one minute and hard the next. It's like she's trying to be like a man."

webTitle: Farmers urged to defend animals from cull

fields.headline: Farmers urged to defend animals from cull
fields.standfirst:
Protesters threaten countryside revolt
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Protesters threaten countryside revolt
fields.body:
Farmers told to slaughter livestock not infected with foot and mouth have been called upon to stand in front of the slaughterman's gun to stop the "unnecessary killing" of their animals.

Members of Farmers for Action, the group that began last year's fuel protests, have warned that there will be a "revolt in the countryside" if the government goes ahead with plans for a mass cull.

David Handley, the chairman of FFA, said yesterday that farmers would not allow the wholesale slaughter of their animals if they believed they were not infected. A fellow FFA member, Andrew Spence, who is a mile and a half away from one of the outbreaks in Cumbria, threatened to barricade himself into his farm if anyone came to kill his sheep.

Mr Handley said: "Farmers are saying enough is enough. They are not going to sit down and allow perfectly healthy animals which have gone through a period of quarantine to be slaughtered.

"There's no justification in killing them. We will go out and prevent that from happening. We will stand in front of them to stop them being shot. There's no scientific evidence to show this is justified. If they show us scientific evidence which justifies it then we will allow them to do it."

However, the government was yesterday trying to explain that animals with the virus do not always display symptoms, and can carry the disease and pass it on to other stock without farmers being aware of it. FFA demanded that farmers be shown "scientific proof".

As tension in the countryside mounted yesterday, a farmer in Penrith, Cumbria, had his firearms confiscated after he allegedly made a telephone threat to foot and mouth officials who had contacted him about culling his "healthy livestock".

Cumbria police said: "During the current foot and mouth outbreak police are aware of the potential of people to make threats with firearms against anyone who may come on to their land. While understanding the distress which provokes such a response, police cannot accept a threat to life and will remove the firearms of anyone who makes such threats. We went to see the family and the farmer handed over the shotgun voluntarily. He was understandably very upset."

Condemning the use of any firearms, Mr Handley, who coordinated last year's fuel protests from his farm in south Wales, went on to warn that there would be some sort of revolt if similar cases of slaughter continued. "We have done it before and we will do it again," he said.

"This is a nightmare scenario. You wake up every morning and the first thing you have got to do is march the cattle up a piece of concrete to see if they are lame. It really is gut-wrenching but so far they are not infected. We have got this far and we will stand in front of the uninfected animals that they intend to shoot. We have got people's livelihoods at stake here."

Mr Spence said: "If I back onto an exclusion zone and they said they were coming to slaughter my animals, I would try to stop them gaining access to my farm. I would shove a tractor across my gate. I am standing with my sheep now and if they had foot and mouth I would walk into the slaughterhouse with them now. But for the slaughter of them for no reason other than they are in a restricted area, I won't let that happen.

"I have run this farm since I was 14 and you can't expect me just to give it up. If they get it they will be slaughtered and that's me on the dole, that's an inevitable fact of foot and mouth. We are farmers, we are not butchers or slaughterers."

The FFA has advised farmers to contact their local coordinator if they want help stopping their livestock from being killed. Mr Handley said: "Basically what we are saying is if you don't want this to happen and you are not satisfied with the scientific evidence given to you and you don't want your animals slaughtered, contact your local FFA coordinator. We will help you.

"If you want someone to come and assist you stopping them from killing your animals we will help. I am not talking about thousands of farmers travelling from one side of the country to another. But people can go to the drive end of the farm."

Mr Handley said the group was "playing things by ear" and considering options, one of which was some kind of "tarmac protest".

He said farmers were demanding that the army should be brought in to clear up the backlog of dead animals and that the government should ban meat imports until the crisis is over.

A fellow FFA member, Andrew Spence, who is a mile and a half away from one of the outbreaks in Cumbria, threatened to barricade himself into his farm if anyone came to kill his sheep. Mr Handley said: "Farmers are saying enough is enough. They are not going to sit down and allow perfectly healthy animals which have gone through a period of quarantine to be slaughtered. "There's no justification in killing them. We will go out and prevent that from happening. We will stand in front of them to stop them being shot. There's no scientific evidence to show this is justified. If they show us scientific evidence which justifies it then we will allow them to do it." However, the government was yesterday trying to explain that animals with the virus do not always display symptoms, and can carry the disease and pass it on to other stock without farmers being aware of it. FFA demanded that farmers be shown "scientific proof". As tension in the countryside mounted yesterday, a farmer in Penrith, Cumbria, had his firearms confiscated after he allegedly made a telephone threat to foot and mouth officials who had contacted him about culling his "healthy livestock". Cumbria police said: "During the current foot and mouth outbreak police are aware of the potential of people to make threats with firearms against anyone who may come on to their land. While understanding the distress which provokes such a response, police cannot accept a threat to life and will remove the firearms of anyone who makes such threats. We went to see the family and the farmer handed over the shotgun voluntarily. He was understandably very upset." Condemning the use of any firearms, Mr Handley, who coordinated last year's fuel protests from his farm in south Wales, went on to warn that there would be some sort of revolt if similar cases of slaughter continued. "We have done it before and we will do it again," he said. "This is a nightmare scenario. You wake up every morning and the first thing you have got to do is march the cattle up a piece of concrete to see if they are lame. It really is gut-wrenching but so far they are not infected. We have got this far and we will stand in front of the uninfected animals that they intend to shoot. We have got people's livelihoods at stake here." Mr Spence said: "If I back onto an exclusion zone and they said they were coming to slaughter my animals, I would try to stop them gaining access to my farm. I would shove a tractor across my gate. I am standing with my sheep now and if they had foot and mouth I would walk into the slaughterhouse with them now. But for the slaughter of them for no reason other than they are in a restricted area, I won't let that happen. "I have run this farm since I was 14 and you can't expect me just to give it up. If they get it they will be slaughtered and that's me on the dole, that's an inevitable fact of foot and mouth. We are farmers, we are not butchers or slaughterers." webTitle: Scientists fear breach of confidentiality will threaten research

fields.headline: Scientists fear breach of confidentiality will threaten research
fields.standfirst: Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: The case of Stephen Kelly has alarmed research scientists because police, armed with a warrant, were able to sweep aside guarantees of confidentiality to link blood samples provided separately by Kelly and his ex-girlfriend Anne Craig to two research studies on HIV.
fields.body:
The case of Stephen Kelly has alarmed research scientists because police, armed with a warrant, were able to sweep aside guarantees of confidentiality to link blood samples provided separately by Kelly and his ex-girlfriend Anne Craig to two research studies on HIV.

Kelly was serving a sentence at Glenochil prison when he agreed to give a sample as part of a study to find out the extent of an HIV outbreak through needle-sharing among drug addicts. The prisoners were assured that the findings would be held in the strictest confidence.

The virus takes different forms and the samples from the prisoners at Glenochil, who had passed it on to each other, were all strikingly similar. A Channel 4 documentary had alerted police to the study.

When Anne Craig felt unwell, she gave a blood sample which was forwarded to a research project funded by the Medical Research Council (MRC) on genetic diversity of HIV in Scotland.

Andrew Leigh Brown, head of the centre for HIV research at Edinburgh University, who led the study, said: "This transmission was of a virus very similar to the Glenochil cluster and distinct from other viruses that we see in Scotland."

Prof Leigh Brown, now a visiting professor at the University of California at San Diego, was appalled when this confidential information was pulled out as part of the investigation.

"To me, it seems this was an invasion of human rights.Talking to individuals here in California, they are appalled. This would be forbidden by American privacy regulations.

"I wouldn't touch another molecular epidemiology investigation in Scotland unless there is some clarification of whether this seizure of material is or is not appropriate."

The trial judge held a "trial within a trial" to decide whether it would be fair to use the evidence. He ruled that it could be put before the jury.

Alexander McCall Smith, Professor of Medical Law at Edinburgh University, said: "There are strong arguments why it is not in the public interest for the authorities to breach medical confidentiality. If people are to be encouraged to participate in medical research they must be assured that confidentiality will be respected.

"Only in a very extreme case, where there is a need to breach medical confidentiality to prevent future harm to another, might it be permissible to penetrate coded research samples. In my view, this technique of obtaining evidence poses a threat to medical research."

Owen Davies, a QC specialising in criminal law, said the courts in England and Wales also had power to authorise the use of confidential medical data.

"I'm surprised doctors don't make more of a fuss about this. There is a clear public interest that outweighs the individual interest in the rare case where police would like to know what went on between doctor and patient."

A spokesman for the MRC said: "Confidentiality has never been an absolute. The law allows police investigating serious crimes to obtain orders forcing health professionals to disclose information, and the General Medical Council instructs doctors that they have a professional duty to comply with the courts' instructions.

"This case involved an investigation into a serious crime where the police already had a great deal of information on the accused.

"There was thus a strong public interest in disclosure of the small amount of specific information needed. This rare and exceptional case does not change the general position on the confidentiality of information obtained for medical research."

webTitle: Woman found guilty of towpath rape

fields.headline: Woman found guilty of towpath rape
fields.standfirst: Teenager punched victim and held her down in gang attack
fields.trailText: Teenager punched victim and held her down in gang attack
fields.body:
A teenager became what is believed to be the youngest woman ever to be convicted of rape yesterday when a court ruled she stripped, punched and pinned down a 37-year-old woman during a "particularly vile and horrifying" sex attack.

Claire Marsh, 18, joined the handful of women convicted of the crime after the jury found she was a central figure in the gang rape, which happened after 14 people lured the victim to the side of the Grand Union canal in Ladbroke Grove, west London, in July last year.

The jury at Blackfriars crown court decided that she not only held down her victim so that two friends could rape her but rallied the teenagers with cries of "Yeah, do her" and "Go on, give her some".

Richard Whittam, for the prosecution, said: "If she was party to the group attack and if she was actively encouraging and therefore ready to lend a physical hand or if she was holding down while the offence was taking place, she in law, would be guilty of rape, although a female."

The teenager's conviction came after her two fellow rapists, Marvin Edwards, 18, of Brentford, west London, and a 15-year-old, from Plaistow, east London, changed their pleas to guilty at the start of the three-week trial. A second 15-year-old and 16-year-old, who also stood trial with Marsh for being part of the "joint enterprise", were cleared.

As her verdict was read, Marsh, a one-time bingo-caller from Margate, Kent, remained stony-faced before turning to shrug at her mother in the public gallery, who was crying.

Judge Timothy Pontius rejected a bail application, ruling that she remain in custody until sentencing at the Old Bailey on May 8. "Given this was a particularly vile and horrifying offence of sexual brutality, a substantial custodial sentence is inevitable," he warned.

The jury had heard how the night of the rape, July 21, had begun as a "pleasant evening" for the victim, drinking in the sunshine of Ladbroke Grove with friends.

The woman, a professional who is now eight months' pregnant, though not as a result of the rape, had a couple of pints at her local before meeting her boyfriend at 7pm at a pub in Portobello Road and then moving on alone to a bar in the nearby Harrow Road in the hope of meeting a girlfriend. She was not there, but the woman remained drinking with other friends before leaving at midnight to go home.

The woman met a stocky black youth and a woman "with short dark hair" - believed to be Edwards and Marsh.The pair offered her a joint and, in a "pretty tipsy" state, she followed them on to the tow-path.

That decision led her to fall straight into the clutches of the Drayford Crew - a gang of teenagers, some as young as 12, who spent their days playing truant, "smoking pot and getting laid" in a local park and, for some, "borrowing" mopeds on which to drive around the area's estates.

Only two of the youths had convictions for petty crimes - but the 10 boys and four girls were, in practice, a band of thieves who terrorised the local estates and had a fear of being seen as "a grass."

So intense was this fear that Edwards warned the 16-year-old not to talk to police by threatening to blow up his home. Four of the gang - including the cleared 15-year-old - were taken to a youth court for intimidating a girl member.

The crew did not regard their crime as morally repugnant in any way. Police were able to arrest them quickly because Edwards and the guilty 15-year-old had been bragging about what they had done in the neighbourhood; gang members insisted "she was asking for it". As for Marsh, who has nine GCSEs and came across in police interviews as confident, level-headed, quietly-spoken and intelligent, if somewhat "stern", she showed no remorse.

"She said she was sorry for the woman but I personally felt it wasn't genuine", said Detective Constable Christopher Felton, who first interviewed her. The gang's lack of sympathy for their victim emerged as they watched her from the steps of Ladbroke Bridge, wending her way across the Grand Union Canal. "Let's jack [rob] her", one youth suggested, and Marsh and Edwards ran up to lure her down.

At first the mood seemed light: one of the girls asked for a cigarette and the woman handed over a packet.

Once by the canal the 16-year-old allegedly placed his arm around the victim's shoulders. Marsh began to surreptitiously rifle through her jacket pockets for money.

Gradually, the talk became sexual: there was jesting about swapping pot for "a blow job". And then she felt uncomfortable. "I felt a couple of people, one was a girl, getting close, too close," the woman told the court. "Then I was in the canal. I didn't slip, I was pushed or tripped. I went into very sober escape mode."

She hauled herself out but her ordeal had only just begun. A girl's voice commanded: "Yeah, do her", and then they piled in, with Marsh, the daughter of a martial arts instructor, punching her and holding down her arms.

One gang member told of how she "booted" their victim in the face as she fell, while another described her ripping off the woman's top.

As she did so, the 15-year-old rapist pulled down her trousers and raped her. Edwards, who has learning difficulties, then did the same, while Marsh, who had only known Edwards a few weeks and the others days, taunted her with cries of "Oh, you slag!", and rallied the rapists with the cry: "Go on, give her some."

As her victim was to tell the court: "I just remember the girl, the one I met on the bridge, in front of me, pointing at me and laughing and encouraging them." The woman escaped after 15 minutes but was caught. She later managed to struggle free.

Police said that though "obviously distraught", she was "a strong woman who has coped with it as well as anyone could". But one senior detective said she felt particularly betrayed by Marsh's involvement: "The impression she gives is that she feels more betrayed that a woman could egg on all these boys to do it."

fields.headline: Can you dig it?
fields.standfirst: Of course you can... Your distressed and battered garden needs you. It may look like some post-nuclear battleground, but now is the time to launch your attack on weeds, churn up the cracked soil and strike back with the secaturs. The spring offensive starts here. Ann-Marie Powell shows you where to begin.
fields.trailText: Of course you can... Your distressed and battered garden needs you. It may look like some post-nuclear battleground, but now is the time to launch your attack on weeds, churn up the cracked soil and strike back with the secaturs. The spring offensive starts here. Ann-Marie Powell shows you where to begin.
fields.body:
First things first. Force yourself out of your back door and take a long, hard look at what you see. Stop deluding yourself: your garden is in need of serious surgery. Clear the smokescreen that says it's "mature", "natural-looking" or "filled with unkempt charm". Deep down, you know your plants have grown into a semi-solid, lumpy kind of hybrid that you forgivingly describe as a border. The lawn (if you can call it that) has probably sprouted dandelions and moss over its once-clean surface, and anything that's not perpetually green is now a tangled mass of bunged-together dead growth.

If you're ever going to enjoy a summer barbecue, chinking beers with friends in that twinkling oasis of calm, then you're going to have to take serious action. And you need do it now before it's too late. Too much time considering how you're going to perform that facelift, and your garden will have taken the law into its own hands. Come June, you won't be able to see the plants for the weeds, climbers will have spiralled out of control - becoming a twisted mass of ugly, naked stems with any flowers hanging precariously high up - and shrubs will have developed into veritable monsters; blocking out light and snarling over everything. If you decide to attack them with the loppers, they'll probably curl up and die just to spite you. Now who wants that amount of gardening grief?

Incidentally, if you're thinking of using the "I don't know where to start" routine, then forget it. The first step in organising your garden is organising yourself. So here is a list of what to do: get yourself into gear now and get outside.

Fully tooled-up

Did you really think you were going to get through spring with only the contents of your cutlery drawer to aid your horticultural endeavours? Scissors are not effective at cutting lawns and serving spoons will never replace the trowel. If you can get at your shed, prise open the door, clear the cobwebs and look inside. If anything remotely garden-ish is in there, pull it out and give it a shake. Any tool that has started to rust is best re-housed in the dustbin. Dirty equipment is the fastest way to spread disease, and eventually death, in your borders. If your gardening ventures in the past have been few and far between, then you'll probably need to invest in some tools. Get to the garden centre (avoiding the rows of gorgeous looking plants for now) and head for the tool section. I'm not suggesting you need to buy one of everything, but you will at least need the basics.

The first absolute necessity is a fork. Far more useful than a spade, you can use it to dig, weed, split up plants and shift things. Try out as many as you can before you buy one, to see which suits you best. If you can stretch to the pricier, stainless-steel models, then do - stainless steel cuts through soil better than anything else, taking some of the work out of a tiring job. And think about the handle, too. Wood is soft and kind to hands, not cold like metal or harsh like plastic (which always seems to cut my hands).

Next, pick up some secateurs. They come in lots of different shapes, weights and sizes, and with two different types of blade - anvil and scissor. Go for scissor blades and keep them sharp. Anvil blades tend to crush plant stems, which can lead to infections. A good-quality (and very sharp) set of scissor blades, on the other hand, glides effortlessly through most pruning jobs, making clean cuts which encourage good growth. Buy a hoe, a watering can and a trowel, too. They can be as cheap as you like: in my opinion, one is much like another.

Eventually, you'll probably also need a rake, a wheelbarrow, some loppers and plenty more things, but as you'll never need to use all of them at at once, why not add to the basics as the need arises? Once home, store your shiny new possessions in a dry place, out of direct sunlight, and look after them.

Pruning

There is something intensely satisfying in cutting away at a plant, especially if it's dead, damaged or diseased. Now is the perfect time to wield your power over the shrubs, climbers and perennials languishing in your garden. But only prune for a reason: some plants will never need it and, once in, they'll grow quite happily without assistance from you. Let yourself loose on buddleia, mallow (lavatera), dogwoods (cornus), herbaceous perennials (plants that come up each year) that look dead and overgrown, hazels (corylus) and smoke trees (cotinus). All will benefit from cutting back to the ground. Go easy on fuchsia, hardy plumbago (ceratostigma), caryopteris, spiraea, hibiscus and hydrangea; you don't want to loose their shape. Lavenders should have old flowerheads and some of the stem clipped to keep them nicely hummocked. Clematis that need hard pruning are all the late summer and autumn flowerers. These include the jackmaniis, C. tangutica , C. rehderiana and C. viticella . If you've got an out-of- control C. montana , then it's safe to kerb it after it has flowered, which will be soon. Summer flowering jasmine can be rejuvenated by taking out a third of old growth every spring, while passion flowers can be cut to 1m above ground level every five years. If you're unsure, remember the old saying, "If it flowers before June, do not prune." This way, you won't butcher your garden into submission.

War on weeds

From now on, weeds are the enemy. They steal into your borders, pinching nutrients, light, water and space, eventually killing the plants you want to thrive. Dig them up (including the roots) before they flower, get rid of them and prevent them returning with the use of mulches (or weed-proof membranes), available from garden centres (better still, make your own mulch in a compost heap). Now that you can actually see the soil, dig it over, incorporating as much compost as you can lay your hands on. Compost will open up the soil, making it easier for roots to get down into it, ultimately leading to bigger, healthier plants. Sprinkle some general-purpose fertiliser around (fish, blood and bone is ideal); this will save you time later when you're planting. When digging over, bank the beds away from any lawn, then use your fork to level out the area.

Lawn again

If your lawn is starting to look a bit shaggy, raise the blades on your mower and cut it. Lawns hate being scalped at this time of the year. If you'd actually prefer to spend your time at the garden centre, then just trim the edges - it's amazing what a difference it will make.

Garden centre savvy

I have always thought that opening the door to a garden centre is a bit like opening Pandora's box. Enticed by the glamour of all those supermodel plants, people grab the most beautiful then ram then in the borders back home with no regard to eventual height and spread, main-tenance, sun or shade requirements, or soil type. Before you even step out of your front door, think about the plants your garden needs. Grab a book (Royal Horticultural Society plant encyclopaedias are ideal), see which plants you like (making sure they'll actually grow where you plan to put them), then write a list. And stick to it.

The way forward

That's it. The backbreaking work is over. Now you can take pleasure in watching your garden grow. Resolve to give it 10 minutes here and there, even if it's just once a week, and you'll be rewarded with a space that practically looks after itself

If anything remotely garden-ish is in there, pull it out and give it a shake. Any tool that has started to rust is best re-housed in the dustbin. Dirty equipment is the fastest way to spread disease, and eventually death, in your borders. If your gardening ventures in the past have been few and far between, then you'll probably need to invest in some tools. Get to the garden centre (avoiding the rows of gorgeous looking plants for now) and head for the tool section. I'm not suggesting you need to buy one of everything, but you will at least need the basics. The first absolute necessity is a fork. Far more useful than a spade, you can use it to dig, weed, split up plants and shift things. Try out as many as you can before you buy one, to see which suits you best. If you can stretch to the pricier, stainless-steel models, then do - stainless steel cuts through soil better than anything else, taking some of the work out of a tiring job. And think about the handle, too. Wood is soft and kind to hands, not cold like metal or harsh like plastic (which always seems to cut my hands). Next, pick up some secateurs. They come in lots of different shapes, weights and sizes, and with two different types of blade - anvil and scissor. Go for scissor blades and keep them sharp. Anvil blades tend to crush plant stems, which can lead to infections. A good-quality (and very sharp) set of scissor blades, on the other hand, glides effortlessly through most pruning jobs, making clean cuts which encourage good growth. Buy a hoe, a watering can and a trowel, too. They can be as cheap as you like: in my opinion, one is much like another. Eventually, you'll probably also need a rake, a wheelbarrow, some loppers and plenty more things, but as you'll never need to use all of them at at once, why not add to the basics as the need arises? Once home, store your shiny new possessions in a dry place, out of direct sunlight, and look after them. Pruning There is something intensely satisfying in cutting away at a plant, especially if it's dead, damaged or diseased. Now is the perfect time to wield your power over the shrubs, climbers and perennials languishing in your garden. But only prune for a reason: some plants will never need it and, once in, they'll grow quite happily without assistance from you. Let yourself loose on buddleia, mallow (lavatera), dogwoods (cornus), herbaceous perennials (plants that come up each year) that look dead and overgrown, hazels (corylus) and smoke trees (cotinus). All will benefit from cutting back to the ground. Go easy on fuchsia, hardy plumbago (ceratostigma), caryopteris, spiraea, hibiscus and hydrangea; you don't want to loose their shape. Lavenders should have old flowerheads and some of the stem clipped to keep them nicely hummocked. Clematis that need hard pruning are all the late summer and autumn flowerers. These include the jackmaniis, C. tangutica , C. rehderiana and C. viticella . If you've got an out-of- control C. montana , then it's safe to kerb it after it has flowered, which will be soon. Summer flowering jasmine can be rejuvenated by taking out a third of old growth every spring, while passion flowers can be cut to 1m above ground level every five years. If you're unsure, remember the old saying, "If it flowers before June, do not prune." This way, you won't butcher your garden into submission. War on weeds From now on, weeds are the enemy. They steal into your borders, pinching nutrients, light, water and space, eventually killing the plants you want to thrive. Dig them up (including the roots) before they flower, get rid of them and prevent them returning with the use of mulches (or weed-proof membranes), available from garden centres (better still, make your own mulch in a compost heap). Now that you can actually see the soil, dig it over, incorporating as much compost as you can lay your hands on. Compost will open up the soil, making it easier for roots to get down into it, ultimately leading to bigger, healthier plants. Sprinkle some general-purpose fertiliser around (fish, blood and bone is ideal); this will save you time later when you're planting. When digging over, bank the beds away from any lawn, then use your fork to level out the area. Lawn again If your lawn is starting to look a bit shaggy, raise the blades on your mower and cut it. Lawns hate being scalped at this time of the year. If you'd actually prefer to spend your time at the garden centre, then just trim the edges - it's amazing what a difference it will make. Garden centre savvy I have always thought that opening the door to a garden centre is a bit like opening Pandora's box. Enticed by the glamour of all those supermodel plants, people grab the most beautiful then ram then in the borders back home with no regard to eventual height and spread, main-tenance, sun or shade requirements, or soil type. Before you even step out of your front door, think about the plants your garden needs. Grab a book (Royal Horticultural Society plant encyclopaedias are ideal), see which plants you like (making sure they'll actually grow where you plan to put them), then write a list. And stick to it. The way forward That's it. The backbreaking work is over. Now you can take pleasure in watching your garden grow. Resolve to give it 10 minutes here and there, even if it's just once a week, and you'll be rewarded with a space that practically looks after itself

webTitle: Death of nameless baby has shaken a city

fields.headline: Death of a nameless baby that has shaken a city
fields.standfirst: Police still baffled over tiny charred body as deprived Edinburgh estate unites in grief
fields.trailText: Police still baffled over tiny charred body as deprived Edinburgh estate unites in grief
fields.body:
He was found among the litter in a desolate corner of Edinburgh's Craigmillar estate. Naked and burned and just days old. A small, nameless boy whose death has roused a community and shaken a city to its core.

Billy Franks was walking his dogs at the back of Harewood Crescent last Sunday when he came across the body. It's a bleak landscape of boarded tenement windows and wind-blown rubbish.

The baby had a shock of dark hair and was lying on his side, fists drawn up towards his chest.

Nearby lay a Babygro and a petrol can. Franks, a former soldier who has seen his share of horrors, stumbled to a neighbour's house and called the police.

The story might have ended there. A few paragraphs detailing another local tragedy. But this is Craigmillar, a scheme blighted as much by misconception as by deprivation; and this is Edinburgh, affluent and cultured, glorying in an economic boom.

It's been a week since the discovery, and the police are still baffled.

There is no sign of the mother beyond a sighting of a distressed teenage girl in the area; no hint of what pushed someone to discard the boy on wasteground.

The postmortem examination results have been inconclusive, although police have confirmed that the baby's body was charred. He had drawn breath, however, for at least a couple of days.

The search has widened and 35 officers are now working the case. Craigmillar, meanwhile, has made the boy its own with an outpouring of grief and support. People with little to give have set up a committee to raise money for a funeral and a memorial.

Toys and floral tributes are piling up at the spot where he was left and, if he is never identified, they plan to name him Billy, after Billy Franks. "I think it's the very facts of what happened to the him," said Midge Lamb, the estate's social welfare coordinator. "If he had been abandoned to be found, if he had been stillborn. But the wee soul didn't have a chance and then someone tried to cover the fact that he had ever existed. That's the most horrific thing. That's what's getting to the community.

"But it is not a surprise the way the community has reacted. This is what Craigmillar does and he has struck a chord."

The estate lies on the eastern margin of the city, on the edge of old mining land. Officially, it is being regenerated with some £300m but residents say it is only being prettified by planners keen to erase a blot from Edinburgh's elegant facade. It has a grim reputation. Oxfam's first British project was set up in Craigmillar and the scheme has struggled with economic and social ills. Last year, a commission on social exclusion in the capital identified Craigmillar as one of the key areas of concern.

Richard Holloway, the former Bishop of Edinburgh, who chaired the commission, said he had not been surprised by the overwhelming reaction to the boy's death.

"I think this demonstrates the fact that Craigmillar in spite of its difficulties is filled with warm-hearted people, many of them struggling in quite difficult circumstances," he said. "What strikes me about this response is it has focused on compassion rather than tabloid anger. That is very heartwarming."

Janet McKay, 57, who has lived in the estate all her life, says that it has never lost its heart. "We just feel so strongly about this baby. He belongs to us. He will not be forgotten and he will not go into the ground without a name. We will give him a decent burial with a name and a headstone and there will always be a fresh flower."

At the Richmond Craigmillar Church, minister Liz Henderson has given over her hall to the committee coordinating the community response.

"We have had more than our fair share of tragedies here, " she said. "But I have never seen such an amazing depth of concern for those in need. At the end of the day it doesn't matter how someone dies; if it was an accident or an overdose or a murder. The whole community pulls together.

"There is no sense of judgment. Just deep sadness and a willingness to do whatever they can to help."

Since he found the boy, Billy Franks has busied himself with fundraising and organising. He cannot explain the scale of the reaction, although he feels a bond with the infant. He sat with him until the police arrived and he doesn't want anyone to forget about him. He is pleased his story is reaching beyond Craigmillar'and striking a chord in Edinburgh and beyond.

"I want every mum and dad to think this is their baby, every child to think it's their brother," he said. "If we can get that then maybe we will have achieved something that all the other initiatives the city has come up with have failed to do in terms of bringing people together; showing what's important to us all."

webTitle: Dictionary quest for last word on Mr Nice Guy

fields.headline: Dictionary quest for last word on Mr Nice Guy
fields.trailText: Once they would not have had to dabble in such loose talk. But yesterday the scholars of the Oxford English Dictionary appealed for public help to find out who first gave the English language phrases such as "No more Mr Nice Guy" and "I could murder a curry".
fields.body:
Once they would not have had to dabble in such loose talk. But yesterday the scholars of the Oxford English Dictionary appealed for public help to find out who first gave the English language phrases such as "No more Mr Nice Guy" and "I could murder a curry".

Oxford University Press also needs a fairly urgent hand in nailing seven other modern words and phrases, including Murphy's law and mushy peas.

The lexicographers are ranging through M, N and O in their new revision of the 20-volume OED for theprint version and the international website. They already have many helpers: two dozen full-time readers of books, papers and magazines; 150 unpaid "principal" members of the public; and thousands of others who send in the occasional jewel.

But these helpers are not always versed in popular culture. The dictionary founder, Sir James Murray, did not have to worry about rude slang 143 years ago. Today it is an embarrassment that the OED has no provable usage for "off one's tits" earlier than John Birmingham's 1994 Australian student novel He Died With a Felafel in His Hand.

Stale peas mashed into paste were in the diet of the poor for centuries before reaching modern chip shops. Yet the best the helpers can offer is Guardian Weekly's 1981 mention: "Mushy peas would have been the sailors' victory feast."

If the helpers are to be believed, Punch coined another phrase in 1986 when a contributor wrote: "I could murder a plate of ham and eggs." Edmund Viner, OED deputy editor, wants to hear of earlier usages - especially references to murdering curry and pints.

He thinks the helpers may be on safer ground in dating No more Mr Nice Guy to a 1973 song title by the rock singer Alice Cooper.

Murphy's law is usually credited to Captain Edward Murphy, who in a 1945 US air force study on deceleration wrote: "I noted that, if things could be done wrongly, they would be."

However, the veteran US astronaut John Glenn is said to trace it to a fictional character in a US navy wartime educational cartoon series, but no one has yet sent Mr Viner a reference authenticating this.

Other terms on which the OED would like help are monopolising as an adjective (earliest reference 1891), mop bucket (1941), musical statues (1955) and smart casual (1982).

Information to oed3@oup.co.uk or the OED at Walton Street, Oxford OX2 6DP.

webTitle: HIV man jailed for knowingly infecting lover

fields.headline: HIV man jailed for knowingly infecting lover
fields.standfirst:
Five-year sentence will deter openness about virus and discourage testing, say support groups

Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: Five-year sentence will deter openness about virus and discourage testing, say support groups
fields.body:
A man found guilty of infecting his girlfriend with the HIV virus was jailed for five years yesterday in a case that has made British legal history and caused an outcry by HIV and human rights campaigners.

Stephen Kelly, 33, of Provanmill in Glasgow, was found guilty last month of endangering Anne Craig, a mother of three, by repeatedly having sex with her despite knowing he carried the virus. At the high court in Edinburgh yesterday he was jailed for five years for culpable and reckless conduct.

It is the first time in the UK that anyone has been convicted of deliberately infecting another person with the virus, and the sentence has been condemned by campaigners who say it will only criminalise the disease and further stigmatise and alienate sufferers.

There are also concerns that police investigating the case were able to seize evidence of blood samples from a confidential clinical trial to use in the prosecution.

Kelly, who denied the charge, had met Ms Craig in 1994, six months after he had been diagnosed with HIV while serving a prison sentence.

Ms Craig, 34, told the court during Kelly's trial that she had asked him if there was any reason other than the risk of pregnancy why they should not have unprotected sex. He said no. Kelly had argued that he had been honest about his heroin use and HIV infection during their relationship.

Sentencing him, the judge, Lord Mackay of Drumadoon, said Kelly had shown total disregard for Ms Craig, and the jail term reflected the gravity of the charge and the severe consequences of his actions. "She has suffered several years of serious illness and her life expectancy has been seriously reduced," he said.

The judge said it was for the prison authorities and Scottish ministers to decide whether a deterioration in Kelly's medical condition warranted early release from prison. Kelly showed no emotion as he was led away to begin his sentence.

In a statement released afterwards, Ms Craig said the sentence itself was irrelevant. "I have no comment to make on the severity or leniency of the sentence, as it's irrelevant to me," she said.

"All I wanted was for the jury to hold Mr Kelly responsible for what has happened to me and I was delighted by its decision. Mr Kelly refused to accept responsibility for this offence, but the court did that for him. That was all that mattered to me."

Her lawyer, Cameron Fyfe, said the sentence reflected the "life of misery" to which Kelly had subjected his former girlfriend.

"This case contains a warning that we should be cautious about our sexual health," he said. "It should also be a deterrent to others not to act in the way Mr Kelly has done."

HIV support groups, however, said the sentence could have a devastating effect on efforts to destigmatise the disease and persuade people to be open about infection. Kelly was prosecuted under common law in Scotland but the Home Office said a similar prosecution could be pursued in England and Wales under the 1861 Offences Against the Person Act.

"We don't believe that criminalising the virus is going to make things any better," said Lisa Power of the Terrence Higgins Trust.

"It will discourage people from testing and it will create a false complacency because people may see the trial and think in future people will tell me.

"It is really going to help restigmatise HIV in a way that is hugely unhelpful. We have been working towards a situation where people with HIV are able to talk about their status and don't feel afraid or feel they need to conceal it."

At the Phace West support group in Glasgow, director Charlie Macmillan said they had already had calls from sufferers following the trial. "People are just very worried and very unclear what the limits are. Will it relate to use of dirty needles or mother to child transmission? The boundaries of this are so unclear."

Lawyers for Kelly had told the judge that he had believed Ms Craig had known of his HIV status. Defence counsel Petra Collins said the couple had embarked on a relationship shortly after Kelly had lost his long-term partner and had been diagnosed with HIV. She said he had not shown any symptoms for some time but had recently started taking combination therapy drugs.

"He is suffering as Ann Craig is suffering and at this stage in both their lives it is not helpful to define who is suffering the most," she said. "This is a tragedy for both of them and for both of their families."
