webTitle: Search for a new sort of fan

fields.headline: Search for a new sort of fan
fields.standfirst: Measures to broaden football support base embraced by FA
fields.trailText: Measures to broaden football support base embraced by FA.
fields.body:
A call was issued yesterday for a new type of England fan to try to break the stereotype of the shaven-headed racist hooligan normally associated with the team.

The Football Association announced that it is to comply with a Home Office report released yesterday suggesting that the 30,000-strong England Members Club (EMC) be scrapped and replaced with a new supporters' club.

The new organisation will be known as Club England and will be formally launched in the summer. A Club England roadshow will also tour the country in an attempt to recruit more ethnic-minority England fans.

The EMC, which organises travel to matches at home and abroad, has been accused of being dominated by white males, many of them racist.

The report, which was chaired by Home Office minister Lord Bassam, makes several recommendations on combating football hooliganism and widening the support base of the England team.

The report concedes: "It will not be easy to attract a more diverse following, particularly when England matches are shrouded in an atmosphere of xenophobia and violence."

One aim of Club England will be to make "supporting the national side a more attractive option to those sections of society currently under-represented, families, women and minority ethnic communities.

"It is unacceptable for any section of the community to feel excluded."

All 30,000 members of the existing EMC will be asked to reapply to join Club England. All new members will be asked to declare any convictions. The Home Office and the FA are currently working on guidelines which could rule out people with certain types of convictions. During matches, covert filming of England fans could also take place. If any club members are found indulging in anti-social behaviour, they could be expelled. Members will also sign up to a code of conduct before being admitted to the club.

The report also calls for England stewards to travel with fans to away matches. It suggests that some of these stewards should be capable of speaking the language of the country England are visiting.

The report was compiled by organisations including the FA, supporters' groups, players' representatives, anti-racism groups and members of the England Members Club.

Regarding the domestic game, the report calls for clubs to improve the standard of stewarding to tackle anti-social behaviour and ensure crowd safety. It also calls for clubs to encourage self-policing amongst fans so that they can point out troublemakers.

Lord Bassam said: "Football has a key role to play in fostering a positive national identity and combating social exclusion. We are not prepared to tolerate our national game being blighted by violence."

webTitle: Police fear birth of the intercontinental hooligan

fields.headline: Police fear birth of the intercontinental hooligan
fields.trailText: Never mind the Intercity Firm, the big threat at next year's World Cup could be the high-flying, hard-drinking intercontinental hooligan, according to the head of the police football intelligence unit.
fields.body:
Never mind the Intercity Firm, the big threat at next year's World Cup could be the high-flying, hard-drinking intercontinental hooligan, according to the head of the police football intelligence unit.

Gangs of drunk and disorderly fans on flights to Japan and South Korea pose safety and security problems unseen at previous football events, said Bryan Drew, detective superintendent of the national criminal intelligence service.

"Potentially there are threats to the safety of aeroplanes if passengers are drinking for eight, nine and 10 hours at a stretch," Mr Drew warned the organisers at a symposium in Tokyo. "This is an issue that requires serious consideration."

As a possible countermeasure, the British detective suggested that airline operators should consider restrictions on free in-flight alcohol services during the May 31 to June 30 tournament.

In Japan, which has never had a hooligan problem, organisers are uncertain how to deal with an influx of European supporters.

Many were shocked at the sight of drunken and violent fans on the rampage during the 1998 World Cup in France and the 2000 European championships in Belgium and the Netherlands.

The experts at the symposium yesterday said alcohol was often a factor in violence. "Scottish, Swedish, Danish and Irish fans are all heavy drinkers, but they have fun when drunk. Other nationalities, including the British, are more inclined to become aggressive," said David Beaumont, an inspector at the football licensing authority.

The Japanese organisers believe that the long distance and high cost of visiting Japan and South Korea will deter many potential hooligans. They also hope to reduce the possibility of trouble through a named ticketing system that will allow police and stewards to check the identity of ticketholders.

"We mustn't be complacent, but preparations are proceeding smoothly," said Takahisa Nishida, director of security in the Japan World Cup organising committee. "We aim to present the smiling face of Japan to the world, but, if there is trouble, we are ready to lock up and prosecute hooligans."

Even if England or Wales qualify, many hooligans will be prevented from travelling to the Far East. Under new laws, proven troublemakers will have to surrender their passports before the tournament.

Three hundred fans are already subject to the international ban. Mr Drew said the number will be closer to 1,000 by next year.

webTitle: Surprise encounter for thief and victim

fields.headline: Surprise encounter for thief and victim
fields.trailText: Forcing criminals to meet their victims to discuss their crimes is often recommended as a form of crime prevention. But usually the criminal does not have to face a victim wearing a wig and a red gown and waiting to pass sentence.
fields.body:
Forcing criminals to meet their victims to discuss their crimes is often recommended as a form of crime prevention. But usually the criminal does not have to face a victim wearing a wig and a red gown and waiting to pass sentence.

That was the position Dennis Noel, of London, found himself in yesterday when he arrived in the dock at Middlesex crown court.

Noel, who had pleaded guilty to charges of burglary and theft of computers from offices in the Gray's Inn area of London - home to countless members of the legal profession - was to be sentenced by recorder Geoffrey Robertson QC.

But shortly before the hearing, the prosecution was given a list of 50 similar offences to be taken into consideration.

There was consternation in the court when the prosecuting counsel realised that among the items Noel admitted stealing was a personal computer belonging to the judge, which had been taken from his chambers in July last year.

"I shall resist the temptation to ask what happened to it," Mr Robertson told Noel, before ordering that the case be dealt with by another judge, on the grounds that he might be perceived to be biased.

Sentencing was adjourned until March 30.

webTitle: Gardens of Eden open to public

fields.headline: Gardens of Eden open to public
fields.trailText: After the wobbly bridge and the Dome fiasco, a millennium success story.
fields.body:
After the wobbly bridge and the Dome fiasco, a millennium success story. The Eden Project, three huge domes of horticultural diversity housed in a disused clay pit, opens today on time and to near universal approval.

The £86m project, part-funded by the Millennium commission, was conceived by horticulturalist and former TV executive Tim Smit. The greenhouse, in St Austell, Cornwall, will house 12,000 plant species from all five continents in three "biomes" with artificial climates.

The largest biome, 55 metres tall and 100 metres wide, reproduces the 65% humidity and temperatures of the tropics and features plants from west Africa and south America.

Philip McMillan Browse, horticultural director, said: "This is not a garden. We are creating a museum and the plants are a series of exhibits."

It is hoped that the project will boost Cornwall's economy with 750,000 visitors expected annually. Around 500,000 people have already been to watch the huge domes being built.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Teachers' salaries | Eastenders plots stolen | Truck rolls into North sea | Bloody Sunday film grant | Charm school for cabbies
fields.body:
Teachers 'need £20,000 plus"

Starting salaries for teachers ought to be in the mid-£20,000s, Lord Puttnam, Labour peer and chairman of the general teaching council said yesterday but stressed it was a personal view. He also said that training institutions needed to be improved to attract the generation of teachers the country would need.

EastEnders plots stolen

Burglars stole a computer and hard disk containing storylines from EastEnders from the home of a scriptwriter, prompting fears they were looking for plotlines revealing who shot bad boy Phil Mitchell.

Truck rolls into North sea

A truck with 12 tons of fresh fish lorry and three vans ended up in the North sea when they rolled off the back of the HSS Discovery ferry sailing to Britain from the Hook of Holland.

Bloody Sunday film grant

Bloody Sunday, a film about the 1972 events when paras killed 13 during a civil rights march in Derry, has been given a £250,000 grant from the New Cinema Fund which aims to encourage homegrown successes. It will be directed by Paul Greengrass, who made Murder of Stephen Lawrence for television, and star Tim Pigott-Smith.

Charm school for cabbies

More than 600 taxi drivers in Scarborough, Whitby and Filey, North Yorkshire, will have to take part in a charm course as part of a new condition of their licences.

fields.headline: Famous then
fields.standfirst: Dee Hepburn
fields.trailText: Dee Hepburn
fields.body: Devotees of Crossroads may always think of her as Anne Marie Wade, but it is for her earlier role as the football-loving tomboy in the 1980 film Gregory's Girl that actress Dee Hepburn is most remembered. Just 16 at the time of the film, Hepburn continued to act for a further eight years, consciously ending her career in 1988 when Crossroads closed its doors. 'I took a few small parts in various television programmes, but I'd really decided by then that I wanted to settle down, and carrying on with acting just wouldn't have allowed that.' She now has two children, Stephen, nine, and Cassie, eight (above). Having gained sales experience with a video company before her children were born, Hepburn today works part-time as a medical rep for Ferring Pharmaceuticals, selling drugs aimed at combating bed- wetting. 'If I hadn't gone into acting, I would have liked to have pursued a medical career. I was too old to start studying after having the children, but the sales side was open to me. It's very rewarding, even though the attitude towards reps in this country is very bad. Bed-wetting is a heart-rending problem for families, and by passing accurate information on to GPs and sufferers, you really can make a difference.'

webTitle: Gap year teenagers die in Malawi crash

fields.headline: Gap year teenagers die in Malawi crash
fields.trailText: Three British teenagers teaching in Malawi on a gap year have died in a car crash, the Foreign Office said last night.
fields.body:
Three British teenagers teaching in Malawi on a gap year have died in a car crash, the Foreign Office said last night.

Amber Montgomery, 18, and Arabella McDonald, 19, who had both attended Benenden school in Cranbrook, Kent, and Kate Morgan, 18, were killed in the single vehicle accident.

Another woman, Elizabeth Ryan, was injured in the smash, which happened in Bawi, near Ntcheu, about two hours' drive from the capital Lilongwe.

"Five people, including three British teenage girls, were killed in the crash," said a Foreign Office spokesman. It is unclear how it happened but we know that no other vehicle was involved."

The three women arrived in the central African country in January for a four-month teaching attachment at the country's Mlanda girls secondary school. They were on a year out between school and university.

The families of the dead women have been informed, said the spokesman. Ms Ryan is being treated in the clinic at the British high commission in Lilongwe. Benenden said the deaths were a "tragedy".

The headmistress, Claire Oulton, said: "We are all deeply shocked. The school mourns the loss of two wonderful young women.

"Prayers have been said for Arabella and Amber and for their families and friends to whom we extend our deepest sympathies."

Press Association

fields.headline: OK! That's life
fields.trailText: You may have missed the story, but Muriel Harper, 83, of Walsall has just had her life saved by Esther Rantzen.
fields.body:
You may have missed the story, but Muriel Harper, 83, of Walsall has just had her life saved by Esther Rantzen. Not wanting to watch a moment more of her show and with the remote control broken, Mrs Harper got out of her chair to change channels. At that very instant her neighbour Mick Cassidy lost control of his Rolls-Royce, whereupon it crashed through her house and destroyed the chair she had been sitting in.

What a miracle worker Esther is! Uri Geller used to claim paranormal feats when he did go on TV. She saves lives by not appearing. We do not know whether she can bring back to life the Royal Opera House's production of Boulevard Solitude by Hans Werner Henze. This is, I am told, a difficult work, and not even a particularly good example of the composer's oeuvre. So the ROH has cut prices and has taken the curious step of offering free tickets to celebrities including Carol Vorderman, Joanna Lumley and Esther Rantzen. They must be desperate. I would probably turn down dress circle tickets to Madam Butterfly if I thought Esther might be in the audience, but then I am probably in a minority.

It's all part of this grotesque mania we have for celebrities. Look at the incredible success of Celebrity Big Brother, in which a bunch of people sit around boring the pants off each other and us. Out of the Sunday Express this week there fell a 74-page special edition of OK! magazine, devoted to glossy pictures of celebrities, only a few of whom have ever registered on most people's consciousness - including "handsome Emmerdale star Tim Vincent, Anne Davies of GMTV", plus a feature called Australian Actress Isla Fisher Shares Her Best Beauty Tips. To be fair there is some stuff about names one knows, including "Jeremy Beadle honoured" - not a line you often see in print.

Daniel Boorstin famously wrote that celebrities were people who were famous for being famous. These days that's not enough. You need a start. But, like the minute quantity of yeast which can make the largest, puffiest, spongiest white loaf, it doesn't need to be much. A part in a daytime soap. An affair with a footballer. A single hit record. A well-publicised cocaine habit. A relationship with Darren Day who seems to escort and later abandon a lot of women who become famous through being associated with him, a man who is famous in the first place for knowing them

The Leviathan has to be continually fed with yet more celebrities to fill our papers, most of which have much more newsprint than material to fill it with. As the Opera House problem reveals, celebrities are thought to have magical powers. Next: The Old Nail Forge Theatre, Devizes, presents Strindberg's most obscure play, in Swedish, to an audience of TV weather girls.

I was invited this week to the annual Meet the British press party thrown by the Foreign Press Association in their superb Carlton House Terrace premises. Gosh, it was embarrassing. Everyone was frightfully polite, but after about three seconds each conversation turned to "why on earth has everything in this country gone so wrong?" How can you reply, especially to people from functioning nations such as France or Switzerland? I could have said to the Swiss chap, "at least we're not insufferably complacent and boring" but you can hardly say that to a Frenchman. When various correspondents from the Third World asked the same thing, I was tempted to say: "You're right, pestilence and floods do stalk the land and our trains are a shambles, but at least the government doesn't imprison and torture its opponents, like yours." Of course I didn't. No doubt things will improve here in time, but it looks like being a few years.

The Conservatives are charging £9,000 per journalist to follow William Hague around for the election campaign. This seems a lot, even if it does include bus journeys, some trips by air and a modicum of food. I rang the upmarket travel agents Voyages Jules Verne to ask what holiday I could buy for the same amount. They said they didn't have anything as expensive, but a month at a luxury resort in the Maldive Islands, with flights, would cost around £6,700. Hmm, four weeks in the sun on a fabulous tropical island with £2,300 spending money, or a month with William Hague? I'll need time to think about that.

Today is St Patrick's Day, when we celebrate the last Englishman the Irish whole-heartedly welcomed until Jack Charlton. A kind friend has sent me a CD called I Can't Believe They're Not Bitter, a compilation of sectarian songs from Northern Ireland, both sides alternating on the disc with satirical effect. The Catholic songs tend to rejoice in their victimhood and triumph over persecution (The Men Behind The Wire, Kevin Barry), the Protestant songs more likely to raise a toast to the joys of vicious mayhem (The Night We Burned Ardoyne). But the eerie thing for the non-involved listener is that they all sound much the same: the same fiddles, the same lilting, jaunty rhythms and plangent airs verging on self-pity. Only an expert could possibly tell which side was which. There may be a lesson there, but I'm not altogether sure what it is.

Thanks for your many letters about the late lecturer Monica Jones, whom I suggested last week was the most fictionalised woman in Britain of the past 50 years. Several point out that her lover Philip Larkin wrote his novels before he met her, though apparently he did write a rather cruel one, in which she did figure, but which was never published. John Sutherland and others say that she is indeed Dr Viola Masefield in Malcolm Bradbury's Eating People Is Wrong, a kinder version than her appearance as Margaret in Lucky Jim. Ben Brown has sent me a copy of his play Larkin With Women, produced at Alan Ayckbourn's theatre. She's not strictly fictional in this work, but I think my point is made.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum
fields.standfirst: 'Why doesn't Gordon do  the decent thing and elope with Elaine again?'
fields.trailText:
'Why doesn't Gordon do
the decent thing and elope with Elaine again?'
fields.body:
Trapped, trapped, trapped. Great Aunt losing touch with reality, Harriet asleep all day and awake all night adorned with white make-up and hoping Hannibal Lecter will come down the chimney like a kind of carnivorous Santa. She got into the film easily, even though officially too young. It's people like me, over 50 and of a Nervous Disposition, who should be refused entry. "Did you recognise any places in Florence that we visited two years ago?" I enquire with a pitiful instinct to turn a depraved, atavistic eroticism into an educational experience. "Uh, yeah, that street . . ." grunts Harriet. Phew! That's all right, then. Trapped by crabbed age and youth, but most of all by Elaine and her child. For nearly three months she has been here, a refugee from her flooded and subsiding house. Will I never get rid of her? Why doesn't Gordon do the decent thing and elope with her all over again? I'm trapped with him, too. I seem to be running a day-care centre for obscure figures from my past. Any minute now I shall be making cups of tea for my own placenta.

Distribute the newspapers: the local paper to aged aunt and the Financial Times to Gordon. "Why the Financial Times?" I ask tartly. "Some mistake surely?" "It's a virtual thing," he explains. "Like being a eunuch on a topless beach." "Dulcie? May I check my emails?" Elaine is in the middle of negotiations with Tom in Italy. He and his restored sweetheart Francesca have started a business restoring old ruins. They are doing well and Elaine is coming to terms with losing him to Francesca, who has Italian roots and therefore an unfair advantage. Settle Elaine down with computer. I hate the way her pert nails click on the keyboard. I no longer have nails. I have begun to eat myself, starting at the edges. It's both an economical source of nourishment and ecologically responsible. "Have you seen the Rrrusbrrridge Gazette, dearrr?" Aunt comes faltering up. Drat the silly old bat! Settled her down with it only minutes ago.

"Have you been to the loo, Auntie?" "Can't rrrememberrr, dearrr." Find the newspaper in her bathroom and restore it to her. Oh God! The loss of marbles is an awful thing. "Dulcie! I've had an email from Tom! He says I can have the house - God, what a relief!" Congratulate Elaine, although still not convinced that sole possession of a structurally-damaged old rectory surrounded by ruined stables, decaying sheds, etc, on a flood plain, is much to celebrate. "What shall we do, Gordon?" she asks. Unnerved by the faintest whiff of a "we", he leaps up and dives into his coat. He has become an ardent supporter of Rusbridge Rovers, so that on Saturday afternoons, at least, he can escape the gang of tormenting harpies he lives with. Decide to put the kettle on. "Any jobs for me in the Gazette, Auntie?" I ask, squeezing past her chair, which has also acquired the faintest whiff of a wee. Aunt remains engrossed in local news. Her hearing aid is switched off. Safe in the WI reports, I expect. Intellectual equivalent of Ovaltine.

"What do you think, Gordon?" Elaine still convinced that a man always knows best. "Shall we get an estate agent in to value it?" Gordon frowns, pulls on his woolly hat and shrugs. "Possibly," he murmurs. "I'll give it some thought." Little Sandy comes cannoning into the room with his toy trumpet. Gordon cringes. "It says herrre in the paperrr" begins Aunt Elspeth - we all turn towards her with a patronising sigh. Must humour the old biddy.

What confused old twaddle will she come up with now? - "that they'rrre going to build flood defences just upstrrream of Great Pofforrrd. They'rrre going to demolish the old brrridge so they can imprrrove the channel and rrraise the flood defences. That'll drrry out that whole plain wherrre yourrr house is, Elaine. So, if I werrre you, dearrr, I'd get planning perrrmission on all those auld buildings of yourrrs and sell the whole site to a developerrrr!" Gordon pauses by the door. "Maybe we should get an architect to advise us," he ponders. Ah, he's plunged eagerly into the "we" now. As for the aged aunt, perhaps it is too soon to offer her a commode. fields.bodyText: Trapped, trapped, trapped. Great Aunt losing touch with reality, Harriet asleep all day and awake all night adorned with white make-up and hoping Hannibal Lecter will come down the chimney like a kind of carnivorous Santa. She got into the film easily, even though officially too young. It's people like me, over 50 and of a Nervous Disposition, who should be refused entry. "Did you recognise any places in Florence that we visited two years ago?" I enquire with a pitiful instinct to turn a depraved, atavistic eroticism into an educational experience. "Uh, yeah, that street . . ." grunts Harriet. Phew! That's all right, then. Trapped by crabbed age and youth, but most of all by Elaine and her child. For nearly three months she has been here, a refugee from her flooded and subsiding house. Will I never get rid of her? Why doesn't Gordon do the decent thing and elope with her all over again? I'm trapped with him, too. I seem to be running a day-care centre for obscure figures from my past. Any minute now I shall be making cups of tea for my own placenta. Distribute the newspapers: the local paper to aged aunt and the Financial Times to Gordon. "Why the Financial Times?" I ask tartly. "Some mistake surely?" "It's a virtual thing," he explains. "Like being a eunuch on a topless beach." "Dulcie? May I check my emails?" Elaine is in the middle of negotiations with Tom in Italy. He and his restored sweetheart Francesca have started a business restoring old ruins. They are doing well and Elaine is coming to terms with losing him to Francesca, who has Italian roots and therefore an unfair advantage. Settle Elaine down with computer. I hate the way her pert nails click on the keyboard. I no longer have nails. I have begun to eat myself, starting at the edges. It's both an economical source of nourishment and ecologically responsible. "Have you seen the Rrrusbrrridge Gazette, dearrr?" Aunt comes faltering up. Drat the silly old bat! Settled her down with it only minutes ago. "Have you been to the loo, Auntie?" "Can't rrrememberrr, dearrr." Find the newspaper in her bathroom and restore it to her. Oh God! "What shall we do, Gordon?" she asks. Unnerved by the faintest whiff of a "we", he leaps up and dives into his coat. He has become an ardent supporter of Rusbridge Rovers, so that on Saturday afternoons, at least, he can escape the gang of tormenting harpies he lives with. Decide to put the kettle on. They'rrre going to demolish the old brrridge so they can imprrrove the channel and rrraise the flood defences. That'll drrry out that whole plain wherrre yourrr house is, Elaine. webTitle: Dee free at last as Comic Relief heads for record

fields.headline: Dee free at last as Comic Relief heads for record
fields.standfirst: Special report: Big Brother
fields.trailText: Watching Vanessa Feltz lose her hair extensions in the cooking might not be everyone's idea of quality television, but viewers of the compulsive Celebrity Big Brother helped Comic Relief raise tens of millions, after a week-long ordeal for six contestants.
fields.body:
Watching Vanessa Feltz lose her hair extensions in the cooking might not be everyone's idea of quality television, but viewers of the compulsive Celebrity Big Brother helped Comic Relief raise tens of millions, after a week-long ordeal for six contestants.

Big Brother, the surreal centrepiece of this week's events, turned its overwhelmed winner, comedian Jack Dee, into a national sweetheart.

Red Nose Day has become an institution, with this year's slogan of "Say pants to Poverty" adding another twist to the already bizarre spectacle of 4m plastic noses adorning British faces and cars yesterday in aid of the charity.

During the Big Brother contestants' painfully public incarceration in a house full of cameras, Dee made several foiled escape attempts, managing to break free just long enough to give his wife Jane a hug. Last night, allowed to leave the house legitimately after being voted the winner by the viewing public, deadpan Dee finally showed emotion when he was greeted outside by Jane, hugging her tightly and planting a kiss on her lips.

Earlier Keith Duffy, a member of the boy band Boyzone and one of the most jovial members of the house, left after being voted out. He embraced fellow housemates Claire Sweeney, the Brookside actress, and Dee before leaving to a rapturous reception from fans gathered in the rain outside. He shouted: "I need a good drink."

The show has so far raised £500,000 for charity. The houses's first evictee, former boxer Chris Eubank, had been swiftly followed by a crestfallen Feltz, Anthea Turner, then Duffy and finally runner-up Sweeney.

Despite sour grapes from "nasty" Nick Bateman, Big Brother's original celebrity, who dismissed the latest contestants as "a bunch of desperate celebrities trying to advance dwindling careers", the programme raised millions as the public phoned to vote for the latest evictees.

Elsewhere, more than 150,000 fundraising events led up to yesterday's BBC television extravaganza, which also featured a long-awaited interview between Ali G and the Beckhams.

Robbie Williams's personal belongings were auctioned and Billy Connolly performed one of his habitual streaks, this time around Eros in Piccadilly. It was only to be screened last night if television audiences raised £1m in an hour. A special edition of Harry Potter books looks set to raise up to £20m from worldwide sales.

A total of £174m has been raised since Red Nose Day's inception in 1985. Then it was launched from a refugee camp in Sudan in 1985 as an attempt to relieve poverty in Africa.

But more than a quarter of this year's money has come from commercial donors, turning Red Nose into a brand in its own right and posing questions about the spirit of the campaign.

Earlier in the week BT was criticised for taking a hefty portion of money from people calling its Comic Relief premium rate line.

fields.headline: How to...
fields.standfirst: be normal
fields.trailText: be normal
fields.body:
Normal people are extremely unusual. Think of all the people you know and ask yourself how many are normal. None of them. In fact, you're probably the most normal of the lot. Of course, normality is a relative thing. If you have relatives, they're unlikely to be normal. Normal people wear things that aren't trendy, but neither are they uncool. Only when flared trousers hit the high street will normal people be wearing them. Abnormal people will have worn them willy-nilly for the past 10 years. Normal people don't have their own taste in anything. They like whatever is good at the moment. Not really good, but averagely good. The fashion industry is dedicated to changing what is normal. That's why models and what they wear never look normal. Normal people don't ask you what you do for a living because this only encourages you to ask what they do, and what they do is very normal; so normal, in fact, that conversations usually falter after they tell you.

Normal people do normal things in bed with other normal people. Occasionally they try something a little bit different or they do it with somebody a little bit different. That's all perfectly normal. Normal people are distinguished by the fact that they all believe they are a little bit different, a little bit unique and a little bit special. This feeling is shared with all normal people. The only people who don't share this are wide-eyed, staring eccentrics who think that they are perfectly normal. Being normal is actually a very good disguise for being a barking eccentric. Under many a v-neck sweater there beats a heart of utter bizarreness. When multiple axe-murderers are discovered, the comments of the neighbours always tend to be along the lines of, 'He seemed perfectly normal.'

Most normal people have something about themselves that they consider to be abnormal, like big ears, or no hair, or a funny voice or pigeon toes. These people would rather that they had normal hair, ears, voice, toes, etc. But there's only one place on earth where people are perfectly normal and that's Hollywood. In our own minds we're all Hollywood potential if only everyone else wasn't blinkered to our potential by being so abnormally dim. It's galling to know that everything you do is perfectly normal. Trying to do something interesting and different is a real challenge, but millions and millions of people struggle to do it. There is one thing, however, that makes us all completely different and excitingly unique individuals, but you'll have to find that out for yourselves. Guy Browning

fields.headline: A true Brit
fields.trailText: What passed for salad dressing in the BV (Before Vinaigrette) era - and still serves where mayonnaise is considered exotic. The basics Salad cream seems to be an invention of the 19th century, when it was first called English sauce.
fields.body:
The subject: What passed for salad dressing in the BV (Before Vinaigrette) era - and still serves where mayonnaise is considered exotic.
The basics: Salad cream seems to be an invention of the 19th century, when it was first called English sauce. Appropriate, because no one seems to eat the stuff anywhere else. Britain buys around five million bottles a year; when Heinz proposed scrapping it a year or so back, the outcry forced it to reconsider. Heinz claims to be the alpha and omega salad cream. All it did, of course, was industrialise it and give the product a new name.
The details: Industrial-grade salad cream does not make a pretty list of ingredients: spirit vinegar, vegetable oil, water, sugar, mustard, salt, egg yolks, xanthan gum and guar gum, and colouring. All the more reason to make your own, following Ms Acton's recipe or Jane Grigson's Actonian adaptation in English Food if you need something modern (wimp!). Just one word of Knowledgerian warning: don't expect your potion to have the creamy stability of what squirts from the Heinz bottle. Salad cream is an emulsion. Emulsions, like your favourite teacup, have a tendency to break. (Why do you think Heinz uses stabilisers?) But better a grainy texture than a mouthful of xanthan gum. The Knowledge does acknowledge that some people retain a nostalgic fondness for the bottled stuff, even if he's not one of them. He eats it when it's served - for reasons investigated but undiscovered - with fried seafood dishes in certain Chinese restaurants. Homemade: for cold meat, poultry and fishy dishies. Salad - in the leafy sense of the word - is the worst place to splash it. The high gloop-factor sits as successfully on a leaf of cos as an elephant sits on a soap bubble.
The easy way out: Cream Meanz Heinz.
Where to buy: Eh?

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Conor McPherson
fields.trailText: Conor McPherson
fields.body:
Conor McPherson, 29, was born in Dublin. While he was studying philosophy at universilty, he began writing plays. His work was first performed in Dublin pubs, and then, in 1994, he was commissioned to write a screenplay. The resulting film, I Went Down, won Best Screenplay at the San Sebastian Festival. He made his name with the play The Weir, which won a string of awards. Port Authority, his latest work, premieres at the New Ambassadors Theatre in London until Saturday, March 31.

What is your idea of perfect happiness? Being dead for 400 years.
With which historical figure do you most identify? Socrates - because he claimed he knew nothing.
Which living person do you most admire? Billy Roche - because I love his work and I want him to be appreciated.
What has been your most embarrassing moment? From 1971-2001.
What is your greatest extravagance? A lie-in.
What objects do you always carry with you? Guilt and a notebook, but no pen.
Where would you like to live? In a grave.
What do you most dislike about your appearance? Other people's views.
What is your favourite book? Ceremony Of Innocence, by Anthony James Cassidy/American Psycho, by Bret Easton Ellis/The Dead School, by Pat McCabe.
What is your favourite fantasy? An open room, no commitments.
Should the royal family be scrapped? No, they are funny.
Do you believe in capital punishment? No.
Do you believe in monogamy? I'm not qualified.
What or who is the greatest love of your life? Work.
Which living person do you most despise? George W Bush - he scares me.
Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it? Yes.
What is your greatest regret? Being born.
How do you relax? I don't.
How often do you have sex? When I have the money.
What single thing would improve the quality of your life? Children.
Do you believe in life after death? I hope there isn't.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.body:
Ever since I began this column, I have been sniped at, mugged in print and, I must admit, epistolarily energised by readers who fall, roughly (all Guardian readers fall roughly; it is a considerable part of their charm), into two camps: those who find any wine that costs more than a tenner, or close to this horrific sum, unacceptable as a superplonk, and those who wonder how it is conceivable that anyone could possibly manufacture, let alone consume, a wine costing a good deal less than £2.99. Let us get the latter horror out of the way first. Somerfield's (and Kwik Save's) Vin de Pays des Coteaux de l'Ardeche Rouge 1999 is dry with a hint of rustic sod, and goes well with spicy food. It rates 14.5 points, and can be yours for the princely sum of £2.49 until April 3. At the other end of the scale, and over at Majestic, there is Wynns Coonawarra Cabernet Sauvignon 1997 at £9.99. Majestic demands nigh on a tenner from you to take off with a single bottle of this wine, but, of course, you can claim this single bottle only as part of a mixed case or a whole case. This wine offers a stunning level of classy elegance, with real live tannins that permits the lovely rich 17-point fruit to be textured, beautifully gripping and lingering.

If this is insufficiently outrageous for you, then Oddbins offers several alternatives. Elderton Barossa Shiraz 1997 (17 points, £12.99), from Australia, parades immensely dark fruit and depth with balsamic-textured hedgerow fruitiness and a great flourish on the finish. It is a brilliant example of truly sensual shiraz. Not to be outdone, Italy offers its own style of sensual fruitiness with Inferi Marramiero Montepulciano d'Abruzzo 1996 (17 points, £10.49), which has a jammy intensity allied to a delicious, food-friendly earthiness. You can, however, spend less at Oddbins and get more. Château de Nages Cuvée Joseph Torres Costières de Nimes 1997 (17.5 points, £6.99) is a complex, delicate yet rich and highly polished red wine offering a luxurious experience at what is, for certain drinkers, almost a vulgar plonk price. For them, Colomé Cabernet Malbec 1998 (17 points, £15.99), from Argentina, is comfortingly expensive and svelte. It is remarkably complex and deep; a wine that evolves at length on the tongue to reveal figs, tobacco, blackberries and spice, and then simply hangs on in there. To finish a meal at which such a gorgeous wine is served with the main course, there is the sybaritically honied Dindarello Maculan Veneto 1999 (17.5 points, in the half bottle for £6.99), which has an intense sweetness that reveals layers of pineapple, candied ginger and brûléed strawberries. It is a dessert wine to sip in awe or, indeed, in Ayr (where Oddbins has a branch).

These hedonistic and, it must be said, expensive treats are countered, this week, by Safeway, which has five interesting wines all for less than a fiver. Chilean Sauvignon Blanc 2000 (16 points, £3.99) is an own-label bottling, which is crisper and more compelling than many a Sancerre. Château de Lausières Coteaux du Languedoc 1999 (16 points, £4.75) is herby, earthy and characterful, a meaty mouthful, with a wonderful rush of tannins on the finish. It is, though, in what is characterised as 'limited distribution', which means that not every Safeway branch can flog it to you (call 01622 712926 for details). Cruz de Piedra Garnacha 1999 (15 points, £3.99), from Spain, has more support among branches of Safeway. It has an unusual richness and a bramble-fruited style not entirely typical of this red grape, which is, of course, grenache. The own-label Argentinian Syrah 2000 (15 points, £3.99) is rich, deep, fleshy and with an odd spicy lilt that gives it a distinctiveness marking it out from the Australian version of this Rhône-originating syrah grape. It is a deliciously softly textured wine. Trulli Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, £4.49), from Apulia, Italy, is a marvellously fluent wine, dry, crisp, complex and elegant. This is also in short supply, but if your local Safeway hasn't got it, try Somerfield.

For the latest wine news, or to email Malcolm Gluck, visit superplonk.com

To finish a meal at which such a gorgeous wine is served with the main course, there is the sybaritically honied Dindarello Maculan Veneto 1999 (17.5 points, in the half bottle for £6.99), which has an intense sweetness that reveals layers of pineapple, candied ginger and brûléed strawberries. It is a dessert wine to sip in awe or, indeed, in Ayr (where Oddbins has a branch). These hedonistic and, it must be said, expensive treats are countered, this week, by Safeway, which has five interesting wines all for less than a fiver. Chilean Sauvignon Blanc 2000 (16 points, £3.99) is an own-label bottling, which is crisper and more compelling than many a Sancerre. Château de Lausières Coteaux du Languedoc 1999 (16 points, £4.75) is herby, earthy and characterful, a meaty mouthful, with a wonderful rush of tannins on the finish. It is, though, in what is characterised as 'limited distribution', which means that not every Safeway branch can flog it to you (call 01622 712926 for details). Cruz de Piedra Garnacha 1999 (15 points, £3.99), from Spain, has more support among branches of Safeway. It has an unusual richness and a bramble-fruited style not entirely typical of this red grape, which is, of course, grenache. The own-label Argentinian Syrah 2000 (15 points, £3.99) is rich, deep, fleshy and with an odd spicy lilt that gives it a distinctiveness marking it out from the Australian version of this Rhône-originating syrah grape. It is a deliciously softly textured wine. Trulli Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, £4.49), from Apulia, Italy, is a marvellously fluent wine, dry, crisp, complex and elegant. This is also in short supply, but if your local Safeway hasn't got it, try Somerfield. For the latest wine news, or to email Malcolm Gluck, visit superplonk.com

fields.headline: Spadework
fields.trailText:
Rare stakes
Samosa, cannon , tutu and bomb are just some of the wood-fired pots and planters by Dorset potter Jonathan Garratt. He has also branched out into what he calls 'garden punctuation' - sculpture on metal stakes that you move about your garden as the fancy takes you. The collection includes flames and traffic signs. To view, contact Jonathan Garratt at the Hare Lane Pottery, Cranbourne, Dorset, 01725 517700.

Time to...
Spike badly drained areas of lawn with a fork and brush grit into the holes. Bare patches can be reseeded, while a good fertiliser, such as fish, blood and bone, sprinkled over the surface will give the grass a boost.
Plant of the week
The honeysuckle is a good plant to grow if you are new to gardening: undemanding, it scrambles over bare fences, has a sweet scent and is tolerant of a whole variety of water and temperature situations. Of the 180 varieties, the native woodbine, Lonicera periclymenum , grows with vigour and flowers from summer through to autumn. As with other honeysuckles, plant with its roots in the shade and its shoots in the sun. Readers can order a L. periclymenum for £9.49, inc UK p&p, by calling 0870 4421940. Last orders April 17. Allow up to 28 days for delivery.

Put the boot in
Good-looking and effective: what more could you ask of a boot scraper? This one is made out of concrete and bristle, with the added bonus that, unlike more traditional designs, it's not in the shape of an obnoxiously twee hedgehog. From the Conran Shop, 81 Fulham Road, London SW3, 020-7589 7401. It costs £24.95.

fields.headline: Stairway to heaven
fields.standfirst:
What do you find in the house of a serious architectural theorist, famed for his books on postmodernism? 
A riot of clashing styles and cosmic references, finds Hugh Aldersey-Williams
fields.trailText:
What do you find in the house of a serious architectural theorist, famed for his books on postmodernism? 
A riot of clashing styles and cosmic references, finds Hugh Aldersey-Williams
fields.body:
If Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen had collaborated on an interior with Albert Einstein, chances are the result would be something like the home of Charles Jencks. Here, in elegant Kensington, London, swagged curtains hang across windows into parallel universes and extravagant joinery conceals keys to the cosmos. It hits you even in the tiny lobby, where a frieze portrays thinkers through history, while above your head in a "Cosmic Oval" sculpture and beneath your feet are concentric patterns representing our solar system. Everything is loaded with meaning.

Jencks is the critic loved or loathed by architects the world over as the high priest of postmodernism. It was Jencks who first made sense of the chaos of classical and popular references that erupted in the architecture of the 80s, and that now is all around us in pedimented office blocks and Sainsbury's stores with Egyptian-style columns. Jencks's 1977 book, The Language Of Post-Modern Architecture, ran to six editions until 1991, roughly spanning the period when such architecture was popular.

Jencks's house is his book in built form. It is a riotous clutter of clashing symbols, a monument, he says, for the education of postmodernist architects. So many of them, in Jencks's austere mind, fell short of the mark. The most famous of them is the American Michael Graves, best known in Britain for his conical whistling-bird kettle for Alessi. But, in Jencks's opinion, he was lost forever when he became court architect to the Disney Corporation. His latest achievement here is to create a loo brush for Marks & Spencer.

When it comes to another postmodernist leading light, Robert Venturi, architect of the National Gallery extension, Jencks says his ideas about symbolism are wrong. Venturi's most (in)famous example was an old people's home in Philadelphia with a giant TV aerial - "a symbol of the aged, who spend so much time looking at TV," according to the architect. For Jencks, though, it fell short of the ambiguity of a symbol: it was simply a crude "sign" with only one interpretation.

For a man so demanding, Jencks's house is full of architectural and decorative witticisms. The back of the house, he says, can be "read" as a family portrait of Jencks, his late wife and their two children, with the windows making the faces. The place is overloaded with objects and designs that clamour to be decoded. A large, blocky fireplace by Graves is Egyptian-inspired; the kitchen is Mogul. It is overdesigned, he cheerfully admits. "I wouldn't have done it like this, except to criticise Venturi."

More than 20 years after its genesis, he has not tired of giving tours of the so-called Thematic House. When I arrive early for our interview, he is showing round a group of visiting cosmologists. I am left sitting in a circle of sofas in the Spring Room, one of four inter-connecting rooms on the ground floor, themed for the seasons. There is much to look at -not just the antiques and shelves of art books, but geological specimens and sculptures by members of his family. The small standard lamps that illuminate the area, I notice, are supported on . . . a spring.

There are equally painful puns scattered round the house. The den where Jencks writes his architectural manifestos is lined with shelf units, each one shaped like a building of the period it houses. Except that fashions change, and the medieval section now accommodates an explosion of books on Japanese architecture.

Some ideas may not have aged well in the 20 years since he rebuilt this 1840s house with the help of Terry Farrell Architects. Some of the edges are by now scuffed, revealing the plywood beneath the painted stonework effect. But this wear makes the house strangely liveable. It may be a three-dimensional lesson in architecture and symbolism, but it is also comfortable. If you think it might be tiresome to live amid this jostle of intellectual foppery, just remember your own Victorian moulded ceilings whose details have their own forgotten symbolic meaning. The presence of so much history makes modern, everyday things look like an intrusion in Jencks's home. A computer room is discreetly tucked away for this reason. If there are the usual appliances in the kitchen, they lurk behind extravagantly detailed facades in their sunset colours. "To design a symbolic house in an agnostic age may seem to be a folly," Jencks once wrote about the house. "What is there to symbolise?" Typically, he provides his own answer: cosmology. This is Jencks's grand new theme after postmodernism. The kitchen table has the orbits of the planets notched into it. A central feature is the spiral Solar Stair, providing a vertical ascent from darkness - there is a "black hole" mosaic in the basement floor - into light. This journey is one of the oldest ideas in architecture, but updated for our uncertain, godless age. There are 52 steps, one for each week of the year, and seven layers to each step. The spiral itself purports to symbolise our spiral galaxy, even if a stair is not strictly a spiral but a helix. But why let that spoil a nice game of symbolism?

The mix of metaphors reflects his own restlessness. Postmodernism is finished, and Jencks has moved on. He has commissioned a cancer care centre in Dundee in memory of his wife, garden designer Maggie Keswick, from their friend, Frank Gehry, architect of the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao - building work is due to start next month.

Jencks is now co-opting the greats to lend weight to his cosmic ideas. It's not only friends such as Gehry and Daniel Libeskind, whose original model of the Spiral extension to the V&A sits on Jencks's coffee table alongside a rock that contains an unnerving pre-echo of its shape. It's the great names of modernism, too. Jencks's latest book, his 30th or so, is Le Corbusier And The Continual Revolution In Architecture. Part lively biography, part iconoclastic critique, it offers fascinating new insights into the inner world of the Swiss-born architect. Le Corbusier underwent his own seismic shifts in style, and Jencks contends that it was two muses, one of them Josephine Baker, who stimulated the change in him. Jencks supports his case by drawing attention to the architect's hitherto neglected paintings - a series of voluptuous nudes and lesbian double portraits. Jencks once shocked architectural purists by claiming Le Corbusier as one of the first postmodernists. (Look at Ronchamp Chapel, one of his most famous works, Jencks said; see how it looks like a priest, a ship, a cupped hand. It is stuffed with metaphor.) Now he finds a cosmic strand running through the work. The two muses come together, since, for Le Corbusier, even the female body was "a cosmic force".

Jencks would like his house to emulate Le Corbusier's greatest work by revealing many meanings - providing inspiration for new generations. "You can look at it and feel it," he says. "Or you can sit down and analyse it. Its intention is to do what Ronchamp does." It's a stretch to see an end-of-terrace house in Kensington in the same light as a pilgrimage chapel in a remote part of France. But then, Jencks has his pilgrims. And with that, no doubt, he is ready for the next tour group

Le Corbusier, by Charles Jencks, is published by the Monacelli Press at £35. To order a copy for the special price of £32, plus £1.99 first-class p&p, call CultureShop on freephone 0800 316 6102.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText: Just because a group is secretive doesn't mean they are conspirators, and so open to all sorts of accusations, from who killed Princess Diana, to deliberately nobbling the British economy with BSE and foot and mouth so Britain will beg to join the euro without a referendum - and all so their giant plan for us and the world can continue unhindered (Who Pulls The Strings?
fields.body:
Just because a group is secretive doesn't mean they are conspirators, and so open to all sorts of accusations, from who killed Princess Diana, to deliberately nobbling the British economy with BSE and foot and mouth so Britain will beg to join the euro without a referendum - and all so their giant plan for us and the world can continue unhindered (Who Pulls The Strings? March 10). Of course, that's pure fantasy. Or is it?
John Finegan
Co. Cavan, Republic of Ireland

Give Jon Ronson Journalist of the Year Award - and a cordon of burly security guards.
Paul Strong
Durham

The most worrying aspect of the Bilderberg meetings is not the power that money still wields, the inclusion of Peter Mandelson in such dizzy circles or the absence of Africans or Asians in the report. The fact that the best thing these people find to do with their spare time is play golf is causing me no end of concern.
Peter McKnight
Belfast

Thanks to Jon Ronson, I now know that those conspiracy theorists with whom I have always argued were right. What is more, he leaves it deliciously open as to whether or not this is a Good Thing.
Tommy Beavitt
Boath, Alness

Oh dear, David Stafford (March 10), I fear you would commit strange faux-pas of cross-cultural misunderstanding if ever you visited the Arab world. The ululations of Arab women are a sign of joy, and go on for hours, even days, at weddings and other celebrations. It's also the sound from which we get our 'alleluia'.
Jo Simister Younis
Wallington, Surrey
Alexander Chancellor's article on Harold Stassen (March 10), who was my boss at the White House, stated that his best chance of the presidency was in 1952. He came closer in 1948, when he lost the Republican nomination by a hair's breath to Thomas Dewey. The debate between the two centred on communism and its threat to the American people, and was lost by the more liberal Stassen. This led to an unexpected victory for the unpopular Democrat, Harry Truman.
Harold Brooks-Baker
harold@brooks-baker.fsnet.co.uk

Julie Bindel (March 3) is mistaken to conflate condonement of child abuse with my advocacy of an age of consent at 14 to end the criminalisation of young people. Fourteen is now the average age of first sexual experience, yet two 14-year-olds in a consenting relationship face two years to life imprisonment. My support for consent at 14 is conditional on better sex education, including in abuse issues, to empower young people to resist and report unwanted sexual advances. Contrary to Julie's suggestion, the age of consent itself does not protect: abusers ignore consent laws.
Peter Tatchell
London SE1

I wonder if Jeremy Lee, on his treks around spice world, ever discovered salt. I ask because, after sharing with us 'the classic, simple approach' to making 'proper' hoummos (Food, March 10), he missed out this vital ingredient. Do follow his recipe, but add salt to taste: it will improve the flavour no end. It might even improve the flavour of tile grout, but I wouldn't suggest going that far.
Simon Joseph
London SW10

Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email: weekend@theguardian.com. Fax: 020-7239 9935. A postal address must be supplied. Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.

fields.headline: A rough trade (part 2)
fields.trailText: The owl and the bullshitcat
fields.body:
The owl and the bullshitcat

Later that afternoon I journeyed from San Fernando to Pasadena. I was expected at a conference on "The Novel In Britain, 1950-2000" at the Huntingdon Library. After some prompting, I told a gathering of delegates about my recent experiences. "Pussies are bullshit" became the (unofficial) conference slogan.

If pussy is bullshit then bullshit is pussy. On the second night I played a regrettably sophomoric parlour game on this theme with Ian McEwan, Salman Rushdie and Mr and Mrs Christopher Hitchens. What's New Bullshitcat. Bullshit in Boots. The Owl and the Bullshitcat ("Oh lovely Bullshit! O Bullshit, my love,/What a beautiful Bullshit you are.") Bullshit-whipped. Bullshit-wagon. Bullshit's in a well. Someone mentioned the character from Goldfinger: Bullshit Galore, Salman Rushdie paused; his eyes widened and he said, suddenly,

"Octobullshit."

Jokes have been defined (by Nietzsche) as epitaphs on the deaths of feelings. In other words, the best jokes are always a new low. It is utterly characteristic that the coiner of "pussies are bullshit" had no idea that he was joking. In any case, porno is littered - porno is heaped - with the deaths of feelings.

Every time a porno star opens a megastore, or advertises a line of perfume, or does a walk-on in a TV show, porno people start saying that porno is "mainstream", that porno is hip, that porno is cool. Is masturbation hip? It doesn't feel hip. And it doesn't look hip either: you don't see anyone doing it. Porno can never be mainstream, partly because of the contrarian nature of the form. For porno to become mainstream, human beings would have to change.

Porno people: they've changed. In the yard of the house on Dolorosa Drive, during a break in filming, Chloe, Artie and Lola stood there naked, discussing a new rollercoaster ride called Desperado. They were all smoking. I came across many a good little smoker in pornoland. What with the risks they run already, who cares about smoking? Then it was butts out and back to work. And I do mean work. Porno is a proletarian form. And porno people are a hard-grafting, ill-paid fraternity who, by and large, look out for each other and help each other through. They pay their rent, with the deaths of feelings.

No, Chloe, you are not a prostitute, not quite. Prostitution is the oldest profession. And porno is the newest profession. You are more like a gladiator: a contemporary gladiator. Of course, the gladiators were slaves - but some of them won their freedom. And you, I think, will win yours.

In the yard of the house on Dolorosa Drive, during a break in filming, Chloe, Artie and Lola stood there naked, discussing a new rollercoaster ride called Desperado. They were all smoking. I came across many a good little smoker in pornoland. What with the risks they run already, who cares about smoking? Then it was butts out and back to work. And I do mean work. Porno is a proletarian form. And porno people are a hard-grafting, ill-paid fraternity who, by and large, look out for each other and help each other through. They pay their rent, with the deaths of feelings. No, Chloe, you are not a prostitute, not quite. Prostitution is the oldest profession. And porno is the newest profession. You are more like a gladiator: a contemporary gladiator. Of course, the gladiators were slaves - but some of them won their freedom. And you, I think, will win yours. © Martin Amis

webTitle: Audio: Bad Blood by Lorna Sage, read by Jenny Agutter

fields.headline: Bad Blood by Lorna Sage, read by Jenny Agutter
fields.standfirst:
(HarperCollins, £8.99, 180mn)
Buy it at a discount at BOL
Hear an extract
You will need RealPlayer to listen to this clip. You can download it here free
fields.trailText: This deservedly prize-winning account of childhood in the 1940s and 1950s is moving and bleakly funny
fields.body: Sage's grandfather, a boozy, womanising clergyman in a dull Flintshire village, was lucky not to have made it into the News of the World , especially after seducing a schoolgirl. To the infant Sage, the future academic and literary critic, who lived in the vicarage while her dad was away at the war, he passed on his bibliophilia - plus, her parents reckoned when she became pregnant in the sixth form, his wantonness. Hence the atavistic bad blood of the title. But books saw her break through to university. She and the baby's father became the first married couple in the country to graduate together. This deservedly prize-winning account of childhood in the 1940s and 1950s is moving and bleakly funny. It would have been best told by the author, but alas she died. Her story is beautifully served by Jenny Agutter, who reads it with conviction, sympathy and, one senses, more than a little recognition.

fields.headline: Et cetera
fields.standfirst: Steven Poole  on Metaphysical Horror by Leszek Kolakowski, Republic.com by Cass Sunstein, and Book Business by Jason Epstein
fields.trailText: Steven Poole on Metaphysical Horror by Leszek Kolakowski, Republic.com by Cass Sunstein, and Book Business by Jason Epstein
fields.body:
Metaphysical Horror
Leszek Kolakowski
(Penguin, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Not an essay in the genre of vampire films, but a subtle and rather beautiful defence of the search for meaning, Kolakowski's book is at base a worrying at the question of whether the universe is pointless. Philosophers, after all, have been asking the same questions for thousands of years, and none of them has been definitively solved, however much some modern mavericks have claimed that they just don't make sense and that philosophers should go out and get a proper job. We are shown various ideas of the Absolute: a thing, or a god, or a scientific principle, that by virtue of its perfection and self-causing makes sense of our otherwise horribly contingent cosmos. The trouble is that any idea of an Absolute can easily be finessed into pure nothingness, because of its innate unknowability. Such is the horror metaphysicus of Kolakowski's title. Our salvation will be in continuing the search, even if it is futile. "We shall never be free of the temptation to perceive the universe as a book in secret code to which somewhere there is a key, and we will stubbornly go on searching for that key."

Republic.comBR>Cass Sunstein
(Princeton, £12.95)

So, the internet is wonderful because we have so much choice over our info-streams, yes? Er, no, actually. Living as I do in the future, I get my own e-newspaper every morning containing nothing but stories about Keanu Reeves, consumer electronics and metaphysical detective novels. I never come across any information that I have not already expressed an interest in. In general, we will never have to grapple with points of view that do not coincide with our own, instead being constantly reinforced in our blissful prejudices. The world will dissolve into cliques of extremist nutters who can't talk to each other at all. That, argues Sunstein's refreshingly stern book, is a bad thing. Democracy, rather than pure populism, requires that we experience unplanned encounters with opposing views. He insists that we need to think more carefully about how to use the internet as responsible citizens, rather than as mere consumers.

Book Business
Jason Epstein
(Norton, £16.95)

Publishing, Epstein argues, must return to its cottage-industry roots and abandon the greedy conglomeration and vain profit-chasing of the 1980s if it is to survive. Empowered by the internet, authors - and not just Stephen King, mind you - could always threaten go it alone and take a much greater share of the revenue from their mindfruit than the laughable tithe grudgingly handed down to them today. Indeed McSweeney's, not mentioned here, is already helping authors do just that. Epstein also delivers a honey-lensed goodbye to his days as an editor in the 1950s and 1960s, with dismayingly pedestrian anecdotes about Nabokov and Auden, cocktail bashes and New York apartments, and his gradual disillusionment at Random House. I most enjoyed the paratextual joke that this tiny book is so expensive.

fields.headline: In other words
fields.standfirst: John Dugdale looks at The Language Instinct by Steven Pinker, and P G Wodehouse by Frances Donaldson
fields.trailText: John Dugdale looks at The Language Instinct by Steven Pinker, and P G Wodehouse by Frances Donaldson
fields.body:
The Language Instinct
Steven Pinker
(Penguin, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Chomsky, let's face it, is excruciatingly boring, and perhaps the biggest deterrent to more widespread interest in linguistics. Gently mocking his MIT colleague as a theoretician disengaged from vernacular speech, Pinker reworks his core thesis - that language is part of our biological make-up, not a cultural invention - and cannily garnishes it with literary titbits, swipes at pedants tut-tutting about misused words, and cute examples drawn from his own research with children. You won't find Chomsky using Dorothy Parker ("I've been too fucking busy and vice versa") to advance an argument about phonological rules.

P G Wodehouse
Frances Donaldson
(Prion, £10)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

As a schoolmate of his stepdaughter, the late Frances Donaldson first met the creator of Jeeves when she was 14. Far from evincing one toff assiduously protecting another's image, however, her reissued 1982 bio is clear-eyed about a "freakish" fear of human contact and a quasi-autistic lack of normal emotions and reactions ("if the Germans want to govern the world," he asked in 1939, "why don't we just let them?"). His infamous wartime broadcasts apart, Wodehouse spent 75 years doing little but writing. The thoroughness of Donaldson's work makes embarking on a new Life seem a pointless as well as a thankless task.

fields.headline: Ice to see you
fields.trailText: Isobel Montgomery looks at Prince by I B Michael, Mrs Fytton's Country Life by Mavis Cheek, Fred & Edie by Jill Dawson, and A Lesson Before Dying by Ernest J Gaines
fields.body:
Prince
I B Michael
(Vintage, £6.99)

From the opening paragraphs in which Michael describes the formation and destruction of an iceberg "from cathedral to village church, from palace to ruin", you know that this is going to be an uncommonly realised world. The narrator is transformed at will into ice, corpse, fly in amber and stone to relate the goings-on at a boarding house on the Danish coast. Central to the novel is Malte, an orphaned boy who discovers a coffin on the shore and imagines a history for the dead sailor it contains. The narrative device is a little too other-wordly, but the descriptions reverberate with light, and Prince makes you eager for Michael's other novels to be translated.

Mrs Fytton's Country Life
Mavis Cheek
(Faber, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Cheek displays a wicked delight in setting up Angela Fytton as a proper Mrs Perfect who plays the madonna/whore successfully for 20 years until her husband picks up a younger model. Angela, undefeated, comes over all bucolic and abandons west London for a Somerset idyll. "Town bad, country good" is Angela's mantra, but naturally the country folk are just as bad, only different. Cheek's journey into the world of the scorned wife does not yield new discoveries, but she cracks through some comedy set pieces at a fine pace. "Oh, an aga ," coos Angela, 50 pages in. Yes, Trollope is here, but the references reach, pleasingly, beyond the obvious.

Fred & Edie
Jill Dawson
(Sceptre, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

"How loved I felt by your caring for me, by your actually thinking it mattered that I suffered unhappiness," writes Edie Thompson to her lover, Fred Bywaters, as they await trial for the murder of Edie's husband, Percy. The Times of the 1920s said that "there were no circumstances in the case to evoke the slightest sympathy", and they were hanged on January 9, 1923. Dawson's Whitbread-shortlisted novel demonstrates why Edie deserves our understanding. The letters she writes from Holloway reveal Edie's slippery grip on reality, her possible pregnancy, and the pain and cruelty of her marriage. Dawson's portrait of a foolish, unhappy woman may not exonerate, but it does explain.

A Lesson Before Dying
Ernest J Gaines
(Serpent's Tail, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

There is an inescapable didacticism about Gaines's writing: barely a chapter passes without another point about the injustice and prejudice of the American South. The story tells how Grant, a teacher at a plantation school, counsels Jefferson, as he waits for death by electrocution. Gaines's narrative is also a rich portrait of how a small post-war, pre-civil-rights southern community functions. Best of all is Grant's relationship with his aunt and Miss Emma, Jefferson's godmother. These indomitable old ladies manipulate the tyro Grant, until he joins Jefferson's battle for dignity under their terms.

webTitle: Pick of the week: The Human Stain by Philip Roth

fields.headline: Death and dumb
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  relishes an angry indictment of dumb America in The Human Stain by Philip Roth
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard relishes an angry indictment of dumb America in The Human Stain by Philip Roth
fields.body:
The Human Stain
Philip Roth
(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Coleman Silk, the first Jewish dean of stuffy Athena college, a classics professor who has almost singlehandedly transformed the academic New England backwater, one day asks his class if anyone knows two students who have, five weeks into the semester, yet to attend. "Do they exist," he asks, "or are they spooks?"

Unfortunately for Silk, not only do they exist, but they hear of his question and take the word "spook" in its archaic derogatory sense of "negro". And as they are black, and feel personally aggrieved, Silk is compelled to take a resentful and unplanned early retirement. His wife dies of a stroke, which for a while completely unhinges him. And then, to make things worse, Silk - who is 71 - takes on a 34-year-old mistress, an illiterate woman who works as a cleaner. This is where the novel begins, Silk having struck up an unlikely friendship with our old, dear and now cancer-riddled friend, the reclusive Nathan Zuckerman.

We are, then, in the thick of an America revelling in an ecstasy of recrimination, the "malevolent puritanism" worse than any cold-war hunt for imaginary communists. This urge to denounce inappropriate behaviour prevents people from saying anything that goes against the consensus and has resulted, deliberately or not, in the dumbest generation in American history and the kind of atmosphere where a student can successfully complain that the plays of Euripides are misogynist and should not be taught. It is perhaps a calculated affront to this way of "thinking" that there is a short scene in the novel where Coleman overhears three men arguing that Clinton could have spared himself public embarrassment by placing his penis inside Monica Lewinsky's rectum rather than her mouth. "Had he fucked her in the ass, the nation could have been spared this terrible trauma." Well, that's one theory, and it's interesting that this is more or less the last word the novel has to say on the matter; and that we're meant to find it - as, personally, I do - grimly funny.

Yet this, being a novel by someone who seems at the peak of his very considerable powers (whereas Zuckerman is not only impotent but, as a result of a prostate operation, incontinent; very much a minor player here, he has stopped, so to speak, dicking us around), is not the whole story. Silk has a momentous secret, and although you find it out early on (and may remember it from reviews of the hardback), I will urge you, as I have never urged before, to buy the book and discover it for yourself. The stuff about dumb, hysterical America is, it turns out, only background noise, the backdrop to a picture of a century where matters of race, ambition, character and war come together like a car crash. It is a fizzing, unplayable spitball of a book, almost unfairly brilliant, its sentences the familiar Roth string of ungainsayable urgency, intelligence and passion.

This novel not only stares death - "the ceaseless perishing" - in the face, it stares the whole unruly parade of our lives in the face, and declares, more eloquently and persuasively than anything else you will have read on the subject, that we are imperfect fabricators of our own destinies. And, by the way, that as a novelist Roth is in a league of his own.

webTitle: Review: Grammars of Creation by George Steiner

fields.headline: Original bliss
fields.standfirst: Roy Porter  acclaims an anatomy of creativity in Grammars of Creation by George Steiner
fields.trailText: Roy Porter acclaims an anatomy of creativity in Grammars of Creation by George Steiner
fields.body:
Grammars of Creation
George Steiner
288pp, Faber, £16.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

'In the beginning, God created the Heaven and the Earth," opens the Bible narrative. Genesis being a story, the philosophy of divine creativity is not dwelt upon - it is taken as read that creating is what God does. As George Steiner explains, however, the business of genesis has never in reality been that unproblematic.

How, for instance, did the gods themselves come into being in the first place? This was the conundrum underlying so many ancient myths. And then, having got that far, did deities or the Deity truly, as Judaeo-Christianity teaches, create out of nothing ( ex nihilo ); or was it, as in most other traditions, a matter of some celestial ordering of chaos, imposing form on mucky, pre-existent Ur-stuff? And did the Almighty create because He had no choice (creativity being the divine essence)? Or because He willed it (it was His foible)? Or even, as has been read by some theologians out of, or into, the Old Testament account, because He was a bit lonely? Not least, how do we account for the creation of evil?

These are the grand questions posed in a study that is philosophical in conception, yet deeply humane too. Steiner engages, as we'd expect, with the weighty theologies and philosophies that have debated these fundamental issues - from Plato, Aristotle and Aquinas up to the moderns, including Hegel, Husserl and Heidegger. Yet he also evokes the personal side. Here is the tormented Job shaking his head or fist at a Yahweh who seems to have created him solely to make him suffer. What sense lies in a Creation that inflicts pointless pain? This objection is drawn out of Job's agony and brought right forward, in Steiner's masterly telling, to that "virtuoso of abstention", Samuel Beckett. Why not nothing? Is the real problem with existence not Godot's absence but God's presence?

These issues might be waved aside as "academic" - no longer relevant in an age in which God is dead. But this would be wrong because, as Steiner persuasively argues, they are the very problems present whenever we confront a poem or a painting, especially in an electronic age when old ideas about language are under threat. Why do we set such a high value on originality in art? Why call this lyric or that sonata a work of genius? What are the distinguishing features of (in today's jargon) "creative" writing? What is the point of art?

Music, for instance, has been commended as uniquely creative on the grounds that it is "pure" - it doesn't merely imitate sounds that are out there already. Yet we will often praise a novel for its "realism" or a portrait for being "lifelike": does that make the novelist or painter any the less "creative"? And if so, does it matter?

And the enigma of the creator in the imaginative arts applies equally, Steiner shows, to other fields. Some celebrate mathematics as the most original human endeavour of all, precisely because pure maths, at least, is all in the mind. The scientist, however, occupies a more ambiguous position. As a discoverer, he or she is granted higher status than the "inventor" who is a mere "maker" or "fabricator" - a word always carrying undertones of "fiction". Yet since we idolise a Galileo or a Newton for removing Nature's veil and "discovering" her eternal laws, how can they truly claim a place in the pantheon of "creators"?

The concentricity of these theologies, philosophies and aesthetics of creation is brought home by Steiner through a brilliant reading of Dante. For that 13th-century Florentine, God alone could create; what redeemed man was faith. It was not until romanticism, half a millennium later, that creativity marked the destiny of the writer, the poet's imagination became divine and art was deemed redemptive. Critics denounced those claims as blasphemous, and the compulsion to create became the destructive demon of the romantic agony, especially once the joy of creating degenerated into fin-de-siècle creation as pathology. It was not only Freud who viewed art as symptomatic of neurosis.

Indeed, the hubris involved in the artist's claim to godlike creative powers has been but part of that terrible modern malaise that not only produced Nazism and Stalinism, but conscripted art to consecrate such barbarism: the familiar Hitler and Wagner problem, a variant on God creating evil. Here Steiner takes up again a theme he has pursued before: in the shadow of the Shoah, might the nothingness of silence be the only honourable recourse for art?

An astonishing wealth of ideas has been compressed within the compass of this book. However, significant omissions and blind spots remain. Despite the odd stray reference to Star Trek , the question of what kinds of grammars of creation apply to such modern media as film is not broached. And Steiner's troupe of poets and philosophers is conspicuously men-only. I point this out not to make a cheap, politically correct point, but to go some way towards explaining the absence from his discussion of one major matrix of thinking about creativity.

For artistic creativity has often been conceived in terms of conception itself - begetting, giving birth, artwork as brainchild. Here the models and metaphors have been sexual (pens and penises), gynaecological, obstetrical, paediatric: a writer goes into the throes of labour, a poem is delivered into the world. Our word "genius" comes from gignere , Latin for "to beget" or "to be born". And there are conceits that have been particularly dear to female writers, but far from exclusively so. They bring with them rich possibilities: a bastard or monstrous offspring, or endless variations on the theme of the muse as the "onely begetter". Steiner skirts these "low", bodily traditions of thinking about creation.

Overall, however, this is a mesmerising book that demands and amply repays the closest attention. For breadth of culture and depth of erudition, Steiner has few peers. To those critics who have found his earlier works Olympian, oracular or obscure, the answer lies here: Grammars of Creation is a sustained outpouring of strenuous thinking, but it is expressed in prose that is unfailingly apt, luminous and evocative. From its earliest propositions ("this book is an in memoriam for lost futures"), arguments flow that hold the mind. What more fitting testament to Steiner's own prodigious creativity?
