As George Steiner explains, however, the business of genesis has never in reality been that unproblematic. How, for instance, did the gods themselves come into being in the first place? This was the conundrum underlying so many ancient myths. And then, having got that far, did deities or the Deity truly, as Judaeo-Christianity teaches, create out of nothing ( ex nihilo ); or was it, as in most other traditions, a matter of some celestial ordering of chaos, imposing form on mucky, pre-existent Ur-stuff? And did the Almighty create because He had no choice (creativity being the divine essence)? Or because He willed it (it was His foible)? Or even, as has been read by some theologians out of, or into, the Old Testament account, because He was a bit lonely? Not least, how do we account for the creation of evil? These are the grand questions posed in a study that is philosophical in conception, yet deeply humane too. Steiner engages, as we'd expect, with the weighty theologies and philosophies that have debated these fundamental issues - from Plato, Aristotle and Aquinas up to the moderns, including Hegel, Husserl and Heidegger. Yet he also evokes the personal side. Here is the tormented Job shaking his head or fist at a Yahweh who seems to have created him solely to make him suffer. What sense lies in a Creation that inflicts pointless pain? This objection is drawn out of Job's agony and brought right forward, in Steiner's masterly telling, to that "virtuoso of abstention", Samuel Beckett. Why not nothing? Is the real problem with existence not Godot's absence but God's presence? These issues might be waved aside as "academic" - no longer relevant in an age in which God is dead. But this would be wrong because, as Steiner persuasively argues, they are the very problems present whenever we confront a poem or a painting, especially in an electronic age when old ideas about language are under threat. Why do we set such a high value on originality in art? Why call this lyric or that sonata a work of genius? What are the distinguishing features of (in today's jargon) "creative" writing? What is the point of art? Music, for instance, has been commended as uniquely creative on the grounds that it is "pure" - it doesn't merely imitate sounds that are out there already. Yet we will often praise a novel for its "realism" or a portrait for being "lifelike": does that make the novelist or painter any the less "creative"? And if so, does it matter? And the enigma of the creator in the imaginative arts applies equally, Steiner shows, to other fields. Some celebrate mathematics as the most original human endeavour of all, precisely because pure maths, at least, is all in the mind. The scientist, however, occupies a more ambiguous position. As a discoverer, he or she is granted higher status than the "inventor" who is a mere "maker" or "fabricator" - a word always carrying undertones of "fiction". Yet since we idolise a Galileo or a Newton for removing Nature's veil and "discovering" her eternal laws, how can they truly claim a place in the pantheon of "creators"? The concentricity of these theologies, philosophies and aesthetics of creation is brought home by Steiner through a brilliant reading of Dante. For that 13th-century Florentine, God alone could create; what redeemed man was faith. It was not until romanticism, half a millennium later, that creativity marked the destiny of the writer, the poet's imagination became divine and art was deemed redemptive. Critics denounced those claims as blasphemous, and the compulsion to create became the destructive demon of the romantic agony, especially once the joy of creating degenerated into fin-de-siècle creation as pathology. It was not only Freud who viewed art as symptomatic of neurosis. Indeed, the hubris involved in the artist's claim to godlike creative powers has been but part of that terrible modern malaise that not only produced Nazism and Stalinism, but conscripted art to consecrate such barbarism: the familiar Hitler and Wagner problem, a variant on God creating evil. Here Steiner takes up again a theme he has pursued before: in the shadow of the Shoah, might the nothingness of silence be the only honourable recourse for art? An astonishing wealth of ideas has been compressed within the compass of this book. However, significant omissions and blind spots remain. Despite the odd stray reference to Star Trek , the question of what kinds of grammars of creation apply to such modern media as film is not broached. And Steiner's troupe of poets and philosophers is conspicuously men-only. I point this out not to make a cheap, politically correct point, but to go some way towards explaining the absence from his discussion of one major matrix of thinking about creativity. For artistic creativity has often been conceived in terms of conception itself - begetting, giving birth, artwork as brainchild. Here the models and metaphors have been sexual (pens and penises), gynaecological, obstetrical, paediatric: a writer goes into the throes of labour, a poem is delivered into the world. Our word "genius" comes from gignere , Latin for "to beget" or "to be born". And there are conceits that have been particularly dear to female writers, but far from exclusively so. They bring with them rich possibilities: a bastard or monstrous offspring, or endless variations on the theme of the muse as the "onely begetter". Steiner skirts these "low", bodily traditions of thinking about creation. Overall, however, this is a mesmerising book that demands and amply repays the closest attention. For breadth of culture and depth of erudition, Steiner has few peers. To those critics who have found his earlier works Olympian, oracular or obscure, the answer lies here: Grammars of Creation is a sustained outpouring of strenuous thinking, but it is expressed in prose that is unfailingly apt, luminous and evocative. From its earliest propositions ("this book is an in memoriam for lost futures"), arguments flow that hold the mind. What more fitting testament to Steiner's own prodigious creativity?

webTitle: Reviews: The River Cottage Cookbook by Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall, and Apricots on the Nile by Colette Rossant

fields.headline: Fur, fish and feathers
fields.standfirst: Tom Jaine  goes wild in the country with The River Cottage Cookbook by Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall, and mixes memory and cookery with Apricots on the Nile by Colette Rossant
fields.trailText: Tom Jaine goes wild in the country with The River Cottage Cookbook by Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall, and mixes memory and cookery with Apricots on the Nile by Colette Rossant
fields.body:
The River Cottage Cookbook
Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall, photographs by Simon Wheeler
447pp, HarperCollins, £19.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Apricots on the Nile: A Memoir with Recipes
Colette Rossant
188pp, Bloomsbury, £12.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

There are some cookbooks you want, a few you need, and a lorry-load that leave you lifeless with boredom. Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall's, the most recent from a man fecund with bright ideas, is a strong candidate for the second group: as good for the armchair as it is in the kitchen, even worth packing for reference outdoors.

Many have witnessed his TV escapades: twice at River Cottage itself where, among folds in the Dorset hills, he seems to exist in a hecatomb of fur, feather and fin; before that, when he invaded the homes of willing victims to help compose singular dinners; or when he instructed us in the art of scavenging the countryside. These have all been memorable, not least for their air of suppressed hysteria abetted by his own mad-professor appearance.

The River Cottage Cookbook arises out of the series rather than merely replicating the visual experience. It's chunky, with pages of instruction for would-be smallholders, hunter-gatherers and gardeners. The text is peppered with cookery wisdom and lore although, in fact, there are fewer than 100 stand-alone recipes. These are good stuff, albeit heavily garlicked and raddled with chilli - but then, so is most food nowadays. There are two things to applaud: first, that many of the dishes are one-pot affairs, in other words, good family cooking (though how many children will tuck in willingly to squirrel shanks or pig's ear is questionable); and second, that he is not afraid to make terrines, patties, pies, stews - old-fashioned, messed-about cookery that many fashionable cooks shy away from.

Most people will turn to this book for a broader take on food in general. The River Cottage project is a dabble in the art of self-sufficiency: raise the pig to kill, then work out what to do with all the parts; sow the carrots and reap the soup. And it includes the wild world: almost a third deals with fish and food gathered in hedgerow and woodland.

But although we are all peasants at heart - or at least think so as we board the 8.05 - few make the transition from town to rustic bliss. For the stay-at-homes, there's lots about shopping: what to look for in a ripe melon, how to tell fresh from foul. For those who like a little activity, there are things to do on walks (shoot squirrels, pick blackberries, harvest mussels), and for the driven, all they need to know about home-smoking, eel traps and egg-laying. Farmer Hugh would like even the do- nothings to appreciate better our place in the food chain.

As a manual, it has plenty of gaps (nothing on dairy work, no mention of goats, geese or ducks) and suffers from the usual problem of DIY books: over-optimism. The reality of smallholding, or even self-sufficiency of The Good Life variety, is that it's hell most of the time. Hugh's breezy canter through the hurdles of pigs, sheep and cows makes light of the 2am breech birth, the psychotic sow unable to bear its own offspring, or the ram intent on flattening any human that comes within range. So, too, in the garden. I have planted orchards of apple trees, yet am still without fruit; waited months for parsley to germinate; and spent millions at garden centres. Now, I visit the greengrocer.

Reservations notwithstanding, the book is still necessary. By travelling from one end to the other of an animal's life (or a carrot's) he gives perspective to what we eat, even if at the last gasp you leave it to those more versed in the niceties. And it's worth it for the pig alone: like George Orwell, Fearnley-Whittingstall recognises the pig's supremacy of wit, charm, beauty and, finally, taste. Even the urban dreamer can take instruction in pickling belly or smoking bacon. This is rippingly good, and the product 10 times more enjoyable than pancetta.

Whether you think the writer well served by his publisher may depend on your approach to book-craft. A cookbook is meant to be used; the present generation of book designers seems to think otherwise. Margins are small, type is smaller, reading at a distance (as you do at the stove) impossible. Instead of diagrams (which you need to learn about skinning rabbits and eviscerating cuttlefish), what you get is mood photography. Who needs a photograph of a bowl of soup? It's green and flat, and the china is white. Mood is the writer's job, and Farmer Hugh is up to it.

If Fearnley-Whittingstall's book is the size and weight of a brick, Colette Rossant's memoir of her wartime Egyptian childhood is a slender bookmark. First published in America, it combines explicit memories with their evocation through recipes. I always have more faith in memoirists if they know how old they are, and this one does not. On one page she is six, on the next seven, then later she is eight when by my calculations she should have been 13 or 15. One author, one agent, two publishers, two editors: don't they do arithmetic? The book may be slight, but it raises big questions that are never really tackled. Living among the rich Jewish community in Cairo during the second world war, it seems as if nothing untoward was going on beyond the great iron gates of their mansion.

Neglected, mistreated and forced into Catholicism by a bolter of a mother, the author obviously had a dysfunctional emotional life, but we understand little of it. And the mainly Middle Eastern recipes may act as pinpricks to her memory, but strike me far more as monuments to the connectivity of the Levant. At one moment I am reading about a dish in a 10th- century Arabic cookbook written in Baghdad; the next it appears in this text from New York. I find that more uncanny than anything.

webTitle: Review: Blackbird Singing by Paul McCartney

fields.headline: Roll over, Andrew Motion
fields.standfirst: Blackbird Singing by Paul McCartney reveals that the ex-Beatle was a poet long before his first verse collection, declares Michael Horovitz
fields.trailText: Blackbird Singing by Paul McCartney reveals that the ex-Beatle was a poet long before his first verse collection, declares Michael Horovitz
fields.body:
Blackbird Singing: Poems and Lyrics 1965 - 1999
Paul McCartney, ed Adrian Mitchell
190pp, Faber, £14.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Mo Mowlam was unfairly derided when, asked on Any Questions whom she'd recommend for poet laureate, she suggested that Paul McCartney would be "a very popular choice". The songs he's written, with and without John Lennon, have almost certainly reached more listeners than all the official poems of all the poets laureate put together - and a good thing too. The lyrics of many of the songs, along with the best of Woody Guthrie, Chuck Berry, Bob Dylan, Ray Davies, Patti Smith and other transatlantic troubadours, remain pacesetters to the movement that's achieved the big shift towards more people getting their poetry by ear again over the last half century. Some say pop lyrics can't be poetry - a grotesquely unhistorical prejudice. Lyric denotes "poetry sung to the lyre", which is how the craft began in the hands of David, Solomon, Sappho, Homer et al. Pop, short for popular, means "of the people".

In 1964 Adrian Mitchell wrote in his first book of poems that "Most people ignore most poetry because most poetry ignores most people" - as did most mid-century hit-parade fodder. But many more people today are relating to more poetry, because more poetry - like much recent pop song - has been relating to the realities of many more people. The interplay between poets and singer-songwriter-musicians has been crucial to this development, putting the lyre back into the lyric and original lyrics back into music and verse. At Liverpool art school in the late 1950s, Lennon edited "The Daily Howl" in homage to the protest poems of Allen Ginsberg, who was accompanied in his old age on stage and disc by McCartney.

Mitchell writes in his introduction to Blackbird Singing that "one of the highlights of my life was performing four of my poems backed by Paul, Linda and their band on the Southend leg of his world tour in 1991. Around that time Linda phoned me to suggest that I edit a collection of Paul's poems." When it came to the nitty-gritty of publication, Mitchell's role was pivotal. Macca admits that "Originally I only wanted poems in the book, but Adrian persuaded me into including the song lyrics. I looked at them again, and thought, yes, some of them could be read."

Mitchell emphasises that "Paul is not in the line of academic or modernist poets. He is a poet in the tradition of popular poetry. Homer was and is a popular poet, understood and loved by millions of people who never saw a university. William Blake, who used to sing his Songs of Innocence and Experience to a small circle of friends, has become one of the most popular of all poets. Whenever critics say there is something inferior about poetry which is sung, my advice is to sing Blake's 'Tyger' or Burns's 'O My Luve's Like a Red, Red Rose' at them. A few songwriters, although they know you can get away with banal nothingness in pop lyrics, have a vision and try to convey it to us. A few manage to write truthfully about the world." Quite apart from his strengths as a composer, musician and vocalist, this is exactly what McCartney has done in nearly as many songs as Blake did.

The new book is made up of about 50 song lyrics and close on 100 non-musical pieces. It may be partly because they have been the soundtrack to the best years of my life, but it's mainly the lyrics that strike poetic gold for me. Many of the unsung texts read more like sketches or notes than finished poems - as might be expected of any aspiring poet's first volume (regardless of the fact that this poet has been a master songsmith for four decades).

The craft and hard graft of writing nonstop for gigs, broadcasts and recordings left hardly a wasted syllable in the most verbally intricate of the songs. J K Rowling spoke for thousands of writers when she said on Desert Island Discs last Christmas that the most precious and elusive skill is simplicity - and she surely spoke for millions of readers and listeners when she cited "Yesterday" as a classic example. She might equally have chosen "Blackbird" or "Big Boys Bickering", which marry McCartney's liquid sweetness to a punchy, unblinking social conscience: "Who will win, who will lose? / Which way do the big boys choose? // While they argue through the night, / Shaking their sticks of dynamite, / Babies are dying through the day, / They want to blow us all away . . ."

I love McCartney as I do Shakespeare, the Marx Brothers, Bessie Smith and Louis Armstrong, because I find the ups and downs of existence so intensely immortalised in his work. Other lyrics here that portray unmistakably universal experience include the poignant "Eleanor Rigby" and "When I'm Sixty-Four", and the sharply observed "She's Leaving Home" and "Lovely Rita". Each of these is built on lines far more comparable with Robert Browning, to my mind, than Eminem's rap attacks were set up to be by Giles Foden in the Guardian . The couplets, "I could be handy, mending a fuse / When your lights have gone. / You can knit a sweater by the fireside, / Sunday mornings go for a ride" and "Indicate precisely what you want to say, / Yours sincerely, wasting away" read like a jaunty Scouse music-hall rejoinder to Gregory Corso's wild beatnik variations on "Marriage", with their cri de coeur : "What if I'm 60 years old and not married, / all alone in a furnished room with pee stains on my underwear".

The way every detail of the "Penny Lane" street scene comes together - from the "barber showing photographs / Of every head he's had the pleasure to know" (hear him saying it!) to the nurse selling poppies from a tray "Behind the shelter in the middle of the roundabout" who "feels as if she's in a play" - is as atmospheric and revealing as the market walkabout in Browning's "How It Strikes a Contemporary". Both Eminem and Browning are generally too preoccupied with technical effects to achieve the televisual succinctness with which McCartney records the nuances in tone, vocabulary and naked human emotion of the diverse folk befriended in his songs.

Most of these lyrics, like most worthwhile poems, will be as reso nant long after we're all dead as when they were first released, perhaps most notably the compassionate but unsentimental requiem for "all the lonely people" penned by Macca, with a little help from his friends, in 1966. "Eleanor Rigby died in the church and was buried along with her name. / Nobody came. / Father McKenzie, / wiping the dirt from his hands as he walks from the grave. / No one was saved . . ." One needn't chase the sub-textual possibilities of "Nobody came" to sense that it's not a million miles from Betjeman and Larkinland; or to see why William Burroughs admired McCartney's talent for packing such a wealth of narrative into so few lines, or why another distinguished novelist, A S Byatt, finds it "a perfect sung lyric . . . with the minimalist perfection of a Beckett story".

So what of the other two-thirds of this collection? Macca's Sunday-painter's eye and seasoned musician's ear too often get muffled by imprecise doodles -in "City Park", "All sorts of ducks / Mill slowly round white swans" just two breaths away from where "A crow cackles / With thumb on black comb rasp". The "Mill slowly round" and "black comb rasp" are sure-footed poesy, but "All sorts of" is uninformative prose and "crow cackles" is routine cliché.

On the other hand, the nine-page "Standing Stone" sequence, more than four times the length of anything else included, is a remarkable feat of historical imagination - a primeval redemption myth whose sustained narrative detachment bursts into a subtly orchestrated lyric orgasm. It evokes the whole-earth mystique that has gathered such practical momentum since the 1960s (partly thanks to campaigning by the likes of Linda and Paul): "On contented drone of bee / musicians improvise a melody / fuelled by feast fermented fruit. / Sun-cooked air blew through flutes / and round bright maypole strings / a jig in plaited time . . . / Birds and butterflies flit / from wayside bush and ditch. / The track from town to stone / soon jammed with revellers / inching chattily towards/ their sacred site / where she and he / vow their proud love . . . // A distant black bird circled overhead and wondered why / so many bite-sized creatures spent their lifetime / running on the spot."

About 20 pages are devoted to Paul's late wife and muse, and though they are uneven (sometimes because of their palpable sincerity), they contain meditative lines that will speak volumes to anyone who has experienced the solitary confinement that follows the loss of a soulmate. "My love is alive / My love is dead // I hear her voice / inside my head // There's a lot to remember / a lot to forget// . . . There's a lot to be said / There's nothing to be said".

McCartney has observed how many of these poems stem from grief and bereavement, carrying a greater personal weight than the songs. But most illustrate - and a good many fulfill - his perennial life-enhancing "Hey Jude" riff: "don't make it bad, / Take a sad song and make it better". Though some of the poeticising is as formally slipshod as most of the songcraft is immaculate, every page of this profoundly innocent and vastly enjoyable toybox of a book is pure in spirit - the purity of the actor said to have complained to Sam Beckett in rehearsal, "It's no good, I'm failing", and the purity of the reply attributed to Beckett: "That's all right. But try to fail better."

The couplets, "I could be handy, mending a fuse / When your lights have gone. / You can knit a sweater by the fireside, / Sunday mornings go for a ride" and "Indicate precisely what you want to say, / Yours sincerely, wasting away" read like a jaunty Scouse music-hall rejoinder to Gregory Corso's wild beatnik variations on "Marriage", with their cri de coeur : "What if I'm 60 years old and not married, / all alone in a furnished room with pee stains on my underwear". The way every detail of the "Penny Lane" street scene comes together - from the "barber showing photographs / Of every head he's had the pleasure to know" (hear him saying it!) to the nurse selling poppies from a tray "Behind the shelter in the middle of the roundabout" who "feels as if she's in a play" - is as atmospheric and revealing as the market walkabout in Browning's "How It Strikes a Contemporary". Both Eminem and Browning are generally too preoccupied with technical effects to achieve the televisual succinctness with which McCartney records the nuances in tone, vocabulary and naked human emotion of the diverse folk befriended in his songs. Most of these lyrics, like most worthwhile poems, will be as reso nant long after we're all dead as when they were first released, perhaps most notably the compassionate but unsentimental requiem for "all the lonely people" penned by Macca, with a little help from his friends, in 1966. "Eleanor Rigby died in the church and was buried along with her name. / Nobody came. / Father McKenzie, / wiping the dirt from his hands as he walks from the grave. / No one was saved . . ." One needn't chase the sub-textual possibilities of "Nobody came" to sense that it's not a million miles from Betjeman and Larkinland; or to see why William Burroughs admired McCartney's talent for packing such a wealth of narrative into so few lines, or why another distinguished novelist, A S Byatt, finds it "a perfect sung lyric . . . with the minimalist perfection of a Beckett story". So what of the other two-thirds of this collection? Macca's Sunday-painter's eye and seasoned musician's ear too often get muffled by imprecise doodles -in "City Park", "All sorts of ducks / Mill slowly round white swans" just two breaths away from where "A crow cackles / With thumb on black comb rasp". The "Mill slowly round" and "black comb rasp" are sure-footed poesy, but "All sorts of" is uninformative prose and "crow cackles" is routine cliché. On the other hand, the nine-page "Standing Stone" sequence, more than four times the length of anything else included, is a remarkable feat of historical imagination - a primeval redemption myth whose sustained narrative detachment bursts into a subtly orchestrated lyric orgasm. It evokes the whole-earth mystique that has gathered such practical momentum since the 1960s (partly thanks to campaigning by the likes of Linda and Paul): "On contented drone of bee / musicians improvise a melody / fuelled by feast fermented fruit. / Sun-cooked air blew through flutes / and round bright maypole strings / a jig in plaited time . . . / Birds and butterflies flit / from wayside bush and ditch. / The track from town to stone / soon jammed with revellers / inching chattily towards/ their sacred site / where she and he / vow their proud love . . . // A distant black bird circled overhead and wondered why / so many bite-sized creatures spent their lifetime / running on the spot." About 20 pages are devoted to Paul's late wife and muse, and though they are uneven (sometimes because of their palpable sincerity), they contain meditative lines that will speak volumes to anyone who has experienced the solitary confinement that follows the loss of a soulmate. "My love is alive / My love is dead // I hear her voice / inside my head // There's a lot to remember / a lot to forget// . . . There's a lot to be said / There's nothing to be said". McCartney has observed how many of these poems stem from grief and bereavement, carrying a greater personal weight than the songs. But most illustrate - and a good many fulfill - his perennial life-enhancing "Hey Jude" riff: "don't make it bad, / Take a sad song and make it better". Though some of the poeticising is as formally slipshod as most of the songcraft is immaculate, every page of this profoundly innocent and vastly enjoyable toybox of a book is pure in spirit - the purity of the actor said to have complained to Sam Beckett in rehearsal, "It's no good, I'm failing", and the purity of the reply attributed to Beckett: "That's all right. But try to fail better."

fields.headline: Big in thrillers
fields.standfirst: Chris Petit looks at The Company of Strangers by Robert Wilson, Beekeeper by J Robert Janes , The Sleep of the Dead by Tom Bradby, The Prometheus Deception by Robert Ludlum, Flint by Paul Edd
fields.trailText: Chris Petit looks at The Company of Strangers by Robert Wilson, Beekeeper by J Robert Janes , The Sleep of the Dead by Tom Bradby, The Prometheus Deception by Robert Ludlum, Flint by Paul Edd
fields.body:
The post-cold war, post- Le Carré spy novel is on something of a roll. Robert Harris, Alan Furst, John Lawton and Robert Wilson all produce educated, well-upholstered and faintly nostalgic thrillers with a commercial edge, combining political acumen and traditional narrative skill. The Company of Strangers (HarperCollins, £12.99), by Robert Wilson, takes a young romantic heroine who wouldn't be out of place in a Daphne du Maurier novel and drops her into the intrigue of a neutral country in wartime. The queasiness of fascist Portugal in 1944 is not so far from Manderley: a world of bizarre housekeeping, economic tangle and emotional repression. The masculine arena of deferral and inchoate emotion, which translates into a scarcely veiled sadism, is both thrilling and repellent to the naive Englishwoman. Wilson's tale is a plotter's delight: spanning several decades and cleverly reworking past narratives in the light of new evidence, he creates an intriguing moral maze for his heroine to negotiate - and a puzzle of metaphors to match (he's a better stylist than du Maurier). Recommended.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Alan Furst's Ambleresque stories of prewar and wartime Paris have created a virtual monopoly, but J Robert Janes's Beekeeper (Orion, £16.99) is a notable alternative. Where Furst concentrates on espionage and the elisions of compromise, Janes has less smoothness and more narrative spike, recapturing some of the dankness of Simenon's non-Maigrets without his narrative economy. Janes's story is based on the neat premise that ordinary crimes in occupied Paris still have to be solved, but policework is complicated by the need to accommodate the Gestapo. Everything acquires another dimension in wartime, and the murder of the beekeeper is anything but straightforward. If the plotting is sometimes too intricate, the reward comes in Janes's portrait of occupied Paris and his vivid understanding of collaborative shadings and black markets.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The Sleep of the Dead (Bantam Press, £9.99), by Tom Bradby , explores middle-class English families: their reserve, decency and underlying nastiness. After spoiling a promising career in the army, a young woman returns to her family village to confront ghosts from her congested childhood: a double murder and the ambiguous role played by her army officer father, killed soon afterwards in the Falklands. Bradby understands the army mindset, but early tension falters as suspicion gets mistaken for suspense and too many familiar skeletons emerge.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The Prometheus Deception (Orion, £12.99), the latest from the late Robert Ludlum (proclaimed "the world's number-one storyteller"), is notable for its post-cold war paranoia and hysterical revisionism, if nothing else. Was the super-secret, super-elite US intelligence agency known as the Directorate run by the Kremlin all along (ditto the wife of its top agent)? Do we care? Tired double crosses and tough-guy camp - "If you really think I'd fall for this crap, you're out of your goddam mind" - are the yawning result in what feels like a bad Clint Eastwood picture. To judge by this, the Ludlum franchise - even before his death this week- was a largely absentee one, as it displays zero evidence of authorial presence.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Flint (Headline, £10), a first novel by Sunday Times journalist Paul Eddy, is also intended as an exercise in franchise - one that has already earned over £1m in advances, plus film rights. The sell is a central character playable by any of a dozen Hollywood actresses - smart undercover cop full of identikit contradictions (tough/vulnerable, controlling/ damaged, dull/duller). Eddy's investigative background shows in a money-laundering plot, all cut-and-paste rather than proper narrative, which reads like an extended film treatment. While neither original nor memorable, the anonymously efficient result has a confidence that suggests the author knows he could be on to something.
Buy it at a discount at BOL

webTitle: Review:  Fabulous Time by Christina Koning

fields.headline: Hippy shakes
fields.standfirst: Alex Clark  enjoys English whimsy in Fabulous Time by Christina Koning
fields.trailText: Alex Clark enjoys English whimsy in Fabulous Time by Christina Koning
fields.body:
Fabulous Time
Christina Koning
274pp, Viking, £12.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The rather unconvincing hippies who lounge on the cover of Fabulous Time , all mocked-up moustaches and vacant grins amid a sea of floating neon flowers, make very little impression on the novel itself, save for one dreamy episode that may have lasting consequences. For the rest of the characters, these exotic children - first happened upon during a clifftop picnic - are fleetingly fascinating but largely irrelevant representatives of modern life. Theirs are walk-on parts in a family drama whose most obvious characteristic is its determined retreat from the outside world.

It is a family that seems to consist almost entirely of stock characters. Dotty Constance Reason lives in Dunsinane, a decrepit country house in Sussex, sustained by the companionship of her dog, the odd ghostly visitation from Wilfred (the late husband who never quite recovered from shell shock) and her memories of youthful indiscretions in Shanghai with a bohemian ne'er-do-well. Just up the road, her mannish niece Iseult struggles stoically with the family farm and her monstrously theatrical mother, Leonora, in equal measure. A further sister is dead, and it is the arrival of her offspring, the down-at-heel antiques dealer Sandy, and his oikish boyfriend Ray, that gets the plot going.

Borrowed straight from an Orton play, Ray goes about his machiavellian business with very little subtlety and even fewer scruples; having copped a furtive glance at Auntie's will, he realises that the quickest way to an early retirement from turning tricks on the Brighton seafront is to persuade Sandy to do the old girl in. And so it is that poor Sandy, a decent-enough chap being driven half mad with unconsummated lust, comes to find himself creeping about Dunsinane doctoring cups of cocoa, toying with pillows and wrestling with his conscience. A highly unsuitable Macbeth, he has also to contend with the long-smothered attentions of Iseult, who has never quite cottoned on to the fact that he might not be that kind of chap.

Koning's aptitude for an accomplished comedy of manners, jauntily arranged and never too far from resolution, makes this an amiable novel that skates lightly over the surface of rather darker waters. We never, for example, get much further with Connie's compromised past, nor with her stalled relationship with the ruined Wilfred. Nor does the loutish Ray become a great deal more than a nasty piece of work whose menace will, at some point, be neutralised by the straightforward virtues of Connie and Iseult.

But even if the characters verge on the two-dimensional and the plot comes to seem like a rather annoying set of hurdles to be toppled over, Fabulous Time remains a charming, old-fashioned entertainment: a gentle farce in a pleasant setting that will deliver to its protagonists their just deserts - aside from one or two rather extravagant sacrifices. Bereft of any particularly challenging explorations of motive, daring experimental forays or plot developments that you can't see coming straight over the Sussex Downs, it will doubtless translate effortlessly into a comforting piece of Sunday-night drama. The flower-power set piece, in which the hippies, a clutch of rock stars and their groupies, wreath Dunsinane in spliff smoke and nudity, will look especially well - its finale the moment when the ancient chandelier crashes to the ground. As an emblem of the passing of the ruling class, it's a little creaky; as a comic interlude in a highly enjoyable piece of whimsy, it just about does the trick.

webTitle: Review: I'm Off by Jean Echenoz

fields.headline: Joking apart
fields.standfirst: Giles Foden  sees custard pies thrown at convention in I'm Off by Jean Echenoz
fields.trailText: Giles Foden sees custard pies thrown at convention in I'm Off by Jean Echenoz
fields.body:
I'm Off
Jean Echenoz, trans Guido Waldman
169pp, Harvill, £9.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

This Prix Goncourt-winning novel begins and ends with the words "I'm off" - or "Je m'en vais", as the book's French title has it. Beginning with gallery owner Félix Ferrer leaving his wife, the story mainly concerns his trip to the Arctic in an icebreaker to salvage (and, he hopes, sell) a collection of Inuit artefacts abandoned in a ship that has been trapped in the floes for 40 years. He has been put on to this scam by the "competent pundit" Delahaye, one of his acquisition advisers at the gallery.

In his mid-50s, Ferrer is an inveterate womaniser and fugitive from responsibility. During the journey on the icebreaker, he tries to tempt the delicious nurse Brigitte away from her regular boyfriend for some illicit canoodling. As well as being the nurse, Brigitte also runs the ship's video library, logging out Rio Bravo or The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse with the same indulgent smile as The Check-Out Girls or The Voracious Alumna .

This indulgence of both high and low culture (of virtually anything at all, in fact - the whole shoot) is very much Jean Echenoz's own approach, and the reason why he has so rapidly become France's leading writer, with only five novels prior to this one under his belt. The last was Lake , the tale of secret agent Franck Chopin, who has to deal with femme fatale Suzy Clair and the divagations of some live bugs (trained flies fitted with mini microphones). It was, said Le Figaro , "a diabolical thriller, but also the most accomplished parody of its genre".

In I'm Off , Echenoz continues to throw custard pies at literary norms, in particular the machinery of your average novel. But the custard itself is of a very high quality. When he mocks the flashback, for instance, he does it so suavely - "What was not working so well, six months earlier, was business at the gallery" - that we swallow the tired convention whole.

Flash-forwards are employed just as slyly: "But had he been told that each one of the three people gathered in his flat this evening was about to disappear in his or her own way before the month was out, not excluding himself, he would have been considerably alarmed."

With reference to the Inuit guides who accompany Ferrer on the latter part of his trip (during which sleigh dogs eat a frozen mastodon), Echenoz also mocks the technical notation espoused by the likes of Tom Clancy: "They are equipped with carbines (Savage 116 FFS All-weather), binoculars (15x15 IS with image stabiliser), knives and whips. Napaseekadlak's knife has an oosik handle, a bone that stands in for a walrus's sexual organ, and whose suppleness, resistance and porosity are ideal for a firm grip. Angutretrok's knife is less traditional, a White Hunter II Puma with a Kraton handle."

Often, an authorial voice butts nonchalantly into the action: "Now, if you'll permit me, for a change of scene, to join the man who answers to the name of Baumgartner." This is the alias of the villain who contracts a junkie thief called Le Flétan to steal the artworks.

Before Le Flétan meets a miserable end - the fact that his name translates as "the halibut" gives a clue as to how - his covert dealings with Baumgartner are brilliantly done. "On Place de la Porte de Chatillon, Le Flétan double-parked by a telephone box. He got out, entered, lifted the receiver. He appeared to be given a laconic reply then, bequeathing a few of his molecules to the handset - a gob of earwax blocking the perforation of the earpiece, a drop of saliva in an orifice of the mouthpiece - he hung up and raised an eyebrow."

Echenoz himself is always writing with one eyebrow raised, especially when dealing with narrative time, which he handles as ironically as Beckett: "The days, thereafter, trickled by, for lack of alternative, in the customary order." Or: "Let us also continue to make progress, now, let us speed up." Or: "But isn't it about time Ferrer got himself sorted out?"

The question of how the novel paces itself is bound up with the women Ferrer seduces in the course of it. "So he found himself more than ever in a womanless condition but, knowing him, it wouldn't last. Just a matter of time."

Having breached a chapter division, we are then presented with these lines: "Well, what did we say? Not two days have passed and here's one already." The subject of Ferrer's seduction this time around is Sonia, who is assisting in the valuation of the artworks. The start of the liaison with her is conducted in the conditional of Ferrer's randy hopes: "It was a fine day, it would be good to take a table outside, and the account of Ferrer's journey was bound to interest the girl, indeed to fascinate her - to such a degree that she'd switch off her mobile and light one cigarette after another". But all this turns out, almost imperceptibly, to be for real. It's a typical Echenoz trick.

An hour or so later and the lovers are moving through her apartment in "a clumsy sideways dance, like two crabs enlaced, towards Sonia's bedroom, where a black bra could be unfastened and dropped gently onto the rug in this room like an outsize pair of sunglasses".

That is just one of many extra-ordinary images in an extraordinary book. In France, where he has been compared to Queneau (one might also mention Sterne), Echenoz is perceived as leader of the so-called "école du dérisoire", the school of the derisory, for want of a better translation. This refers to the way he and others "deride" the exhausted literary tropes of various genres, whether they be the Hitchcock-style whodunnit, the spy novel or the Conradian adventure yarn.

Of course, there is nothing new about this: Conrad himself did the same thing with the naval novels of Captain Marryat and books such as R M Ballantyne's The Coral Island . Writers have always adapted generic traditions for their own ends. The difference with Echenoz seems to be that he does not see himself as adding to a tradition through its alteration, but simply fending off absurdity. "Better to laugh," as he has said in one interview. "Otherwise things tend to be . . . un peu catastrophique, n'est-ce pas ?" Yet in the books themselves this fending off becomes, almost in spite of itself, a fresh and amazingly graceful way of looking at the world.

Of course, there is nothing new about this: Conrad himself did the same thing with the naval novels of Captain Marryat and books such as R M Ballantyne's The Coral Island . Writers have always adapted generic traditions for their own ends. The difference with Echenoz seems to be that he does not see himself as adding to a tradition through its alteration, but simply fending off absurdity. "Better to laugh," as he has said in one interview. "Otherwise things tend to be . . . un peu catastrophique, n'est-ce pas ?" Yet in the books themselves this fending off becomes, almost in spite of itself, a fresh and amazingly graceful way of looking at the world.

fields.headline: Fit to print
fields.trailText: The sad news of thriller writer Robert Ludlum's death has the Loafer scurrying to his oeuvre for illumination, only to find disturbing news of the Guardian itself
fields.body:
 The sad news of thriller writer Robert Ludlum's death has the Loafer scurrying to his oeuvre for illumination, only to find disturbing news of the Guardian itself. The Holcroft Covenant features John Tennyson, a European reporter who drops in at the old place: "Tennyson walked through the London offices of the Guardian, receiving the compliments of his colleagues and their subordinates. As always, he accepted the compliments modestly." Tennyson also pays attention to other staff. "He studied the women casually. The secretaries and the receptionists invited this most beautiful of men to acknowledge them, invited him, actually, to take whatever he wished. It struck him that he might have to select one of these women . . ."

Ah yes, the Guardian, hotbed of carnal desire and complimentary friendliness. In reality Tennyson is a master assassin named "The Tinamou". He rejects the status of the byline and alerts his editor to a forthcoming series of killings linked to a world crisis that, alas, is far too sensitive for a "responsible newspaper" to report, an edict the editor takes in his stride. Now, that is far-fetched.

 Item: a letter from Random House US to one of its authors, alerting her to an opportunity to buy some surplus stock: "Dear Ms Shelley, This is to advise you that shortly we will be offering your title listed below to the Remainder Marketplace. You may purchase quantities at the unit cost, plus the applicable sales tax for your shipping address. All payments must be made in US dollars. We must receive your order with payment no later than 30 days after the date of this letter. Enclosed is a postage-paid self-addressed envelope for your convenience. Sincerely . . ." Yep, that would be Mary "Frankenstein" Shelley. You may be a long time dead, but you're never beyond the reach of the sales department.

 Among those attending deb novelist Santa Montefiore's party at Claridge's was AA Gill, joining other posh folk such as Annabel Heseltine, royal nanny Tiggy Legg-Bourke and the author's sister Tara Palmer-Tomkinson. Perhaps the Gillster, expert in fine food and smutty novels, was able to give the partyholder some line by line analysis. He has just been appointed a judge of the Forward Poetry Prize, whose organisers were obviously looking for a bit of class.

webTitle: Blair told to give cabinet members their full salary

fields.headline: Blair told to give cabinet members their full salary
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair must allow cabinet members to accept their salaries in full because Labour's freeze on ministerial pay is distorting the parliamentary pay system, an independent review group recommended yesterday.
fields.body:
Tony Blair must allow cabinet members to accept their salaries in full because Labour's freeze on ministerial pay is distorting the parliamentary pay system, an independent review group recommended yesterday.

In a strong rebuke to the prime minister, the senior salaries review body dismissed the cabinet's decision not to accept their full salaries after Labour came to power in 1997.

"This action distorts the parliamentary pay system and creates inequity," the report said. "While recognising the government's motive of setting an example of moderation we would hope that the distortion will be remedied as soon as possible."

The prime minister tried to set an example of restraint after the election when he ordered the cabinet not to accept increases recommended by the review body in 1996. His ruling means that Mr Blair receives £112,951 a year, rather than the £158,658 to which he is entitled. Many cabinet ministers were infuriated by the freeze, which means that they earn less than William Hague. Cabinet ministers are paid £96,887 a year, rather than the £114,543 to which they are entitled. The Tory leader earns £109,030 a year, the full amount to which he is entitled as leader of the opposition.

Yesterday's report by the review body will be welcomed in private by John Prescott, the cabinet's self-appointed "shop steward", who has complained to the prime minister about the freeze. Although salaries are increased annually in line with inflation, Mr Prescott has made clear to Mr Blair that the original freeze was unfair to ministers who spent years in opposition surviving on the relatively modest MP's salary.

Downing Street indicated yesterday that it was unlikely to accept the recommendation of the report. A spokesman said: "We will look at this but we cannot see any changes. Ministers are more focused on foot and mouth rather than looking at their own pay."

The spokesman's remarks indicated that ministers in the House of Lords will have to forgo a pay rise, despite pleading with the review body for an increase. The report said that their pay should be increased by £4,000 over the next two years because peers do not receive a salary as members of the Lords. This would take the salary of the leader of the Lords to just under £90,000.

Lord Carter, the government chief whip in the Lords, who earns £66,294, told the review body that his fellow ministers in the Lords deserved a rise. In diplomatic terms, the report made clear that he had put out the begging bowl.

"It was argued that ministers in the Lords had to cover their whole department's responsibilities in the house, as well as having their own area of responsibility," the report said. "Ministers and whips might therefore be argued to shoulder a bigger range of responsibilities than those in the commons and we were asked to consider recommending a higher increase."

The report also called for MPs to receive a pay rise of £4,000 over the next two years, taking their salary to £53,822. This is likely to be accepted because MPs are given a free vote on the report.

MPs should receive a pay rise because their salaries have fallen behind comparable groups in the public and private sectors, the report said. An NHS administrator, considered to be on the same skills level as an MP, earned on average £54,800 last year.

The recommendations in yesterday's report come on top of the 3% annual increase MPs and peers will receive from next month.

webTitle: Fans in the dark over foul play in the box

fields.headline: Fans in the dark over foul play in the box
fields.trailText: The heart of the World Cup is now up for grabs, and by the time the average British telewatcher finds out it will all be too late.
fields.body:
It is 1954 and on television football fans in England have never had it so good. Over the previous 12 months, for the price of a TV licence, they have seen Stanley Matthews at last collect an FA Cup-winners' medal and then watched Hungary explode the myth of English supremacy. Now a World Cup is being beamed into their living rooms.

The black-and-white transmission might have the quality of a box Brownie snap of a dull day at Blackpool, the little screen will be blinded by a snowstorm whenever an unsuppressed internal combustion engine passes by and low-flying aircraft will frighten the picture away altogether.

In spite of these hazards the 1954 tournament in Switzerland, which remains one of the best, is hugely enjoyed, being the now familiar mix of spectacle, excitement, controversy and the downright daft.

In the quarter-finals, for example, an Englishman, Arthur Ellis, referees the Battle of Berne as Hungary and Brazil turn their match into a brawl, Nandor Hidegkuti having set the scene by scoring after losing his shorts.

Then West Germany become world champions against the odds, beating Hungary 3-2. England are long gone but English enthusiasm for the World Cup, dampened by the miserable exit of 1950 when Walter Winterbottom's team lost to the United States, has been rekindled.

How times change. For next summer's tournament in the Far East the humble terrestrial viewer will have less chance of seeing all the action than did his predecessor of 47 years ago, when the bloke next door could scupper reception with a bit of inconsiderate DIY.

In this instance the culprit is not a bad neighbour but a 70-year-old Bavarian with more money than sensitivity. Five years ago Leo Kirch's media group bought the European television rights to the next two World Cups to open the way for pay-TV, a development which for British viewers ended the assumption that they would always be able to watch the tournament on BBC or ITV courtesy of the European Broadcasting Union.

It is now up to the television companies, terrestrial or satellite, to bid for the bulk of the games. The opening match, semi-finals, final and third-place play-off remain sacrosanct. Both Fifa and Kirch guarantee that these will continue to be available on terrestrial TV along with all games played by whatever nation happens to be the broadcaster's country. But the heart of the World Cup is now up for grabs.

By the time your average British telewatcher is aware of what is happening it will be too late; the pass to see the nuts and bolts of the world's greatest sporting event bar none will already have been sold. Out of 64 matches only five will be covered by the licence fee, along with those played by England and Scotland and, more hypothetically, Wales and Northern Ireland, provided they qualify.

Under the Fifa-Kirch agreement, had the TV technology been in place, such historic World Cup events as North Korea's elimination of Italy in 1966, the full pomp of Pele in 1970, the blooming of Holland in 1974, the glorious quarter-final between France and Brazil in 1986, Germany's early elimination by Bulgaria in 1994 and Holland's stunning victory over Argentina in France 98 would have been available exclusively on satellite, digital or pay-TV.

Given the time difference between the Far East and Europe, the television audience for next year's World Cup may be only slightly more miffed at missing live coverage of Liberia versus Bahrain than they would normally be at having to pass up the Richard and Judy show. But the crunch will surely come in 2006 when the World Cup lands on Kirch's doorstep in Germany.

This week Fifa graciously reassured European football enthusiasts that everybody would still be able to watch the start and finish of the tournament on TV come what may. Yet in abandoning the principle of universal satellite-free coverage by selling out to Kirch it has still betrayed the huge following the tournament now enjoys and which was assiduously built up under the presidency of Joao Havelange, who increased the number of finalists from 16 to 32.

Football's television punters are addicts for whom the price of a fix grows ever higher. In England regular live coverage of league games began modestly in 1983 when the BBC and ITV shared 10 matches a season. In 1992 Rupert Murdoch, realising the importance of football to the BSkyB package, blew rival bidders out of the water and viewing became dearer.

Kirch, with Fifa's acquiescence, has merely taken the World Cup in the same direction while the public have hardly noticed. If Brazil play Germany, Italy meet Argentina or France face Holland in the 2002 World Cup quarter-finals the message will be received and understood, but the pictures might cost an arm and a hamstring.

To be on the safe side, once England have gone out, it might be worth taking up residence in Switzerland for the rest of the tournament since their TV picks up regular German, French and Italian transmissions as a matter of course. Or Lichtenstein if you can find a parking space.

fields.headline: TV fails to do its homework on Scholar
fields.trailText: TV fails to do its homework on Scholar
fields.body:
This week's sycophantic documentary The Men Who Changed Football (Tuesday, BBC2) lionised Irving Scholar, Tottenham's go-ahead chairman in their "Big Five" period. Strangely there was no mention of his machinations that led the manager Keith Burkinshaw to resign, famously remarking that "there used to be a football club over there". And was it not Scholar's much-trumpeted excursions into the stock market and merchandising that helped usher in Tottenham's vast debts by the end of the 80s? Perhaps the second episode will remind us.

Is there no limit to the Sepp Blatter personality cult? Fifa's official magazine includes a riveting article on fan letters sent to Zurich ("their words represent a genuine declaration of love for Fifa") and Sepp above all. "The signature of Fifa president Joseph S Blatter is also popular, with some 40 signed photos being sent out every month. Slightly less popular are the signatures of Pele and Michel Platini . . . " Naturally.

Kazakhstan, for reasons best known to themselves, are applying to join Uefa. "More than 20% of Kazakhstan is in Europe, while Uefa member Turkey is represented in Europe by only 3% and Israel is in Asia," a Kazakh spokesman argues. The bid fits a pattern. A few years ago the country's capital was moved from scenic Almaty to Astana on the barren Steppes - "a totally stupid idea" according to one diplomat. Still, never an easy place to get a result.

Our discography of inappropriate football music is expanding. Hull City fan Stephen Brasher recalls a game at Ashton Gate some years ago, when the Tannoy blasted out the theme from All Creatures Great and Small. "All I can think is that they thought it was a Yorkshire theme for Yorkshire fans," he says.

A Uefa disciplinary committee finds Raul's handballed goal against Leeds to be "a manifest act of cheating committed deliberately with the sole objective of gaining personal profit". At the appeal, the ref admits he saw the incident, but not the hand. "Thus, the Appeals Body ruled that it is of no importance whether this decision was correct or wrong," Uefa conclude. So that's all sorted, then.

Mark Wright, once of Liverpool, was furious after his Southport side lost 1-0 to Chester in the FA Trophy last week. "The referee was an utter disgrace," he railed in the Non-League Paper. "He was in charge when we lost to Rushden and was a disgrace that day. Yet again he has worked against us." Strong stuff, but wait for the most damning indictment. Wright spat: "The ref is an Evertonian."

fields.headline: Kinnear back where he belongs
fields.trailText: Luton's new manager is loving life back at the training ground.
fields.body:
Joe Kinnear has never been one to resist a laugh at his own expense. So he enjoyed a good chuckle behind the wheel of his car when he heard a radio reporter suggesting that by leaving Oxford to become the Luton Town manager he was swapping a club with both feet in the Second Division grave to a club with only one.

There was, however, a compelling reason for Kinnear's switch a month ago. Buying and selling players for Oxford on a freelance basis, with no input into the team, he just did not feel involved enough, did not feel any real sense of fulfilment.

After almost two years' recuperation since his heart attack in March 1999, he was desperate to start yelling at players on the training field again and begin moulding and building another team. And any new club's league position was irrelevant, Kinnear just wanted to feel like he was making a difference again.

He realised how badly he was longing for a return when he bumped into Sir Alex Ferguson before last summer's Euro 2000 final and Fergie casually broached the subject of whether he had considered going back into management. Kinnear was surprised to hear himself say: "Christ, I'd go back in the morning."

After 18 months of hospital visits and cholesterol checks and heart monitoring and, worst of all, sensible eating, Kinnear felt he was ready when Sheffield Wednesday came calling in the summer.

"I was desperate to take the job and I spent a week up there looking round," he says. "They're a massive club and the contract was terrific and the money tremendous. But I wanted to be a hero in the job, I wanted to go in and blow a trumpet and take them straight back into the Premiership.

"The more they told me, the more I realised that would be impossible. They were something like £36m in debt and the banks wanted £16m of that immediately. So my first job would have been to sell half the team. I loved everything about the place but I thought the challenge was unfair."

He laughs again when he recalls his words to the Wednesday directors, that it would be a struggle for survival, when that is just the task he has taken on at Kenilworth Road. He does, though, see a club trying to move forward rather than one stuck in reverse, perhaps fatally so.

The challenge he has been offered by the Luton chairman Mike Watson-Challis is to build a team in the next 3 years to fill the 18,000 all-seater stadium near junction 10 of the M1 that should be finished by 2003.

He says: "The way I break that down is for us to stay up this season and then have a punt next year, maybe getting into the play-offs and, if not, get promoted the following year. And once you're in the First Division, everyone starts dreaming of the Premiership. Sounds simple doesn't it?"

He believes he has inherited a nucleus of young players similar to those he found at Wimbledon. Liam George, an Irish Under-21 striker, his partner up front Stuart Douglas, 20, and the defenders Matthew Taylor and Emmerson Boyce, are all players who Kinnear describes as having "massive potential".

He also has a small kitty to spend before next week's transfer deadline - Kinnear has had discussions recently with the former Leicester striker Steve Claridge about signing a short-term contract with Luton - though he was not encouraged by a visit to a reserve game between Watford and West Ham. "West Ham had Titi Camara and Kaba Diawara up front and Paul Kitson on the bench. Any one of those three would do us but they're on 10 grand a week."

The board, he says, are also all great football fans, and prove it by acting pottier than the genuine supporters. Director Rob Stringer, who is the Chairman of SonyMusic Entertainment UK, broke off from a lunch with Fidel Castro in Cuba, where the Manic Street Preachers were playing, to get an update on Luton's game at Notts County, which they won 3-1. And when he stepped off the plane from Havana at Birmingham airport, he instructed his driver to take him straight to Walsall for Luton's game.

That ended in defeat, but Kinnear has chiselled a remarkable 16 points from eight games. And he clearly has a more philosophical approach to the game after his heart scare. He says: "As soon as they got me into hospital, they give me this adrenalin injection and said the next hour would tell. You're thinking this is it, it's all over, and that was the longest hour of my life.

"Then they wire you to this heart monitor and you're listening to it go 'bleep . . . bleep . . .' and it's the most agonising sound on earth because you're expecting it to stop. And you're watching the line zigzag across the screen and thinking it will go straight in a minute and they'll all come running through the frigging door and leap on top of you like in the movies. But thank God, it just kept bleeping and bleeping and bleeping and then you think what a wonderful sound that is."

Luton's, and football's gain, however, has been the Little Chef's loss. Kinnear says that his car was incapable of passing one on the way back from scouting missions, where he would tuck into a midnight feast of eggs, bacon, beans and toast. He says: "The doctors told me that all had to go, as well as the Guinness. So now I eat porridge every morning, fruit for lunch and fish in the evening, and you know what? It's completely boring."

He laughs at himself again and, though it's left unsaid, you sense that, despite those deprivations, now that he's got his football back, life has never felt better.

He realised how badly he was longing for a return when he bumped into Sir Alex Ferguson before last summer's Euro 2000 final and Fergie casually broached the subject of whether he had considered going back into management. Kinnear was surprised to hear himself say: "Christ, I'd go back in the morning." After 18 months of hospital visits and cholesterol checks and heart monitoring and, worst of all, sensible eating, Kinnear felt he was ready when Sheffield Wednesday came calling in the summer. "I was desperate to take the job and I spent a week up there looking round," he says. "They're a massive club and the contract was terrific and the money tremendous. But I wanted to be a hero in the job, I wanted to go in and blow a trumpet and take them straight back into the Premiership. "The more they told me, the more I realised that would be impossible. They were something like £36m in debt and the banks wanted £16m of that immediately. So my first job would have been to sell half the team. I loved everything about the place but I thought the challenge was unfair." He laughs again when he recalls his words to the Wednesday directors, that it would be a struggle for survival, when that is just the task he has taken on at Kenilworth Road. He does, though, see a club trying to move forward rather than one stuck in reverse, perhaps fatally so. The challenge he has been offered by the Luton chairman Mike Watson-Challis is to build a team in the next 3 years to fill the 18,000 all-seater stadium near junction 10 of the M1 that should be finished by 2003. He says: "The way I break that down is for us to stay up this season and then have a punt next year, maybe getting into the play-offs and, if not, get promoted the following year. And once you're in the First Division, everyone starts dreaming of the Premiership. Sounds simple doesn't it?" He believes he has inherited a nucleus of young players similar to those he found at Wimbledon. Liam George, an Irish Under-21 striker, his partner up front Stuart Douglas, 20, and the defenders Matthew Taylor and Emmerson Boyce, are all players who Kinnear describes as having "massive potential". He also has a small kitty to spend before next week's transfer deadline - Kinnear has had discussions recently with the former Leicester striker Steve Claridge about signing a short-term contract with Luton - though he was not encouraged by a visit to a reserve game between Watford and West Ham. "West Ham had Titi Camara and Kaba Diawara up front and Paul Kitson on the bench. Any one of those three would do us but they're on 10 grand a week." The board, he says, are also all great football fans, and prove it by acting pottier than the genuine supporters. Director Rob Stringer, who is the Chairman of SonyMusic Entertainment UK, broke off from a lunch with Fidel Castro in Cuba, where the Manic Street Preachers were playing, to get an update on Luton's game at Notts County, which they won 3-1. And when he stepped off the plane from Havana at Birmingham airport, he instructed his driver to take him straight to Walsall for Luton's game. That ended in defeat, but Kinnear has chiselled a remarkable 16 points from eight games. And he clearly has a more philosophical approach to the game after his heart scare. He says: "As soon as they got me into hospital, they give me this adrenalin injection and said the next hour would tell. You're thinking this is it, it's all over, and that was the longest hour of my life. "Then they wire you to this heart monitor and you're listening to it go 'bleep . . . bleep . . .' and it's the most agonising sound on earth because you're expecting it to stop. And you're watching the line zigzag across the screen and thinking it will go straight in a minute and they'll all come running through the frigging door and leap on top of you like in the movies. But thank God, it just kept bleeping and bleeping and bleeping and then you think what a wonderful sound that is." Luton's, and football's gain, however, has been the Little Chef's loss. Kinnear says that his car was incapable of passing one on the way back from scouting missions, where he would tuck into a midnight feast of eggs, bacon, beans and toast. He says: "The doctors told me that all had to go, as well as the Guinness. So now I eat porridge every morning, fruit for lunch and fish in the evening, and you know what? It's completely boring." He laughs at himself again and, though it's left unsaid, you sense that, despite those deprivations, now that he's got his football back, life has never felt better.

webTitle: Robson licks his wounds before a derby dogfight

fields.headline: Robson licks his wounds before a derby dogfight
fields.trailText: A season spent flirting with Uefa Cup qualification is threatening a fizzled finale as Newcastle, racked by injuries and denied the chequebook clout of the Keegan era, stumble into this afternoon's north-east derby against Middlesbrough.
fields.body:
The Toon is troubled. A season spent flirting with Uefa Cup qualification is threatening a fizzled finale as Newcastle, racked by injuries and denied the chequebook clout of the Keegan era, stumble into this afternoon's north-east derby against Middlesbrough.

Three defeats in four Premiership games have derailed the Geordies' unlikely challenge. To make matters worse, Alain Goma became the second fractious Frenchman to leave this season grumbling about training techniques and a lack of ambition; Kieron Dyer's shin injury has been misdiagnosed; Alan Shearer has suffered a relapse; and Nolberto Solano and Clarence Acuna are considering returning to the Peru and Chile national set-ups against Bobby Robson's wishes.

"It's just more bad news after another," growls Newcastle's manager. "Acuna came here on the basis he had given up his international career under his own volition. But now the coach has persuaded him otherwise. What can you do?"

In his talismanic captain's case, very little. After two months on the sidelines, Shearer was supposed to be playing with a "new leg"; instead he jarred the knee last week and is likely to watch from the stands. "He did not twist it, so it has not blown up," says Robson.

Dyer faces a second operation today after it emerged that what Newcastle thought was a cyst on his knee was in fact a stress fracture. The England midfielder will undergo a bone graft from his hip to his shin; United hope he will be fit to resume training in August. At least Carl Cort, the £7m striker bought from Wimbledon, returns today from persistent hamstring trouble.

While Robson's players were dropping like flies, the board kept the purse strings tight while the European Union laboured over the future of the transfer system and the club contemplated paying back the £40m it owes on the re-development of St James' Park.

"Most Newcastle fans are feeling pretty down," says Mark Jensen, editor of the club fanzine The Mag. "The lack of money to spend is the worrying thing. If it is a short-term tactic to bring the wage bill down before Robson is given cash in the summer, people will accept it. We're all for giving kids the chance, but you have to back them up with experience. If we go into next season with the current squad, the fans will not be pleased."

The sales of Goma and Didier Domi, for a combined £8m, have at least bolstered the coffers, if not a defence that has failed to keep a clean sheet in 24 games. They might fancy their chances of ending that depressing sequence this afternoon; Boro have yet to beat Newcastle in the Premiership.

"We've had a few mediocre performances recently," added Robson. "Whenever that happens people immediately say that the players aren't trying. I've played golf loads of times and not very well, but I've been trying like hell. We're due a big game."

webTitle: Kilner in danger after Evans fiasco

fields.headline: Kilner in danger after Evans fiasco
fields.trailText: Stockport County's attempts to lure Roy Evans back into football collapsed last night, leaving the manager Andy Kilner and his chairman Brendan Elwood embroiled in a furious row.
fields.body:
Stockport County's attempts to lure Roy Evans back into football collapsed last night, leaving the manager Andy Kilner and his chairman Brendan Elwood embroiled in a furious row.

Kilner's position is now in jeopardy after making it clear that he was not willing to work alongside Evans and demanding to know why he had not been consulted.

Elwood initially announced that the former Liverpool manager had agreed to work alongside Kilner and that both parties were "comfortable with it".

But Evans then turned down the offer after learning Kilner did not want him to play any part at Edgeley Park. "It seems this was somebody's idea at the club, without consulting the most relevant people," said Evans. "While that remains the case, it's a total non-goer."

Kilner was said to be "incensed" but Elwood was unsympathetic, broadly hinting there could yet be changes in the club's management.

"There was no question of Roy wanting to steal his job or do a Terry Venables and start picking the team," said Elwood. "We offered him help and he turned it down. You will have to ask him for his reasons. But after that, maybe the circumstances might be different."

Tony Cottee has left as player-manager of Barnet after only 4 months in charge, admitting his first managerial job had not worked out as planned. Barnet have slumped in the Third Division and lie just five points ahead of bottom-placed Halifax. John Still resumes as manager until the summer.

Roy Essandoh, who scored Wycombe's FA Cup winner at Leicester last Saturday, is to sign a contract with the club for the rest of the season.

Wycombe's manager Lawrie Sanchez, charged with misconduct by the FA after being banished from the touchline at Leicester, is likely to be in the dug-out again for the semi- final with Liverpool on April 8.

If Sanchez appeals within the next 14 days the case will almost certainly not be heard until after the semi-final. He faces a three-match touchline ban if found guilty.

webTitle: Eriksson's England await test of mettle

fields.headline: Eriksson's England await test of mettle
fields.trailText: The events of the next 10 days will tell us a great deal more than we currently know about England's standing in the world of football.
fields.body:
Tomorrow night Sven-Goran Eriksson will announce his list of 25 players for the forthcoming World Cup qualifying matches against Finland and Albania. In reducing the size of his squad from the 31 convened for last month's encouraging friendly against Spain the coach will be providing a clearer idea of the nature of his discoveries since his arrival in England. And the events of the next 10 days will tell us a great deal more than we currently know about England's standing in the world of football.

The latest Fifa rankings, released this week, placed England 16th among the world's 203 footballing nations. Brazil, France, Argentina, Portugal and Italy comprise the top five. England are sandwiched between Colombia and Croatia - which might be a fraction generous, taking a slightly broader view of recent history, since the Croatians finished third in the last World Cup while England failed to make it into the quarter-finals.

And yet this week the English Premier League achieved the feat of placing three clubs - Manchester United, Arsenal and Leeds United - in the last eight of the Champions League, matching the performance of Spain's Liga and totally eclipsing Italy's Serie A, whose last representative was ejected on Tuesday night. A certain amount of self-congratulation was only to be expected.

No one really knows, however, which statistic is the more reliable indicator of the health of English football. What will it mean, for example, if all three Premier League clubs are eliminated in next month's quarter-finals? If, on the other hand, England provide both finalists, as Spain did last year, and Eriksson leads the national team to resounding victories next Saturday and the following Wednesday, would we be right to conclude that, after last year's traumas, the domestic game has been returned to life?

Eriksson's debut, in last month's widely applauded 3-0 win in a friendly against Spain, justifiably reawakened hopes of qualification for the World Cup finals in 2002. Suddenly the prospect of group matches against Germany and Greece, as well as Finland and Albania, did not seem so daunting. The feeling was quick to arise that, if Eriksson could continue his work of getting the players to observe the basic technical and tactical principles of football at international level, then the dismal opening to the campaign - a single point from matches against Germany and Finland - might yet be overcome.

"It's a very good new start for English football," Christian Damiano, Jean Tigana's assistant at Fulham, said yesterday. Damiano was one of the coaches who plotted France's ascent to the glories of 1998, as national director of youth development and Aime Jacquet's assistant coach with the World Cup-winning squad. "Eriksson's team played well against Spain," he continued, "at a time when Spanish football is a reference point. The players seemed to have a new confidence."

It is hard to imagine that Eriksson has been the recipient of any blinding revelations since he watched his inaugural selection function with such unfamiliar but welcome efficiency at Villa Park. The chances are that his starting XI against Finland at Anfield next Saturday will closely resemble the one that began the game against Spain.

Perhaps, if the coach is in a conservative mood, David Seaman will replace David James. If he is feeling adventurous, Ashley Cole may take over from the 31-year-old Chris Powell, even though the Charlton left-back performed brightly enough in Eriksson's first match to be hopeful of keeping his place for the second.

The elimination of Nick Barmby, removed from the reckoning by an ankle injury, would appear to open a place on the left of midfield for Steven Gerrard, his Liverpool team-mate. Gerrard's long-standing fitness problem rendered him unavailable for selection for the first squad, but against Porto at Anfield in Thursday night's Uefa Cup tie he produced a performance of such energy and commitment that the watching Swede could hardly fail to have been impressed all over again. Andy Cole and Michael Owen would be right to feel aggrieved if they were not given another opportunity to establish their credentials as a partnership. On current form, however, David Beckham would probably be replaced by Steve McManaman, with Sol Campbell taking the captaincy.

McManaman has been in increasingly impressive form for Real Madrid, scoring against Real Sociedad last weekend and being rested for the trip to Anderlecht on Wednesday, when they lost their "dead" Champions League group match 2-0. It would be good to see Eriksson recognising and exploiting the strength of character which saw him through last summer's ordeal. But the type of football McManaman has learnt to play in Madrid, with its disciplined use of fast-moving triangles, might not have best prepared him for the sort of tactics he is likely to find England operating, even under Eriksson's relatively enlightened tutelage, although it would be nice to think that one day it could.

Once again, however, the team's backbone is likely to be provided by the Manchester United contingent. Five of them started against Spain and it is unlikely that fewer will be chosen to confront Finland.

"It's very important," Damiano said, "that, when international coaches only have the players for a few days at a time, they have a group of five or six or even seven players who are already synchronised with each other. In my view Manchester United are the best club team in Europe, perhaps the world, and I think that provides a very useful foundation for the England team."

The ideal combination, of course, is a strong domestic league feeding a strong national team. But that, as many countries have found, is curiously difficult to achieve. France won the World Cup and the European Championship on the back of a hopelessly ineffectual league, virtually all their international players earning their living abroad. In Spain the situation is reversed: their clubs rule European competition while their national team cannot do more than give tantalising glimpses of their potential.

In the case of England's renaissance, the thing to avoid is impatience, on and off the field. Eriksson's team beat Spain because they observed a sensible pattern and kept calm. Against Finland and Albania, of course, the atmosphere will be very different. World Cup qualifying points will be at stake. But the principles will be the same, and so should the players' state of mind.
