fields.headline: Sacked Graham to sue Spurs
fields.trailText: George Graham has threatened to take legal action against Tottenham following what he called the club's "bizarre and inexplicable" decision to sack him for an alleged breach of contract.
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin, Vivek Chaudhary and Martin Thorpe
fields.body:
Yesterday morning George Graham was looking forward to leading Tottenham into an FA Cup semi-final against Arsenal in three weeks' time. By the evening he was preparing for a court battle after being sacked during an extraordinary day at White Hart Lane.

Graham's dismissal, which he has vowed to fight with legal action, came after a 15-minute meeting with the club's executive vice-chairman David Buchler yesterday lunchtime and follows three days of tension at the club.

Buchler said the Scot had been fired for "breach of contract" after making public comments about Tottenham's financial position which led him to question whether Graham "had the real interests of the club at heart".

Graham had said at a press conference on Thursday that he had learned, in a meeting with Enic the previous day, that he would be given only "limited funds" for transfers.

Buchler was livid to see his remarks from a private meeting in the newspapers and his anger was exacerbated by the fact that they came on the day he met Sol Campbell and his agent in an attempt to convince the captain to remain at the club beyond the summer.

Graham was called to a meeting yesterday with Buchler and the club's financial director John Sedgwick to explain his comments and was said by Buchler to have given what amounted to "a two-fingered salute".

"He was defiant, he was aggressive," Buchler said. "He used inappropriate words in the course of the conversation. It was a most uncomfortable conversation and I hadn't anticipated it.

"It was clear to me that we not only had a situation where he had broken his contract but I question the motives behind being put in the situation I was. As a result of that George Graham was dismissed."

Buchler, who has put the club's director of football David Pleat in temporary charge, hinted that Graham had deliberately provoked him into the sacking. "I was not expecting to come out of the meeting having to dismiss somebody," he said. "His reaction probably said it all. When he was dismissed he shrugged his shoulders, said 'So be it' and walked out."

Buchler insisted that he had hoped the Scot, who was appointed in October 1998, would see out his contract, which runs to the end of next season.

But Graham, who said he was "shocked and extremely upset" at the "bizarre and inexplicable decision", claimed his future had already been decided and that his remarks to the press had been used as an excuse to sack him.

"Mr Graham was stunned and could not believe that such a flimsy excuse was being given for his dismissal," his lawyers said in a statement. "Mr Graham believes that Enic always intended to sack him when they came in and for them to say that it was him who had 'his own agenda' was untrue and a complete reversal of the facts."

Graham added: "Every club has a limited budget and to say that I have broken some confidence in revealing this 'secret' just demonstrates how little the new owners understand about the game."

According to ENIC sources, Wednesday's five-hour meeting, which was attended by Buchler, Graham and Pleat, became quite heated and Buchler became increasingly annoyed at Graham's attitude. Enic say that he did not appear interested in their vision for the club and the objectives they were outlining.

Sources said Buchler detailed a three-year and a five-year plan for the club. Money for new players, new contracts for existing players and a particular player Spurs have put in a bid for were also discussed. But Graham apparently was concerned only about money and how much would be available to him for new players.

According to the source, Buchler told Graham: "You have already spent £;40m and all you've got to show for it is one away win this season."

The meeting ended on a bad note and that same evening, Buchler expressed his dismay at Graham's attitude to Daniel Levy, the Enic vice-president.

While Graham began thinking of court the fans started thinking of who will take over. Glenn Hoddle, Terry Venables and Peter Taylor - three former Spurs players - are among the bookmakers' favourites, together with the former Chelsea manager Gianluca Vialli.

Buchler said he had not spoken with any managers or their agents and promised to scour Europe to find Graham's successor. Many expect he will look no further than Southampton, where Hoddle is in charge.

Hoddle's agent Dennis Roach refused to rule out a return for the former darling of White Hart Lane. Hoddle recently signed a new contract to keep him at Southampton until the summer of 2002.

"At this moment in time Glenn Hoddle is the manager of Southampton and is happy there," said Roach. "We have had no communication or negotiations with Tottenham. Glenn is an intelligent person and will look at the situation if it arises."

Southampton are reported to have sounded out Kevin Keegan as a replacement for Hoddle.

Buchler insisted the decision had not been taken because of pressure from fans but there is no doubt the news will be greeted with joy by sections of the club's supporters, who have been lobbying for Graham's removal for some time.

"I am delighted Graham has gone," said Mark Jacob, chairman of the Tottenham Action Group. "He should not have been appointed in the first place. He never knew what Tottenham was about."

Graham delivered the club's first trophy since 1991 by winning the Worthington Cup in 1999 but many fans disliked his style of play and his connections with Arsenal, where he was a player and later manager.

The chain of events: Last Wednesday afternoon

George Graham and David Buchler, executive vice-chairman of Spurs, meet for five hours to discuss new owner Enic's plans for the club. Graham asks how much money will be available to him to spend. The meeting is considered to be difficult and breaks up acrimoniously.

Wednesday evening

Buchler speaks to Daniel Levy, Enic's vice-president, and expresses his dismay at Graham's attitude.

Thursday morning

Graham takes training at the club's ground in Essex, then tells newspaper and television journalists that he has met with Buchler and has been led to believe that there will be limited funds with which to purchase new players.

Thursday afternoon

Buchler meets Sol Campbell's agent, Sky Andrew, to discuss a new contract for Campbell. His deal ends at the end of this season and he has said that he will leave Spurs if they show a lack of ambition.

Yesterday 10am

Buchler wakes up to reports in a number of morning papers which carry accounts of Graham's press conference. He telephones Graham and says he wants to see the manager after training.

2pm

Buchler and Graham meet in north London. Graham is defiant according to Buchler, defending his right to talk to the press. Buchler sacks Graham for breach of contract.

3.30pm

Having told Tottenham's staff of the decison, Buchler speaks to the press.

5pm

Graham releases a statement announcing his intention to sue for wrongful dismissal.
fields.bodyText: Yesterday morning George Graham was looking forward to leading Tottenham into an FA Cup semi-final against Arsenal in three weeks' time. By the evening he was preparing for a court battle after being sacked during an extraordinary day at White Hart Lane. Graham's dismissal, which he has vowed to fight with legal action, came after a 15-minute meeting with the club's executive vice-chairman David Buchler yesterday lunchtime and follows three days of tension at the club. Buchler said the Scot had been fired for "breach of contract" after making public comments about Tottenham's financial position which led him to question whether Graham "had the real interests of the club at heart". Graham had said at a press conference on Thursday that he had learned, in a meeting with Enic the previous day, that he would be given only "limited funds" for transfers. Buchler was livid to see his remarks from a private meeting in the newspapers and his anger was exacerbated by the fact that they came on the day he met Sol Campbell and his agent in an attempt to convince the captain to remain at the club beyond the summer. Graham was called to a meeting yesterday with Buchler and the club's financial director John Sedgwick to explain his comments and was said by Buchler to have given what amounted to "a two-fingered salute". "He was defiant, he was aggressive," Buchler said. "He used inappropriate words in the course of the conversation. It was a most uncomfortable conversation and I hadn't anticipated it. "It was clear to me that we not only had a situation where he had broken his contract but I question the motives behind being put in the situation I was. As a result of that George Graham was dismissed." Buchler, who has put the club's director of football David Pleat in temporary charge, hinted that Graham had deliberately provoked him into the sacking. "I was not expecting to come out of the meeting having to dismiss somebody," he said. "His reaction probably said it all. When he was dismissed he shrugged his shoulders, said 'So be it' and walked out." Buchler insisted that he had hoped the Scot, who was appointed in October 1998, would see out his contract, which runs to the end of next season. But Graham, who said he was "shocked and extremely upset" at the "bizarre and inexplicable decision", claimed his future had already been decided and that his remarks to the press had been used as an excuse to sack him. "Mr Graham was stunned and could not believe that such a flimsy excuse was being given for his dismissal," his lawyers said in a statement. "Mr Graham believes that Enic always intended to sack him when they came in and for them to say that it was him who had 'his own agenda' was untrue and a complete reversal of the facts." Graham added: "Every club has a limited budget and to say that I have broken some confidence in revealing this 'secret' just demonstrates how little the new owners understand about the game." According to ENIC sources, Wednesday's five-hour meeting, which was attended by Buchler, Graham and Pleat, became quite heated and Buchler became increasingly annoyed at Graham's attitude. Enic say that he did not appear interested in their vision for the club and the objectives they were outlining. Sources said Buchler detailed a three-year and a five-year plan for the club. Money for new players, new contracts for existing players and a particular player Spurs have put in a bid for were also discussed. But Graham apparently was concerned only about money and how much would be available to him for new players. According to the source, Buchler told Graham: "You have already spent £;40m and all you've got to show for it is one away win this season." The meeting ended on a bad note and that same evening, Buchler expressed his dismay at Graham's attitude to Daniel Levy, the Enic vice-president. While Graham began thinking of court the fans started thinking of who will take over. Glenn Hoddle, Terry Venables and Peter Taylor - three former Spurs players - are among the bookmakers' favourites, together with the former Chelsea manager Gianluca Vialli. Buchler said he had not spoken with any managers or their agents and promised to scour Europe to find Graham's successor. Many expect he will look no further than Southampton, where Hoddle is in charge. Hoddle's agent Dennis Roach refused to rule out a return for the former darling of White Hart Lane. Hoddle recently signed a new contract to keep him at Southampton until the summer of 2002. "At this moment in time Glenn Hoddle is the manager of Southampton and is happy there," said Roach. "We have had no communication or negotiations with Tottenham. Glenn is an intelligent person and will look at the situation if it arises." Southampton are reported to have sounded out Kevin Keegan as a replacement for Hoddle. Buchler insisted the decision had not been taken because of pressure from fans but there is no doubt the news will be greeted with joy by sections of the club's supporters, who have been lobbying for Graham's removal for some time. "I am delighted Graham has gone," said Mark Jacob, chairman of the Tottenham Action Group. "He should not have been appointed in the first place. He never knew what Tottenham was about." Graham delivered the club's first trophy since 1991 by winning the Worthington Cup in 1999 but many fans disliked his style of play and his connections with Arsenal, where he was a player and later manager. The chain of events: Last Wednesday afternoon George Graham and David Buchler, executive vice-chairman of Spurs, meet for five hours to discuss new owner Enic's plans for the club. Graham asks how much money will be available to him to spend. The meeting is considered to be difficult and breaks up acrimoniously. Wednesday evening Buchler speaks to Daniel Levy, Enic's vice-president, and expresses his dismay at Graham's attitude. Thursday morning Graham takes training at the club's ground in Essex, then tells newspaper and television journalists that he has met with Buchler and has been led to believe that there will be limited funds with which to purchase new players. Thursday afternoon Buchler meets Sol Campbell's agent, Sky Andrew, to discuss a new contract for Campbell. His deal ends at the end of this season and he has said that he will leave Spurs if they show a lack of ambition. Yesterday 10am Buchler wakes up to reports in a number of morning papers which carry accounts of Graham's press conference. He telephones Graham and says he wants to see the manager after training. 2pm Buchler and Graham meet in north London. Graham is defiant according to Buchler, defending his right to talk to the press. Buchler sacks Graham for breach of contract. 3.30pm Having told Tottenham's staff of the decison, Buchler speaks to the press. 5pm Graham releases a statement announcing his intention to sue for wrongful dismissal.

webTitle: Graham's dismissal signals worrying sea change

fields.headline: Graham's dismissal signals worrying sea change
fields.trailText: Football managers usually leave their clubs due to bad results but George Graham continues to be an exception to the rules.
fields.body:
Football managers usually leave their clubs due to bad results but George Graham continues to be an exception to the rules. He left Arsenal over the bung scandal, then walked away from a successful Leeds team three years later to take over at Tottenham. Now he has been sacked by Spurs because he apparently spoke out of turn.

Graham's departure is not surprising. Once Sir Alan Sugar sold his controlling interest to Enic he was presumed to be on borrowed time.

White Hart Lane fans were increasingly fed up under Graham. At home Spurs were a force in the League but played tedious football. Away they were pushovers - and still played tedious football. Glenn Hoddle, making bricks without straw at Southampton, had already been touted as the next manager.

Yet the manner of Graham's dismissal is worrying as it signals a sea change in the way club owners regard managers. They have always been dispensable but the explanation by David Buchler, Spurs' vice-chairman, of why Graham had gone still made depressing reading.

Buchler is entitled to be miffed if details of a private meeting were leaked to the newspapers suggesting that Graham had become frustrated at the limited amount of cash offered by Enic for new players.

It is, however, an odd kind of reaction which sacks the manager just when he has managed to bring the team within reach of some kind of success. Last Sunday's 3-2 win at West Ham, which took Spurs to a semi-final against Arsenal, was a reminder of Graham's ability to organise a team for a big occasion. Now David Pleat will be responsible for getting Tottenham to the final.

Yesterday Buchler's statement was pure company-speak. "I am not prepared to have someone who is not a team player, who is not looking after the club's interest," quoth he.

Presumably any echoes of the company man in Drop The Dead Donkey were purely coincidental. But, when the director of a football club starts blathering on about needing team players off the pitch when it is quite clear that not a lot of money will be available to put decent players on it, then those supporters who did handstands when Sugar left may soon begin to pine for the days of good old Alan.

According to Buchler, Graham showed "a defiant attitude". He should be so lucky. At another club in another age he might have found himself up against Brian Clough.

webTitle: Greece match to be played at Old Trafford

fields.headline: Greece match to be played at Old Trafford
fields.trailText: Old Trafford will host England's final 2002 World Cup qualifier against Greece on October 6, continuing the trend of spreading internationals around the country while Wembley is rebuilt.
fields.body:
Old Trafford will host England's final 2002 World Cup qualifier against Greece on October 6, continuing the trend of spreading internationals around the country while Wembley is rebuilt.

The 67,000-capacity stadium drew the approval of the England coach Sven-Goran Eriksson, a frequent visitor at Manchester United.

"Sven thinks the stadium is magnificent and that the atmosphere is fantastic. He's relishing the prospect of bringing England here," said the Football Association's director of marketing Paul Barber.

"He had a significant say, as all the England coaching staff do, as to where we play the games. Clearly towards the back end of the qualifying campaign we wanted two of the biggest grounds in the country."

The FA announced on Monday that the match against Albania on September 5 will be at Newcastle United 's 51,000-capacity St James' Park.

The England Under-21 coach Howard Wilkinson has included Newcastle's striker Shola Ameobi in his squad of 27 for Friday's European Championship qualifier with Finland at Oakwell.

The 19-year-old has been invited by the Nigerian FA to participate in a forthcoming training camp, but if he plays next week, he will be tied to England for the rest of his career. Ameobi made his Under-21 debut in last month's friendly with Spain at St Andrews.

Michael Ball, the Everton defender who made his senior debut against the Spaniards at Villa Park, drops back into the Under-21 squad, while the Leeds striker Alan Smith is missing as he starts a three-match suspension for his sending off in Finland.

The Republic of Ireland coach Mick McCarthy has called Nick Colgan and Keith O'Neill into his squad for the World Cup qualifiers against Cyprus in Nicosia next Saturday and Andorra in Barcelona four days later.

Colgan, the Hibernian goalkeeper who has yet to represent his country at a senior level, replaces Charlton Athletic's Dean Kiely (groin), while Middlesbrough's O'Neill replaces Niall Quinn (back).

Ryan Giggs is almost certainly out of Wales's World Cup trip to Armenia, and could also miss the home fixture against Ukraine four days later. In light of Giggs's battle with a hamstring injury, his manager at Manchester United Sir Alex Ferguson has cast doubt on whether the winger can cope with international football in his current condition.

England U21 squad (v Finland, Oakwell, March 23): Robinson (Leeds), Kirkland (Coventry), Weaver (Man City), Terry (Chelsea), Bramble (Ipswich), Griffin (Newcastle), King (Tottenham), Rigott (Derby), Barry (Aston Villa), Ball (Everton), Bridge (Southampton), Johnson (Derby), Davis (Fulham), Naylor (Wolves), Dunn (Blackburn, capt), Chadwick (Man Utd), Parker (Charlton), Prutton (Nottm Forest), Wilson (Man Utd), Young (Tottenham), Greening (Man Utd), Hargreaves (Bayern Munich).

fields.headline: Lenders with double standards
fields.standfirst: Borrowers are furious at being excluded from better home loan deals. Patrick Collinson and Rupert Jones investigate
fields.trailText: Borrowers are furious at being excluded from better home loan deals. Patrick Collinson and Rupert Jones investigate.
fields.body:
Halifax is facing complaints to the banking ombudsman from customers furious that they are locked into its old 7.5% standard variable mortgage rate, rather than its much-trumpeted new 6.75% rate.

Two years ago Chris Wright of Henley-on-Thames took out a £106,000 loan with Halifax capped at no more than 7.25% until 2003 and tracking rates down if they fell. So when Halifax issued its new standard rate of 6.75%, he naturally assumed that his mortgage would fall to 6.75%.

Not so. When he rang his local branch they told him he was tied to the old standard variable rate until 2004. If he wanted to exit, the cost would be 4% of his loan, or £4,240.

Mr Wright runs a drums and percussion retailing business and says he would never treat loyal customers in such a way. "I've been with Halifax for 30 years and never missed a payment, but they won't see me for dust once the penalty period expires. I can't understand an organisation that treats its best customers in such a shabby way."

He is also suspicious about how Halifax will treat its "old" standard variable rate. "Having invented two SVRs, they can now with impunity ignore market forces and keep the old SVR high." He says he has obtained a "deadlock" letter from Halifax and will be taking his case to the banking ombudsman.

Mr Wright is not alone; this week several readers contacted Jobs & Money angry at being tied to old SVRs at Halifax, Nationwide and Abbey National.

David Heyes, of Londonderry, says: "My Halifax mortgage is on the 'standard variable rate' according to my documents. When I asked to be transferred to this rate I received the immortal response, 'We have two standard variable rates and you are on the higher one'. Eventually they agreed to transfer my mortgage to the lower rate. Has anyone considered a legal challenge since nowhere in my documentation is there any reference to anything other than the 'standard variable rate'?"

Emily Watnick, a charity fund manager from Carshalton in Surrey, adds: "My husband and I took out a two-year discounted rate mortgage in 1996, with a further three-year 'overhang' penalty period during which the discount would have to be repaid if we redeemed the loan. I was very surprised to learn that taking up the Halifax's new 'standard' rate would count as redemption of the loan, and would incur a penalty, in our case of over £9,000. Needless to say, I did not take the application any further, and of course will be moving our mortgage from the Halifax at the earliest opportunity in three months' time."

Halifax's response is that its rate cut has benefited most of its customers, giving them savings of £200m, and that most borrowers on special deals are already on rates below 6.75%. It also insists that it is being more generous than Nationwide or Abbey National for borrowers in the "overhang" lock-in period after the fix or discount has run out. It says it will "port" any borrower in an overhang period to the 6.75% rate free of charge, and that the penalty will only apply if they switch lenders. So at branch level are customers such as Ms Watnick being wrongly informed? "This should have been explained to her when she contacted her branch," says a spokeswoman.

To clear up the confusion, Halifax this week promised Jobs & Money that it will mail all customers who are in an extended repayment period to emphasise that they can take advantage of the lower base rate and daily interest immediately.

Other lenders have also faced flak over old SVRs. Nationwide introduced a new 6.49% "base mortgage rate", while Abbey brought in two new rates, one at 6.65% and the other at 6.75%. However, both lenders say that borrowers on discount loans will continue to be linked to the old SVR - 6.99% in the case of Nationwide and 7.49% in the case of Abbey - until the discount ends. Nationwide says it has 300,000 people on such deals, and 125,000 locked in to the old SVR after being on such a deal. However, it denies that it is not playing fair.

Abbey National has 1.3m borrowers on special deals, with an unspecified number in the overhang period. A spokeswoman says: "They have taken that deal out during a certain period of time and chances are that the deal they have got now would not even exist on the new rate. You can't have it both ways."

Do you feel you are unfairly locked into an "old'" standard variable rate? Contact us at jobs.and.money@theguardian.com

webTitle: Pensions firm National Mutual has announced windfall details.

fields.headline: Bastion reveals possible payout to members
fields.standfirst: Pensions firm National Mutual has announced windfall details. Rupert Jones reports
fields.trailText: Pensions firm National Mutual has announced windfall details. Rupert Jones reports.
fields.body:
More details emerged this week about the windfalls that could be on the way for members of National Mutual, the 105-year-old pensions company whose past policyholders included Queen Victoria and Winston Churchill.

National Mutual is one of the last bastions of mutuality in the insurance world but looks set to ditch its member-owned status after announcing it is putting itself up for sale.

The company has 250,000 policyholders, 150,000 of whom hold with-profits policies, and the company made clear that only this latter group would receive windfalls. As to how much they will get, some observers have claimed payouts could average £3,000-plus.

National Mutual announced eight days ago that it is talking to potential buyers as part of a review of its mutual status. Since then it has been claimed that Liverpool Victoria, Britain's biggest friendly society, is preparing to launch a £500m bid for the company, which concentrates on specialist pension products such as self-invested personal pensions (Sipps).

Dividing £500m between 150,000 with-profits policyholders would suggest average windfalls of around £3,300 each. However, this is all speculation at the moment, and National Mutual is stressing that a takeover is by no means a certainty. Even if it does happen, it's possible the insurer will distribute the bulk of the windfall money in the form of extra bonuses added to people's policies. That is what is happening at Scottish Life, the insurer being acquired by Royal London.

Gavin Hill, National Mutual's managing director, says it is too early to talk about windfalls but adds it is "highly improbable" that any money would go to people who don't hold with-profits policies. Each mutual insurer has different rules and in National Mutual's case only with-profits policyholders are members.

In the event of the company being bought, the with-profits people will probably get a payout (either cash or extra bonuses) based on the type of policy, its size and for how long it has been held . In addition they may also get a fixed cash payment of perhaps a few hundred pounds as compensation for the loss of their voting rights.

Some of the with-profits policyholders such as those holding FSAVC (free-standing additional voluntary con tribution) top-up pension plans and Sipps are not members, but would still get payouts. In the case of these people, it is the trustee of the pension scheme who is actually the member, but National Mutual says it intends to treat FSAVC and Sipp policyholders who are invested in the with-profits fund as if they were in fact members. However, they will not be entitled to vote on any resolution put to members.

In the case of National Mutual with-profits endowment policies that have been sold on the second-hand market to investors, the original policyholder remains the member.

National Mutual says it will announce the outcome of its review in a few months' time. Members will have to vote on any deal that is proposed, and to go ahead it will require the support of at least 75% of those people voting.

Policies issued after March 9 will not be eligible for any windfalls.

Anyone with a with-profits policy would be strongly advised not to do anything which might jeopardise their entitlement to a windfall. If you have any queries call the helpline: 0845 718 1716.

webTitle: Put money on hi-tech to win? All is not lost

fields.headline: Put money on hi-tech to win? All is not lost
fields.standfirst: As the value of technology shares continues to tumble, investors should not panic but look to the long-term, says Liz Stuart
fields.trailText: As the value of technology shares continues to tumble, investors should not panic but look to the long-term, says Liz Stuart.
fields.body:
This time last year, investors, not wanting to peer too closely into a gift horse's mouth, were clamouring to feed money into the flotation of Lastminute.com. This week the same investors are feeling very silly indeed, as they have watched its share price, which hit an all-time high of 555p, plunge by around £5.

But sadly, lastminute.com investors are not alone: the story could be told about almost any technology stock in either the UK or the US markets. Even more prudent sorts, who chose to hedge their bets and invest in the technology sector via a collective vehicle, are finding the going little better. The thoroughbreds of last year's Isa season, Henderson Global Technology, SocGen Technology, Aberdeen Asset Management Technology, Jupiter Global Technology, Framlington, NetNet and Gartmore Technology Tornado funds have fallen by an average of 60%, with the Framlington fund tumbling furthest - by 74.7%. Most of the £2.8bn in these trusts came from private individuals - retail money - rather than big institutions.

So what should these people, many of whom were younger investors and recent converts to the stock market, but were excited about technology because they use it in their everyday lives, do with their falling assets? Has the horse already bolted, leaving only the door to shut?

NetNet fund manager Chris Bell admits that things have been difficult. "It's been an interesting year - 2000 started with a lot of optimism about technology investments and ended with complete pessimism. Hundreds of companies were chasing a market that did not really exist and were spending millions on advertising."

Most investment experts agree, but this is not particularly helpful to the consumer. Amanda Davidson, director of advisers Holden Meehan, says: "It's such a shame that just as people were starting to get their confidence in the market it bombs. I really feel for people who have lost two-thirds of their money. But the message is, do not panic. When you invest in these volatile areas, you must have the faith to stay there, and people may find that they have to stay for longer than the original five years before they see profits. It could be a matter of waiting 10 years."

She draws a parallel between this situation and clients who put money into the Far East. "I have clients who went into Asian funds in 1993-5 whose investments have reached their original levels and are now making profits, but people who went in in the last two or three years are still having to wait."

Jason Hollands, from Best Invest, says that investments are for the long term, and as the fundamentals - the whole investment story from product to management to market - are still good, if you already hold tech funds you should definitely hold on to them.

Clive Holbrook, of independent financial adviser Hallmark, agrees. "If you are in there, if you have taken the decision to go in, then you've got to be prepared to ride the ups and downs of that particular storm. If you are really not comfortable being there, you could come out of the market. It's all down to the individual."

But if you do decide to sell now, you will have lost a lot of money. Ms Davidson suggests that nervous people wait until their investments have reached their original level and then pull out, although she adds: "If you are investing through an Isa, you should remember not to cash it in, but to transfer it, otherwise you lose the tax benefits."

Although the market may still have further to fall, if you do ride the storm, it is likely to go up again.

Paradoxically, now may be a good time to invest in tech stocks if you do not already do so. "The art of successful investment is to buy when things are out of fashion, rather then when they have been ramped up.

"There is evidence that there is likely to be a series of interest rate and tax cuts in the US by Bush, and sectors such as technology benefit from this because as rates come down, it makes their borrowing less costly, and they tend to be companies with high borrowing.

"I can understand that if people have lost money they feel aggrieved, but you should not invest on a one-year only basis, and so you should not sell. If you don't already have any exposure to technology stocks, and you are willing to be bold, if you dip your toes in then you are likely to get handsome returns. Technology companies are still fundamentally good investments, its just about getting them at the right price," says Mr Holland.

Holden Meehan is advising its clients that now is a good time to buy the Henderson fund: "We like the fund now they have taken on Scottish Equitable's fund managers or Aberdeen Asset Management." Ms Davidson adds that UK and Europe funds are also now good value for money, "although I would not recommend a tracker".

fields.headline: Equitable raises withdrawal penalty to 15%
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Troubled mutual life assurer Equitable Life shocked investors yesterday by saying that - for the second time in four months - it was raising the penalty charged to customers surrendering policies early.
fields.body:
Troubled mutual life assurer Equitable Life shocked investors yesterday by saying that - for the second time in four months - it was raising the penalty charged to customers surrendering policies early.

With half the fund invested in UK equities, the firm blamed the increase from 10% to 15% on the 9% fall in the FTSE 100 stock index since the company closed to new business at the end of last year. Its previous rise - from 5% - led to an investigation by the office of fair trading.

Chief executive Charles Thomson said in a statement: "We regret the need to increase our financial adjustment but market conditions have forced the decision on us."

The move was criticised by Kean Seager, chairman of the Equitable Policyholders Action Group, as "very sad and very disappointing".

An independent financial adviser in Bristol, Mr Seager said no other company had to his knowledge sought to increase their fees to protect themselves against recent stock market volatility. "It demonstrates how very thin their financial situation is," he said.

The Equitable was forced to shut to new business on December 8 after failing to set aside reserves needed to pay guaranteed income pensions sold up to 40 years ago.

The original surrender fee was increased to 10% from 5% to prevent a stampede of investors plunging the company into an even deeper crisis.

Spokesman Alistair Dunbar said that the surrender rate of policies was running at about £50m a week in January, four times the normal level.

But since then, the Halifax announced its takeover of the bulk of the business for £1bn and the outflow had slowed to £25m a week.

Mr Dunbar said with-profits policies which ran their full-term were smoothed to iron out fluctuations in their value but this was not possible with those that were surrendered early without damaging the interests of remaining investors.

He said it was "obviously reasonable" to increase charges to protect them. "If one does not make the adjustment they are taking more than the underlying value of the policy and that obviously is detrimental to those who remain in the fund," he said.

A spokeswoman for the OFT said there was concern about the contractual ability of funds to increase penalties at will, however.

fields.headline: Steinbeck's circus at the Tramway
fields.standfirst:
Burning Bright
Tramway, Glasgow
***
fields.trailText:
Burning Bright
Tramway, Glasgow
***
fields.body:
Like his better known work, Of Mice and Men, Burning Bright was written in novella and play form by John Steinbeck. First performed on Broadway in 1950, it has only rarely been seen since, sometimes as an opera, a form which would suit its heightened drama and symbolism well.

V.amp, a new theatre company led by the actress Alison Peebles, takes this drama as its first show. It isn't a subtle play: four archetypal characters spin into heavily plotted misery. A woman, Mordeen, takes a lover to get pregnant knowing her husband, Joe Saul, to be sterile but desperate to continue his family line. The lover she chooses, Victor, is known as a philanderer. When she falls pregnant, Victor is transformed and in love; Joe Saul gets a medical and realises the child cannot be his. Only his friend, Ed, can resolve matters.

It is not a great play. Joe Saul and Victor, as diametrically opposed versions of manhood, never seem real. The writing is not satisfying and does not suspend disbelief; when Joe Saul nips off to the doctor for a routine check-up and comes back knowing he is infertile, you do wonder how.

What lifts the play is Gabriel Quigley's performance as Mordeen, its most convincing character: the woman who loves her husband so much she betrays him and we will forgive her. She had an abortion five years ago, and so has her own quest to bring a new life into the world, as well as trying to keep her marriage.

V.amp also go to town on the staging of the play, creating a thrilling visual spectacle. Steinbeck sets the three acts in a circus, a dusty old farm and then on board a ship. The latter is superbly realised, with two unwelcoming decks cranked into place during the interval, and in each setting there is some impressive attention to detail. When we are backstage at the circus, the crowd noise is so convincingly done you think there really is another audience outside; same with the farm setting, and the cries of wild animals.

Throughout, the circus theme is kept alive, with trapeze artists slithering in and out of the action, mirroring emotions and amplifying the symbolism. They represent the life almost bludgeoned out of these unlucky characters, and the small moves they make to claw something back.

 Until March 24. Box office: 0141-287 3900.

webTitle: Ailing giant rings the changes to survive

fields.headline: Ailing giant rings the changes to survive
fields.standfirst: Now little more than a bit player in the world markets, BT is preparing a rights issue to generate £5bn, writes Patrick Collinson
fields.trailText: Now little more than a bit player in the world markets, BT is preparing a rights issue to generate £5bn, writes Patrick Collinson
fields.body:
Massive debts, a tumbling share price, calls for the resignation of the chief executive; BT today is a far cry from when it was hailed as the first and most successful privatisation of the Thatcher era.

Two million small shareholders enjoyed a bonanza on December 3, 1984 when the price of BT stock nearly doubled on the first day of trading. Sixteen years later there are still 1.3m small investors with BT shares, but the bonanza may be about to go into reverse.

This week BT signalled that it is preparing the City for a record-breaking £5bn cash call to shore up its finances - which one big stockbroker estimates will mean small shareholders being asked to stump up £500-£750 each in a "rights issue" .

Someone who bought the standard allocation of BT shares at all three privatisation "tranches" in 1984, 1991 and 1993 and still holds them today is sitting on a tidy profit - they would have cost £1,800 and be worth £3,090 today, according to figures from Barclays Stockbrokers. But they would have been worth £9,000 a year ago, and anybody who has bought BT shares over the past three years and holds them now has probably lost money.

The BT share price edged ahead steadily from 1984 to 1997, but then soared as the stockmarket became transfixed by the potential profits from the mobile phone boom.

At its peak in late 1999 the stock briefly hit £15, but following this week's dramatic falls on the stock market was trading at around 515p. Its shares have been savaged by investors who wonder if the billions it paid for third-generation mobile phone licences will ever pay off.

BT has accumulated a £30bn debt mountain - equal to three-quarters of its stock market valuation - and had hoped to pay some of it back by selling off parts of the business. But the prices it could fetch - if it can find a buyer - are much lower than first predicted because of the sharp stock market downturn of recent months.

"It's pig-stuck with debt and has been slow to react to change. It still gets most of its income from land-lines, which everybody else is trying to get out of," says Justin Urquhart Stewart of Barclays Stockbrokers.

"They have got the choice of floating or selling off parts of the business, or going for a rights issue. Either the chairman, Sir Peter Vallance, or the chief executive, Sir Peter Bonfield, will have to fall on their swords," he says.

BT, once regarded as a potential global giant, is now regarded as a bit player on the world stage and has fallen far behind Vodafone in British investors' affections. "There's no question of BT going bust, but will it exist in its current form in five years' time? It may be that it just becomes the junior partner of another international operation," says Mr Urquhart Stewart.

So what should small shareholders do now? Sell out, hold on, or even buy more?

Nomura, for example, has issued a "sell" note, which is based on a forecast that BT's profits will slide from the £3.1bn it reported for 2000 to £2bn in 2001 and only £459m in 2002. It issued its recommendation in November last year, well before the current market slide, and can boast that it got it right more than the other brokers listed.

The consensus of market estimates for BT's profits in the next two years is extremely negative; no one expects BT to match last year's profits, with the average of forecasts seeing a slide of one-third to £2,063m. The average forecast for 2002 is even gloomier; profits at BT will dip to £1,475m, 60% below the £3.6bn it rang up at its peak in 1997. But there are optimists. Deutsche Bank issued a "strong buy" recommendation on BT shares last month, confident that newly appointed finance director Philip Hampton has a firm grip on the business. Mr Hampton is widely tipped as the likely successor to Sir Peter Bonfield if he is forced out of the chief executive role at BT.

"Philip Hampton made a very encouraging debut at the results presentation demonstrating, in our opinion, a sound financial and operational grasp of the business. The level of disclosure and coherence of delivery improved markedly from what we have become accustomed to in the recent past," says Deutsche Bank.

However, Deutsche Bank admits that there are several factors which are making it difficult to be too upbeat about BT. "Whilst we retain our current rating, we acknowledge that in the current climate the sceptics hold the upper hand."

Deutsche says it is concerned about a steep fall in profitability at Concert, BT's international call joint venture with American telecoms giant AT&T. Concert profits dropped from £60m in the first quarter to £46m in the second quarter and then dived to just £2m in the third quarter.

BT is an internationally held stock, so the views of Wall Street investors are as important as UK investment banks. Here there is a glimmer of hope; according to multex.com, a website which carries recommendations from the big Wall Street banks, the consensus view in New York is that BT is "buy/hold".

'Biggest cash call in trading history'

If British Telecom decides to go ahead with a £5bn rights issue, it will be the biggest cash call upon shareholders in stock market history - and mean that millions of small investors will be asked to send cheques to BT.

Rights issues are used by stock market-quoted firms to raise money by issuing new shares and giving the shareholder the "right" to take them up. New shares are offered in proportion to existing holdings; for example, a "1 for 3" rights issue means the shareholder is offered one new share for every three held.

But you have to pay for these rights; the price of the shares is fixed, usually at a small discount to the current share price. But in BT's case, the market expects the rights issue to be heavily discounted - for example, the new shares may possibly be issued at 400-450p compared to the current 515/520p share price. If someone has 600 BT shares (the standard allocation at its three-stage privatisation), and the rights are "1 for 3", the cost of taking up the rights would be around £800.

There is no obligation on small investors - BT has 1.3m shareholders who own parcels of 800 shares or less - to take up the rights, but if they are ignored, then the result is "dilution". Rights issues result in an increase in the total amount of shares in BT, which in turn means that when it comes to dividends, the payment is spread over many more shares, or in effect "diluted". Shares not taken up by existing shareholders are sold on the open market by investment banks which underwrite a rights issue.

webTitle: My Fair Lady, National Theatre, London

fields.headline: My Fair Lady
fields.standfirst:
National Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
National Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
Shaw passionately championed a National Theatre. Even he, however, might have been astonished at the thought that it would one day present a musical version of Pygmalion in tandem with a commercial management. Undeniably it is well done; whether it is the blazing masterpiece Trevor Nunn claims is another matter.

In fact, the first half of the evening is shamelessly enjoyable. Alan Jay Lerner's book sticks close to Shaw's play, Frederick Loewe's music has an operetta-like charm and the performance is full of unbridled vivacity. Martine McCutcheon's Eliza has a fine, hands-on-hips cockney truculence and she negotiates the numbers well. Jonathan Pryce's Higgins also possesses the right mix of academic arrogance and boyish petulance and there is a striking Pickering from Nicholas Le Prevost, who turns him into a dandified clubman.

Best of all is Matthew Bourne's inventive staging of the big numbers. With a Little Bit of Luck becomes a tipsy cockney bacchanal, led by Dennis Waterman's ebullient Doolittle, that starts in a smoky pub and ends on the street outside with dustbin lids attached to the dancers' feet. Anthony Ward's skeletal set also provides space for the Ascot gavotte which, although improbably staged in black to mark a royal death, gives Bourne his head: top-hatted dancers turn into high-stepping horses while the ladies twirl funereal parasols.

But, after the interval, doubts come in about the show. The miracle of Shaw's Pygmalion is that it shows not just how a duchess is made out of a flower girl but how a woman is made out of a duchess: the final act in which a growingly independent Eliza and an irritatedly tenacious Higgins confront each other is a Strindbergian battle of wills. But the musical, with a sentimentality that would make a rhinoceros vomit, shows Eliza tamely returning to Wimpole Street; and, even if she does not actually fetch Higgins's slippers, there is an implied sexual future between the two of them that is grotesquely improbable.

Even the performance loses tension. McCutcheon, excellent as the cockney flower girl and the defiant pupil, lacks the emotional and vocal guns to carry off the confrontation with Higgins in his mother's conservatory - she is less the "consort battleship" Higgins describes than a trim frigate. And, though Pryce maintains baffled impatience, the final scenes have none of the embattled ecstasy when Alec McCowen and Diana Rigg confronted each other in Pygmalion.

Nunn directs the show well and marshals his forces with great skill. But his argument that "My Fair Lady supersedes Pygmalion dramatically" does display an unwontedly tin ear. The musical is pleasant, vivacious and tuneful and will both please many and profit a few but in the end it is a soft-centred betrayal of Shaw.

 Until June 30. Box office: 020-7452 3000.
fields.bodyText: Shaw passionately championed a National Theatre. Even he, however, might have been astonished at the thought that it would one day present a musical version of Pygmalion in tandem with a commercial management. Undeniably it is well done; whether it is the blazing masterpiece Trevor Nunn claims is another matter. In fact, the first half of the evening is shamelessly enjoyable. Alan Jay Lerner's book sticks close to Shaw's play, Frederick Loewe's music has an operetta-like charm and the performance is full of unbridled vivacity. Martine McCutcheon's Eliza has a fine, hands-on-hips cockney truculence and she negotiates the numbers well. Jonathan Pryce's Higgins also possesses the right mix of academic arrogance and boyish petulance and there is a striking Pickering from Nicholas Le Prevost, who turns him into a dandified clubman. Best of all is Matthew Bourne's inventive staging of the big numbers. With a Little Bit of Luck becomes a tipsy cockney bacchanal, led by Dennis Waterman's ebullient Doolittle, that starts in a smoky pub and ends on the street outside with dustbin lids attached to the dancers' feet. Anthony Ward's skeletal set also provides space for the Ascot gavotte which, although improbably staged in black to mark a royal death, gives Bourne his head: top-hatted dancers turn into high-stepping horses while the ladies twirl funereal parasols. But, after the interval, doubts come in about the show. The miracle of Shaw's Pygmalion is that it shows not just how a duchess is made out of a flower girl but how a woman is made out of a duchess: the final act in which a growingly independent Eliza and an irritatedly tenacious Higgins confront each other is a Strindbergian battle of wills. But the musical, with a sentimentality that would make a rhinoceros vomit, shows Eliza tamely returning to Wimpole Street; and, even if she does not actually fetch Higgins's slippers, there is an implied sexual future between the two of them that is grotesquely improbable. webTitle: Risk and return: Beware dodgy dealers posting rumours

fields.headline: Beware dodgy dealers posting rumours
fields.standfirst: It's wise to be wary of scams devised to make money out of novice investors, as Rupert Jones reports
fields.trailText: It's wise to be wary of scams devised to make money out of novice investors, as Rupert Jones reports.
fields.body:
Thousands of investors regularly log on to online bulletin boards to swap share tips and offer their often forthright opinions about companies and stock market issues.

They have been particularly popular with tech-stock investors but financial watchdogs are concerned that while they can provide useful help and advice, they can also be used to perpetrate misinformation, malicious gossip and fraud. One of the best-known scams is share price "ramping" - buying shares at a low price, then putting out rumours on bulletin boards to raise the price.

This week online financial information provider StockHouse issued advice to help investors spot dodgy bulletin board messages. StockHouse (www.stockhouse.co.uk) reckons that despite the current market turbulence and the problems that have beset the technology sector, the use of online boards "is set to soar in the UK". But it adds: "There is an increased risk novice investors will be deceived by unscrupulous posters [people who put messages on the boards]."

It advises investors to watch out for people who keep banging on about te merits of a single company. It adds they may well post between eight and 20 messages daily, sometimes more, and will probably keep doing this until they have sold their shares or until they have fulfilled their obligation to the company that employed them to talk up the stock.

Most people using bulletin boards seem to adopt bizarre monikers and some of the scamsters will use multiple identities, which makes them hard to detect. Generally the poster will run with one identity until he has become despised on the message boards - then he/she will switch to a new identity. "If one carefully studies such an individual, it will be found that he/she posts repeatedly about the same set of stocks or just one stock," says StockHouse. "The poster will post during the same time each day or night. His messages will usually be the same length. His writing style will be similar, using the same phrases or key words."

In particular, look out for people who hype a share and then suddenly change their mind and begin attacking the company. It may be that he or she has a "short" position in the stock - which means they have sold shares they don't actually own, hoping to buy them cheaply later when the price has fallen as a result of the negative publicity. Meanwhile, someone who goes out of their way to continually spread bad news about a company might be a disgruntled ex-employee.

fields.headline: How to keep your shirt on
fields.standfirst: Patrick Collinson and Tony Levene assess what action you can take to protect your finances from market meltdown
fields.trailText: Patrick Collinson and Tony Levene assess what action you can take to protect your finances from market meltdown..
fields.body:
Feverish speculation about bank collapses in Japan plus a string of profit warnings from US companies sent world stockmarkets into a tailspin this week. But it is not just pin-striped City traders who are losing their shirts; millions of small savers with Isas and pensions will be hurt by the global market panic.

What is the impact on your finances, and what action should you be taking? We consult the investment experts.

Isas and unit trusts

Last year's favourite Isa choice - technology funds - turned out to be disastrous, turning a £7,000 Isa investment in March last year to £3,500 or less this year. "WWWin with Jupiter's new global technology fund" gushed one advert last March. The fund has since fallen by 56%. "Get plugged in. Plus 106% in nine months," proclaimed Framlington for its NetNet fund. It's down by a whopping 75%, cutting a £7,000 investment to less than £1,700 in just 12 months.

"We believe pessimism is overdone and frankly the best thing to do is just hang on," said a Framlington spokesman.

Former Henderson technology guru Brian Ashford Russell, who quit to set up a specialist technology company, Polar Capital, said this week: "Sentiment in the market is appalling out there. Just as this time last year newsflow was about as good as it could possibly get, now the newsflow is about as bad as it can get. We're sorry we haven't protected investors better from this downturn." But he is confident that the Nasdaq technology index has fundamental support at the 1700-1800 level, not far below the 1950-2000 level it was trading at this week.

It is not just technology fund Isa investors who are suffering. The average UK fund, largely invested in FTSE100 stocks, is down 8.3% over the past year, while European funds are showing an average loss of 15.6%.

Investment advisers were this week pleading with the public not to put off buying an Isa ahead of the April 5 deadline, warning that they will lose forever the tax-free £7,000 allowance offered by an Isa. Jason Hollands, deputy managing director of Bestinvest, said: "It is quite clear that a great many investors are ignoring their 2000/1 Isa allowances ... but Isas aren't one-year investments and history suggests that buying into weak markets with the indices at low levels is attractive. Investors should be bold and use their Isa allowances."

The Pep and Isa Managers Association recommends that nervous investors should take out a self-select Isa, in which the investor can hold £7,000 in cash for a couple of months before committing it to shares. Alternatively, investors can 'drip-feed' their money through a monthly savings plan.

With-profit bonds

With profits bonds have been big sellers - £25bn over the past two years. But while the value of a unit cannot fall, the cash-in worth of a policy can slip - thanks to the market value adjuster (MVA). But there are no clear rules for the MVA - it is an arbitrary decision by actuaries.

"We call it a market value reduction to reflect what it is," says Norwich Union actuary John Lister. "We are not applying it at the moment and we shall tell policyholders who want to cash in should we do so." NU policyholders have seen annual bonuses falling - from 5.75% in 2000 to 5.25% this year in line with share prices.

Any MVA will be based on the severity of a bear market and reduced for long term holders. But many bonds allow MVA-free withdrawals - often on the 10th anniversary of purchase, generally on regular withdrawals (only used by around one in five) and always on death.

Pensions

Stock market falls can be fatal for the retirement ambitions of personal pension holders. Their final pot - and that of employees in money purchase company schemes including additional voluntary contributions - depends on investment performance.

"Those who should really worry are pension buyers retiring this weekend with a very high equity exposure," says Tom McPhail at IFA Torquil Clark in Wolverhampton. "They could have lost 10 to 15% over the past year while annuity rates have basically remained static. They will be worse off. However, most pension funds are conservatively managed with little in the way of high tech or media stocks. "

Few plans are linked 100% to share values - most have other elements such as cash, property or bonds which cushion stock market falls.

Pension investors cannot have their money back, but they can change their risk profile. "It's a customer choice," says Colin Ledlie at Standard Life. "Typically, a holder elects, five years before retirement, to move a fund month by month into a more cautious area - generally bonds to reflect the eventual annuity. Anyone forced to retire now, who did not do this, still has some options - income drawdown which defers the annuity or giving up some annuity income by opting for a with-profits annuity which will gain from any future equity uplifts."

webTitle: Jobs and money: Stop-loss is key for clubs

fields.headline: Stop-loss is key for clubs
fields.trailText: It's the most difficult decision for any novice investor. The share you bought was supposed to fly high; instead it has fallen by 50%: do you cut your losses and sell out, or hang on and hope it will recover one day?
fields.body:
It's the most difficult decision for any novice investor. The share you bought was supposed to fly high; instead it has fallen by 50%: do you cut your losses and sell out, or hang on and hope it will recover one day?

It is a question that will be posed in pubs and meeting rooms across the UK where members of Britain's 10,000 investment clubs gather and discuss their stock selections. Unfortunately, many new investors are psychologically unable to implement 'stop loss' rules used rigorously by big fund managers to control their losses in a falling market.

Stop loss systems are a controlled and planned way to sell shares. It works as follows: assume you buy shares for 100p, you might decided to se up a stop loss of 20%. Therefore you would automatically sell your shares if the share price fell below 80p. Stop loss systems should also be adjusted as the share price moves up. In other words, if the 100p share moves up to 200p, the stop loss would be set at 160p (200p less 20%).

A stop loss system would have allowed investors in boom-and-bust technology stocks to reap the gains and avoid the steep falls. Instead, investors held on and on as their dot.com stocks fell first by 10%, then 50% before joining the '90% club' - the stocks which are trading 90% below their peak. Members of the 90% club include lastminute.com and net auction house QXL.

Mike Dyson, chairman of the Flyboys Club - 16 instructors at the Cabair Flying School in Cranfield, Bed fordshire - wishes the club had implemented a stop loss policy. Instead, it has seen the value of its shares fall by half to £7,250 from £15,000. "We have had a poor stop loss policy. We have made big paper losses on a number of speculative stocks, such as Durlacher, E Capital and Baltimore and should have sold them, even at a loss, long ago. Now we're stuck with them because they've fallen so much they're hardly worth cashing in."

Three years ago there were just 300 investment clubs in Britain, where people meet together monthly to pool their investment knowledge and invest in portfolio of shares. Now there are nearly 10,000, and many are facing declining markets for the first time.

Proshare, the not-for-profit organisation that gives advice on setting up investment clubs, has posted advice on what to do in a falling market on its website at www.proshare.org.uk. Its golden rules are:

Don't panic or sell in haste.

Take a long term view. Stockmarket crashes level out over time, the FTSE All Share index recovered to its pre-1987 crash levels within two years.

Balance your portfolio. Invest in a range of shares across different industrial and commercial sectors, and ensure that blue chip companies in the FTSE100 make up the basis of your portfolio.

Adopt a drip-feed approach. Put a little money into the stockmarket at regular intervals. This means that you will be buying shares at different times and prices, sometimes high and sometimes low, but you will pay a price close to the middle, and avoid investing a lump sum at the top of the market.
