fields.headline: Happily ever after
fields.standfirst: For these men retirement hold no fears of hardsh thanks to their hugely enhanced pensions. but, Phillip Inman reports, it's a different story outside the boardroom, whith those on less rewarding schemes facing a bleak future when they quit work
fields.trailText: For these men retirement hold no fears of hardsh thanks to their hugely enhanced pensions. but, Phillip Inman reports, it's a different story outside the boardroom, whith those on less rewarding schemes facing a bleak future when they quit work.
fields.body:
Fears that Britain will be as divided in retirement as it is in work were fuelled this week by a survey that revealed the number of company directors who will be paid a pension of more than half a million pounds has more than trebled.

Last year, seven company directors in the survey could lay claim to a pension worth more than £500,000. A further 35 can rely on a pension package that will bring them more than a £250,000 each year, index linked to the rate of inflation. In 1999 there were only two members of the half a million pound club.

Unilever, the maker of Elizabeth Arden cosmetics and Wall's ice cream, provides one of the seven. Bob Phillips, who managed the cosmetics division, left the company last year. He can look forward to £556,723 in annual pension payments. Drugs giant Glaxo Smithkline is more generous. It is due to give its chief executive Jean-Pierre Garnier a pension of £700,000 and chairman Sir Richard Sykes £551,000.

Yet the survey underestimates the amount of money pouring into boardroom pension schemes and the number of directors who benefit. Only those directors with the largest pension entitlement in each FTSE 100 company are highlighted. Behind them lurk many more.

Unilever is a case in point. Niall Fitzgerald, the company's chairman, is also a member of the exclusive club after amassing a pension of £502,0000 so far.

Most directors of large companies enjoy the security of a pension linked to their final salary, known as a defined benefit scheme. They are guaranteed a proportion of their salary as a pension, which means that the sound of crashing stock markets will not keep them awake at night.

Employees often have more to fear. Final salary schemes are expensive and directors have been ditching them, if not for themselves, but certainly for the staff.

Those companies that have switched from offering final salary schemes to money purchase pensions, which have a defined contribution rather than defined benefit, will have seen their pensions gain little in the past year as stock markets stood still or tumbled.

In the last couple of years GlaxoWellcome, media group Reuters and the banks Alliance & Leicester, Halifax, Barclays and HSBC have all closed their final salary schemes to new staff. Employees joining these firms must pay into a money purchase scheme instead.

If staff are lucky enough to keep their final salary scheme they will be protected from the vagaries of the markets and will enjoy a better pension than anyone who has missed out. But they usually find themselves playing by a different set of pensions rules to directors.

To keep with Inland Revenue rules, companies can offer up to two-thirds of the final salary as pension. Traditionally, workers and directors needed to clock up 40 years out of a nominal 60 in the occupational scheme to get their two-thirds.

This rule can be bent and frequently is. What are called pensionable years can be added to your total in order to reach the 40 years target more quickly. Revenue rules allow directors to add pensionable years at a rate of one for every 30 years rather than 60, halving the time it takes to reach the maximum level. Other complex rules allow pensions to leap at a rate unimaginable for an employee. Clive Thompson, the chief executive of cleaning and business services company Rentokil Initial, had accrued a pension of £406,000 in 1999, according to the company's annual report for that year. By last year, the figure had risen to £502,000. The 23% jump in pension income is not in line with him adding another pensionable year to his tally. Nor is it justified by any increase in the company's profits, which moved up by 10.3%, or the share price. Since January 1999 Rentokil's share price has more than halved from 460p a share to 204p.

Geoff Mulcahy, the boss of B&Q to Superdrug retail business Kingfisher, capitalised on a 15% jump in profits to push his pension entitlement up by 24% from £440,000 to £548,000. Shares in the firm dropped by more than a third in the same period. None of the usual measures seems to account for the huge increases in accrued pension income. Even more interestingly, both companies have just reported drops in profits in the last month, along with further falls in their share prices. The effect on directors' pensions, however, will not be known until the latest annual reports appear next month.

The government believes that forcing companies to become more transparent about the rules around pay and perks packages will embarrass them into dropping ludicrous schemes that cannot be justified by either rises in share prices or profits. Instead of limits on boardroom excess or increased powers to stakeholders like employees, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers said this week there will be new disclosure requirements to take effect from later this year. It is not known if pensions will be mentioned, but experts reckon it is unlikely. Shareholders will be the sole judges of excess, and they concentrate their fire on huge share option schemes rather than soaring pensions.

Rows this week about executive pay are typical. Matt Barratt, chief executive of Barclays, who could receive £36m if the bank meets certain targets, revealed further jumps in his own income. Most critics, however, focused on the cost of share options offered to Mr Barratt, which directly affect shareholders.

So for the moment, the situation is left to drift. Companies are paying their directors enhanced pensions in the good years as part of burgeoning pay and perks packages, while employees in the same scheme rely on clocking up their years of service. In addition, a growing band of employees rely on money purchase schemes.

The latest figures from the government actuary's depart ment for 1995 report that 52% of male employees were members of a final salary occupational pension scheme, down from 64% in the mid-1980s. The proportion of women in final salary schemes increased to 39%, but the rise followed a huge influx of women into the labour market in general.

Unfortunately, the problems for employees in money purchase schemes are not just about how the slow growth of investments can affect pension payouts.

The Association of British Insurers highlights that employers tend to put less money into money purchase schemes. Laurie Edmans, chairman of the association's pensions committee, says employers, on average, will cut their levels of contributions from 15% of salary to 10% after they move from final salary schemes.

Life insurers, while they like becoming the pension manager for a company money purchase scheme, are concerned by the overall drop in cash coming from employers into pensions investments. In effect, their own livelihoods are at risk along with the prospective pensioner if more employers dump final salary schemes.

Jim Cousins, a prominent backbench Labour MP and member of the Treasury select committee, is deeply concerned about the widening gap between pensions paid out to boardroom directors and employees. He is also disturbed by the uncertainty faced by employees who are only given the option of a money purchase scheme.

"We could be looking at the creation of a pension rich and pension poor. I think it is urgent that we look at the ways employees are treated compared to directors."

Mr Cousins says that ministers have failed to see the warning signals that shares can go up as well as down. "I think the government has been extremely naive in respect of the switch from defined benefit schemes to defined contribution. Given the falls in the stock market this week and over the last year, it shows how the payout from defined contribution schemes leaves the employee vulnerable."

He adds: "The government has projected the benefits of defined contribution pensions based on the gains of the last 10 years, which I think is a flawed way to approach an assessment of the next 10 years."

Help the Aged is concerned that the pensions landscape is changing to the detriment of employees. "It could be that the best days of pension policies in the UK are behind us," says Mervyn Kohler, the charity's head of public affairs.

He believes the current crop of employees nearing retirement are the real winners in the pensions battle. "They are doing quite well because many will have final salary pensions and unlike generations before them, the pensions payments have been protected from erosion by inflation. But now it is a pretty scary scenario."

He points to the way pensions are paid for on the con tinent, which involves a large commitment from the employer. "On the continent it is expected that employers must put in a decent whack of money to safeguard the pensions of employees. We seem to be going more in the direction of the US where everyone is left to fend for themselves."

Moderate trade unions such as the electrical and engineering union AEEU say directors should use the same rules as employees when calculating pensions.

The union's general secretary, Sir Ken Jackson, says: "We have never opposed reasonable levels of pay for directors, but there is clearly a problem when one set of principles is used for the board and another for employees."

Mr Barratt, of Barclays, negotiated a separate pension scheme that accelerated his path towards his two-thirds entitlement, says a spokesman for the bank. BP Amoco also admits that directors will earn their pension credits at twice the speed of employees.

According to the survey, conducted annually by Labour Research, early retirement is also governed by a "one rule for you and another for me" policy.

Ian Strachan, the former chairman of automated controls group Invensys, left the company last year at the age of 56. He received £1.5m compensation for cutting short his contract, £53,970 in other benefits and a pension credit of £64,724, taking his annual pension to £331,351. Given the large compensation package, it is not surprising he felt he would defer taking his pension until a later date.

 Additional research by Juliet Shedden.
fields.bodyText: Fears that Britain will be as divided in retirement as it is in work were fuelled this week by a survey that revealed the number of company directors who will be paid a pension of more than half a million pounds has more than trebled. Last year, seven company directors in the survey could lay claim to a pension worth more than £500,000. A further 35 can rely on a pension package that will bring them more than a £250,000 each year, index linked to the rate of inflation. In 1999 there were only two members of the half a million pound club. Unilever, the maker of Elizabeth Arden cosmetics and Wall's ice cream, provides one of the seven. Bob Phillips, who managed the cosmetics division, left the company last year. He can look forward to £556,723 in annual pension payments. Drugs giant Glaxo Smithkline is more generous. It is due to give its chief executive Jean-Pierre Garnier a pension of £700,000 and chairman Sir Richard Sykes £551,000. Yet the survey underestimates the amount of money pouring into boardroom pension schemes and the number of directors who benefit. Only those directors with the largest pension entitlement in each FTSE 100 company are highlighted. Behind them lurk many more. Unilever is a case in point. Niall Fitzgerald, the company's chairman, is also a member of the exclusive club after amassing a pension of £502,0000 so far. Most directors of large companies enjoy the security of a pension linked to their final salary, known as a defined benefit scheme. They are guaranteed a proportion of their salary as a pension, which means that the sound of crashing stock markets will not keep them awake at night. Employees often have more to fear. Final salary schemes are expensive and directors have been ditching them, if not for themselves, but certainly for the staff. Those companies that have switched from offering final salary schemes to money purchase pensions, which have a defined contribution rather than defined benefit, will have seen their pensions gain little in the past year as stock markets stood still or tumbled. In the last couple of years GlaxoWellcome, media group Reuters and the banks Alliance & Leicester, Halifax, Barclays and HSBC have all closed their final salary schemes to new staff. Employees joining these firms must pay into a money purchase scheme instead. If staff are lucky enough to keep their final salary scheme they will be protected from the vagaries of the markets and will enjoy a better pension than anyone who has missed out. But they usually find themselves playing by a different set of pensions rules to directors. To keep with Inland Revenue rules, companies can offer up to two-thirds of the final salary as pension. Traditionally, workers and directors needed to clock up 40 years out of a nominal 60 in the occupational scheme to get their two-thirds. This rule can be bent and frequently is. What are called pensionable years can be added to your total in order to reach the 40 years target more quickly. Revenue rules allow directors to add pensionable years at a rate of one for every 30 years rather than 60, halving the time it takes to reach the maximum level. Other complex rules allow pensions to leap at a rate unimaginable for an employee. Clive Thompson, the chief executive of cleaning and business services company Rentokil Initial, had accrued a pension of £406,000 in 1999, according to the company's annual report for that year. By last year, the figure had risen to £502,000. The 23% jump in pension income is not in line with him adding another pensionable year to his tally. Nor is it justified by any increase in the company's profits, which moved up by 10.3%, or the share price. Since January 1999 Rentokil's share price has more than halved from 460p a share to 204p. Geoff Mulcahy, the boss of B&Q to Superdrug retail business Kingfisher, capitalised on a 15% jump in profits to push his pension entitlement up by 24% from £440,000 to £548,000. Shares in the firm dropped by more than a third in the same period. None of the usual measures seems to account for the huge increases in accrued pension income. Even more interestingly, both companies have just reported drops in profits in the last month, along with further falls in their share prices. The effect on directors' pensions, however, will not be known until the latest annual reports appear next month. The government believes that forcing companies to become more transparent about the rules around pay and perks packages will embarrass them into dropping ludicrous schemes that cannot be justified by either rises in share prices or profits. Instead of limits on boardroom excess or increased powers to stakeholders like employees, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers said this week there will be new disclosure requirements to take effect from later this year. It is not known if pensions will be mentioned, but experts reckon it is unlikely. Shareholders will be the sole judges of excess, and they concentrate their fire on huge share option schemes rather than soaring pensions. Rows this week about executive pay are typical. Matt Barratt, chief executive of Barclays, who could receive £36m if the bank meets certain targets, revealed further jumps in his own income. Most critics, however, focused on the cost of share options offered to Mr Barratt, which directly affect shareholders. So for the moment, the situation is left to drift. Companies are paying their directors enhanced pensions in the good years as part of burgeoning pay and perks packages, while employees in the same scheme rely on clocking up their years of service. In addition, a growing band of employees rely on money purchase schemes. The latest figures from the government actuary's depart ment for 1995 report that 52% of male employees were members of a final salary occupational pension scheme, down from 64% in the mid-1980s. The proportion of women in final salary schemes increased to 39%, but the rise followed a huge influx of women into the labour market in general. Unfortunately, the problems for employees in money purchase schemes are not just about how the slow growth of investments can affect pension payouts. The Association of British Insurers highlights that employers tend to put less money into money purchase schemes. Laurie Edmans, chairman of the association's pensions committee, says employers, on average, will cut their levels of contributions from 15% of salary to 10% after they move from final salary schemes. Life insurers, while they like becoming the pension manager for a company money purchase scheme, are concerned by the overall drop in cash coming from employers into pensions investments. In effect, their own livelihoods are at risk along with the prospective pensioner if more employers dump final salary schemes. Jim Cousins, a prominent backbench Labour MP and member of the Treasury select committee, is deeply concerned about the widening gap between pensions paid out to boardroom directors and employees. He is also disturbed by the uncertainty faced by employees who are only given the option of a money purchase scheme. "We could be looking at the creation of a pension rich and pension poor. I think it is urgent that we look at the ways employees are treated compared to directors." Mr Cousins says that ministers have failed to see the warning signals that shares can go up as well as down. "I think the government has been extremely naive in respect of the switch from defined benefit schemes to defined contribution. Given the falls in the stock market this week and over the last year, it shows how the payout from defined contribution schemes leaves the employee vulnerable." He adds: "The government has projected the benefits of defined contribution pensions based on the gains of the last 10 years, which I think is a flawed way to approach an assessment of the next 10 years." Help the Aged is concerned that the pensions landscape is changing to the detriment of employees. "It could be that the best days of pension policies in the UK are behind us," says Mervyn Kohler, the charity's head of public affairs. He believes the current crop of employees nearing retirement are the real winners in the pensions battle. "They are doing quite well because many will have final salary pensions and unlike generations before them, the pensions payments have been protected from erosion by inflation. But now it is a pretty scary scenario." He points to the way pensions are paid for on the con tinent, which involves a large commitment from the employer. "On the continent it is expected that employers must put in a decent whack of money to safeguard the pensions of employees. We seem to be going more in the direction of the US where everyone is left to fend for themselves." Moderate trade unions such as the electrical and engineering union AEEU say directors should use the same rules as employees when calculating pensions. The union's general secretary, Sir Ken Jackson, says: "We have never opposed reasonable levels of pay for directors, but there is clearly a problem when one set of principles is used for the board and another for employees." Mr Barratt, of Barclays, negotiated a separate pension scheme that accelerated his path towards his two-thirds entitlement, says a spokesman for the bank. BP Amoco also admits that directors will earn their pension credits at twice the speed of employees. According to the survey, conducted annually by Labour Research, early retirement is also governed by a "one rule for you and another for me" policy. Ian Strachan, the former chairman of automated controls group Invensys, left the company last year at the age of 56. He received £1.5m compensation for cutting short his contract, £53,970 in other benefits and a pension credit of £64,724, taking his annual pension to £331,351. Given the large compensation package, it is not surprising he felt he would defer taking his pension until a later date.  Additional research by Juliet Shedden.

fields.headline: Philharmonia/Svetlanov
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall, London/Radio 3
****
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall, London/Radio 3
****
fields.body:
Now 71, Yevgeny Svetlanov is the doyen of conductors in Russia. He took charge of the USSR State Symphony Orchestra in 1965, and has been with the orchestra (now the Russian State Symphony) ever since; over that period he has regularly visited London. Though it is claimed he has recorded more of the Russian orchestral repertory than anyone else, his sympathies range far wider: he once conducted Elgar's The Dream of Gerontius, of all things, in the Festival Hall.

So although there was Tchaikovsky in his concert with the Philharmonia, there was Debussy too. The prelude to Tchaikovsky's The Queen of Spades was a reminder that Svetlanov began his professional career at the Bolshoi Theatre in Moscow, and went on to become its chief conductor. The tragic drama of the work was concentrated into its four minutes, with a starkness that prefigured the Pathétique Symphony, written four years later. His minimal platform gestures were enough to encourage the Philharmonia brass to add a distinctly Slavonic openness to their tone, and the woodwind to acquire a mordent edge.

In the same composer's Violin Concerto he created a bold, well-characterised platform for the soloist, Joshua Bell, whose playing was its usual model of unflashy musicianship, wonderfully delicate articulation and infectious enthusiasm for what he is interpreting - every bar was a delight.

In all of that, Svetlanov's total familiarity with the Russian tradition was obvious to hear; in Debussy's Prelude à l'Apres-Midi d'un Faune and La Mer, it was the music's Russian affiliations that came to surface. Though the opening flute solo was kept on too tight a leash with rubato strictly rationed, it was the way the climaxes were shaped, and the sinuous characters of the string lines, almost recalling Rimsky's Sheherazade, that caught the ear. For once La Mer lived up to its subtitle - three symphonic studies - with the midday sun of the first movement depicted in blazing splendour. If the play of colours in the other movements was understated, Svetlanov kept their shape and coherence absolutely intact.

fields.headline: Julian Joseph
fields.standfirst:
Djanogly Recital Hall, Nottingham
****
fields.trailText:
Djanogly Recital Hall, Nottingham
****
fields.body:
People with an aversion to the heavier side of jazz would be distressed by the music of Julian Joseph. The pianist and presenter of Radio 3's Jazz Legends is only occasionally interested in the concept of swing, and he spends most of his time exploring fathomless depths of complexity.

The concert began with an original number called Do Yourself a Favour and Wake Up. Joseph traded deceptively unassuming licks with the guitarist Adam Salkeld, before turning on the heat, bashing out declamatory chords and then weaving them into a bewildering tapestry. Towards the end of the piece, he reiterated the same riff over and over, the grin on his face challenging his colleagues to strive for inventiveness.

A studiously untuneful take on Ellington's Prelude to a Kiss introduced us more comprehensively to Joseph's style, which often veered away from jazz and into classical. His playing was cerebral rather than sensual, full of clusters of dissonant chords and abstruse harmonic explorations that were reminiscent of ponderous Beethoven sonatas.

Another original piece, All the Things You Are, showcased Salkeld, who stirred emotion with an eastern sounding refrain punctuated by sudden bluesy flashes. He then went on to lay the foundations of an expansively melancholy groove that gave everyone space to breathe - for a while.

Throughout the gig, the double bass player Orlando le Fleming exuded a curiously anxious energy. Although his performance was flawless, he appeared to be struggling a bit, beaming with relief each time he emerged from a tricky passage. This was hardly surprising, given the lofty standards set by Joseph, who threw down the gauntlet every half-second with quite unreasonable degrees of virtuosity. During his solo on Faith, he played chords that have probably never been attempted before, then bravely knotted them together into a rhythmically insane fugue.

Unsurprisingly, there was no lollipop offered in the encore; instead we got another billion-note odyssey that went on for 15 minutes, and ensured that the final round of applause was pointedly brief. Ultimately, there is one thing that Joseph doesn't manage to do with his piano, and that is leave you gagging for more.

webTitle: At last, Paul McCartney gets to meet his suffragette

fields.headline: At last, Paul McCartney gets to meet his suffragette
fields.standfirst: Avid collectors will haggle over the price of classic cigarette cards and old postcards this week
fields.trailText: Avid collectors will haggle over the price of classic cigarette cards and old postcards this week
fields.body:
Is nothing sacred? Is there no area of memorabilia which the Beatles have not infiltrated and come to dominate prices? I picked up Phillips auction house's catalogue for its sale of cigarette cards and trade cards (ie postcards) of the world this Thursday, and there it was. The number one item was the Beatles set with an asking price of £130-£150.

Cigarette cards are the little pictures that used to go in a pack of 10 cigarettes produced by G&O Wills, Players and others. They would be a series of sportsmen, soldiers, trains, motorcars and theatrical figures. They were popular before the second world war. They were like an early loyalty card but after the war they were largely discontinued.

Now given that the "Fab Four" from Liverpool were not even in short trousers at that time, let alone famous, what are they doing on little cards? The answer is bubble gum cards superseded cigarette cards. They were put inside bubble-gum packets from the 1950s onwards and lingered on until the 1970s. This Beatles set was made by A & B.C.Gum. They were cheaper versions of the cigarette card for obvious reasons: bumble gum did not cost as much as cigarettes.

Another form of card, which survived the second world war, was the Brooke Bond card, which came with packets of tea. Many of these were for overseas markets, and there are issues of Rhodesian and South African series which had collections of African wildlife on them. The Canadian issues include a set of songbirds of North America.

While the cigarette cards seem to have disappeared from view as smoking is frowned upon, and while the bubble gum cards might be deemed inferior, they are both popular among collectors, as are the Brooke Bond cards. According to David Stuckey, the editor and publisher of Card Times: "Demand for cards is quite strong at the moment." His journal has 3,000 subscribers. They are usually male, in their forties, have some disposable income and want to take a trip down memory lane.

He says that there is always a premium on anything to do with the Beatles, but adds that you would not pay much less for a set of Elvis cards or even a set of Monkees cards.

Individual cards start at around £1 and used to go up to £50 for a set a few years ago. Now a set can easily cost over £100. Not all cards are equally in demand. There is little call for cigarette cards with flowers or recipes. "Anything to do with sport is avidly collected," says Stuckey.

Of the total 442 lots on sale, half are trade cards of the world. The first postcards were introduced in Britain in 1871. Their attraction was not illustration - they were buff coloured - but the price. They cost half a penny to post, while the letter was 1p. By 1890 illustrations were allowed on the cards, and between 1900 and 1918 they enjoyed a golden age.

It is these Edwardian cards, and not as is commonly assumed the saucy seaside ones of Donald McGill (1875 to 1962), which are most sought after. McGill lived a long life and was prolific. Many of his cards can be found for £1-£2.

Brian Asquith, who is a collector himself and consultant at the Phillips sale, explains: "Postcards were easily the cheapest and most popular means of communication, at the time. They cost half a penny. You could buy six cards for 3p. There were six or seven collections a day, so you could send one to your butcher in the morning and have your meat delivered by the evening when you got home. A telegram cost one shilling, which was a lot for the ordinary person."

There was an explosion of all kinds of cards, cards depicting actresses, the countryside and seaside, trains and boats. Asquith says the most popular are topographical, actual photographs of someone with a village background. How much would you pay for these?

"When my wife and I started collecting 20 years ago, you could find individual cards for 10p. Now you would probably start at 50p and can pay upwards of £40 for a card. In some cases you could pay a three-figure sum. One card fetched over £1,000, but that was something from the Titanic. Prices rise steadily year on year."

Although topographical cards are the most popular, there are exceptions. One of the highlights of the Phillips sale is an unusually large collection of 163 postcards relating to the women's movement. Dating from 1892 to 1917, it features a mix of black and white and colour photographs, illustrations and cartoons. Almost all are humorous and depict a mixture of opinions on the suffragette movement. They are to be sold as one lot and are expected to fetch £1,000 to £1,200, and would sit nicely next to a picture of Sir Paul McCartney - the former Beatle who went on to write the hit song Suffragette for Wings.

For further information: Phillips, tel: 020 7629 6602 www.phillips-auctions.com; Card Times, tel: 01695 423470.

webTitle: Slaughter of hi-tech shares rocks City

fields.headline: Slaughter of hi-tech shares rocks City
fields.standfirst: Forget the farming crisis, it is horrors afflicting the newest industries that worry the square mile, says Robin Stoddart
fields.trailText: Forget the farming crisis, it is horrors afflicting the newest industries that worry the square mile, says Robin Stoddart
fields.body:
It was too much to expect that the nightmare scenes extending across the countryside could leave the City immune. Yet it took the announcement of cutbacks in the newest industry to usher in some fraction of the horrors afflicting the oldest. Ironically, the slump in shares coincided with excellent job statistics.

From its ivory howdah in services, the financial world credits "top down" estimates of prosperity above any erosion of the economic base. Farming, fishing and transport disasters can be set aside when modern industries are humming and leisure pursuits proliferating. But as it is recognised that billions are being wiped from the national product by the spate of setbacks, reservations fester. Budgets, from government to households, will need a recount, even if the census and elections can go ahead as planned. Inflation, like employment, is likely to be much less benign before long.

A revival in US output and demand is necessary if the rest of the world, particularly Germany and the UK, the third and fourth-largest economies at present unstable exchange rates, are to prosper. Strength in depth, if not self-sufficiency, will be a test of credit-worthiness and future prospects. And small businesses, rather than the international giants that are no longer so prominent in either of the oldest industrial countries, hold the key to economic growth. In Germany, the experience of new investors has been especially daunting of late, with shares on average down by more than 80% in a year on the Neuer Markt, catering for smaller companies and hi-tech start-ups.

So far the Alternative Investment Market (AIM) has avoided such a bloodbath, though several initially more successful software and technology companies moved to the main market for its greater liquidity. After a slow start the AIM market has now attracted well over 500 companies and, on average, they have raised more than £10m each, though most are much smaller. This week's setback is unlikely to deter new entrants since tax reliefs for new subscribers and taper down in capital gains tax to 10% four years after a market purchase, provides big incentives.

Although such encouragement for venture capitalists is continuing with government publicity and the Myners report favouring more early stage risk investment by pension funds, the pace of subscription for new venture capital trusts (VCTs) has slowed markedly in recent weeks. Nevertheless, funds with a large AIM exposure have usually achieved their target for funds raised, or come within striking distance of it. A wide spread of investments is again seen as attractive. This must also apply to direct investors in AIM shares. One success may easily offset two failures.

Investment in smaller companies was rewarding for most of the past two years and after the shakeout hopes of appreciation while interest rates are low and there is plenty of capital available should be realised. Top performers like AIM Trust and Eaglet have come down from their peaks, the latter only recently after large build-ups of stakes in the leisure and technology hardware sectors paid off initially. Reduced liquidity means that some discount on underlying share values is called for. With wider and smaller holdings, Aberforth investment and unit funds have become leaders over the last year and Baillie Gifford has almost held its own, while unit holders on average have lost a fifth of their money in the sector after a year of wild swings.

Nevertheless, funds with a large AIM exposure have usually achieved their target for funds raised, or come within striking distance of it. A wide spread of investments is again seen as attractive. This must also apply to direct investors in AIM shares. One success may easily offset two failures. Investment in smaller companies was rewarding for most of the past two years and after the shakeout hopes of appreciation while interest rates are low and there is plenty of capital available should be realised. Top performers like AIM Trust and Eaglet have come down from their peaks, the latter only recently after large build-ups of stakes in the leisure and technology hardware sectors paid off initially. Reduced liquidity means that some discount on underlying share values is called for. With wider and smaller holdings, Aberforth investment and unit funds have become leaders over the last year and Baillie Gifford has almost held its own, while unit holders on average have lost a fifth of their money in the sector after a year of wild swings.

fields.headline: Carpetbagger launches latest campaign
fields.standfirst: A full-scale battle over Nationwide building society's future could be just a few months away after carpetbagger Andrew Muir officially launched his conversion campaign this week, writes Rupert Jones
fields.trailText: A full-scale battle over Nationwide building society's future could be just a few months away after carpetbagger Andrew Muir officially launched his conversion campaign this week, writes Rupert Jones.
fields.body:
Mr Muir aims to force Britain's biggest building society to convert to a bank and pay windfalls he claims could average between £700 and £1,000 to its 10m members.

The Berkshire recruitment firm boss has set up a website, nationwidewindfalls.com, to preach his carpetbagging philosophy and is calling on members who support his cause to print out, complete and return the conversion resolution form included on the site.

If his resolution is declared valid, and he can rustle up enough eligible members to back it, a vote will take place early this summer on whether the society should stay member-owned or convert.

Mr Muir, 36, says he wants to ensure that the 2 million members who have signed away their right to a windfall to charity will also be included in the possible multi-billion pound giveaway. On his website Mr Muir, who claims to have 1,500 supporters already, states: "This may be your only chance to claim a windfall that is rightfully yours ... Nationwide is a huge organisation, a bank in all but name, and will convert at some point. It is better to do it now, while the business is doing well, to get maximum value for members."

The issue was last put to the test in 1998 when Nationwide defeated by the slimmest of margins a conversion campaign mounted by the eccentric butler Michael Hardern. The society has been immune from another challenge until now.

There are several hurdles that Mr Muir needs to jump. He needs the backing of 500 members for his conversion resolution, and the backing of 250 for his nomination for election to the board, and he only has a few weeks to achieve this because the deadline is April 5. And it's not just any old members who can back the resolution - they must have either had £100-plus in a Nationwide savings account or have owed at least £100 on a mortgage, in both cases continually for at least two years. Also, the resolution must be judged valid. The society is likely to go through the wording of the resolution and will reject it if it doesn't stand up to legal scrutiny.

Provided Mr Muir - who stood unsuccessfully for election to the society's board three years ago - can overcome all these obstacles, Nationwide has said members will be able to vote on his resolution at the annual general meeting on July 19.

Pro-mutuality campaigners point to Bradford & Bingley, which floated on the stock market in December, as an example of why it is important for claims made about potential windfalls to be taken with a pinch of salt.

Two years ago Stephen Major, the man who led the campaign to force B&B to convert, said windfalls to members would average £2,000. But when B&B floated last December, the handouts of 250 shares each ended up being worth only £610 at the end of the first day's trading.

fields.headline: Getting lost in Province
fields.standfirst:
Province
Mappin Gallery, Sheffield
***
fields.trailText:
Province
Mappin Gallery, Sheffield
***
fields.body:
Bilbao boasts the Guggenheim (drawing thousands of visitors a year) while Sheffield has the National Centre for Popular Music (now closed); so you might think artists in each city would refrain from invidious comparisons.

Bilbo Arte, the exhibition/ studio complex to which this show transfers after its run in Sheffield, is not the Guggenheim, however. This converted school in Bilbao's rundown San Francisco district ranks as a best-avoid rather than a must-see on most tourism packages. With the new Millennium Galleries due to provide Sheffield with a high-profile venue next month, South Yorkshire's artists could be forgiven for sharing their Basque colleagues' sense of frustration.

Province does present a bewildering juxtaposition of bright ideas and urban blight familiar from any aspiring inner-city area. Bold, fun ideas shout out from miserable surroundings. The insistent sound of drilling comes from somewhere. There are no directions. After 20 minutes of wandering around absorbing the sensory assault, you have to admit it: you're lost.

The only map on offer forms part of Josu Rekalde's Lighthouse to Guide a City in Darkness: a street plan of Bilbao built up in relief with twisted knots of waste material. The Guggenheim is marked with a squished silver foil packet from a discarded printer cartridge.

Further obfuscation arrives in the form of an arcane piece of engineering by Augusto Zubiaga, which combines elements of a navigational sextant with a Van der Graff generator. Cranking the handle produces a small electrical charge, which comes as a mild shock. The Basque duo JaYxa, a contraction of the names Javier and Xavier, turn out to be more of a brand than an artistic partnership. Their gymnastic horse and crash mat ensemble is possibly a reference to vaulting ambition.

The Sheffield contributors Dutton, Peacock and Mel Jordan offer some rather more downbeat topographies that suggest Sheffield is 5% industrial horizon and 95% grey sky. Then they hang them upside down, so the sky could be the sea and Sheffield a film of rust-coloured scurf floating on top. Steve Hawley's re-edited film footage of Sheffield parks and gardens in the 1950s contains an inexplicably tragic shot of two boys mourning a grounded toy yacht. What happened to the boating pond and how did they end up in a herbaceous border? The film, like the rest of this deliberately perplexing exhibition, answers the disoriented tourist with an inscrutable shrug.

 Until April 22. Details: 0114-278 2600.

fields.headline: Spirit
fields.standfirst:
Royal Court, London
***
fields.trailText:
Royal Court, London
***
fields.body:
Improbable Theatre, as one of the most energising and provocative forces in British theatre, has produced a piece that is as much about making theatre and stories as it is about telling them. Whether you find it irritatingly self-conscious or that it talks to you straight from the heart, this is a show you cannot ignore.

The presence of this strongly physical, visual piece at the Royal Court is significant: nothing less than a signpost to the future. But it does not strike me as being among the company's most potent work. There are some typically wonderful moments: clouds suddenly scudding across the steeply raked stage, a little pop-up skyscraper city being bombed to oblivion, an actor being manipulated as if he were a puppet.

Most of all there is the company's ability to connect with an audience so it feels as if we are linked by an invisible and pulsating umbilical cord. Then there is the design - a little miracle of tiny doors and openings that reveal the secrets of the heart sign, presumably largely the brainchild of Julian Crouch.

But the story about three baker brothers, one of whom joins the army during a conflict, gets constantly subverted by the manner of its telling. Improbable has never been about acting in any traditional sense, although there has never been any doubt about the performers' skills. In its shows the persona of the individual and the role they are playing are always distinct and yet intimately connected. There are no transformations. Yet because the actors always make it clear that they are actors, the whole thing somehow feels truer and more real.

Here, however, everything has been deconstructed into oblivion and for the first time a worrying sense of ego appears that sometimes obscures the storytelling rather than helping it. Previous Improbable shows have played strongly with autobiography and this one is no different. It has never mattered whether what they tell us actually is the truth, what has counted is the emotional truth of what they tell us. But in this show on the theme of conflict, it seems too pat when one performer starts telling us how much he hates another.

For all I know this may be true, but my suspicion is that this is just acting, even if the underlying resentments are real. A note of emotional dishonesty has crept in that renders the whole show slightly suspect.

Others may have no difficulty with this, and it is the nature of Improbable's work that the show changes so tomorrow's performance won't be like yesterday's. I can only suggest that you go and make up your own mind.

 Until April 7. Box office: 020-7565 5000.
